This is a pilot study that aims to understand the profile of the gut microbiome in adult patients diagnosed with gallstone disease and its relationship with patient outcomes, including the development of complications (such as biliary colic, cholangitis, cholecystitis, pancreatitis, and gallstone ileus) and post-operative complications (such as hospital stay, wound healing, and post-cholecystectomy diarrhea). The study will use a prospective cohort design to collect data from 75 adult patients presenting with newly diagnosed gallstone disease at East Kent University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust. Stool samples will be collected at various timepoints, including at diagnosis, before and after cholecystectomy, and at 6-month intervals. The primary outcome measure is the bacterial DNA profile, which will be used to assess the diversity of species present in the participants' stool samples.

The key aspects of the provided clinical trial document are:

1. The study included adult sepsis patients (≥18 years) and excluded those with various types of chronic liver disease, viral hepatitis, and other liver-related conditions. Patients without simultaneous AST and PLT data in the first 24 hours after ICU admission were also excluded.

2. The study aimed to assess the correlation between the initial aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to platelet (PLT) ratio index (APRI) and the development of sepsis-associated liver dysfunction (SALD) in adult sepsis patients.

3. SALD was diagnosed based on the following criteria: (1) ALT or AST ≥20 folds upper limit of normal level; or (2) total bilirubin (TBIL) ≥2.0 mg/dL. SALD was further divided into hypoxic hepatitis and sepsis-induced cholestasis (SIC) based on the presence or absence of elevated TBIL.

4. The primary outcome measure was the occurrence of SALD within 30 days after ICU admission

This is a randomized, double-blind, active-controlled clinical study evaluating the immunogenicity and safety of an Omicron BA.4/5-Delta recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and older with different immunization programs. The study has four arms: 0-1-month immune program study group, 0-1-month immune program control group, 0-6-month immune program study group, and 0-6-month immune program control group. The primary outcome measures are the number of adverse events and laboratory markers of immunity, such as geometric mean titer of neutralizing antibodies and positive conversion rate, after two doses of the vaccine. The secondary outcome measures include additional laboratory markers of immunity at different time points. The study aims to assess the safety and immunogenicity of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta recombinant vaccine compared to the recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine.

The study aimed to examine the impact of early skin-to-skin contact on maternal-infant bonding and perception of traumatic birth. The study population consisted of 367 women who had normal vaginal deliveries at a hospital in Batman, Turkey between December 2021 and May 2022. The participants were randomly assigned to an experimental group that received skin-to-skin contact immediately after delivery (n=180) or a control group that received standard postpartum care (n=187). The primary outcome measures were maternal attachment scale scores assessed at 1 month postpartum and traumatic birth perception scale scores assessed within 2 hours after delivery. The study used a randomized controlled experimental design to evaluate the effects of the skin-to-skin contact intervention.

This was a prospective, randomized, controlled, double-blind, single-center study that evaluated the effect of an ultrasound-guided sacral erector spinae plane block (ESPB) on postoperative pain in patients undergoing lumbar discectomy. 54 patients were randomly assigned to either the ESPB group (n=27) or the control group (n=27). The ESPB group received a bilateral sacral ESPB with 20 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine at the end of the surgery, while the control group received no block. Both groups received standard general anesthesia and postoperative analgesia with a patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) device. The primary outcomes were patient pain scores (Visual Analog Scale) and total opioid consumption over 24 hours. Secondary outcomes included the incidence of nausea/vomiting and patient satisfaction. The study found that the ESPB group had significantly lower pain scores and opioid consumption compared to the control group over the 24-hour postoperative period.

The study aims to develop and validate a practical and inexpensive biomarker for lumbar myofascial pain using multimodal ultrasound imaging. The key aspects of the study are:

1. The study will investigate the echogenicity of latent and active trigger points, the dynamic spatial-temporal tissue deformation in the thoracolumbar fascia and multifidus muscle, and the viscoelastic properties of the fascia and muscles using ultrasound shear wave elastography.

2. The study will use deep learning to integrate these ultrasound measurements into a predictive biomarker and validate its ability to classify the myofascial components of pain and predict response to treatment.

3. The study will recruit four groups of participants: healthy normals, chronic low back pain (cLBP) patients with myofascial pain (MP) but no trigger points, cLBP patients with MP and latent trigger points, and cLBP patients with MP and active trigger points.

4. The primary outcome measure is the diagnosis of one of the four MP-related categories, and the secondary outcome measure is the presence of substantial myofascial pain.

The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial is a 2-year, two-arm, blinded, randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of an adapted telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use at 3 months among opioid-naïve adult Emergency Department (ED) and urgent care patients with musculoskeletal pain. 

The study will enroll 200 participants and randomize them 1:1 to either the intervention (video) or usual care (standard care) arms, stratified by age (18-40 years; 41+ years). The intervention consists of an interactive 15-minute video that provides information on pain management and encourages patients to discuss treatment options with their provider. 

The primary outcome is a combined pain severity and interference score measured using the Brief Pain Inventory-short form (BPI-SF) at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months. Secondary outcomes include pain severity, pain interference, opioid use, physical function, global health, and healthcare utilization (ED/urgent care and non-ED/urgent care visits) at 1 and 3 months.

The study aims to investigate the impact of Neuro-Linguistic Programming (NLP) techniques on the academic performance, behavior, and ADHD symptoms of primary school students in Lebanon. The study will involve 130 schoolchildren aged 5-11 years, who will receive a 6-session NLP intervention developed by a team of specialists. The primary outcome measures include:

1. Identification of school triggers through a questionnaire.
2. Assessment of children's strengths and difficulties using the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ).
3. Evaluation of children's concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning using the Vanderbilt Assessment Scale.

The study has a single-group assignment design and is triple-masked. The interventions will be delivered to both teachers and children, and the outcome measures will be assessed 2 months after the intervention.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of using the ECOX teaching tool in the emergency department on OSCEs (Objective Structured Clinical Examinations) for medical students. The study will compare the performance of medical students who use the ECOX tool during their training to those who use standard learning methods. The primary outcome is the students' average score on the end-of-course OSCEs. Secondary outcomes include the students' psychological status (anxiety) and their performance on the behavioral assessment during the service OSCEs. The study will include medical students aged 18 and older who are participating in the service OSCE at the end of their emergency department internship. Participants will be randomized to either the ECOX intervention group, where they will use the ECOX tool, or the control group, where they will use standard learning methods. The study duration is 10 weeks.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of a web-based health care program on symptom management, social support, activity tolerance, and quality of life in patients with pulmonary hypertension. The study is a randomized, parallel-group, single-blind trial that will compare the web-based program to usual care. The primary outcome is change in pulmonary arterial hypertension symptoms at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in social support, activity ability, and quality of life at 6 months. The study will enroll adults aged 20-90 years old with a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

This study aims to evaluate the effects of long-term ventilation support on the quality of life of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and their families. The study will compare the quality of life between ALS patients who choose to receive long-term mechanical ventilation support and those who decline it. 

The primary outcome measure is the overall quality of life assessed by the Quality of Life Scale at various time points (inclusion, 3 months, 9 months, 15 months, and 21 months). Secondary outcome measures include health-related quality of life assessed by the Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire, Kidsscreen-27, EQ-5D-5L, and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Assessment Scale-5 items (ALSAQ-5), as well as caregiver burden assessed by the Zarit Burden Interview.

The study has a non-randomized, parallel assignment design, with two active comparator arms: ALS patients who choose life-prolonging treatment with long-term mechanical ventilation support, and ALS patients who decline such treatment. The study is open-label and includes A

This is a single-arm, open-label study investigating the use of electrocorticography (ECoG) monitoring in patients undergoing surgical evacuation of chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH). The primary outcome is the incidence of postoperative neurologic deterioration, as measured by changes in the Markwalder grading scale or Glasgow Coma Scale. Secondary outcomes include extended Glasgow Outcome Scale (eGOS), Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), NIH Toolbox Cognitive Battery, PROMIS-29 profile, TBI-QOL, and Headache Disability Index, assessed at 30, 90, and 180 days. The study aims to evaluate the presence of spreading depolarization in cSDH patients and its association with neurologic outcomes.

This is a multicenter, randomized, controlled, non-inferiority trial that aims to evaluate the impact of annual versus biannual infusions of ocrelizumab in patients with active multiple sclerosis (MS), after 2 years of initial treatment, on freedom from radiological disease activity at two years.

The primary outcome measure is the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesions >3mm on cerebrospinal MRI at 24 months compared to the inclusion MRI. Patients must be 18 years or older, have received a minimum of 4 semi-annual cycles of ocrelizumab, and meet other eligibility criteria. Participants will be randomized to receive either annual or biannual (semi-annual) infusions of ocrelizumab, and the study is designed as a single-blind trial.

The SPARCOL study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the outcomes of combined endoscopic laparoscopic surgery (CELS) versus standard surgical resection for early-stage colon cancer in elderly, frail patients. The primary outcome measure is the change in patient-reported postoperative recovery, as assessed by the Quality of Recovery 15 (QoR-15) scale. Secondary outcome measures include changes in exercise capacity, physical condition, quality of life, and various surgical and oncological outcomes. The study includes participants aged 75 years and older with colon cancer classified as T1/T2 N0 M0, who are eligible and suitable for CELS. The study design is an open-label, parallel-group trial with two arms: the experimental CELS group and the active comparator standard surgical resection group. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of the organ-sparing CELS approach in this elderly, frail population.

This is a phase 2 open-label pilot study investigating the effectiveness of nebulized hypertonic saline (6%) in reducing respiratory exacerbations in people with neuromuscular disease (NMD) or neurodisability. The primary outcome is the course of antibiotics prescribed for respiratory infections over 52 weeks. Secondary outcomes include lung function measures, airway inflammation, bacterial diversity, ease of airway clearance, quality of life, treatment satisfaction, and health economics. Eligible participants are aged 5 years and above with a diagnosis of NMD or neurodisability, a history of at least one respiratory exacerbation requiring antibiotics in the previous 12 months, and the ability to tolerate nebulized 6% hypertonic saline. Participants are randomized to receive either nebulized 6% hypertonic saline or nebulized 0.9% normal saline (control) for 52 weeks.

This is a case-control study investigating paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia. The study aims to assess various psychological, behavioral, and biological factors associated with these conditions and the risk of sexual violence.

The key aspects of the study are:

1. The study will recruit a clinical cohort of patients seeking treatment for paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and/or sexsomnia, as well as a control group of healthy volunteers matched for age and sex.

2. The primary outcome measure is the Karolinska Interpersonal Violence Scale (KIVS), which assesses exposure to and use of violence. Secondary outcome measures include various psychological, behavioral, and biological assessments.

3. The study will follow the clinical cohort for 12 months, monitoring their treatment, number of completed visits, and interrupted treatments. It will also assess long-term outcomes, such as convictions for sexual offenses, after 10 years.

4. The study includes a qualitative interview component to explore the progress of sexual deviations from the first memory to the current state.

5. The study aims to investigate the underlying mechanisms and risk

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Primary Objective: To characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter kio*V differs in tumor versus normal brain, and assess the validity of aMRI as a metabolic imaging approach by comparing it to 18FDG PET.

2. Secondary Objectives: 
   a. To determine the utility of aMRI to differentially assess the metabolically active tumor periphery and necrotic core regions, and compare it to 18FDG PET.
   b. To characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter kio*V differs in various normal appearing brain sub-regions unaffected by tumor, in comparison to 18FDG PET.

3. Exploratory Objective: To compare how the aMRI metabolic parameter kio*V within disease lesions changes with different disease types, their disease stage, and their treatment status.

4. Participants: Adult patients (>18 years) with glioma who require MRI and 18FDG-PET imaging.

5. Interventions: Patients receive 18FDG IV, then 60 minutes

This is a cluster-randomized study designed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Clinicians will be randomized to one of three arms: (1) usual care, (2) multi-pronged clinical decision support (CDS) including a patient portal message, an interruptive advisory, and a best practice advisory with a GDMT order set, or (3) multi-pronged CDS with referral to integrated clinical pharmacist co-management. Additionally, each clinical practice site will be assigned to receive either early or delayed education. The primary outcome is GDMT prescription increase within 30 days of the index visit. Secondary outcomes include GDMT prescription increase at 60 and 90 days, and addition of SGLT2 inhibitors or angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors within 30, 60, and 90 days.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) alone versus ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy in treating upper ureteric stones. The study will enroll patients aged 18-70 years with a single upper ureteric stone size ranging from 6-15 mm and a history of less than 6 months. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients cleared from ureteric stones at 4 weeks. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either ESWL alone or ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy.

The study is an interventional clinical trial investigating the treatment of tracheal stenosis following percutaneous tracheotomy. The primary outcome measure is the rate of successful decannulation after the intervention, assessed up to 12 months. The secondary outcome measures include technical success of the intervention, number of required reinterventions, type of intervention performed (cryoablation, APC, loop extraction), clinical success (no stridor or dyspnea), and the number of patients requiring additional surgical treatment or stent placement, all assessed over a 12-month period.

The study is a non-randomized, parallel-assignment, prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the impact of a community-based psychiatric intervention on viral exposure, substance use severity, and quality of life in people who inject drugs (PWID) in Haiphong, Vietnam. The study will enroll 600 participants, with 200 PWID diagnosed with depression, psychosis, or suicide risk receiving the psychiatric intervention, and 400 PWID (200 HIV-positive and 200 HIV-negative) without psychiatric disorders serving as a control group. The primary outcome measures are viral exposure score, severity of substance use score, and quality of life score, all assessed at 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include HIV treatment compliance, access to care, incidence of methamphetamine-induced psychotic disorder, HIV/HCV incidence, incidence of psychiatric disorders in the control group, and the cost of the community-based psychiatric intervention.

This is a randomized, clinical, superiority trial with 3 parallel arms that aims to compare the effectiveness of conventional endodontic treatment (ET) with ET combined with photodynamic therapy (PDT) in patients with apical lesions. 

The study will have 3 treatment groups: 
1. Placebo group receiving conventional ET with simulated PDT treatment.
2. Conventional ET associated with PDT using a 660 nm diode laser for 10 seconds per canal.
3. Conventional ET associated with prolonged PDT using a 660 nm diode laser for 20 seconds per canal.

The primary outcome is the reduction in size of the apical lesion, measured by radiographic assessment and the PAI index score, at 6 months post-treatment. 

The secondary outcomes are:
1. Disinfection of the root canals, assessed by analysis of colony formation (CFU/mL) before and after treatment.
2. Success rate of the treatment, based on clinical and radiographic findings, at 6 months post-treatment.

The study will enroll adult patients (18-80 years) with

The study aims to investigate the use of psychoanalysis, sertraline, duloxetine, and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in the treatment of various psychiatric conditions, including PTSD, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), OCD, agoraphobia, depression, anxiety, ADHD, borderline personality disorder, social anxiety disorder, and avoidant personality disorder, among adults aged 18 to 70 years. The primary outcome measures include the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAM-A), Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-7), Dissociative Experiences Scale - II (DES-II), The Defeat Scale (D Scale), Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS), Severity Measure for Agoraphobia-Adult, BPD Check List, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE), Young Schema Questionnaire (YSQ), Personality Belief Questionnaire (PBQ), and Behavioral Satisfaction Questionnaire (X and Y axes). The secondary outcome measures include heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and diastolic blood pressure. The study is

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

The study is a pilot, prospective study designed to primarily assess the ability of blood-based liquid biopsy using next-generation sequencing (NGS) to monitor disease progression to Trastuzumab Deruxtecan (T-DXd) in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer previously treated with one line of therapy including pertuzumab and trastuzumab or trastuzumab alone.

The primary objective is to dynamically assess circulating alterations associated with resistance to T-DXd, including changes in HER2 status using a novel approach called HER2-2D that simultaneously assesses HER2 amplification and overexpression in blood. 

Secondary objectives include:
1) Molecular stratification of patients using a dynamic approach with liquid biopsy
2) Assessment of lead time (anticipation of progression) using liquid biopsy
3) Evaluation of the association between HER2-2D status and outcome in terms of progression.

Patients will receive T-DXd as second-line treatment and undergo serial blood sampling for liquid

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the potential effectiveness of Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) in addressing mental health problems among adults affected by the recent earthquakes in Türkiye. The study will recruit 30 eligible participants who will be randomly assigned to either the CPT intervention group or an enhanced care-as-usual (E-CAU) control group. The primary outcome is the change in post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms, as measured by the PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5). Secondary outcomes include changes in symptoms of depression, anxiety, and well-being, as assessed by the PHQ-9, GAD-7, and WHO Well-Being Scale, respectively. The study will also measure changes in psychological distress using the Kessler Psychological Distress Scale (K-10). Participants in the CPT group will receive 12 one-hour sessions of the manualized CPT intervention, while the control group will receive information about available mental health support services. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, post-intervention (one week after the last CPT session), and one-month follow

The study aims to assess the perceived quality of family planning counseling and its associated factors among reproductive-aged women in El-Dakhla District, New Valley, Egypt. It will utilize the validated Quality of Contraceptive Counseling (QCC) Scale, which measures three aspects of counseling quality: information exchange, interpersonal relationship, and disrespect and abuse. The study will collect data through a semi-structured interview questionnaire covering sociodemographic characteristics, family planning practices, facility factors, and the QCC scale. The primary outcome is the quality of family planning counseling as reported by the women. The study will be conducted over one year and involve 423 women of reproductive age seeking family planning services in the district.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study comparing two ablation strategies using pulsed-field ablation (PFA) in patients with persistent atrial fibrillation (PsAF). 

The primary objective is to evaluate the recurrence of atrial fibrillation (AF) or atrial tachycardia (AT) lasting >30 seconds without anti-arrhythmic drugs (AADs) over 12 months of follow-up. 

Secondary objectives include evaluating AF/AT recurrence on AADs, hospitalization rates, cardioversions, PFA-related complications, and quality of life assessments.

Patients will be randomized to one of two groups:
1) PVI group: Pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) only
2) PVI+ group: PVI plus additional lesions including posterior wall isolation, mitral and cavotricuspid isthmus lines

The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years with documented persistent or long-standing persistent AF. Key exclusion criteria include paroxysmal AF,

The Catholic Health Initiatives (CHI) St. Joseph's Children Home Visiting Longitudinal Study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of a home visiting program on child development, maternal health, child health, child maltreatment, linkages and referrals to community resources, positive parenting practices, and family economic self-sufficiency. The study will enroll first-born children aged 3 months or less and their families living within a 3-county area. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the home visiting group, which will receive a 3-year home visiting program, or the control group, which will receive usual care. The primary outcome measures include child development and school readiness, maternal health, child health, child maltreatment, linkages and referrals, positive parenting practices, and family economic self-sufficiency. These outcomes will be assessed at various time points over 15 years of follow-up using standardized assessments, administrative records, and court data.

This is a Phase I clinical trial to assess the safety and immunogenicity of the malaria vaccine candidate RH5.1 soluble protein in Matrix-MTM using two different dosing regimens in healthy adults aged 18-50 years. 

The study has two experimental arms:

1. Delayed regimen: 12 volunteers receiving 3 doses of 10 μg RH5.1 with 50 μg of Matrix-M on days 0, 28 and 182.

2. Delayed Fractional regimen: 12 volunteers receiving 2 doses of 50 μg RH5.1 with 50 μg of Matrix-M on days 0, 28 and 1 dose of 10 μg RH5.1 with 50 μg of Matrix-M on day 182.

The primary outcomes are to assess the safety of the vaccine by evaluating solicited and unsolicited adverse events, safety laboratory measures, and serious adverse events. The secondary outcomes are to assess the humoral immunogenicity, including quantity, quality and longevity of the anti-RH5

This is a monocentric, 18-month, randomized, rater-blinded study to evaluate the influence of a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment plan with integrated mobile palliative care and telemedicine on the quality of life (QoL) of individuals with Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) compared to a historical European MSA cohort.

The study plans to recruit 46 individuals with MSA who will be randomized into two groups:
1. Personalized best medical care
2. Personalized best medical care plus telemedicine (monthly neurological, psychological and neurorehabilitation consultations)

The primary outcome is the change in the EQ-5D-5L score (a measure of QoL) from baseline to 18 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in MSA-specific QoL, motor and non-motor scales, time to clinical milestones, healthcare preferences, satisfaction with the treatment plan, healthcare costs, and caregiver burden.

Informal caregivers of the recruited MSA patients will also be invited to participate in an 18-month observational study assessing their QoL and ca

This is a study investigating the genetic basis of response to growth hormone (GH) treatment in children with idiopathic short stature. The study will compare the genetic profiles of "good responders" (change in height standard deviation score (SDS) >1.0) and "poor responders" (change in height SDS <0.4) to GH therapy. Participants will have a single study visit to provide a non-invasive biological sample. No treatment will be provided as part of this study. The primary outcome is the frequency of genetic variants that differ significantly between the two responder groups. The secondary outcome is the enrichment of genetic variants per gene/pathway. The study will enroll children aged 3-11 years who have received at least 1 year of prior GH therapy.

This is a randomized, single-blind clinical trial investigating the impact of neurocheck frequency on sleep in critically ill adults who have undergone elective coiling of an unruptured cerebral aneurysm. Eligible participants are randomized to either hourly or every-other-hour neurological examinations. The primary outcome is sleep efficiency, measured as the ratio of total sleep time to time in bed. Secondary outcomes include wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, arousals, and subjective sleep quality. All outcomes are assessed within 24 hours of enrollment.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to assess the accuracy of radiologists in identifying extranodal extension (iENE) on imaging and its prognostic significance in terms of overall survival and recurrence rates in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma patients.

2. The primary outcome measures include evaluating the accuracy of radiologic identification of iENE compared to pathologic extranodal extension (pENE), and assessing the prognostic significance of iENE for overall survival and recurrence.

3. The secondary outcome measures include determining radiologic features that best correlate with pENE, assessing the utility of existing standardized diagnostic classification systems for iENE, and measuring interobserver variability among radiologists in grading radiographic extranodal extension.

4. The study will examine data from consecutive patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma treated between 1999-2020, who meet the inclusion criteria and have available imaging and pathology data.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To compare the efficiency and safety of bedside blind bone biopsy versus conventional bone biopsy in the management of diabetic foot osteomyelitis (DFO).

2. Study Design: Open-label, randomized, controlled, non-inferiority trial.

3. Participants: Patients aged >18 years with diabetes and diabetic foot ulcer with suspected DFO.

4. Interventions: 
   - Experimental group: Bedside blind bone biopsy procedure.
   - Control group: Standard bone biopsy procedure (surgical or radiological).

5. Primary Outcome: Remission of DFO at 12 months, defined by epithelialized ulcer for 28 days, absence of local inflammation, stabilization or improvement of radiologic abnormalities, and no need for foot surgery.

6. Secondary Outcomes: Clinical efficacy (e.g., remission at 6 months, need for surgery, recurrence of ulcer, mortality), microbiological results, adverse events, and health economic outcomes (e.g., costs, quality

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to address disparities in end-of-life (EoL) care for African Americans (AAs) by adapting a community-developed training program for clinicians caring for AA older adults with serious illnesses.

2. The study will be conducted in two geographically diverse regions - Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York - using a community-based participatory research (CBPR) approach.

3. The study has three main objectives:
   a. Conduct a comparative ethnographic study to describe AA community values and preferences related to EoL care.
   b. Adapt the prior community-developed training program by integrating community-developed storytelling videos, guidelines for culturally concordant EoL care delivery, and an implicit bias management program.
   c. Conduct a cluster randomized trial to evaluate the adapted training program's impact on patient/family's perception of therapeutic alliance, family-reported goal-concordant care, and clinicians' knowledge, awareness, and confidence.

4. The primary outcome is the patient/family's perception of therapeutic alliance using the Human Connection Scale. Secondary outcomes include family

This study aims to assess the genomic alterations and expression profiles in head and neck cancers that are positive for human papillomavirus (HPV+) versus those that are HPV-negative (HPV-). The study will conduct genetic analysis, including PCR, immunohistochemistry, and immunolabelling, on tumor biopsies from patients with oropharyngeal or oral cavity squamous cell carcinomas to define the molecular profiles of HPV+ and HPV- head and neck tumors. The primary outcome measure is the molecular profile of the tumors, which will be established through analysis of 87 hotspot genes, full-length analysis of 48 genes, copy number analysis of 43 genes, and gene fusion analysis of 51 genes.

The study aims to validate the use of Visual Analog Scales (VAS) to measure satisfaction and well-being at work (SoWell-VAS). The primary outcome measures include burnout, anxiety, job demand, job control, social support, effort-reward imbalance, and work addiction, assessed using both VAS and validated questionnaires. These measures are evaluated at inclusion and one week later. Secondary outcome measures include sociodemographic factors, occupational characteristics, health behaviors, and various aspects of work-related stress and well-being. The study population consists of voluntary adults with a professional activity, excluding minors and protected adults.

This is a randomized, double-blind clinical trial that aims to evaluate the soft tissue contour and radiographic changes of different alveolar ridge preservation techniques after tooth extraction. The study includes four experimental groups and one control group:

1. Spontaneous healing (control group) 
2. Alveolar ridge preservation grafted with bone particles and covered with a subepithelial connective tissue graft
3. Alveolar ridge preservation grafted with bone particles and covered with a vascularized interpositional periosteal connective tissue graft
4. Alveolar ridge preservation grafted with bone particles and covered with a collagen membrane
5. Alveolar ridge preservation grafted with bone particles and covered with a non-resorbable high-density polytetrafluoroethylene membrane (Cytoplast)

The primary outcome measures are changes in soft tissue and hard tissue dimensions, assessed using cone-beam computed tomography and 3D imaging. Secondary outcome measures include changes in keratinized tissue width and patient-reported outcomes using a visual analogue scale. The study will follow participants for up to 12 months after the ridge preservation procedures.

The study aims to compare the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients with Essure contraceptive implants and in control patients with or without endometriosis/adenomyosis. The primary outcome measure is the level of cytokine IL10 in peritoneal fluid, which will be assessed through study completion, an average of 4 months. The study includes three participant groups: Essure patients who underwent implant removal, control patients with no endometriosis/adenomyosis, and control patients with endometriosis/adenomyosis.

This is a retrospective and prospective cohort study investigating the impact of ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) treatment on COVID-19 infection and clinical outcomes in patients with autoimmune liver diseases, including primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) and autoimmune hepatitis (AIH). The study aims to compare the incidence of COVID-19 infection, disease severity, clinical biochemical indicators, hospital stay, and prognosis between UDCA-treated and non-UDCA-treated patients. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of COVID-19 infection in patients with autoimmune liver disease, and the secondary outcome measures include the severity of disease after COVID-19 infection, COVID-19 nucleic acid disappearance time, and COVID-19 infection outcome. The study will enroll patients from January 2021 to December 2023 and follow them for 1 year.

This is a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial that aims to investigate the effect of preoperative prone position training on postoperative pulmonary complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery. The study will divide eligible participants into two groups: the prone position training (PPT) group and the control (C) group. The PPT group will receive daily prone position training for at least 3 days before surgery, while the C group will receive standard perioperative care without any prone position training. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications, including pneumonia, atelectasis, pleural effusion, respiratory failure, and unplanned intubations, within 7 days after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2), extubation time, peak airway pressure, arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), and oxygenation index (OI), which will be assessed at various time points before and after surgery.

This is a Phase I/II, open-label clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 oral liquid combined with pemetrexed and cisplatin therapy in patients with advanced, inoperable or metastatic EGFR wild-type non-small cell lung cancer.

The primary objectives are to determine the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) and recommended dose level (RDL) of BLEX 404 in combination with pemetrexed and cisplatin therapy (Phase I), and to evaluate the overall response rate after 4 cycles of the combination therapy (Phase II).

Secondary objectives include evaluating the overall response rate after at least 1 cycle, the rate of grade 3/4 hematological toxicity, and the effect on quality of life.

The study will enroll patients aged 20-70 years with advanced, inoperable or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer who are EGFR wild-type and intended for first-line treatment. The study uses a 3+3 dose escalation design in Phase I to determine the DLT and RDL, followed by a

The study is a pilot feasibility trial of the "AGE SELF CARE" group visit program, which aims to promote healthy aging in community-dwelling adults aged 65 and older who are pre-frail. The program consists of 8 weekly 90-minute virtual group sessions focusing on chronic disease management, healthy lifestyle education, home adaptation, and anticipatory guidance. The study will assess recruitment rate, completion of testing, attendance, completion of home practice logs, participant satisfaction, and proportion lost to follow-up as primary outcomes. Secondary outcomes include measures of frailty, loneliness, self-reported health, physical activity, self-efficacy, depression, anxiety, sleep, and physical performance. The study is a single-group, open-label, feasibility/acceptability trial.

The key aspects of the provided clinical trial document are:

1. Study Overview:
   - The study aims to gain insight into the course of functional and medical recovery in geriatric rehabilitation patients affected by COVID-19 in Europe.
   - The secondary objective is to understand the treatment modalities and organization of geriatric rehabilitation for post-COVID-19 patients in Europe.

2. Participation Criteria:
   - Inclusion criteria: Recovering from a confirmed COVID-19 infection and having an indication for geriatric rehabilitation.
   - Exclusion criteria: Presence of severe cognitive impairment and patients who opt-out of using their anonymous data for research purposes.

3. Study Design:
   - This is an observational, multi-center cohort study conducted in several European countries.
   - Data will be collected at admission, discharge, and 6-week and 6-month follow-ups.

4. Outcome Measures:
   - Primary outcome: Change in Activities of Daily Living (ADL) functioning, measured by the Barthel Index.
   - Secondary outcome: Change in quality of life, measured by the EQ-5D-5L

The PREPARE-iVAC trial is a multicentre, open-label, controlled, randomized study that aims to investigate whether replacing mycophenolate mofetil/mycophenolic acid (MMF/MPA) with everolimus in kidney transplant recipients (KTRs) results in superior immunogenicity of COVID-19 and herpes zoster vaccinations. The primary objective is to assess the neutralizing antibody titer against the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain after COVID-19 vaccination. Secondary objectives include evaluating humoral and cellular immune responses to COVID-19 and herpes zoster vaccinations, as well as safety outcomes such as acute rejection, kidney function, and adverse events. Eligible participants will be randomized 1:1 to either continue MMF/MPA or replace it with everolimus. The study consists of two parts: a run-in and COVID-19 vaccination phase, followed by an optional herpes zoster vaccination phase. The trial will be conducted at seven study sites in the Netherlands.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes in patients with partial thickness burns covering 30-50% of the body surface area. Sixty patients aged 20-45 years will be randomly assigned to either the study group or the control group. The study group will receive resistance exercises using dumbbells and sandbags 3 times per week for 8 weeks, in addition to their standard physical therapy program and medical treatment. The control group will receive only the standard physical therapy program and medical treatment. The primary outcome measure is the change in plasma liver enzymes (AST and ALT) over a 2-month period.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of upper trapezius stretching on neck pain, range of motion, and disability in patients with cervical spondylosis. The study will compare an intervention group receiving upper trapezius stretching exercises to a control group receiving standard care. The primary outcome measures are changes in neck pain intensity and neck range of motion, assessed at baseline, 4 weeks, and 3 months. The secondary outcome measure is changes in the Neck Disability Index. The study includes adults aged 40-65 years with a diagnosis of cervical spondylosis and excludes those with recent neck trauma, previous neck surgery, or other medical conditions that could affect neck pain and range of motion.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of tecartherapy, a type of deep thermotherapy, on the physical performance of amateur athletes. The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group trial that compares a tecartherapy group to a sham group. The primary outcome measures are changes in 30-meter sprint time and electromyographic activity of the quadriceps during sprinting. Secondary outcome measures include changes in countermovement jump height, electromyographic activity during the jump, isometric leg extension force, and electromyographic activity during the leg extension. The study includes healthy amateur athletes aged 18-30 years who participate in sports involving sprinting and jumping. The tecartherapy intervention involves a 25-minute application of the tecartherapy device to the lower extremities, while the sham group receives the same procedure without power delivery.

This is a clinical trial that aims to quantify cell-free DNA (cfDNA) levels in patients with endometriosis undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment, compared to patients with other infertility causes. The primary outcome measures are the cfDNA rate in serum before IVF stimulation and the cfDNA rate in follicular fluid on the day of oocyte retrieval. The secondary outcome measures include the number of oocytes reaching metaphase II, fragmentation rate, number of cells at days 2 and 3, blastulation rate at day 5, number of clinical pregnancies, and number of live births. The study is a non-randomized, parallel assignment trial with a single-blind design. Eligible participants are women aged 18-43 years with endometriosis or other infertility causes who are undergoing IVF treatment.

The study is a 10-year comparative prospective study that aims to compare the treatment outcomes of fully edentulous patients with maxillary implant overdentures (IODs) retained by either bars or Locator attachments. The primary outcome is the change in marginal peri-implant bone level after 10 years. Secondary outcomes include implant and overdenture survival, peri-implant mucosa health, and patient satisfaction. Eligible participants are fully edentulous patients or those with a mandibular overdenture, who were referred for treatment of lack of retention and stability of their upper (and lower) denture. Patients were treated 10 years ago with four dental implants in the maxilla and an overdenture retained by either bars or Locator attachments.

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a designed exercise program on pain and quality of sleep in patients with sickle cell disease anemia. The study will include 50 adult sickle cell disease patients aged 18-55 years, who will be randomly assigned to either an experimental group or a control group.

The experimental group will receive a 6-week exercise program consisting of diaphragmatic breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, a combination of stretching, stabilization and strengthening exercises, and daily walking. The control group will not receive the exercise program.

The primary outcome measures are the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain. Secondary outcome measures include the WHOQOL-BREF for quality of life, the Fatigue Scale, and the Perceived Stress Scale.

The study will assess the participants at baseline and after the 6-week intervention period. Statistical analysis will be performed to compare the changes in outcome measures between the two groups.

This is a two-armed pragmatic trial that evaluates the effectiveness of cognitive stimulation therapy (CST) for individuals with mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia. The primary outcome is cognitive decline, measured by changes in Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) scores from baseline to 6-month follow-up. The secondary outcomes include cognitive improvement, referral acceptance rate, participant attendance, and participant attrition. Participants in the intervention group will receive a referral from their physician for CST treatment, while the control group will receive standard of care without a CST referral. The study aims to determine if CST can reduce cognitive decline and improve cognitive function in this population.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aimed to assess the levels of anxiety and depression in patients with physiological and pathological DeMeester scores (a measure of esophageal acid exposure) and examine the modulation of anxiety on the severity of reflux symptoms.

2. The study was a prospective observational cohort study conducted at the University Hospital Cologne, Germany, between January 2020 and July 2021. Patients with reflux symptoms underwent diagnostic tests including esophagogastroduodenoscopy, 24-hour pH-metry, high-resolution manometry, and esophagography. Anxiety and depression levels were assessed using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS).

3. The study included patients who completed the HADS questionnaire and excluded those without knowledge of the German language or who did not complete all diagnostic testing.

4. The primary outcome measures were the assessment of anxiety and depression levels during the diagnostic workup of patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a self-guided, personalized treatment for women with disordered eating using mobile technology. The intervention involves a 2-week period of smartphone-based self-monitoring to identify target problems, followed by the delivery of two self-guided treatment modules directly to the participants' smartphones. The primary outcome measures include changes in disordered eating symptoms, anxiety, depression, clinical impairment, and quality of life, which will be assessed up to 8 weeks. The study is an open-label, single-group assignment trial targeting women aged 18-65 who endorse disordered eating and have access to a smartphone or tablet.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the CAD-EYE system in detecting neoplastic lesions in patients with Lynch syndrome, compared to indigo carmin chromoendoscopy (CE) as the reference technique. The primary outcome is the comparison of adenoma detection rate (ADR) between the CAD-EYE group and the CE group. Secondary outcomes include detection rates of specific lesions, diagnostic performance of CAD-EYE, feasibility of a resect and discard strategy, and comparison of colonoscopy procedure times between the two groups. The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-blind trial involving patients with confirmed pathogenic mutations associated with Lynch syndrome. Eligible participants will undergo either CAD-EYE colonoscopy or CE colonoscopy, and the detected polyps will be characterized and removed for histological analysis.

The study was a prospective observational study conducted at nine children's hospitals to evaluate the use of a water-soluble contrast-based protocol in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO). The study included children aged 1-20 years diagnosed with ASBO who underwent a trial of nonoperative management (NOM) on hospital admission. Patients were divided into two groups: those who received an enteral contrast challenge (contrast group) and those who did not (no contrast group). The primary outcome was the number of patients who required an operation due to failure of NOM. Secondary outcomes included total hospital length of stay among patients successfully managed non-operatively and adverse events resulting from contrast administration. The study aimed to enroll 314 patients to detect a 15% difference in operative rate between the contrast and no contrast groups. The use of contrast, including the type, volume, and dilution, was not standardized across sites. The study found that the use of a water-soluble contrast-based protocol was at the discretion of the attending surgeon.

This is a Phase 1, single-center, open-label, randomized, parallel group, single-dose study to compare the pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous itepekimab administered with an autoinjector (AI) versus a prefilled syringe (PFS) in healthy participants. The primary outcome measures are the assessment of pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters of itepekimab, including Cmax, AUClast, and AUC. The secondary outcome measures include additional PK parameters, incidence of anti-itepekimab antibodies, and safety assessments. Participants will be randomized to receive itepekimab via either the AI or PFS. The study will enroll healthy participants aged 18 to 65 years.

The key aspects of the clinical trial document are:

1. This is a multi-site, open-label, randomized, three-arm, 8-week, prospective observational study to assess the relative impact of availability and use of different e-liquid flavors on changes in cigarette consumption among current U.S. adult smokers.

2. The study will enroll adult tobacco consumers aged 21-60 years who smoke at least 20 out of the past 30 days and at least 5 cigarettes per day on the days they smoke. 

3. Participants will be randomized into one of three study arms: Tobacco Flavor, Menthol Flavor, or Non-Tobacco/Non-Menthol (NTNM) Flavor. Each arm will have four flavor variants with two nicotine concentrations (1.5% and 5%).

4. The primary outcome measures are: 1) the number and proportion of subjects who reduce their cigarettes per day (CPD) consumption by at least 50% at Week 6 compared to baseline, and 2) the CPD mean percent reduction at Week 6 compared

This is a multicenter, randomized, open-label study to compare the efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab (IFX) monotherapy versus subcutaneous IFX with concomitant immunosuppression in the treatment of moderate to severe Crohn's disease.

The primary objective is to investigate the proportion of patients in corticosteroid-free clinical remission (CDAI<150) and endoscopic response (≥50% reduction in SES-CD) at week 26.

The key secondary objectives include evaluating the proportion of patients in endoscopic remission, corticosteroid-free remission, clinical remission, symptomatic remission, biochemical remission, and achieving quality of life improvements at various timepoints.

Eligible patients are 18-80 years old with moderate to severe Crohn's disease. They are randomized 1:1 to receive either:
1) Subcutaneous IFX monotherapy (240mg at weeks 0/2, then 120mg every other week)
2) Subcutaneous IFX (same dosing) with concomitant immunosuppressants

This is a pharmacokinetics study of the direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) rivaroxaban and apixaban in cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation. The study aims to describe the pharmacokinetic (PK) profile of these DOACs in this patient population and identify factors that may influence their PK. The primary outcome is the population PK evaluation, including estimated area under the curve (AUC) for each drug. The secondary outcome is a safety evaluation, assessing any thromboembolic events or major bleeding. The study will enroll adult cancer patients and monitor them for 3 years.

This study aims to evaluate the bronchodilator response in patients with bronchiectasis. The primary outcome measures are the change in forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC) after administration of the bronchodilator salbutamol compared to placebo. The secondary objectives are to assess if bronchodilator response is associated with factors such as age, sex, specific bronchiectatic disease, baseline lung function, use of inhaled steroids, history of allergy or Pseudomonas infection, and severity of bronchiectasis. The study uses a crossover design where participants will undergo spirometry testing at baseline, 15 minutes after receiving either salbutamol or placebo, and then 15 minutes after receiving the other intervention. The results will be presented as percent predicted values using the Global Lung Initiative equations.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of gender identity, genetic sex, and hormone status on pain sensitivity, as well as the social and psychological factors that contribute to pain sensitivity in transgender and cisgender individuals. The study will include participants who self-identify as cisgender men, cisgender women, transgender men, transgender women, transgender men on testosterone, and transgender women on estrogen. The primary outcome measures include experimental pain thresholds, pain sensitivity, sleep quality, depression, social support, discrimination, hormone levels, and immune cell function. Secondary outcome measures include community connectedness, bodily pain, quality of life, body image, gender role expectations of pain, and adverse childhood events. The study design involves a single visit for quantitative sensory testing, blood draw, and questionnaires. The findings from this study will provide insights into the complex interplay between sex, gender identity, hormones, and pain perception.

This is a feasibility study that aims to evaluate the use of technology-enriched stroke rehabilitation in the acute and sub-acute phase after stroke. The study will be conducted in an inpatient stroke unit at the University Hospital Wishaw in Scotland. Eligible participants will be adults diagnosed with a new stroke, deemed medically fit for rehabilitation, and able to provide informed consent. The intervention involves supporting participants to use commercially available rehabilitation technologies, such as robotics, adapted treadmills, virtual reality, and mobile devices, in addition to their usual care. The primary outcome measures are the duration of time spent using the technology, the number of movement repetitions, recruitment and attrition rates, and adherence to the intervention sessions. The secondary outcome measure is the acceptability of the intervention, assessed through semi-structured interviews with participants, their families/carers, and the healthcare staff. This is a mixed-methods feasibility study to inform the development of a complex intervention for technology-enriched stroke rehabilitation.

This is a randomized, open-label, crossover clinical study that aims to evaluate the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) on respiratory discomfort in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) patients treated with non-invasive ventilation (NIV). The primary outcome is to assess the effect of IVR on the affective component of dyspnea (scale A1 of the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile questionnaire). Secondary outcomes include evaluating the effect of IVR on the sensory and emotional components of dyspnea, the effect of music therapy on the different components of dyspnea, comparing the effects of IVR and music therapy, and assessing the acceptability of IVR. Eligible patients are adults with ALS, respiratory failure treated with NIV, and persistent dyspnea at rest. Patients will receive both IVR and music therapy sessions in a randomized order, with each session lasting 15 minutes.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial that aims to evaluate the impact of selective reporting for antibiotic susceptibility testing on the prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics by general practitioners (GPs) for women with E. coli urinary tract infections (UTIs).

The primary outcome is the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, defined as the number of urine cultures associated with a prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics (amoxicillin/clavulanic acid, fluoroquinolone, third-generation cephalosporin) prescribed by GPs within 3 days before to 5 days after the report of the antibiotic susceptibility testing, relative to the total number of urine cultures.

The secondary outcomes include the rate of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, the antibiotic de-escalation rate, the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing as a function of the number of selective antibiotic susceptibility testings received per practice, the impact of the intervention on GP and patient characteristics, and the impact based on E. coli antimicrobial susceptibility profiles.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial investigating whether sodium valproate can improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive low-dose sodium valproate (10mg/kg), high-dose sodium valproate (20mg/kg), or placebo (normal saline) for 3 consecutive days, in addition to conventional stroke treatment. 

The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with a favorable outcome, defined as a Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score of 0-2, at 90 days. Secondary outcomes include the mRS score distribution at 30 and 90 days, NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) scores at days 3 and 7, changes in lesion volume from baseline to day 7, and length of hospital stay.

The study aims to determine whether sodium valproate can improve functional outcomes after acute ischemic stroke, and to explore the potential mechanism of increased peripheral anti-inflammatory CD177+ neutrophils reducing neuroinflammation.

This study aims to evaluate whether a virtual weight loss coach can offer a better solution for weight reduction in ventral hernia patients with obesity compared to standard preoperative weight loss tools. The study will enroll participants aged 18-90 years with a BMI of 30 or higher and a diagnosis of obesity. Participants will be assigned to either the virtual coach group or the standard weight loss tools group. The primary outcome measure is the average net amount of weight change per group over 6 months. Secondary outcomes include the number of interactions with the virtual coach, changes in quality of life, and satisfaction with the virtual coach. The study has a non-randomized, parallel assignment design with an open-label approach.

This is a multicenter, randomized controlled, single-blind clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of nebulized umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes for the treatment of moderate, severe, and critically ill COVID-19 patients. 

The study will compare the experimental group receiving nebulized mesenchymal stem cell exosomes plus conventional therapy, to a control group receiving nebulized saline solution plus conventional therapy. 

The primary outcome measures are: 1) symptom remission time after nebulization, 2) improvement of serum inflammatory markers, and 3) changes in lung CT scans (if available). Secondary outcomes include length of hospitalization and time to viral clearance.

The study will enroll COVID-19 patients aged 18-75 years old who meet the criteria for moderate or severe disease. Key exclusion criteria include pregnancy, severe comorbidities, and active immunosuppression.

This study aims to address limitations of prior clinical trials on stem cell exosomes for COVID-19, such as small sample sizes and lack of

This clinical trial aimed to compare the effectiveness of calcium silicate-based sealers (CSS) and epoxy resin-based sealers (ERS) in single-visit root canal treatment. The study enrolled patients aged 18 years or older with irreversible pulpitis and associated symptoms. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either CSS or ERS for root canal obturation after preparation. The primary outcomes measured were changes in pain intensity, pain relief, and treatment outcome evaluation over time (6 hours to 7 days, and 1 week to 6 months). The study used self-assessment scales and clinical assessments to evaluate these outcomes.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a multi-center, open, prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the immunogenicity and immune persistence of two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui and Cecolin) compared to imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years. 

The study enrolled a total of 3,000 participants, with 1,000 in each of the following groups: domestic bivalent HPV vaccine (Wozehui), domestic bivalent HPV vaccine (Cecolin), and imported HPV vaccine. Participants underwent blood collection at 3 timepoints - 30-60 days, 12 months, and 36 months after the last dose of vaccine - to measure HPV type 16 and 18 neutralizing antibody levels.

The primary outcome measures are the neutralizing antibody geometric mean titers (GMTs) and antibody positivity rates for HPV types 16 and 18 at baseline, 12-month follow-up, and 36-month follow-up.

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility of integrating homeopathic approach as a supportive care option for cancer patients in a comprehensive cancer center. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Evaluating the main concerns and reasons for patients to utilize the homeopathic approach.

2. Assessing patient acceptance and adherence to the homeopathic treatment, as reflected by obtaining and self-administering the remedies as prescribed.

3. Obtaining retrospective subjective information from patients on quality of life and symptom improvement using validated questionnaires (MYCaW, Distress Thermometer, ESAS-R).

The study will enroll cancer patients treated at the Division of Oncology in Rambam Health Campus, aged 18 years and above, with an ECOG performance status of 0-2. The primary outcome measures are the feasibility of the supportive approach and the impact on quality of life and distress levels, assessed at 6-12 weeks.

This is a non-randomized, open-label, parallel assignment study that aims to evaluate the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheters and midlines in adult patients hospitalized with catheter-related bacteremia. The primary outcome measure is the duration from the day of diagnosis of septic thrombophlebitis to the day of disappearance of thrombophlebitis signs on Doppler ultrasound, assessed at Day 90. The study involves performing Doppler ultrasound examinations on Day 8, 15, 30, 45, 60, and 90 in patients with confirmed presence of thrombosis, while patients without thrombosis receive no intervention.

This is a Phase 3, open-label, randomized clinical trial to compare the efficacy and safety of odronextamab (an anti-CD20 x anti-CD3 bispecific antibody) in combination with lenalidomide versus rituximab in combination with lenalidomide in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma (FL) and marginal zone lymphoma (MZL).

The study has two parts:
- Part 1 (safety run-in): Participants with relapsed/refractory indolent lymphoma (FL and MZL) will receive odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide.
- Part 2: Participants with relapsed/refractory FL and MZL will be randomized 1:1 to receive either odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide or rituximab in combination with lenalidomide followed by lenalidomide monotherapy.

The primary outcome measures are:
- Incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs) and treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) for odronextamab in combination with

This is a clinical trial investigating the effect of Proliverenol supplementation on liver function in patients with Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD). The study will have 4 treatment groups, with 20 subjects in each group, receiving different dosages of Proliverenol or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures are changes in serum ALT and AST levels from baseline to weeks 4, 8, and 12. Secondary outcome measures include changes in controlled attenuation parameter (CAP) and transient elastography (TE) on ultrasound, as well as the AST/ALT ratio. The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial that aims to evaluate the impact of ozone application in the treatment of periodontitis. The study will compare the outcomes of non-surgical periodontal treatment with and without the addition of ozone therapy.

The primary outcome measures are probing pocket depth at baseline and 3 months after treatment. Secondary outcome measures include plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, proportions of specific bacterial species, and levels of inflammatory parameters in gingival crevicular fluid, all assessed at baseline and 3 months.

Eligible participants are systemically healthy adults aged 18-65 years with periodontitis, who have not received any periodontal treatment or taken antibiotics/anti-inflammatory medications within the past 6 months. Participants with less than 20 teeth, partial dentures, or fixed prosthodontics will be excluded.

The study will randomize participants to either the experimental group, receiving non-surgical periodontal treatment plus ozone therapy, or the control group, receiving non-surgical periodontal treatment alone. Ozone therapy will be applied immediately after the initial non-surgical treatment and three times

This study aims to compare the expression of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in pterygium tissue samples and normal conjunctival tissue samples. The study will enroll 60 patients with pterygium, with 30 patients forming the control group with normal conjunctival samples. Immunohistochemical staining will be performed on the tissue samples to assess the expression of the three markers. The study will use IBM SPSS software for statistical analysis of the findings.

The key aspects of the TINO clinical trial are:

1. Objectives: To identify the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in vital and frail older individuals.

2. Participant Groups:
   - Young adults (18-30 years old)
   - Healthy elderly (>65 years old)
   - Frail elderly (>65 years old, Clinical Frailty score >3)

3. Interventions: No intervention, only sample collection at baseline and 3 months. Additional samples collected if respiratory symptoms develop.

4. Primary Outcome Measure: Frequency of nasal CD8+ T cells in young adults and frail older adults.

5. Secondary Outcome Measures:
   - Phenotype, functionality, transcriptomic profile, and clonality of nasal and blood T cell populations.
   - Stability of nasal T cells and immune populations over 3 months.
   - Comparison of nasal and peripheral immune cell populations between age groups.
   - Concentrations of nasal and systemic cytokines and metabolites.
   - Respiratory tract microbiota profiles

This study aims to evaluate the use of platelets to lymphocytes ratio (PLR) and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio (MLR) as predictors of treatment response in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The study will enroll cirrhotic patients with ascites and untreated SBP, as well as normal individuals. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of PLR and MLR as predictors of treatment response in cirrhotic patients with SBP. The study will be conducted from April 19, 2023, to April 30, 2024, and will involve an ascitic fluid study as the diagnostic test.

The study aims to evaluate whether point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) performed by emergency medicine physicians (specialists and residents) can increase diagnostic accuracy in patients presenting with acute dyspnea compared to routine assessment. It is a prospective observational study that will include adult patients presenting to the emergency department with shortness of breath, low oxygen saturation, or high respiratory rate. Physicians will first assess the patients using routine diagnostic procedures and document their estimated likelihood of various diagnoses. They will then perform a structured POCUS examination, and the initial physician will re-evaluate the likelihood of the diagnoses after considering the POCUS findings. The primary outcome is the discharge diagnosis, which will be compared to the estimated likelihoods before and after POCUS to calculate the diagnostic accuracy.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the impact of respiratory training and relaxation techniques (R&R) on improving adjuvant radiation therapy in deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) for patients with left-sided breast cancer.

2. The primary outcome measure is the change in maximum radiation dose (Dmax) to the heart during the 4-week radiation therapy course.

3. Secondary outcome measures include improvements in quality of life, cardiac radiation doses (mean doses to the heart, left anterior descending artery, and left ventricle), clinic workflow metrics, patient satisfaction, and radiation doses to other organs at risk.

4. The study uses a randomized, parallel-group design, with one arm receiving the R&R intervention and the other arm receiving standard DIBH instruction.

5. The study population includes female breast cancer patients with left-sided disease, treated with surgery prior to radiation therapy, aged 18 years or older, and with a good performance status.

This is a Phase IB clinical trial that aims to determine the safety and tolerability of the combination of canakinumab, tislelizumab, nab-paclitaxel, and gemcitabine in the neoadjuvant treatment of patients with resectable or borderline resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. The primary outcome measures are the number of dose-limiting toxicities and the number of patients who proceed to surgical resection. Secondary outcome measures include overall response rate, R0 resection rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, and the number of delays or changes in surgical outcomes attributed to the study drugs. Eligible patients are adults aged 18 years and older with histologically or cytologically confirmed pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, an ECOG performance status of 0-1, and adequate organ function. Patients with locally advanced or metastatic disease, previous immunotherapy, or certain medical conditions are excluded.

This study aims to co-design and evaluate a digital mental health tool called "Connected for Wellness" (CFW) to support mental health navigation and improve access to mental health services for youth aged 13-22 in Los Angeles and Riverside counties. The study will use a stepped-wedge design to test the implementation of the CFW app supported by mental health navigation models (peer and family navigators) across 10 high schools and 10 primary care clinics. The primary outcome is the proportion of youth referred to mental health services who initiate care, and the secondary outcome is the proportion of youth completing a mental health screening who are referred to care. The study will measure these outcomes using electronic medical records over a 1-year period.

This is a double-blinded, prospective, randomized, comparative clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of intramyometrial oxytocin injection and intramyometrial tranexamic acid injection in reducing the risk of postpartum bleeding after cesarean delivery in primigravida at term. The study will be conducted at the Kasr Al-Ainy Hospital, Maternity Hospital, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt, from October 2021 to October 2022. Fifty primigravida women at term pregnancy undergoing elective cesarean delivery will be randomly divided into two equal groups: the tranexamic acid group and the oxytocin group. The primary outcome is to decrease intra- and postoperative blood loss to reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage after cesarean section. The secondary outcome is the need for extra uterotonic drugs. The study is designed as a double-blinded, randomized, comparative-placebo trial.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the ReceptIVFity test, a vaginal microbiome swab, in improving pregnancy outcomes in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) or IVF/ICSI procedures. The study will randomize participants of European origin into two groups: a shared-decision-making group that uses the ReceptIVFity microbiome profile to guide treatment decisions, and a physician decision group that postpones treatment until a favorable microbiome profile is achieved. The primary outcome measures are the rate of successful pregnancy (positive heartbeat at 12 weeks), the number of successful IVF/ICSI cycles, and the total number of IVF/ICSI cycles per patient. Secondary outcomes include patient satisfaction, total treatment costs, and pregnancy outcomes in women of non-European origin. The study will be conducted over a 3-year period.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed tea in patients with hyperlipidemia (high blood lipid levels) without diabetes. 114 participants aged 18-70 years old with high triglyceride levels (1.7-4.5 mmol/L) will be randomly assigned to receive either fenugreek seed tea (5g/day, twice daily) or a control black tea for 8 weeks. 

The primary outcome is the between-group difference in change in serum triglycerides. Secondary outcomes include changes in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, non-HDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, plasma apolipoprotein B, and plasma microRNAs (miR-122 and miR-34a) as potential biomarkers. 

The study aims to determine the lipid-lowering effects of fenugreek seed tea in individuals with hyperlipidemia without diabetes, and to investigate associated changes in plasma microRNAs as non-invasive biomarkers.

This is a prospective, randomized, and open clinical study that aims to investigate the role of pioglitazone in vascular transcriptional remodeling in individuals undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery. The study will enroll 20 male participants over 40 years of age, who are either non-diabetic or have diabetes with a duration of less than 10 years, with a glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) less than 8% and not using NPH insulin. The participants will be randomized to receive either pioglitazone hydrochloride 45 mg/day for 5 days before surgery or no intervention. The primary outcome measure is the change in S1P content of isolated HDL between baseline and after treatment with pioglitazone. The secondary outcome measures include differences in the expression of SPHK1 and S1PR1 in various vascular tissues between the two groups. The study aims to evaluate the effects of pioglitazone on vascular transcriptional remodeling and S1P content in HDL in patients undergoing CABG surgery.

This was a single-dose, randomized, open-label, five-treatment, five-period, five-sequence crossover study conducted in 20 obese healthy subjects to assess the pharmacodynamics (PD) and pharmacokinetics (PK) of three new developed coated glucose beads formulations (containing glucose (8 g) and caffeine), one coated glucose beads formulation (containing glucose (8 g)), and one uncoated glucose beads formulation (containing glucose (8 g) and caffeine) after single-dose administration under fasting conditions.

The primary outcome measures were various PD parameters of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), including area under the curve (AUC), maximum concentration (Cmax), and time to maximum concentration (tmax). The secondary outcome measures included PK parameters of caffeine and glucose, as well as visual analogue scale (VAS) assessments of appetite and stomach rumbles, and safety/tolerability evaluations.

The study aimed to evaluate the effect of using different strips (celluloid matrix, fruit leather, and chewing gum) on reducing the palatoglossal airspace (PGA) shadow error in panoramic radiography. 

The study included 270 participants over 15 years old, who were randomly assigned to three groups: control group (no intervention), fruit leather group, chewing gum group, and celluloid matrix group. Participants in the intervention groups were instructed to hold the respective strip on their tongue during the panoramic imaging procedure.

An oral and maxillofacial radiologist assessed the panoramic radiographs in a single-blinded manner and classified them as diagnostically acceptable, unacceptable, or excellent based on the degree of the PGA shadow error. 

The study found that the use of celluloid matrix strips had the highest success rate (99%) in reducing the PGA shadow error, followed by the fruit leather group (90%) and the chewing gum group. The control group had the highest rate of unacceptable radiographs due to the PGA shadow error.

This study aimed to compare the acute effects of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT), ESWT combined with Kinesio Taping (KT), and placebo ESWT on pain severity and lower extremity functionality in patients with plantar fasciitis. 

The study included adult patients (18-65 years) diagnosed with plantar fasciitis. Participants were divided into three groups: ESWT group, ESWT+KT group, and placebo ESWT group. The ESWT group received a single session of ESWT at 10 Hz frequency, 2.5 Barr energy, and 2000 shocks. The ESWT+KT group received the same ESWT protocol followed by the application of a KT tape, which was kept for one week. The placebo ESWT group received sham ESWT treatment.

The primary outcome measure was the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) score for pain, assessed at baseline and one week after treatment. The secondary outcome measure was the Lower Extremity Functional Scale, also assessed at baseline and

The study aims to establish a couple intervention program for adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The intervention involves a behavioral approach of couple group therapy, which focuses on communication skills, emotion management, and relationship building.
