The study will assess the effectiveness of the intervention by measuring changes in ASD symptoms, empathy, social responsiveness, and quality of socialization over a 6-week period. The study includes couples where at least one partner has an ASD diagnosis or scores above 26 on the autism spectrum quotient. Participants must be between 20 and 60 years old and able to communicate in Chinese. Individuals with psychiatric disorders or communication impairments are excluded.

This is a randomized controlled study that aims to evaluate the effects of an individually tailored exercise program on time spent in upright position, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), physical activity, physical and psychological function, and work ability in patients with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) following COVID-19 infection.

The study will recruit 60 adult patients (>18 years) diagnosed with POTS after COVID-19 infection. Participants will be randomized to either the intervention group or the control group. 

The intervention group will receive a 16-week individually tailored exercise program supervised by a physiotherapist once a week, in addition to standard care. The control group will receive standard care only.

The primary outcome measures are:
1. Change in time spent in upright position and steps per day
2. Change in health-related quality of life (HRQoL) measured by the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire

Secondary outcome measures include changes in walking distance, oxygen saturation, symptoms, anxiety, depression, fatigue, physical function, blood pressure, heart rate, muscle strength, and post-ex

The BRANT study is a multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint, parallel-controlled trial that aims to determine whether intravenous tirofiban is effective in increasing the proportion of excellent functional outcome (modified Rankin Scale score 0-1) at 90 days in patients with acute branch atheromatous disease (BAD)-related stroke, when initiated within 48 hours of onset. The primary efficacy outcome is the proportion of patients with excellent functional outcome at 90 days, and the primary safety outcome is the proportion of patients with major bleeding. Secondary outcomes include early neurological deterioration, NIHSS score, Barthel index score, incidence of ischemic stroke, stroke, TIA, composite endpoint, major bleeding, serious adverse events, and changes in various blood and urine parameters. A total of 516 eligible patients aged 18-75 years with acute BAD-related stroke will be randomized 1:1 to receive either intravenous tirofiban or standard antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or aspirin plus clopidogrel) for 48 hours.

The study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the use of personalized pacing to improve the quality of life in patients with sinus node dysfunction. The study will compare two groups: the PLR group, where the pacemaker lower rate is set at 75 bpm and may be adjusted based on the physician's diagnosis, and the control group, where the pacemaker lower rate is set at 60 bpm. The primary outcome measure is the quality of life, assessed using the SF-36 questionnaire, within three months after the surgery. The secondary outcome measures include cardiac functional changes, measured by left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), and the correlation between elevated blood pressure and bradycardia, assessed through 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring, also within three months after the surgery.

The study aims to compare the effects of remote diagnosis and treatment versus outpatient treatment on the 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure rhythm of patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Patients were randomly assigned to either a telemedicine group or an outpatient group. The telemedicine group received remote sleep apnea testing and APAP treatment monitoring, while the outpatient group received in-person care. The primary outcome was the change in 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure after 3 months of APAP treatment. Secondary outcomes included APAP treatment compliance, sleep-related symptoms and quality of life, cardiovascular risk markers, and cost-effectiveness. The study aims to explore the mechanisms by which APAP treatment improves ambulatory blood pressure in OSA patients and evaluate the response of different OSA subtypes to blood pressure improvement.

The study aims to investigate the influence of communication between nursing staff and patients on the analgesic response following cesarean section. It is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study conducted at the maternity ward of Carmel Hospital. The study population includes female patients aged 18-50 years undergoing elective cesarean section under spinal anesthesia. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two study arms: the enhanced communication arm, where the nurse will provide positive verbal communication about the analgesic medication, or the normal communication arm, where the nurse will communicate as per usual clinical practice. The primary outcome measure is the change in pain intensity on a 0-10 scale, assessed one hour after the administration of analgesics. The study also plans to assess relevant personality traits using the Self-Consciousness Scale (SCS-R) and the Short Suggestibility Scale (SSS).

This is a clinical trial that aims to assess novel biomarkers in participants undergoing targeted lung health checks. The study is focused on lung cancer and is recruiting adults aged 55 to 74 years who have attended the NCL NHS Targeted Lung Health Check (TLHC) program. The primary outcome is to identify novel molecular, immune, and clinical biomarkers that can improve the sensitivity and specificity of lung cancer screening beyond conventional risk prediction models and low-dose CT scanning. The study will utilize various techniques, including proteomics, metabolomics, genomics, and immune repertoire characterization, performed on peripheral blood samples. The study duration is 5 years.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telepharmacy on the clinical outcomes of patients with arterial hypertension. The primary outcome is the rate of patients reaching the target blood pressure range, while secondary outcomes include medication adherence, patient satisfaction, and the clinical significance of pharmacist interventions. The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing a telepharmacy group receiving pharmaceutical care via telephone consultations to an in-person group receiving face-to-face pharmaceutical care. The study population includes elderly patients (aged 60 years and above) with uncontrolled hypertension who have a cell phone and can use it. The study duration is 3 months.

The key aspects of the ICU LIBERATION Study are:

1. The study aims to investigate the current epidemiology and treatment strategies for patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), particularly after the COVID-19 pandemic, and evaluate how the implementation of evidence-based ICU care is associated with patient outcomes.

2. The primary outcome measures include:
   - Mortality at hospital discharge
   - Compliance with lung-protective ventilation within the first two weeks of ICU admission
   - Implementation rate of the ABCDEF bundle within the first two weeks of ICU admission
   - Incidence of Post-Intensive Care Syndrome (PICS) at 3 months after hospital discharge

3. The study includes patients on invasive or non-invasive ventilation within 24 hours of ICU admission, who are expected to be on a ventilator for more than 48 hours and meet the diagnosis of ARDS within 24 hours of ICU admission.

4. The study aims to increase the generalizability of the results by including participants from various regions of the world, and the findings will contribute to the development of ICU care guidelines to improve outcomes for

This is a randomized, parallel, placebo-controlled, triple-blind clinical trial to evaluate the effect of consuming two doses of Pomanox®P30 (367 mg or 700 mg) on skin aging in humans. The primary objective is to assess the effect on hyperpigmented skin spots, while secondary objectives include evaluating the effects on other skin aging parameters, markers of collagen and hyaluronic acid metabolism, oxidative stress, anti-glycan effect, inflammation, and gut and skin microbiota composition. The study will enroll 66 women aged 30-65 years with Fitzpatrick skin phototypes II-IV. Participants will be randomized to one of three groups: 367 mg Pomanox, 700 mg Pomanox, or placebo (maltodextrin), with treatments taken daily for 12 weeks. Key outcome measures include changes in skin melanin index, wrinkles, hydration, elasticity, erythema, pores, acne, and keratin, as well as various biomarkers in blood, urine, and stool samples. The study also assesses participant self-assessment of skin quality

This study aims to investigate the relationship between prostate medication, gut microbiota, and metabolic characteristics in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer (PCa). The study has two experimental arms:

1. BPH cohort: Participants will receive 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (finasteride, dutasteride, or combination) for BPH treatment. Gut microbiota and metabolic characteristics will be assessed before and after 2 months of treatment.

2. PCa cohort: Participants will receive androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) with an LHRH antagonist (degarelix) for PCa treatment. Gut microbiota and metabolic characteristics will be assessed before and after 2 months of treatment.

The primary outcome measures are the changes in gut microbiota signatures before and after the prostate medications in both cohorts. The secondary outcome measures are the changes in gut and systemic metabolic characteristics before and after the prostate medications.

This is a clinical trial studying the use of magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess the genomic characteristics of glioma brain tumors. The primary objective is to correlate MRS-measured metabolite concentrations (2-hydroxyglutarate and cystathionine) with the IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion status of the tumors. Secondary objectives include correlating diffusion MRI metrics with 1p19q codeletion status, and monitoring changes in MRS-measured metabolites, diffusion MRI, and amide proton transfer signals during anti-tumor treatment in relation to changes in tumor volume and clinical response. The study involves a single group of participants who will undergo MRI examinations without contrast. Eligibility criteria include having a suspected or confirmed grade II/III glioma, adequate performance status, and no contraindications to MRI.

This study evaluates the long-term efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide in patients with beta-thalassemia. The study involves an initial 6-month period of hydroxyurea monotherapy, followed by the addition of thalidomide to the treatment regimen. The primary outcomes measured are the frequency of good responders, responders, and non-responders, changes in laboratory parameters (hemoglobin, platelets, leukocytes, urea, creatinine, and ferritin), and changes in liver and spleen size over 1-3 years of combination therapy. The secondary outcome is the comparison of XmnI polymorphism with treatment outcomes. The study has an open-label, single-group assignment design, and it excludes patients with certain comorbidities, mental disorders, and a history of thrombosis.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The main objective is to determine the role/position of diagnostic imaging in the patient journey for a patient with active or healed venous leg ulceration, and to establish the minimum diagnostics required for this patient cohort.

2. The study involves two components:
   a. A one-time questionnaire sent to primary care practitioners in the UK to determine current practices in venous leg ulcer management and availability of referral services.
   b. A Delphi consensus questionnaire conducted among vascular scientists across the UK to determine current practices for diagnosis and management of suspected venous leg ulcers.

3. The primary outcome measures are:
   a. For primary care practitioners - to determine current practices and availability of services.
   b. For vascular scientists - to determine current practices for diagnosis and management, with consensus to be achieved when 70% agreement is reached.

4. The study aims to determine the cost-effectiveness of implementing the minimum diagnostics in both primary and secondary care settings.

This is a randomized, parallel-group clinical trial that aims to enhance prospective thinking in individuals in early recovery from stimulant use disorders. The study compares the effects of a Virtual Reality Avatar experience versus a Virtual Reality Park experience (control) on various outcomes, including reduced drug use, increased abstinence, future self-identification, future time perspective, and delayed reward preference. The study will measure these outcomes at the study day visit, 30-day follow-up, and 6-month follow-up. The study excludes individuals with unstable medical or psychiatric conditions, habitual drug use, and those under 18 years old.

The provided clinical trial document summarizes a study that aims to evaluate the stability of short implants (6 mm) compared to standard-length implants (10 mm) with internal sinus floor elevation in the posterior maxilla. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two intervention groups: 1) short implants and 2) regular-length implants with internal sinus lift. The primary outcome measure is the crestal bone level, which will be assessed by standardized periapical radiographs at 1 year. The study includes patients with single edentulous sites in the maxillary posterior region, with available bone height of 7-8 mm below the maxillary sinus and adequate bucco-palatal bone width. Exclusion criteria include local pathological defects, habits that may affect implant longevity, inadequate inter-arch space, and smoking.

This is a phase I/II clinical trial evaluating the use of Wharton's Jelly Mesenchymal Stromal Cells (WJ-MSCs) as prophylaxis against Graft-versus-Host Disease (GVHD) in patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) with a haploidentical donor. 

The primary objective is to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of WJ-MSC infusions, defined as the highest dose where no more than 1 out of 6 patients experiences a dose-limiting toxicity within 7 days of infusion. 

The secondary objectives are to assess the incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, toxicity-related mortality, relapse incidence, overall survival, GVHD and relapse-free survival, and poor graft function at 12 months.

The study will enroll patients aged 18-70 years with hematological malignancies (AML, ALL, MDS, MPN, lymphoid neoplasms) who require allogeneic

This study aims to rapidly deploy a clinical decision support tool called eCARTv5 within the electronic health records of multiple medical-surgical units. eCARTv5 combines a real-time machine learning algorithm to identify patients at increased risk for intensive care unit (ICU) transfer and death, with clinical pathways to standardize the care of these high-risk patients.

The primary outcome measure is hospital mortality for patients with elevated eCARTv5 risk scores. Secondary outcome measures include total hospital length of stay, ICU-free days, and ventilator-free days for these high-risk patients.

The study uses a parallel design, with an intervention group where eCARTv5 is actively used by providers, and a control group where the tool runs silently in the background. The primary analysis will compare the pre- and post-implementation results between the intervention and control hospitals.

The study aims to demonstrate that implementing eCARTv5 will be associated with decreased ventilator utilization, length of stay, and mortality for high-risk hospitalized adults.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment-Partners Alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) intervention in reducing maternal depression and improving other maternal and infant outcomes among African-American mothers. The ASSET-PPD intervention targets fathers to increase their involvement, mental health knowledge, communication skills, and division of family tasks in order to reduce maternal stress and support the mother's depression treatment. The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial that will enroll 50 African-American mother-father dyads, with 25 dyads receiving the ASSET-PPD intervention and 25 receiving standard care. The primary outcomes are maternal depression and anxiety, measured using the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated (IDS-SR16) and the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7-item (GAD-7). Secondary outcomes include breastfeeding, infant affect and mood regulation, and parent-infant interaction quality.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate a proactive identification and digital mental health intervention approach to address unmet psychosocial needs of individuals living with cancer. The study will compare a behavioral activation therapy mobile app (Moodivate) to treatment as usual. Eligible participants must have elevated depressive symptoms, be at least 18 years old, own a compatible smartphone, and be willing to use a mobile app for depression treatment. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of eligible individuals who enroll in the study. Participants will be randomized to either the Moodivate app or treatment as usual, which involves providing educational materials about mood management. Both groups will complete weekly questionnaires for 4 weeks, with the Moodivate group continuing for an additional 8 weeks.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to test new algorithms for detecting insulin pump malfunctions and infusion set occlusions in individuals with type 1 diabetes using an automated insulin delivery (AID) system.

2. The study consists of three phases:
   a. Phase 1: Collection of glycemic and insulin administration data from patients using their AID system in free-living conditions.
   b. Phase 2: Induction of hyperglycemia by temporarily suspending insulin infusion to simulate a pump malfunction, under medical supervision.
   c. Phase 3: Retrospective analysis of the collected data to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting insulin suspension.

3. The primary outcome measure is the sensitivity of the tested algorithms, defined as the fraction of correctly detected insulin suspensions.

4. The secondary outcome measure is the number of false positive alarms per day during the baseline pre-intervention period.

5. The study population includes adults (18-70 years old) with type 1 diabetes who have been using an AID system for at least 3 months.

This is an open-label, single-group study to evaluate the effect of Funk It Cycle Bites on premenstrual syndrome (PMS) in women aged 18-40 with regular menstrual cycles and mild to moderate menstrual pain. The primary outcome measures are changes in PMS symptoms, acne, pain levels, mood stability, and energy levels from baseline to 4 months. The secondary outcome measure is participant enjoyment of the product. Eligible participants will consume 1 Cycle Bite per day for 4 months.

This is a parallel cluster randomized trial to assess the (cost)effectiveness of the personalized risk assessment tool PERSARC in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices in high-grade extremity soft-tissue sarcoma patients, compared to usual care. The study will be conducted in 6 Dutch hospitals that are soft-tissue sarcoma expertise centers, with hospitals randomized to either standard care (control) or care with the use of PERSARC (intervention). The primary outcomes are decisional conflict and informed choice, measured one week after the treatment decision. Secondary outcomes include decision regret, cancer worry, involvement in decision-making, patient-reported outcomes, utilities for cost-effectiveness, healthcare costs, and work productivity. The study will also evaluate the actual use, satisfaction, and barriers/facilitators of PERSARC integration in the treatment decision-making process.

Summary:

This study aimed to investigate the prevalence of early childhood caries (ECC) in Jordanian children attending kindergartens, identify associated risk factors, and evaluate the effectiveness and acceptance of silver diamine fluoride (SDF) as a caries control measure.

The study had a cross-sectional epidemiological design, involving 887 children aged 3-5 years. Data on demographic, socioeconomic, oral hygiene, and dietary factors were collected through questionnaires. A subset of 159 children with ECC were then randomized to receive either a single application of 38% SDF (study group) or no intervention (control group). 

The primary outcomes were the prevalence of ECC, prevention of new cavities, and arrest of existing cavities after 1 year of follow-up. Secondary outcomes included identification of ECC risk factors and parental acceptance of SDF application.

The study provides important insights into the burden of ECC in Jordan and the potential role of SDF as a caries control measure in young children.

This is a retrospective study to evaluate the effectiveness of Pfizer's ABRYSVO vaccine in preventing severe respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection in older adults. The primary objective is to estimate the vaccine effectiveness (VE) of ABRYSVO against RSV-related lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI) requiring hospitalization. The study will employ a test-negative design (TND) case-control analysis and a retrospective cohort analysis. 

The TND will assess RSV-related outcomes, while the cohort study will assess all-cause outcomes and may also assess RSV-related outcomes. Secondary objectives include estimating VE against RSV-related severe LRTI, RSV-related acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) hospitalizations, and emergency department (ED) visits, as well as all-cause LRTI and ARI outcomes. Analyses will be stratified by factors such as age, comorbidities, RSV subgroup, and frailty.

The study population includes Kaiser Permanente Southern California members who are eligible for ABRYSVO vaccination per current recommendations. Patients will be classified as vaccinated (received ABRYSVO

The key aspects of the OSsIRIS clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To confirm the performance and safety of the bone substitute b.Bone in the treatment of surgically created bone defects or bone defects/voids resulting from traumatic injury in the extremities and pelvis.

2. Intervention: Bone grafting using the b.Bone device to promote healing in the pelvis, upper and lower extremities.

3. Primary Outcome: Radiographic healing/union rate after 12 months, assessed using the modified radiographic Union Scale for Tibial fractures (mRUST) or modified Neer classification.

4. Secondary Outcomes: 
   - Change in patient-reported pain (Visual Analogue Scale) and quality of life (Health Questionnaire) at 3, 6, and 12 months.
   - Incidence of adverse events (AEs), serious adverse events (SAEs), and reinterventions up to 24 months.

5. Eligibility: Patients aged 18 years or older undergoing standard of care bone grafting with b.Bone for surgically created or traum

This is a 1-year prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the prognostic significance of acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness in patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF). The primary objective is to study the change in liver and splenic stiffness values at day 7 from baseline (day 1) between those with or without transplant-free survival at day 90. The secondary objectives include evaluating the change in liver and splenic stiffness at day 14, the association of baseline and changes in stiffness with ACLF etiology, severity scores, organ failures, inflammatory markers, and esophageal varices. The study will enroll consecutive ACLF patients over 1 year, with no intervention. Liver and splenic stiffness, biochemical markers, and clinical scores will be assessed at days 1, 7, and 14. The study aims to determine if acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness can predict transplant-free survival in ACLF patients.

This is a randomized, triple-masked study that aims to compare the efficacy and safety of onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injections for the treatment of glabellar lines (frown lines) when administered at a depth of 2mm (superficial dermis) versus 4mm (intramuscular). The primary objective is to compare the efficacy of the two injection depths in improving glabellar lines, as measured by the Merz aesthetic scale. The secondary objective is to determine any adverse effects associated with the two injection depths. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 and older who have not received botulinum toxin treatment in the face within the past year and do not have a history of neuromuscular disorders or facial surgery/scars that could confound the study results. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive onabotulinumtoxinA injections at either 2mm or 4mm depth, and the outcomes will be assessed at 120 days. The study hypothesizes that the depth of injection will not affect the efficacy of botulinum toxin for improving glabellar lines, and if validated, this could lead to

This is a randomized, open-label clinical trial investigating the use of music therapy as a tool for reducing anxiety in patients with localized breast cancer undergoing adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy. The primary outcome is to evaluate the impact of music therapy on anxiety, measured using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) before the first and third chemotherapy sessions. Eligible participants are female patients aged 18 years or older with localized breast cancer, who are indicated for adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Patients will be randomized to either the music therapy arm, where they will receive music therapy before the first 3 chemotherapy cycles, or the standard care arm. The study has a primary purpose of supportive care and uses a parallel assignment intervention model.

The study aims to evaluate different conditioning regimens for HLA-matched donor transplantation in patients with severe aplastic anemia (SAA). It is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study.

The study has two arms: 
1) Experimental arm: Busulfan-included conditioning regimens (Bu/Flu/Cy/ATG or Bu/Cy/ATG) 
2) Control arm: Fludarabine/Cyclophosphamide/ATG (Flu/Cy/ATG) or Cyclophosphamide/ATG (Cy/ATG) conditioning regimens

The primary outcome measure is failure-free survival at 1 year post-hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of mixed chimerism, regimen-related toxicity, engraftment, graft-versus-host disease, CMV/EBV reactivation, transplant-related mortality, and overall survival at 1 year post-HSCT.

The study includes patients diagnosed with SAA or very severe aplastic anemia (vSAA

This is a single-arm, open-label clinical trial to investigate the safety and tolerability of switching from emicizumab to fitusiran prophylaxis in male participants aged 18 years or older with severe hemophilia A, with or without inhibitors. The primary outcome is the number of participants with adverse events during the fitusiran treatment period. Secondary outcomes include changes in thrombin generation, antithrombin levels, emicizumab concentrations, treatment satisfaction, pain intensity, physical functioning, joint health, and annualized bleeding rate during the fitusiran treatment period.

The study aims to translate and validate the Malay version of the painDETECT Questionnaire (PDQ-M) for assessing neuropathic and nociceptive pain. The study includes participants with neuropathic or nociceptive pain, who are able to read and understand Malay. Participants will complete the PDQ-M, Numeric Rating Scale (NRS), and Short-Form 36 (SF-36) questionnaires. The primary outcome measure is the total PDQ-M scores, which will be assessed within 2-5 weeks.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a community-based complex exercise program for stroke patients. The study will compare an exercise group that receives the complex exercise program to a control group that continues their daily life activities. The primary outcome measure is the 6-minute walk test, and secondary outcome measures include various assessments of physical function, balance, strength, quality of life, and depression. The study will enroll stroke patients aged 30 years or older who meet specific inclusion criteria related to their level of independence, mobility, and cognitive function. The exercise program consists of warm-up, aerobic, strength, and balance exercises conducted over a 6-week period, with assessments performed at baseline and follow-up.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-finding study to evaluate the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV-552 in participants with mild Alzheimer's disease. The study will enroll participants aged 50 to 90 years with a diagnosis of probable Alzheimer's disease. Participants will be randomized to receive one of three doses of ABBV-552 or placebo once daily for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog 14) score from baseline to week 12.

This observational study aims to evaluate cases of acute liver failure (ALF) and acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF), determine the most likely causes, complications, and assess the mortality and morbidity rates, as well as in-hospital and 6-month follow-up outcomes in patients admitted to intensive care units with severe acute liver disease.

The study will include patients with reduced conscious state, jaundice, abnormal liver function tests, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure. Patients with known cardiac cirrhosis or pre-existing renal disease will be excluded. The study will involve thorough history, clinical examination, imaging, and laboratory investigations, including liver and kidney function tests. Specific scoring systems (CLIF-SOFA, CLIF-C OFs, DF, ABIC, GAHS, MELD, MELD-Na, CHILD) will be used to assess the patients.

The primary outcome measures are the assessment of liver and kidney function, and fluid overload in the patients. The secondary outcome measures are the evaluation of mortality and morbidity rates.

This study aims to determine the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on the quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study will be conducted at the Adıyaman Besni State Hospital in Turkey from October 2023 to February 2024. The sample will consist of 54 outpatients diagnosed with bipolar disorder according to the DSM-5 criteria and who are in the euthymic mood state. Data will be collected through self-report questionnaires, including the Brief Quality of Life in Bipolar Disorder Scale, Barratt Impulsivity Scale-11 Short Form, and Coping Attitudes Evaluation Scale. The primary outcome measures are the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on the quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study aims to provide insights into the factors that influence the quality of life in this patient population, which can inform the development of targeted interventions to improve their well-being.

The study aims to evaluate and compare the 2-year clinical performance of two different single-color universal composite resin restorative materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) with a multi-color composite resin material (Filtek Z250) in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions. The study is a double-blind, prospective, randomized controlled trial. The primary outcome measure is the clinical performance of the restorations according to the modified United States Public Health Service (USPHS) criteria, and the secondary outcome measure is the clinical performance according to the World Dental Organization (FDI) criteria. The study will assess parameters such as retention, marginal discoloration, marginal adaptation, secondary caries, and postoperative sensitivity at 6, 12, 18, 24, and 36 months. The study aims to test two null hypotheses: (1) there is no difference between the two single-color universal composite resin materials in terms of clinical performance, and (2) the universal composite resin materials are not different from the multi-color composite resin material in terms of clinical performance.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of neuromuscular reversal agents, sugammadex and neostigmine, on the time to first available neurological assessment in critically ill patients after endotracheal intubation.

The study will randomize patients into three groups: sugammadex, neostigmine, and a control group. The primary outcome measure is the time from administration of the neuromuscular blocker (rocuronium) to the first available neurological assessment, defined as the time the patient can make a directed movement (Motor score of 6 on the Glasgow Coma Scale). 

Secondary outcome measures include the time to first spontaneous eye opening, changes in processed EEG and cerebral oxygen saturation, time to extubation, length of hospital and ICU stay, and in-ICU and in-hospital mortality.

The study will assess neurological function through regular evaluations of the Glasgow Coma Scale, as well as monitoring of processed EEG and cerebral oxygen saturation. Patients in the sugammadex and neostigmine groups will receive the respective reversal agents 30 minutes after rocuronium administration, while the control

This is a randomized, open-label clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral weight loss intervention in promoting primary prevention and uterine preservation in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer. 

The study has two arms:

1. Experimental arm: Participants receive a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (LNG-IUD) plus a telemedicine-based behavioral weight loss intervention.

2. Active comparator arm: Participants receive an LNG-IUD plus enhanced usual care, which includes educational materials on healthy eating, exercise, and behavioral strategies.

The primary outcome is the number of participants with atypia-free biopsy and uterine preservation at 2 years. Secondary outcomes include time to resolution of hyperplasia, change in weight, change in cancer-worry specific distress, and atypia-free or endometrial cancer-free survival.

The study is designed to assess whether the addition of a behavioral weight loss intervention to standard progestin therapy can improve uterine preservation and prevent progression to endometrial cancer in premenopausal women with

The study aimed to evaluate a new surgical technique called the "Coconut technique" for performing safe cholecystectomy in patients with stage II acute cholecystitis. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Participants: Three patients (2 females, 1 male) with a mean age of 50 years, diagnosed with stage II acute cholecystitis by CT scan and operated within 3 days of symptom onset.

2. Intervention: The "Coconut technique" involves making a 3-4 cm incision in the inflamed gallbladder wall using electrocautery, identifying the junction between the infundibulum and body of the gallbladder, and carefully separating the outer and inner layers to identify the confluence of the cystic duct and gallbladder. The cystic duct is then clipped, and the gallbladder is removed.

3. Outcome Measure: The primary outcome was the successful application of the new "Coconut technique" of subtotal cholecystectomy in patients with stage II acute cholecystitis, evaluated over a 2-year period.

The study aims to examine the effectiveness of a Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol enriched with Virtual Reality (CBT+VR) in addressing psychological problems experienced by athletes after Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) surgery. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Objectives: To investigate the impact of the CBT+VR protocol on re-injury anxiety, kinesiophobia, rehabilitation adherence, and rehabilitation self-efficacy in athletes who have undergone ACL surgery.

2. Interventions: The study has four participant groups - CBT+VR, VR-only, CBT-only, and a control group. Each group will receive 10 weekly sessions of the respective intervention.

3. Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measures are the Re-Injury Anxiety Inventory (RIAI), Sport Injury Rehabilitation Adherence Scale (SIRAS), Athletic Injury Self-Efficacy Questionnaire (AISEQ), and Tampa Scale for Kinesiophobia.

4. Study Design: The study is a randomized, parallel-group, open-label trial with a 4x5

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to assess the development and implementation of the PT-PENCIL tool, a clinical decision support tool that predicts the optimal frequency of physical therapy to facilitate discharge home, and analyze its effect on improving the proportion of patients discharged home.

2. The study uses a stepped-wedge implementation design, where the PT-PENCIL tool is implemented in a phased manner across the hospital. There are two participant groups: the PT-PENCIL cohort (patients discharged while the tool was active) and the control cohort (patients discharged while the tool was not active).

3. The primary outcome measures are:
   - Effectiveness of the PT-PENCIL tool on discharge home vs. facility
   - Reach (number of patients for whom the tool ran)
   - Adoption (number of therapists who acknowledged the tool's alert)
   - Acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the tool among physical therapists

4. The study includes adult patients (≥18 years) admitted for at least one overnight stay, with a primary medical service in certain specialties, and excludes patients with IC

This is a single-arm, prospective, exploratory study to evaluate the feasibility and effect of Medical Tai Chi Exercise Healing in treating patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC). The study will assess the adherence rates to the 7-Form of Medical Tai Chi Exercise Healing program, which involves 60-minute sessions three times a week for eight weeks. The secondary outcomes include measures of fatigue, sleep quality, quality of life, anxiety, and depression. The study will enroll patients aged 18 to 75 years with mCRC and an ECOG performance status of 0-2, and who meet other eligibility criteria. The study design is an open-label, single-group assignment.

The study aims to determine the effectiveness of the Survivorship ECHO's educational intervention in improving provider knowledge of cancer survivorship best practices. The intervention involves providers attending 6 sessions of the Survivorship ECHO program over 12 weeks, with an optional one-on-one interview to provide feedback. The study measures changes in provider knowledge and comfort with survivorship care, as well as the acceptability, needs, and barriers related to the Survivorship ECHO platform. The study population includes providers from the James Cancer Network in Ohio, including nurses, advanced practice nurses, physician assistants, nutritionists, radiation oncologists, and oncologists.

This was a randomized, controlled trial that compared the effectiveness of post-facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization in improving range of motion (ROM) in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow. The study included 32 participants aged 18-35 years with a limitation of elbow joint ROM greater than 30 degrees in extension and less than 120 degrees in flexion. Participants were randomly assigned to either the Maitland mobilization group or the post-facilitation stretch group. Both groups received hot pack and active/active-assisted exercises for the elbow, wrist, and forearm. 

The primary outcome measures were changes from baseline in numeric pain rating scale, elbow flexion ROM, elbow extension ROM, forearm supination ROM, and forearm pronation ROM. The secondary outcome measure was changes in disability as measured by the DASH (Disability of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand) questionnaire. Outcomes were assessed at baseline and after 4 weeks of intervention.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to evaluate a multidisciplinary approach for early diagnosis of heart failure in high-risk Canadian patients. The study will compare an "ACTIVE" investigational arm, where participants undergo NT-proBNP testing followed by an AI-enabled handheld echocardiogram if NT-proBNP is elevated, to a "CONTROL" arm receiving routine care. The primary outcome is the diagnosis of heart failure within 6 months of randomization, determined by outpatient diagnosis, visits, urgent visits, or hospitalizations. Secondary outcomes include diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and receipt of guideline-directed medical therapy for HFrEF within 6 months.

This is a randomized, crossover study investigating the central and cerebral hemodynamic effects and volume kinetics of Ringer's acetate compared to no intravenous fluids, during experimental hypovolemia and euvolemia in healthy human volunteers.

The primary outcome measure is the half-life of change in cardiac stroke volume over 120 minutes. The secondary outcome measures are the half-life of change in intravascular volume and middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity over 120 minutes.

The study has four arms: 1) No intervention with LBNP 0 (euvolemia), 2) Ringer's acetate 5 ml/kg with LBNP 0 (euvolemia), 3) LBNP 40 mmHg (experimental hypovolemia) with no intravenous fluid, and 4) Ringer's acetate 5 ml/kg with LBNP 40 mmHg (experimental hypovolemia).

The study aims to explore the effects over time of an intravenous fluid bolus on volume expansion and hemodynamic parameters, and how these are affected

The study aims to evaluate the effects and cost-effectiveness of a therapist-guided, internet-delivered psychological treatment program called "eMeistring" for patients with moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. The study is an open, naturalistic, multicenter, cost-effectiveness trial.

The key aspects of the study are:

1. Intervention: The eMeistring program provides therapist-guided internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy (ICBT) for the three patient groups. Patients receive an initial face-to-face visit, followed by 8-9 ICBT sessions/modules, and a final face-to-face visit.

2. Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measures are depression severity (for moderate depression group), social phobia (for social anxiety group), and panic disorder symptoms (for panic disorder group). Secondary outcomes include health-related quality of life, work and social adjustment, anxiety severity, system usability, medication use, work participation, and sickness absenteeism.

3. Eligibility Criteria: Inclusion criteria include having moderate depression, panic disorder, or social anxiety disorder as the primary disorder, and access to a computer and the internet.

This study aimed to compare the perioperative analgesic efficacy of thoracolumbar interfascial plane (TLIP) block and erector spinae plane (ESP) block in patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery. 

Patients were randomly assigned to one of three groups: TLIP block group, ESP block group, and control group. The TLIP and ESP groups received the respective ultrasound-guided nerve blocks with ropivacaine prior to surgery, while the control group received lidocaine infiltration at the incision site. 

The primary outcomes measured were:
1. The sensory blockade area of the TLIP and ESP blocks.
2. Perioperative analgesic effectiveness assessed by total intraoperative fentanyl consumption and Analgesia Nociception Index (ANI) scores.
3. Postoperative analgesic effectiveness assessed by total morphine consumption and Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) pain scores within 24 hours.
4. Incidence of side effects.

The study aimed to evaluate the analgesic efficacy and safety of the TLIP and ESP blocks compared to the control

The study aims to evaluate the performance of a novel wearable device called the Melanin-Adjusted Blood Oxygen Sensor (MABOS) in accurately measuring oxygen saturation levels in individuals with different skin tones. The study will enroll 12 healthy participants, including 4 with African descent, 4 with East Asian descent, and 4 with European descent, with an equal gender distribution. 

The participants will wear the MABOS device and a FDA-approved pulse oximeter (Nonin PureSat) for a 90-minute testing period. The primary outcome measures are the initial and final device safety and comfort questionnaires, which will assess the participants' experiences with the MABOS device. The secondary outcome measures are the device's ability to accurately estimate epidermal melanin concentration and blood oxygen levels, compared to reference methods.

The study will assess the safety, comfort, and accuracy of the MABOS device in measuring oxygen saturation and skin pigmentation across individuals with diverse skin tones.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This is a phase 1/2 open-label, single-group study evaluating the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of interferon beta-1a (FP-1201) to prevent toxicities after CD19-directed CAR T-cell therapy in patients with recurrent or refractory B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, or mantle cell lymphoma.

Patients will receive FP-1201 intravenously for 3-5 days prior to receiving lymphodepletion chemotherapy followed by axi-cel or brexu-cel CAR T-cell infusion on day 0. Patients will undergo various imaging, sampling, and biopsy procedures during the study.

The primary outcome measures are the rate of dose-limiting toxicities and the incidence of adverse events. Secondary outcome measures include the rates of cytokine release syndrome, immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome, corticosteroid use, overall response rate, and complete response rate.

The study aims to enroll patients

This is a randomized, open-label, multicenter phase III clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of camrelizumab plus chemotherapy with or without famitinib as neoadjuvant therapy in participants with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). 

The primary outcome measure is the pathological complete response (pCR) rate, defined as ypT0/Tis ypN0 (no invasive residual in breast or nodes; non-invasive breast residuals allowed) at the time of definitive surgery. 

The secondary outcome measures include event-free survival (EFS), disease-free survival (DFS), distant disease-free survival (DDFS), and objective response rate (ORR) assessed by RECIST v1.1.

Eligible participants must have early or locally advanced, histologically documented TNBC, an ECOG performance status of 0-1, and meet other specified inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study will enroll female participants aged 18 to 70 years.

This study aims to identify early predictors of postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). The study involves a questionnaire survey and collection of blood, placenta, and umbilical cord samples from two groups of GDM patients: those with abnormal postpartum oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) results and those with normal postpartum OGTT results. The primary outcome measures are serum lipidomics and serum metabolomics during the 24-28 gestational weeks, which will be used to screen for markers related to postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in GDM.

This is a clinical trial that aims to assess the sleep quality of hospitalized patients in the intensive care unit (ICU) who are treated with an EEG-guided sleep protection procedure. The study has two arms: the experimental group receives the EEG-guided sleep protection intervention, while the control group receives usual care. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of continuous sleep on day 1. Secondary outcome measures include sleep fragmentation, environmental factors (noise and light), sleep interruptions by caregivers, sleep quality over days 2-4, workload for nurses, patient agitation, performance of the algorithm, patient-reported sleep quality, anxiety levels, respiratory status, presence of delirium, length of ICU stay, and safety of the procedure. The study is non-randomized and open-label, with a sequential assignment of participants to the two arms.

This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAR441566 in combination with methotrexate in adults with moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants achieving at least 20% improvement in the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) score at week 12. Secondary outcome measures include changes in disease activity score (DAS28-CRP), proportion of participants achieving at least 50% improvement in ACR score, safety, and pharmacokinetics of SAR441566. Participants will be randomized to receive one of four dose regimens of SAR441566 or placebo for 12 weeks, in addition to their stable methotrexate treatment.

This is a prospective clinical performance evaluation study of the in-vitro diagnostics medical device MaGIA IBC for the combined screening of HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C. The study aims to assess the diagnostic performance of the MaGIA IBC test in capillary blood, venous blood, serum, and plasma samples. The primary outcome measures are the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) area under the curve (AUC) for HIV, HBV, and HCV diagnostics, the sensitivity and specificity of the test, and the concordance of the diagnostic results across different sample matrices. The secondary outcome is the assessment of study-related adverse events. The study will enroll male and female participants aged 18 years and above who are known or suspected to have HIV, HBV, or HCV infection. The study has a single-arm, open-label design.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to assess the efficacy of the food supplement Endocalyx Pro in reducing sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure. The primary objective is to evaluate the percent change in NT-proBNP, a marker of volume overload, from baseline to 8 weeks in Endocalyx-treated patients compared to placebo. 

The secondary objectives include assessing the effects of Endocalyx on physical limitations, patient-reported outcomes, tissue sodium content, total body water, blood pressure, microcirculation, inflammation, and safety. The study will also explore potential differences in treatment effects between male and female patients.

Eligible patients are adults with chronic heart failure and signs of congestion, such as elevated NT-proBNP levels and use of diuretics. Participants will be randomized to receive either Endocalyx (4 capsules per day) or placebo for 8 weeks. The study will measure various clinical, hemodynamic, and biomarker outcomes at baseline, 4 weeks, and 8 weeks.

This is a feasibility study to evaluate the use of nasogastric tubes (NG tubes) and water-soluble contrast (WSC) in the management of adhesive small bowel obstruction (aSBO). Patients will be randomized into three groups: 1) aSBO treated without NG tubes, 2) aSBO treated with NG tubes and WSC, and 3) aSBO treated with NG tubes and saline. The primary outcome measure is patient-reported quality of life assessed using the PROMIS-29 instrument at various time points. The study aims to determine the feasibility of this approach in managing aSBO.

This is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate a novel combination therapeutic strategy for achieving a functional cure (sustained HBsAg loss) in patients with chronic hepatitis B virus (CHB) infection. The study compares two treatment arms:

1. Experimental group: Patients receive a combination of nucleos(t)ide analogues (NAs), anti-PD-1 antibody, and pegylated interferon-alpha (Peg-IFNα).
2. Active comparator group: Patients receive a combination of NAs and Peg-IFNα.

The primary outcome measures are the changes in serum HBsAg, HBV DNA, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels at baseline, 24 weeks, 48 weeks, and 24 weeks after the end of treatment. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of the novel combination therapy in achieving sustained HBsAg loss, a key indicator of functional cure, in patients with CHB.

This is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked clinical trial that aims to compare the wound healing outcomes between simple and continuous suture techniques in oral surgery. The study will enroll participants aged 40-65 years who require full arch alveoplasty, with no uncontrolled systemic conditions or complications related to wound healing. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the simple suture group or the continuous suture group, and the primary outcome measures include the Laundry Healing Index, Early Wound Healing Score, suturing time, knot looseness, pain at suture removal, and suture removal difficulty, all assessed at various time points up to 7 days after the procedure.

This pilot study aims to explore the feasibility and utility of using an in-home body weight support harness system in children with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) types 1 and 2. The study will enroll children with confirmed SMN1 gene mutations and 2-3 copies of SMN2, who have upright head control and weight under 50 lbs. All participants will receive the in-home harness system, which allows 360-degree mobility and adjustable body weight support. The primary outcomes include caregiver surveys on the perceived impact, child's enjoyment, and ease of use, as well as changes in motor function assessments like the Gross Motor Function Outcome, Hammersmith Functional Motor Scale, and Bayley Scales. Secondary outcomes include a log of harness usage frequency and duration. This open-label, single-arm pilot study aims to evaluate the feasibility and potential benefits of the in-home body weight support harness system for children with SMA.

This is a clinical trial studying the use of Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty (DMEK) in patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence rate of at least one serious DMEK post-operative complication, including graft detachment, graft failure, graft rejection, and macular cystoid edema, at 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include the individual rates of these complications, as well as visual acuity, refractive outcomes, endothelial cell loss, corneal thickness, and posterior keratometry at various time points up to 12 months. The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of DMEK in this patient population with prior ocular surgeries.

The study aims to analyze the mechanism behind the efficacy of oral antibiotic prophylaxis in elective colon and rectal surgery with primary anastomosis. It focuses on the impact of the microbiome on surgical complications, particularly anastomotic leaks. The study compares two groups: one receiving oral antibiotic prophylaxis (neomycin and metronidazole) in addition to mechanical bowel preparation, and the other receiving only mechanical bowel preparation without oral antibiotics. The primary outcome measure is to assess the correlation between septic complications and the microbiome, while the secondary outcome measure is to identify factors that influence the microbiome, such as comorbidities, previous operations, oral antibiotic prophylaxis, and systemic intravenous prophylaxis. The study includes patients undergoing circular stapled anastomosis and excludes those with antibiotic allergies, recent antibiotic use, abdominal sepsis, and immunosuppression.

The study aims to assess the utility of measurements made at the point of maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The study will compare patients with CTS and healthy controls on the following measures: 

1. Difference in the diameter of the median nerve at the site of maximal compression.
2. Difference in the cross-sectional area of the median nerve at the site of maximal compression. 
3. Difference in the echogenicity of the median nerve at the site of maximal compression.

The study will also evaluate the correlation between these ultrasound measures at the point of maximal stenosis and:
1. The clinical severity of CTS as measured by the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) score.
2. The electrophysiological severity grade of CTS.

The study will enroll both patients with CTS and healthy controls, and will perform nerve conduction studies and median nerve ultrasound on all participants.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and symptom burden optimization of tocilizumab in patients with multiple myeloma undergoing autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) following high-dose melphalan conditioning.

The primary outcome measures are:
1. MDASI (M.D. Anderson Symptom Inventory) questionnaire to assess the severity and impact of cancer-related symptoms at day -7 and day 100 after stem cell transplantation.
2. Adverse events recorded according to CTCAE 5.0 from day -7 to day 100 after stem cell transplantation.

Eligible patients are those with multiple myeloma who are eligible for ASCT, have achieved at least a partial response after induction therapy, and meet various other inclusion and exclusion criteria related to organ function, performance status, and medical history.

Patients will be randomized to receive either tocilizumab (8 mg/kg) at day -7 before stem cell infusion or no intervention.

This is a clinical trial comparing the outcomes of Testicular Sperm Aspiration (TESA) and Microfluidic Sperm Separation (MSS) in couples with high sperm DNA fragmentation undergoing Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI). The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate, and the secondary outcome measure is the number of utilizable blastocysts obtained. The study includes men with high DNA fragmentation (>20%) and excludes couples with advanced maternal age (>40 years) or using egg donation. The study aims to determine which approach, TESA-ICSI or Zymot-ICSI, is better for couples with high sperm DNA fragmentation.

The study aimed to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance in archery athletes at the cervical, lumbar, and scapular levels. 

The key aspects of the study are:

1. Participants: 40 archery athletes aged 10-18 years who have been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year.

2. Interventions: The study evaluated the athletes' shooting performance, cervical, lumbar, and scapular stabilization, balance, posture, disability, upper extremity performance, hand grip strength, and muscle tightness.

3. Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measures included cervical stabilization, lumbar stabilization grade, lumbar stabilizator muscle contraction, scapular dyskinesis type and amount, and shooting performance. The secondary outcome measures included balance assessment, posture, disability, upper extremity performance, hand grip strength, and muscle tightness.

4. Study Design: The participants were divided into two groups based on their shooting performance (good performance: ≥589 points, bad performance: ≤588 points), and the outcome measures were assessed at baseline.

This study aims to develop and evaluate an AI-based communication training intervention to improve contraception discussions between pediatricians, adolescents, and their mothers. The study consists of three stages:

1. Formative stage: Characterize communication content and styles of pediatricians, adolescents, and mothers during real-life contraception discussions. Identify optimal communication strategies through group interviews.

2. Development stage: Create and refine an AI-based communication training tool using the insights from stage 1. Test the acceptability and feasibility of the tool with 10 pediatrician learners.

3. Proof-of-concept stage: Evaluate the impact of the AI communication training tool by comparing 50 pre-training and 50 post-training real clinical encounters between pediatricians, adolescents, and their mothers.

The primary outcome measures are the quality of communication interactions, assessed through questionnaires before and after the training intervention. Secondary outcomes include the acceptability and feasibility of the AI-based tool.

This study aims to investigate healthcare disparities in vitiligo, a skin condition characterized by patchy loss of skin pigmentation. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Estimating the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo in the overall population and across different sociodemographic groups (age, sex, ethnicity, and deprivation level).

2. Conducting a subgroup analysis within the vitiligo population to identify disparities in mental health conditions, healthcare utilization (primary care visits, dermatology and mental health referrals), and work-related impact (unemployment and time off work).

The study will use data from the UK's OPCRD database, covering the period from 2004 to 2020. The study population includes all adults and adolescents (aged 13+) registered in the OPCRD during the study period, with a focus on those newly diagnosed with vitiligo. The study does not involve any interventions, but rather an observational analysis of usual care.

The primary outcome measure is the cumulative lifetime incidence of vitiligo, while the secondary outcome measures include the incidence and prevalence of mental health conditions, healthcare utilization, and work-

The study aimed to investigate the effects of a hybrid behavior modification intervention, based on the "Atomic Habits" approach, on stress, self-efficacy, relationships, and conflict for caregivers of children with developmental delays. Caregivers were randomly assigned to either a hybrid intervention group or a self-learning group. The hybrid group received the "Atomic Habits" audiobook, a role structure, a game structure, online schedule reminders, and individual counseling sessions. The self-learning group received a description of the course goals and the "Atomic Habits" book. Outcome measures included intervention fidelity, parenting sense of confidence, parenting stress, conflict tactics, and a satisfaction questionnaire. The study was designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial with a primary purpose of treatment.

This is a phase I/Ib clinical trial evaluating the combination of trotabresib (an oral BET inhibitor) and vinorelbine, with radiation therapy, in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer and central nervous system (CNS) metastases or leptomeningeal disease.

The primary objectives are to:
1. Determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase II dose of trotabresib in combination with vinorelbine (phase I).
2. Measure progression-free survival (PFS) from start of treatment to disease progression at intracranial and extracranial sites (phase Ib expansion).

Secondary objectives include assessing the safety and tolerability of the combination, overall survival (OS), and objective response rate (ORR).

The study has two cohorts:
- Cohort I: Patients receive radiation therapy followed by trotabresib and vinorelbine.
- Cohort S: Patients undergo tumor resection, then receive trotabresib and vinorelbine, with optional radiation therapy.

Key eligibility criteria include HER2-positive breast cancer

The study aims to modify and adapt a validated program to create a culturally-relevant digital health tool for binge eating and weight management in Black women with obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m^2) who binge eat. It will examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of this digital health tool in a randomized clinical trial in primary care.

The study has two main aims:
1. Identify barriers and facilitators to detecting and treating binge eating in Black women with obesity, and strategies for optimizing digital health tools to engage and retain this population. Conduct usability testing to guide content and design refinements.
2. In a randomized clinical trial, examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health "Centering Appetite" program, which combines appetite awareness treatment and behavioral weight loss treatment, in primary care.

The primary outcome measures are feasibility (total number of eligible adults enrolled), retention (percentage of participants retained), and attendance (percentage of intervention sessions attended). The secondary outcome measures are changes in weight regain and number of binge eating episodes from baseline to 3 and 6 months.

The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel assignment trial.

This study aims to investigate the dose-response effect of beetroot juice supplementation on neuromuscular performance during resistance exercise. The study will compare the effects of low (6.5 mmol), moderate (13 mmol), and high (26 mmol) doses of nitrate-rich beetroot juice against a nitrate-depleted placebo on various measures of neuromuscular performance, including power, velocity, and jump characteristics. The study will also assess plasma nitrate and nitrite levels in response to the different beetroot juice doses. The study uses a randomized, double-blind, crossover design, with recreationally active male participants performing resistance exercise after consuming the different beetroot juice supplements.

The study aims to investigate the effect of two different intra-operative intra-abdominal pressure levels (12 mmHg and 14 mmHg) applied to patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia on Mechanical Power (MP). MP is a measure of the energy transferred per unit time from the mechanical ventilator to the respiratory system, which has been associated with ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) and other postoperative pulmonary complications. The study will measure MP at various time points during the surgery in the two groups and compare the results. The primary outcome is the assessment of ventilator-induced lung injury (barotrauma) based on the measured MP values.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) as an alternative to Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT) for the assessment of furcation involvement in molars. The study includes patients with periodontitis and periodontal diseases, specifically those with furcation involvement (FI) grade II or III, who require a CBCT. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of horizontal furcation defects according to the Hamp classification, while the secondary outcome measures are the assessment of horizontal and vertical bone loss. The study accepts healthy volunteers and includes participants aged 18 to 120 years old.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This was a randomized, parallel-group study that compared the plaque removal efficacy of electric and manual toothbrushes in children with ADHD and healthy children. 

The study included 52 children - 26 with ADHD and 26 healthy controls. The participants were randomly assigned to use either an electric or manual toothbrush. 

The primary outcome measures were:
- Gingival Index (GI) to evaluate gingival health
- Turesky modification of Quigley-Hein Plaque Index (TQHPI) to evaluate plaque removal from labial and lingual surfaces
- Approximal Plaque Index (API) to evaluate plaque removal from proximal surfaces

These measures were assessed at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months.

Secondary outcomes included the DMFT (decayed, missing, filled teeth) index for permanent teeth and the dft index for primary teeth, as well as a questionnaire on nutrition, diet, and oral hygiene habits.

The study aimed to comparatively evaluate the plaque removal

This is a prospective, single-arm, open-label, non-randomized, multi-center study to investigate the feasibility and stability of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) using a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead (Solia S) in patients with symptomatic bradycardia. The primary outcome is the implant success rate, defined as the ability of the Solia lead to provide appropriate sensing and pacing at 12 months post-implantation. Secondary outcomes include intraoperative fluoroscopic exposure time, intracardiac electrogram parameters, post-operative imaging data, changes in 12-lead ECG and echocardiography, and serial changes in pacing parameters. The study plans to enroll approximately 150 patients across 7 clinical sites in Taiwan.

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of two sonic electric toothbrushes (Sonicare DiamondClean 9000 and HydroSonic Easy) and two manual toothbrushes (Oral-B 123 and Curaprox CS 5460) in reducing gingival inflammation in pregnant women aged 18 to 40 years. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of gingival bleeding during pregnancy, assessed at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months. Secondary outcome measures include the effect on gingival bleeding, gingival inflammation, dental plaque, gingival attachment, and periodontal pocket depth, as well as customer satisfaction. The study has a parallel assignment design with four experimental arms, and participants will be asked to use the assigned toothbrush daily for 3 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of yoga-based breathing styles, specifically nose-breathing and mouth-breathing, on memory performance and subjective stress levels in adults without prior experience in yoga, meditation, or similar disciplines, and without existing health problems. The study will randomize participants into three groups: a nose-breathing training group, a mouth-breathing training group, and a control group with no intervention. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in memory performance, assessed through a memory test before and after the 2-week training period. The secondary outcome measure is the reduction in subjective stress levels, measured through self-reported stress statements. The study seeks to determine if the nasal breathing training results in significant improvements in memory capacity compared to the mouth-breathing and control groups.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of calisthenics exercises and pulsed electromagnetic therapy on liver function in patients with burn injuries. The study will measure the concentrations of the liver enzymes Alanine transaminase (ALT) and Aspartate transaminase (AST) in the blood plasma before and after 3 months of treatment. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: calisthenics exercise group, pulsed electromagnetic therapy group, or a combination of both interventions. The calisthenics exercise program will involve medium-intensity exercises for 60 minutes, 3 times per week for 12 weeks. The pulsed electromagnetic therapy will be applied to the upper abdominal area for 20 minutes, 3 times per week for 3 months. The study includes male and female participants aged 20-45 years with 30-50% total body surface area burns, and excludes those with cardiac diseases, foot burns, limb amputations, or a history of liver disease.

The study aims to investigate the effects of a nutritional intervention on the bioavailability and immune-activity of PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The primary objective is to evaluate the variability of pembrolizumab clearance during a 12-week nutritional intervention period. The secondary objectives are to assess the feasibility of recruiting 50 patients within 1.5 years and the feasibility of subjects complying with the study protocol. The study is an open-label, single-arm feasibility study where NSCLC patients will receive a daily nutritional intervention (two 200 mL bottles) in addition to their standard-of-care pembrolizumab immunotherapy. Blood samples, questionnaires, and fecal specimens will be collected at various time points to evaluate the effects of the nutritional intervention on the patients' nutritional, immune, and microbiome status, as well as pembrolizumab clearance.

The study aims to investigate the role of integrins and protocadherins in glutamatergic circuits and their potential involvement in anxiety and major depressive disorders (MDD-AD). The study is divided into two parts:

1. Clinical study: 
- Recruitment of 10 patients with MDD-AD and 10 healthy controls (HC)
- Comprehensive clinical and psychopathological assessment using structured interviews and rating scales (SCID-I, SCID-II, HAM-D, MADRS, HAM-A, BPRS)
- Multimodal neuroimaging evaluation using 7T MRI, including structural MRI, functional MRI, and proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS)

2. Preclinical study in murine models:
- Evaluation of the impact of Pcdh9 deficiency on excitatory synapses using electron microscopy
- Assessment of glutamatergic signaling by analyzing the expression of glutamate receptor subunits
- Characterization of the interaction between integrin β3 and Protocadherin9 using co

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This study aims to investigate the association between cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and the intestinal microbiome using multi-omics big data analysis. The study will collect blood and stool samples from a disease cohort of patients with cardiovascular and neurological conditions (idiopathic ventricular tachycardia, restenosis after coronary artery stenting, carotid atherosclerosis, Moyamoya disease) as well as a healthy control group. 

The blood samples will undergo genome and transcriptome sequencing, while the stool samples will undergo metagenomic, metabolomic, and proteomic sequencing. The multi-omics data will be integrated and analyzed using machine learning methods to identify key host genes and microbial factors associated with the diseases. 

The study aims to elucidate the mechanisms by which the gut microbiome influences cardiovascular and nervous system diseases, with the goal of identifying biomarkers and therapeutic targets for disease prevention and treatment.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the prognostic value of a combined approach using KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations and pre-therapeutic FDG-PET/CT radiomic analysis in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients with PD-L1 expression ≥ 50% treated with pembrolizumab.

2. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), defined as the time from initiation of treatment to tumor progression or death from any cause.

3. The secondary outcome measure is overall survival (OS), defined as the time from initiation of treatment to death from any cause.

4. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with histologically or cytologically proven stage IV NSCLC or unresectable stage III NSCLC, with PD-L1 expression ≥ 50% and no previous systemic treatment for NSCLC.

5. The study aims to establish a predictive model for the presence of KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations, which may help identify patients unlikely to

This is a phase II, open-label, non-randomized clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of sacituzumab govitecan (SG), with or without atezolizumab, in patients with rare metastatic genitourinary tumors, including small cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and primary adenocarcinoma of the bladder/urinary tract, renal medullary carcinoma, and squamous cell carcinoma of the penis.

The primary objective is to determine the objective response rate (ORR) of SG, either alone or in combination with atezolizumab. Secondary objectives include evaluating duration of response, overall survival, progression-free survival, clinical benefit rate, and safety.

Eligible patients will receive either SG alone (Arm 1) or SG plus atezolizumab (Arm 2), with treatment given in 21-day cycles until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The study plans to enroll up to 60 patients to account for inevaluable participants and screen failures.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) compared to eccentric exercises combined with electrical stimulation in improving ankle dorsiflexion range of motion and vertical jump performance in professional padel tennis players. The study is a randomized, parallel-group trial with two intervention arms: 1) PNF group receiving proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation for ankle dorsiflexion, and 2) eccentric exercise and electrical stimulation group receiving eccentric exercises and strengthening currents for ankle dorsiflexion. The primary outcome measures are vertical jump and ankle dorsiflexion range of motion, assessed at 1 month. The study includes professional padel tennis players aged 18-50 years, excluding those with traumatic or musculoskeletal history, neurological conditions, or difficulty performing the exercises.

The study is a 12-week multicentre randomized parallel-group open controlled trial with a 6- and 12-month follow-up. The main objective is to assess the effectiveness of dietary counselling promoting the Mediterranean diet (MedDiet) as an adjuvant treatment for major depressive disorder (MDD) in adults with elevated inflammation biomarkers. 

Participants will be randomized to either the intervention group, receiving six nutrition consultations promoting adherence to the MedDiet in addition to usual MDD treatment, or the control group receiving only usual MDD treatment. 

The primary outcome is changes in symptoms of MDD, measured using the Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II) scale. The secondary outcome is changes in inflammation biomarkers (IL-6 and CRP). The study will also evaluate the association between adherence to the MedDiet, changes in inflammatory biomarkers, effectiveness of psychiatric treatment, and health-related quality of life.

This is a community-based participatory study that aims to support refugee parenting and improve family mental health in refugee shelters in Tijuana, Mexico. The study will use a participatory research model to engage community stakeholders in prioritizing 3-5 parenting skills. Participants will be randomly assigned to either receive a culturally adapted parenting curriculum twice a week for 4 weeks or a control group that will receive a handout on childhood nutrition. The primary outcome measures are parenting knowledge and child behavior/parental efficacy, assessed immediately before and after the 4-week intervention period. Secondary outcome measures include observed parent-child interactions, parental stress, qualitative feedback, and longer-term follow-up of parenting knowledge and child behavior/parental efficacy at 2 months post-intervention. The study aims to empower the refugee community through a participatory learning model and improve family mental health.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:
