This is a prospective longitudinal qualitative study across three regions of North England, accompanied by co-design workshops. The study aims to understand and identify priorities for improving the healthcare experiences of people with incurable head and neck cancer (HNC).

The study has two main work packages:

1. Longitudinal qualitative study:
   - Interviews with 18-25 incurable HNC patients and/or their family carers over 18 months, conducted at 4-month intervals.
   - Online focus groups with approximately 20 healthcare professionals involved in the care of incurable HNC patients.

2. Co-design workshops:
   - Initial virtual information exchange meetings with stakeholders (those with lived experience and healthcare professionals).
   - Two in-person co-design workshops to identify priority areas for improving care and generate potential solutions.

The study outcomes include completion of the interviews, focus groups, and co-design workshops, which will inform the development of a logic model and priority areas for future intervention development to improve healthcare experiences for people with incurable HNC.

This is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the use of indocyanine green (ICG) fluorescence imaging to assist in the identification of nerve roots during endoscopic spinal surgery for the treatment of lumbar disc herniation. 

The study has three experimental arms:
1) 0.5 mg/kg ICG group
2) 1 mg/kg ICG group 
3) 2 mg/kg ICG group

The primary outcome measures are:
1) Fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots
2) Fluorescence signal ratio of nerve root to background
3) Time taken to find the nerve root endoscopically

The secondary outcome measures include ICG-related adverse reactions, pain scores, functional outcomes, surgical complications, and length of surgery.

The study is designed as a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment trial to evaluate the clinical application of ICG fluorescence imaging in assisting with nerve root identification during endoscopic spinal surgery for lumbar disc herniation.

This study evaluates the effectiveness of a home-based parenting support program called "Parenting Young Children" (PYC) for parents with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDDs) who are at risk of neglecting their children. The study compares the PYC program to the usual care provided by social services (Treatment as Usual, TAU). 

The primary outcome measures are changes in the parents' occupational performance and satisfaction, as measured by the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure. The secondary outcome measures are changes in parental sense of competence and the child's behavioral and emotional problems, as measured by the Parental Sense of Competence Scale and the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire, respectively. 

The study has a non-randomized, parallel-group design, with participants assigned to either the PYC program or the TAU group. The PYC program involves weekly, one-hour home-based sessions over 3-6 months, focusing on parent-child interaction and child care skills. The TAU group receives a variety of interventions typically provided by social services.

This is a prospective observational study that aims to collect information on patient characteristics and outcomes in male patients undergoing surgery for stress urinary incontinence using either artificial urinary sphincters (AUS) or male slings. The primary outcome measure is the success rate (cure plus improvement) at 5 years after surgery, defined as urinary continence with no need for pads or the use of 1 light security pad. Secondary outcome measures include time being continent, time being revision-free, revision-free rate, patient-reported quality of life, and post-operative general and specific adverse events, all measured at various time points up to 5 years. The study will enroll male patients aged 18 years and older who are willing and able to complete the required questionnaires and provide informed consent.

This is a single-arm, open-label clinical trial that aims to evaluate the use of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 PET imaging to assess 5T4 expression in malignant tumors. The study includes patients with pancreatic, lung, or colorectal cancer who meet the eligibility criteria. Participants will receive a single intravenous dose of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 (1.8 MBq/kg) and undergo PET/CT imaging. The primary outcome is the establishment and optimization of the 68Ga-NOTA-H006 PET imaging method, which will be assessed by analyzing the standardized uptake value (SUV) of the tracer in lesions and comparing it to 5T4 expression in pathological specimens. The study does not include healthy volunteers and has a time frame of 90 minutes from the time of injection.

This study aims to investigate the biological mechanisms behind cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) in heart failure patients. The study will collect blood samples, heart tissue, and clinical data (echocardiography, ECG, medical records) from heart failure patients eligible for CRT and a control group of heart failure patients on medical therapy. The blood samples will be analyzed for proteins and exosomal miRNA, and the heart tissue will be analyzed for proteins, RNA, and contractility. Endothelial function will also be evaluated using EndoPAT and red blood cell studies. The primary outcome measure is to identify biomarkers, such as proteins or exosomal miRNA, that can distinguish CRT responders from non-responders. The secondary outcome measure is to evaluate endothelial function as a potential factor in CRT response. The study aims to enroll patients aged 18 to 80 years and will follow them for up to 12 months.

The study aims to provide evidence on medication strategies for heart failure patients who are intolerant to guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT). It compares the outcomes between heart failure patients who are tolerant to GDMT and those who are intolerant. The primary outcome is the risk of all-cause mortality or worsening heart failure within 180 days. Secondary outcomes include changes in symptoms, biomarkers, and echocardiographic parameters over 180 days. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and excludes those with preserved ejection fraction, severe pulmonary or liver disease, and other conditions. Patients intolerant to GDMT will receive modified treatment regimens, while those tolerant will receive standard GDMT.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to apply behavioral economic strategies to improve patient-reported outcome (PRO) adherence in cancer patients receiving new systemic therapy.

2. It is a randomized, three-arm trial comparing:
   a. Usual practice (encounter-based PRO monitoring)
   b. Encounter-based PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts
   c. Remote PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts

3. The primary outcome is PRO adherence, measured as the proportion of expected PRO questionnaires completed per patient over 3 months.

4. Secondary outcomes include documentation of PROs in clinical notes, time to alert response, percent of patients triggering alerts, acute care utilization, treatment delays/modifications, and duration of therapy.

5. The study population includes adult cancer patients initiating a new line of systemic therapy at participating sites, excluding those who opt out of the pragmatic research.

The study aims to better understand the prognostic awareness of patients with advanced cancer referred to the Enhanced Supportive Care (ESC) service at University College London Hospital. The primary outcome is to assess patients' prognostic understanding using the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire. Secondary outcomes include evaluating patients' preferences for receiving prognostic information, as well as their levels of depression, anxiety, quality of life, trust in medical professionals, and perceived quality of care. The study will be a cross-sectional prospective study, with the goal of including 100 patients. The findings will help inform strategies to improve prognostic communication and delivery of high-quality supportive care for patients with advanced cancer.

This is a pragmatic, randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of direct-from-blood bacterial testing using the T2Bacteria® Panel on antibiotic administration and clinical outcomes in patients with suspected bloodstream infections or sepsis. Eligible patients are adults (≥18 years) presenting to the emergency department at Vanderbilt University Hospital with a clinician-ordered blood culture and intravenous vancomycin. Patients are randomly assigned to either the direct-from-blood testing group or the usual care group. The primary outcome is the time to the last dose of intravenous vancomycin within 14 days of randomization. Secondary outcomes include the time to the last dose of systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotics within 14 days of randomization.

This is a randomized-controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of temperature-elevating armbaths (Hauffe-Schwenninger-Baths) on blood pressure in individuals with arterial hypertension. 50 participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, who will perform the armbaths 5 times per week for 8 weeks, or the waitlist control group, who will continue their usual treatment. Blood pressure will be measured at baseline, 8 weeks, and 6 months using 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring. Secondary outcomes include health-related quality of life, sleep quality, heart rate, adverse events, and changes in blood pressure medication. After 6 months, the control group will also be offered the opportunity to learn the armbath technique.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of acupuncture and mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on perceived stress and health in military service members and veterans. The study will randomize participants to receive either manual standardized stress acupuncture (MSSA) plus MBSR, or MBSR alone. The primary outcome measure is the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS), assessed at baseline, 2 weeks, and 4 weeks post-interventions. Secondary outcomes include the Insomnia Severity Index, the Short Form Health Survey, and a journal log. Eligible participants are active duty and veteran service members aged 18-65 years with self-reported perceived stress symptoms for at least one month and a PSS score of 16 or above. Exclusion criteria include recent surgery, alcohol/substance abuse, and prior acupuncture or MBSR treatment within the past month.

The study aims to determine the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in a cohort of patients in Punta Arenas, Magallanes and Chilean Antarctic Region. The study will include adults aged 18 to 100 years who have had at least one positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-qPCR test between July 2022 and July 2023. The primary outcome is to determine the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in this population over a 13-month period. Secondary outcomes include assessing sociodemographic data, psychological profiles, sleep quality, psychosocial exposures, standard laboratory parameters, inflammatory biomarkers, immunological repertoire, and musculoskeletal function. The study will also provide a clinical determination of whether patients have persistent COVID-19 for appropriate healthcare referral.

The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial that compares intrathecal catheter placement versus resiting the epidural catheter after a dural puncture (UDP) in obstetric patients. The primary outcome is the incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) at 24 hours from the UDP occurrence. Secondary outcomes include PDPH intensity at 24 and 48 hours, quality of analgesia, adverse events, incidence of chronic pain at 1 and 3 months, hospital readmissions, and patient satisfaction. The study includes female patients aged 18 years and older with a confirmed diagnosis of UDP during labor. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the resiting epidural catheter group or the intrathecal catheter placement group. The study is an open-label design with a parallel assignment.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of sectional matrix versus circumferential matrix systems in reconstructing proximal contacts in Class II dental restorations. The study will involve administering local anesthesia, isolating the tooth with a rubber dam, removing caries, and applying either a sectional matrix or a circumferential matrix system. Resin composite restorations will then be completed, and the tightness of the proximal contacts will be evaluated immediately after the procedure using dental floss. The primary outcome measure is the tightness of the proximal contact, which will be categorized as optimum, tight, or open. The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial involving participants aged 18 to 60 years with good general health and fully erupted occluding premolar and molar teeth.

This study evaluates the effectiveness of a Pay for Performance (PFP) program for high-utilizers of mental health services in Santa Clara County, California. The study compares the PFP program to usual care (UC) in terms of the total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services over 12, 24, and 36 months. Secondary outcomes include the costs of specific psychiatric services (e.g., inpatient, emergency, residential) and incarceration rates. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-65 with a history of extensive utilization of 24-hour psychiatric services and a likelihood of continued high utilization. Participants are randomly assigned to either the PFP program or UC. The PFP program provides a tailored mix of assertive case management, crisis intervention, substance use counseling, mental health treatment, peer support, and care coordination, with financial incentives for the provider based on patient outcomes. The study aims to determine if the PFP program can reduce the total cost of psychiatric services compared to UC.

This study aims to determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of Culturally adapted Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CaCBT) and Culturally adapted Family Intervention (CulFI) compared to Treatment as Usual (TAU) in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with First Episode Psychosis (FEP) in Pakistan. 

The study will include 390 participants with FEP from psychiatric units of hospitals in ten centers in Pakistan. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU, or TAU alone. 

The primary outcome measure is the change in Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) scores from baseline to 3, 6, and 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in depression, quality of life, disability, insight, caregiver experiences, anxiety, and medication adherence. 

The study also includes a process evaluation and economic evaluations (cost-effectiveness and cost-utility analyses) of the CaCBT and CulFI interventions.

This is a Phase 1/2 multi-center study evaluating the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 bispecific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy, in participants with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). The study consists of a Phase 1 dose-finding part followed by a Phase 2 part.

The primary objectives are to assess the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs) and other treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs), the investigator-assessed complete response (CR) rate, and the proportion of enrolled participants who receive the target dose in the Phase 1 part. In the Phase 2 part, the primary objective is to assess the complete response rate based on investigator assessment per the Lugano classification.

Secondary objectives include evaluating the proportion of participants who receive the target dose, overall response rate, duration of response, duration of complete response, progression-free survival, overall survival, pharmacokinetic parameters, and persistence of IMPT-314 cells. The study will enroll participants aged 18

The study aims to evaluate the effects of metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its components on cognitive performance and physical activity levels in middle-aged individuals. The study will include two groups: a MetS group consisting of participants diagnosed with MetS, and a control group of healthy individuals without any MetS components. The primary outcome measures include evaluations of MetS components (waist circumference, blood pressure, triglycerides, HDL-C, fasting plasma levels), Metabolic Syndrome Severity Score, Montreal Cognitive Assessment, and Stroop Test. Secondary outcome measures include Mini Mental State Examination, Visual Reaction Test, International Physical Activity Questionnaire Short-Form, and pedometer step counts. The study aims to assess the impact of MetS on cognitive and physical performance in the middle-aged population.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two brief digital interventions, an attitudinal inoculation intervention and a cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)-informed intervention, in increasing COVID-19 vaccination uptake among individuals with anxiety or depression, compared to a conventional public health messaging intervention. The study will recruit undervaccinated participants with and without symptoms of anxiety or depression from the CHASING COVID Cohort, a large US community-based cohort. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three intervention arms and followed for 4 weeks and 6 months to assess the primary outcome of self-reported COVID-19 vaccine receipt, as well as secondary outcomes of vaccine hesitancy. The study is designed as a parallel assignment, open-label randomized trial.

The study examined the effects of binaural beat music on sleep quality, heart rate variability, and depression in older adults with poor sleep quality living in a long-term care institution. The study was a randomized controlled trial with two groups: the binaural beat music (BBM) group and the control group. Participants in the BBM group listened to 15 minutes of Taiwanese Hokkien oldies music with binaural beats embedded, while the control group listened to the same music without binaural beats. The interventions were conducted three times a week for two weeks. The primary outcome measures were the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and heart rate variability (HRV) parameters. The secondary outcome measure was the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS). The assessments were conducted at baseline and on day 14 of the intervention.

This study aims to evaluate the implementation of a Personalised Follow-up (PFU) pathway for patients with head and neck cancer. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Objectives: To understand the barriers and facilitators of implementing the PFU pathway with a high level of fidelity that is sustainable for patients and healthcare providers.

2. Interventions: The study will assess the implementation of the PFU pathway, which involves discharging patients from routine oncology follow-up 2 years after completing radical treatment.

3. Outcomes: The primary outcomes are the acceptability of the PFU pathway to patients and service providers, and the safety of the pathway in terms of timely detection of cancer recurrence. Secondary outcomes include patient and provider experience, and the sustainability of the PFU pathway.

4. Participants: The study will include patients referred to the PFU clinic who are at least 2 years post-treatment and disease-free, as well as healthcare providers involved in the care of head and neck cancer patients.

5. Study Design: This is a mixed-methods implementation science study, involving qualitative interviews and surveys with patients and providers.

This is a randomized, double-blind clinical trial that compares the effects of intrathecal bupivacaine-dexmedetomidine and intrathecal bupivacaine-neostigmine in elective cesarean sections. The study enrolled ASA physical status I and II female patients aged 18-40 years with a height of 150-170 cm and weight of 70-110 kg. Patients were randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) bupivacaine-dexmedetomidine, 2) bupivacaine-neostigmine, or 3) bupivacaine alone (control). The primary outcome measure was the time from the end of intrathecal injection to the achievement of a bilateral sensory block at T10, as assessed by a pin prick needle. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of adding dexmedetomidine or neostigmine to intrathecal bupivacaine for spinal anesthesia in cesarean sections.

This is a 2-year randomized clinical trial evaluating the effectiveness of an air-polishing device with erythritol powder versus a conventional ultrasonic scaler in preventing white spot lesions (WSLs) and gingivitis in patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment. 

The primary outcome measures are the appearance of WSLs and inflammatory lesions during the 2-year treatment period, as well as changes in clinical parameters like plaque, gingival inflammation, and pocket depth. Secondary outcomes include patient acceptance, tooth sensitivity, changes in subgingival bacterial counts and inflammatory markers, and total treatment time.

Sixty patients aged 12-16 years will be randomly assigned to either the air-polishing device group (used monthly) or the ultrasonic scaler group (used every 6 months). Clinical examinations, sample collections, and analyses will be performed every 6 months to assess the primary and secondary outcomes.

This is a pilot study that aims to obtain and analyze tissue samples from patients undergoing cardiac or thoracic surgery. The study will recruit up to 10 patients, including those with and without a history of atrial fibrillation (AF). For cardiac surgery patients, the left atrial appendage will be excised, while for thoracic surgery patients, the ostial pulmonary vein segment will be removed. The study will perform histological and molecular analyses on the collected tissue samples to better understand the drivers of AF and myocardial fibrosis. The primary outcome measures are the histological and molecular analyses, which will be conducted over a 1-year period.

The study aims to compare the effects of integrated and isolated resisted exercise on strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners. The study involves two groups: 

1. Experimental Group 1 (Integrated Resisted Training): This group will perform integrated resisted exercises such as opposite arm and leg lift, bridging, side lying lift, ball back extension, and push-ups. The intensity will be progressively increased over the 8-week training program.

2. Experimental Group 2 (Isolated Resisted Training): This group will perform isolated resistance exercises such as leg press, bench press, ab crunch, barbell curl, and back squat. The resistance used will also be progressively increased over the 8-week training program.

The primary outcome measures are endurance (sit-up test), power (vertical jump test), and strength (1RM maximum). These measures will be assessed at baseline and after the 8-week training program.

The study aims to help coaches and trainers identify the most effective training methods for improving strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners.

The study aims to compare the effects of play-based therapy and functional communication training in children with speech and language delays. The study will enroll children aged 2 to 6 years with comorbidities such as behavioral disorders, autism, and ADHD, but excludes those with other syndromes. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the play-based therapy group or the functional communication training group, and will receive the respective interventions for 3 months, 5 days a week, for 20-30 minutes per session. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in the Speech Questionnaire, an assessment of functional language ability, at the end of the 3-month intervention period.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Purpose: To assess the barriers and facilitators of integrating Horyzons, a digital intervention, in outpatient mental health clinics in North Carolina that provide care for individuals with schizophrenia spectrum and other unspecified psychotic disorders.

2. Participants: 
   - 20 clinicians and/or peer specialists from first episode psychosis (FEP) clinics will be recruited to provide feedback on implementing Horyzons.
   - 50 individuals with FEP will be recruited to use the Horyzons platform for 12 months as part of their clinical care.

3. Procedures:
   - Clinicians/peer specialists will complete surveys and interviews to assess their perspectives on barriers and facilitators to implementing Horyzons.
   - Client participants will be onboarded to the Horyzons platform and their engagement and use of the platform will be monitored.
   - Client participants will complete assessments at baseline, 6 months, 12 months, and 3-month follow-up.

4. Outcomes:
   - Primary outcomes are qualitative and

This study aims to investigate the expression levels of inflammatory and anti-inflammatory genes in liver transplant patients before and after the operation. The researchers will measure the expression of genes related to inflammation (Interleukin-2, Interleukin-6, Interferon-γ, Tumor Necrosis Factor-α) and anti-inflammation (Interleukin-4, Interleukin-10) as well as genes involved in immune response (Triggering Receptor Expressed on Myeloid Cells-1, Human Leukocyte Antigen-G5, Forkhead box-P3, CD14) in peripheral blood samples of liver transplant patients and healthy controls. The study will also measure classical liver function markers (AST, ALT, Platelet Count, Alpha Fetoprotein, Bilirubin, C-Reactive Protein) at different time points (before, 1 month, and 6 months after surgery). The goal is to identify potential biomarkers that can predict rejection and infection after liver transplantation.

This is a clinical trial to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of different doses of BI 771716 administered intravitreally in patients with geographic atrophy secondary to age-related macular degeneration. The study has a single rising dose (SRD) part and a multiple dose (MD) part. The primary outcome measures are the occurrence of ocular dose limiting events in the SRD part and drug-related adverse events in the MD part. Secondary outcome measures include ocular adverse events, pharmacokinetic parameters such as maximum serum concentration, area under the concentration-time curve, and trough concentrations of BI 771716. The study is an open-label, non-randomized trial enrolling men and women aged 50 years or older with geographic atrophy secondary to AMD.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of furosemide-induced diuresis with matched dehydration using the RenalGuard device versus standard diuretic therapy in patients with acute heart failure and fluid overload. The primary outcome is the assessment of acute kidney injury based on daily serum creatinine measurements during the 72-hour study treatment period. The secondary outcome is the daily weight decrease during the study treatment. The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial, with one group receiving standard furosemide infusion and the other group receiving furosemide infusion with matched dehydration using the RenalGuard device.

This is a pilot study to determine the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a self-guided mindfulness-based intervention in pediatric patients with idiopathic chest pain. The study will randomize participants to either a standard of care control group or a mindfulness-based intervention group. The mindfulness-based intervention involves using the Headspace mobile app for 30 days, with participants completing the Basics, Basics 2, and Basics 3 courses. The primary outcome measures are feasibility (recruitment rate, retention rate, program adherence, survey response rate) and acceptability (program evaluation). Secondary outcome measures include pain coping strategies, perceived stress, quality of life, and frequency and intensity of chest pain episodes. The study will enroll patients aged 12-18 years with idiopathic or musculoskeletal chest pain and no acute illness or structural heart disease.

This is a four-arm, double-blind, non-inferiority clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and immunogenicity of concomitant administration of the Novavax (NVX) COVID-19 vaccine and a 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV20) in adults aged 60 years and older. The study will randomize participants to receive either NVX plus placebo, PCV20 plus placebo, the combination of NVX and PCV20, or placebo. The primary outcome measure is the antibody levels at Day 28 after vaccination.

This is a phase I-II clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of combining the anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint inhibitor durvalumab with the TLR-3 agonist rintatolimod in patients with metastatic pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC).

The primary objectives are:
1) In the phase Ib safety run-in, to determine the recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of the combination therapy.
2) In the phase II trial, to determine the clinical benefit rate of the combination therapy.

The secondary objectives are to explore the effects of the combination on overall survival, progression-free survival, circulating and tumor-infiltrating immune profiles, and quality of life.

Eligible patients are adults with metastatic PDAC who have stable disease after prior FOLFIRINOX chemotherapy. Patients will receive rintatolimod twice weekly for 6 weeks, followed by durvalumab every 4 weeks for up to 48 weeks.

The study aims to determine if the combination of an immune checkpoint inhibitor and a TLR-3 agonist can

This is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the potential effects of the flavonoid diosmin on delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) in female athletes from a women's five-a-side soccer team in Brazil. The study will have two experimental groups: one receiving diosmin supplementation (750 mg) and the other receiving a placebo (corn starch tablets). The participants will undergo an intense dynamic exercise protocol, and various outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, 24 hours, and 48 hours after the exercise, including muscle soreness, muscle tissue damage, oxidative stress, and recovery of muscle function and balance. The primary outcome is the evaluation of muscle soreness, while secondary outcomes include creatine phosphokinase levels, lipid peroxidation, antioxidant status, quadriceps strength, vertical jump height, and postural balance.

This is a prospective observational study that aims to investigate the short-term (3 months), medium-term (1 year), and long-term (2 years) effects of intrathecal baclofen (ITB) therapy on personal treatment goals in children with cerebral palsy (CP). The study will be conducted at two academic medical centers in the Netherlands, utilizing the Netherlands CP register for data collection.

The primary outcome measure is the change in goal attainment scaling (GAS), which quantifies the achievement of individual treatment goals. Secondary outcome measures include range of motion, spasticity, dystonia, scoliosis, selective motor control, functional strength, gait analysis, and various questionnaires assessing activities, participation, and quality of life.

The study will include all children and adolescents diagnosed with CP who start ITB treatment in the Netherlands under the age of 16. Exclusion criteria are the lack of consent from the patient and/or caregiver.

The study design involves a linear mixed-model analysis to determine the development of the outcome measures over time, with adjustments for potential covariates. Univariable and multivariable regression analyses will be

The study aims to investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on the risk of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) in pregnant women with low vitamin D levels (<30 ng/mL) and high risk of GDM. Pregnant women between 7-11 weeks of gestation with low vitamin D levels and high risk of GDM will be recruited and randomly assigned to receive either vitamin D3 supplementation (200,000 IU/week) for 4-6 weeks or placebo. The primary outcome is the incidence of GDM based on the 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) at 28 weeks of gestation. The study will contribute to understanding the relationship between vitamin D and GDM risk through a well-designed randomized controlled trial.

This is a prospective, multicenter, single-arm, open-label study to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Neuroguard IEP Direct System for the treatment of carotid artery stenosis in subjects at elevated risk for adverse events following carotid endarterectomy. The primary endpoint is a composite 30-day rate of major adverse events, defined as the cumulative incidence of all stroke, myocardial infarction, and death within 30 days of the index procedure. Eligible patients are those aged 20-80 years with symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% or asymptomatic carotid stenosis ≥70%, who are considered high-risk for carotid endarterectomy. The study will use the Neuroguard IEP Direct System, a 3-in-1 carotid stent delivery system consisting of an angioplasty balloon, an integrated embolic protection device, and a self-expanding nitinol stent.

This is a pilot study that aims to test the feasibility and safety of a Nordic Walking (NW) program for community-dwelling older adults at risk of falling or experiencing fear of falling (FOF). The study will be a two-arm, parallel, single-blind, randomized controlled trial. Forty participants will be randomly assigned to either a 10-week NW intervention group or a control group receiving regular phone calls. The intervention group will receive supervised NW training sessions and be encouraged to practice independently. The study will collect feasibility and safety data, including recruitment, adherence, and adverse events. Effectiveness outcomes will be assessed using measures such as the Timed Up and Go test, Falls Efficacy Scale-International, and Four-Square Step Test. The main focus of the analysis will be to estimate the effect size, test the intervention's feasibility and safety, and inform future studies. In a second stage, qualitative interviews will be conducted with the intervention group to gather feedback on the acceptability, perceived value, barriers, and facilitators of the program.

This study aims to develop and evaluate online interventions to increase help-seeking for anxiety and/or depression among sexual and gender minority youth (SGMY). The study will use a factorial design to test the feasibility, usability, acceptability, and impact on help-seeking intention of four different intervention principles:

1. Intersectionality and Identity
2. Confidentiality and Privacy 
3. Educating Your Community
4. How to Find Affirming Caregivers

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of 16 combinations of these four intervention principles. The study will measure outcomes such as intervention use, usability, acceptability, help-seeking intention, and various secondary outcomes related to mental health, stigma, and social support.

The goal is to develop an engaging, evidence-based online intervention that can help address the unique barriers SGMY face in accessing mental health treatment, ultimately improving their mental health outcomes.

The study aims to evaluate the application of a propofol and remifentanil mixed solution for controlled sedation and analgesia in fiber colonoscopy. It is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-blind study comparing two methods: 

1. Controlled analgesia/sedation (PCAS) group: Patients receive a loading dose of 3 ml of the propofol-remifentanil mixture, followed by continuous infusion at 0.1 ml/kg/h. Patients can self-administer additional 1 ml doses as needed during the procedure.

2. Intravenous combined anesthesia group: Patients receive intravenous fentanyl, midazolam, and propofol to induce anesthesia. Propofol is then titrated to maintain the auditory evoked potential index (AAI) between 30-40 during the procedure.

The primary outcome measure is the auditory evoked potential index (AEPI) at various time points before, during, and after the procedure. The secondary outcome is the time from the end of the procedure to reaching an OAA/S

This is a prospective, observational, confirmatory, single-center study that aims to predict the chronicization of radiation-induced acute intestinal injury (RAII) based on the expression level of immune factors in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer who undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NCRT) and total mesorectal excision (TME). The primary outcome is the area under the curve (AUC) of the prediction model in predicting the chronicization of RAII. The secondary outcomes are the accuracy, precision, specificity, and sensitivity of the prediction model. The study plans to enroll 200 eligible patients aged 18-75 years who develop RAII during NCRT or within 1 month. The expression levels of immune factors will be detected in pathological tissue after TME and applied to the prediction model.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase I clinical trial to evaluate the safety and tolerability of an Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and above. 

The primary objective is to assess the safety, as measured by the incidence of adverse events (AEs), serious adverse events (SAEs), and adverse events of special interest (AESIs) within 12 months after vaccination. 

The secondary objective is to evaluate the immunogenicity, as measured by the geometric mean titer (GMT) of SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibodies 14 days after vaccination.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18 and above who are at least 6 months past their last COVID-19 infection or vaccination. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta vaccine or a placebo.

The study is a clinical trial evaluating the safety and performance of the ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA Left Atrial Appendage (LAA) Closure Device in patients with atrial fibrillation. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of device and procedure-related serious adverse events at 7 days, 45 days, and 6 months post-procedure. The secondary outcome measure is the rate of successful LAA closure at 45 days. The study has a single-arm, open-label design, and participants must meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria, including a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or greater and non-valvular atrial fibrillation. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing (MI) in improving therapeutic alliance and treatment adherence for patients with acute psychosis. Patients will be randomly assigned to either receive four sessions of MI or four sessions of supportive conversations (control group) within two weeks. The primary outcome measures are changes in therapeutic alliance and treatment adherence, assessed using validated scales. Secondary outcomes include changes in symptom severity, motivation for psychotherapy, and self-efficacy. The study targets adult patients (18-65 years) with a diagnosis of psychosis or schizophrenia, who are hospitalized in an acute psychiatric ward. The findings could inform future treatment recommendations for the acute phase of psychotic disorders.

This study aims to evaluate the use of chromosomal instability (CIN) analysis in bile samples, using a method called BileCAD, for the early diagnosis of biliary tract carcinoma. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Objective: To compare the sensitivity and specificity of the BileCAD test for diagnosing biliary tract carcinoma compared to other diagnostic modalities.

2. Participants: The study will include biliary tract carcinoma patients as the experimental group and non-cancer patients as the control group.

3. Intervention: The extracted DNA from bile samples will be analyzed using the BileCAD method to determine the level of CIN.

4. Outcomes:
   - Primary outcomes: Sensitivity and specificity of the BileCAD test for diagnosing biliary tract carcinoma.
   - Secondary outcomes: Consistency of BileCAD microbial analysis results with clinical microbial culture results, and the sensitivity of BileCAD for different types and locations of biliary tract carcinoma.

5. Duration: The study is planned to be conducted over 12 months.

This study aims to evaluate the success of lumbar plexus block in lower extremity orthopedic surgeries using Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS) to measure tissue oxygenation. The study will include patients aged 18-90 years old undergoing femoral neck fracture, femoral shaft fracture, or hip replacement surgery. Patients with BMI>40 kg/m2, infection in the block area, peripheral neuropathy, hemoglobinopathy, peripheral vascular disease, or allergy to local anesthetics will be excluded. The study uses a single group assignment design, where participants will have NIRS probes attached to the operated and contralateral lower extremities. The primary outcome is the regional oxygen saturation (rSO2) measured by NIRS, and secondary outcomes include sensory block level, blood pressure, and fingertip oxygen saturation. The measurements will be taken for 40 minutes after the lumbar plexus block.

The study aims to evaluate the use of a digital platform (mindLAMP mobile application) to support the clinical effectiveness and integration of a task-shared delivery of the evidence-based COPSI (Community care for People with Schizophrenia in India) program in primary care settings in India. The study will compare the outcomes of participants receiving COPSI plus the mindLAMP app versus COPSI alone. The primary outcome measure is the Indian Disability Evaluation and Assessment Scale (IDEAS) which assesses the level of disability in psychiatric patients. Secondary outcomes include measures of positive and negative symptoms, anxiety, depression, overall severity of schizophrenia, and cognitive function. The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-assignment trial enrolling adults (≥18 years) with a primary diagnosis of schizophrenia and at least one risk factor for early mortality. The study aims to address the significant care gap and high mortality rates observed among individuals with schizophrenia in India.

This study aims to investigate the characteristics of the cytokine response in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) treated with occlusal splint therapy. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Participants: Patients diagnosed with myalgia, arthralgia, headache attributed to TMD, and painful disc displacement (with or without reduction) according to the Diagnostic Criteria for Temporomandibular Disorders (DC/TMD) will be included.

2. Intervention: Participants will be treated with a stabilization occlusal splint made of hard acrylic resin.

3. Outcomes:
   - Primary outcomes: Changes in the levels of inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-13, IL-6, IL-7, IL-8, TNF-α) in circulating blood and gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) after occlusal splint therapy.
   - Secondary outcomes: Changes in pain-free opening, maximum unassisted and assisted opening, pain intensity and pain-related disability, oral health-related quality of life, perceived stress levels, jaw function limitation, depressed mood, anx

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effects of different levels of digital training on Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT) knowledge, fidelity, and treatment entry and retention for addiction professionals. The study will randomize participants to one of three intervention arms: 1) digital tutorial overview (T), 2) digital tutorial plus training materials (TM), or 3) digital tutorial, training materials, and feedback/coaching (TMC). The primary outcome is CRAFT procedure fidelity, measured through coded audio recordings of sessions with standardized patients. Secondary outcomes include CRAFT knowledge, program implementation potential, and new treatment entry for clients' loved ones. The study will be conducted over 3 months.

This is a prospective, multi-center observational study that aims to compare the regional left ventricular 99mTc-DPD uptake between patients with hereditary (ATTRm) and wild-type (ATTRwt) cardiac transthyretin amyloidosis. The study will also assess the prevalence of right ventricular 99mTc-DPD accumulation in these patient groups, and evaluate the presence and extent of 99mTc-DPD cardiac uptake among asymptomatic ATTRm variant carriers. Participants will undergo 99mTc-DPD scintigraphy, blood sampling for TTR gene sequencing, and transthoracic echocardiography. The primary outcome is to compare the regional left ventricular 99mTc-DPD uptake, while secondary outcomes include assessing right ventricular 99mTc-DPD accumulation and evaluating 99mTc-DPD cardiac uptake in asymptomatic ATTRm variant carriers.

The key aspects of the provided clinical trial document are:

1. The study aims to investigate the post-COVID-19 syndrome (Long COVID) in children aged 6 to 18 years in the Samara region of Russia.

2. The study will conduct laboratory tests, questionnaires, and physical examinations to research the long-term and chronic symptoms of COVID-19 in children, including those who had asymptomatic or mild infections.

3. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with post-COVID syndrome over a 1-year period.

4. The study has an open-label, single-group assignment design, with all participants receiving the intervention of research on long-COVID-19 in children.

5. The study is designed to help identify patients at risk of chronic COVID-19 infection, prevent the development of such conditions, and enable early rehabilitation of children who have suffered from COVID-19.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of treadmill-based perturbation training in preventing falls after total knee replacement surgery.

2. The study will recruit 378 participants scheduled for primary unilateral total knee arthroplasty. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the perturbation training group or the education control group.

3. The perturbation training group will receive 4 sessions of treadmill-based training over 2 weeks, where they will experience simulated trips and lateral perturbations to improve their balance recovery. The control group will only receive fall prevention education materials.

4. The primary outcome measures are post-training trunk angle and angular velocity during balance recovery, as well as the fall rate during the first year after surgery. The secondary outcome is the fall status during the post-training test.

5. The study is an open-label, randomized, parallel-group trial with the primary purpose of prevention.

This is a single-arm, open-label, multicenter phase II clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of cadonilimab in combination with nab-paclitaxel in patients with persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer who have previously received immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

The primary objective is to assess the objective response rate (ORR) of the cadonilimab and nab-paclitaxel combination. Secondary objectives include evaluating the duration of response (DoR), disease control rate (DCR), time to response (TTR), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), safety, and tolerability of the combination therapy. An exploratory objective is to identify potential biomarkers that may predict the efficacy of the treatment.

Eligible patients must be female, aged 18-75 years, have an ECOG performance status of 0 or 1, and have persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer that has progressed after prior treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors. Patients will receive cadonilimab 10 mg/kg and nab-paclitaxel up to

This is a single-center, prospective, randomized, unblinded, controlled study to compare the visual performance of the trifocal Hanita Lenses Intensity SL IOL (study lens) versus the trifocal Alcon PanOptix IOL (comparison lens) in bilaterally implanted patients. The primary endpoint is to investigate whether the binocular distance-corrected visual acuity achieved with the study lens for distance, intermediate, and near ranges is not statistically significantly inferior to the parameters achieved with the control lens. Secondary endpoints include defocus curve, contrast sensitivity, and patient satisfaction. A total of approximately 58 patients with age-related cataracts will be included at 1 clinical center in Germany. Patients will undergo a maximum of 10 study visits over 3-7 months.

The study aims to retrospectively analyze the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia (1.3 mls of 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine) for hip fracture surgery. The primary outcome is the cohort mean (SD) of non-invasive mean arterial pressure (MAP) measured at 2-minute intervals during the surgery. The secondary outcomes include the cohort prevalence of hypotension (using various definitions), the mean depth and duration of hypotension, the effects of sedation and nerve block on blood pressure, the duration of spinal anaesthesia, and the correlations between hypotension and clinical outcomes (30-day mortality, length of hospital stay). The study population includes adults over 18 years who underwent hip fracture surgery with the specified low-dose spinal anaesthesia technique at a single center between 2017-2020, and for whom electronic vital sign data is available.

This study aims to investigate the impact of malaria and intestinal parasitic diseases on the risk of symptomatic COVID-19, the acquisition and longevity of antibody responses induced by natural infection and SARS-CoV-2 vaccines in Malawi. The study will enroll up to 200 symptomatic COVID-19 index cases, their household contacts (anticipated 700), and up to 600 vaccinees. The key objectives are to:

1. Assess the risk of asymptomatic infection among household contacts of index cases.
2. Evaluate the duration of neutralizing antibody responses against different SARS-CoV-2 variants.
3. Examine changes in innate immune parameters, such as monocyte activation and inflammatory markers, in response to natural infection and vaccination.
4. Measure antibody magnitude, neutralization, Fc-gamma receptor binding, and antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity in the natural infection and vaccine cohorts.
5. Determine the frequencies of SARS-CoV-2-specific B cells and plasma cells, and their relationship with innate immunity parameters.

The study aims to investigate the effect of hot-cold application to the bladder on postoperative urinary retention in patients undergoing orthopedic surgery. It is designed as a single-blind randomized controlled trial, with an experimental group receiving hot-cold application to the bladder and a control group receiving routine clinical care. The primary outcome measure is the prevention of postoperative urinary retention, assessed through physiological parameters and questionnaires during the first 6 hours of the postoperative period. The study includes patients aged 18 years and above, without a urinary catheter during the perioperative process, who are conscious and oriented, and do not have any renal diseases. The study aims to contribute to the effective management of postoperative urinary retention in orthopedic surgery patients, minimize the use of invasive interventions, and increase nurses' awareness of PUR management.

This is a prospective, multicenter study that aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of a deep-learning integrated model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features from high-concentration contrast-enhanced pancreatic CT scans in predicting the one-year recurrence risk of acute pancreatitis.

The study will enroll 694 patients with a first episode of acute pancreatitis who undergo an enhanced pancreatic CT scan within 14 days of symptom onset. Patients will be followed for 12 months and divided into recurrent and non-recurrent groups based on the first recurrence status.

The primary outcome is the sensitivity and specificity of the model in predicting the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis within 12 months. Secondary outcomes include the sensitivity and specificity of the model in predicting recurrence at 3 and 6 months, the image quality of the CT scans, and the performance of the model in predicting recurrence of different types and severities of acute pancreatitis.

The study will use statistical analyses such as descriptive statistics, chi-square testing, and logistic regression to evaluate the predictive performance of the model.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment on polycythemia in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in hematocrit levels after 12 months of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in hemoglobin, health-related quality of life, sleepiness, and the relationship between hypoxic burden and hematocrit/hemoglobin levels. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-80 years with a diagnosis of polycythemia and moderate to severe OSA. Participants will be randomized to either the CPAP treatment group, which will receive CPAP therapy plus conventional pharmacological and lifestyle interventions, or the control group, which will receive only conventional pharmacological and lifestyle interventions.

The study aims to assess the vaginal axis in patients undergoing different apical prolapse surgeries, including laparoscopic lateral suspension, laparoscopic pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation, compared to sacrocolpopexy. The primary outcome measures are the vaginal axis and vaginal distances measured on MRI at 4 months post-operation. Secondary outcome measures include prolapse symptoms, urinary symptoms, sexual function, quality of life, and patient-reported improvement. The study is a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment, and it includes female participants aged 18-80 years with genital prolapse. Control groups consist of hysterectomized women without cuff prolapse and nulliparous women.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of simulation-based teaching on midwifery students' knowledge, satisfaction, and self-efficacy in electronic fetal monitoring management. The study is a randomized controlled trial with an experimental group receiving simulation-based training and a control group receiving traditional theory-based training. The primary outcome measures include an information evaluation form, student satisfaction and self-confidence scale, and self-efficacy scale in electronic fetal monitoring. Secondary outcome measures include a simulation design scale. The study involves midwifery students aged 18-45 years and will assess the outcomes immediately before and after the simulation training, as well as 5 weeks after the first simulation application.

This is a retrospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the clinical outcomes and predictors of mortality in critically ill patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation. The study will be conducted at Dessie Comprehensive Specialized Hospital from August 2023 to January 2024. The primary outcome measure is the clinical outcome (survival or death) of critically ill patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation, defined as successful extubation after more than three spontaneous breathing trials or taking more than 14 days. The study will use descriptive statistics, bivariate and multivariate analyses to identify the predictors of mortality in this patient population. The findings of this study will guide efforts to improve the care and outcomes of patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to compare the pharmacodynamic effects of two bleeding reduction strategies in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI): 
   a) Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) de-escalation - switching from a potent P2Y12 inhibitor (prasugrel or ticagrelor) to clopidogrel while maintaining aspirin.
   b) Potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy - maintaining prasugrel or ticagrelor and discontinuing aspirin.

2. The primary outcome measure is the comparison of the area under the curve (AUC) determined by the Total Thrombus formation Analysis System (T-TAS) between the two strategies at 30 days.

3. The study population includes patients who have been on DAPT (aspirin plus prasugrel or ticagrelor) for at least 30 days (for chronic coronary syndrome) or at least 90 days (for acute coronary syndrome) after PCI.

4. Key exclusion criteria include prior history of stent thrombosis, use

This is a randomized, open-label, crossover study investigating the age-dependent effects of egg intake on HDL and immune profiles. The study will enroll healthy adults aged 18-30 years and 60-70 years. Participants will be randomized to consume either whole eggs, egg yolks, or egg whites for 4 weeks, with a washout period between interventions. The primary outcome is the change in serum concentration of large HDL particles between the egg-free run-in period and the end of each intervention arm.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a patient-driven augmented reality-based rehabilitation system (MyoTrain AR) in improving upper limb amputee outcomes. The study will enroll trans-radial unilateral limb loss patients who are candidates for a 2+ degree-of-freedom myoelectric pattern recognition prosthesis. 

Participants in the experimental group will undergo functional task training using the MyoTrain AR system, which includes an augmented reality head-mounted display, kinematic trackers, surface EMG electrodes, and a desktop computer. The control group will receive motor imagery exercises without real-time control feedback or functional assessment.

The primary outcome measures are the GaMA Cup Transfer Task mean completion time and mean relative grasp duration. Secondary outcome measures include the Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls (ACMC), GaMA Cup Transfer Task completion rate, and wrist activation. All outcomes will be assessed at Day 35.

This is a prospective, double-blinded, randomized controlled trial investigating the use of a gastric electric pacemaker as a treatment for postoperative ileus following extensive surgery. The study will enroll patients undergoing elective cytoreductive surgery with or without heated intraperitoneal chemotherapy for colorectal, appendiceal, or peritoneal metastatic cancer. 

Patients will be randomized to either the treatment group, where a temporary gastric pacemaker is mounted and turned on, or the control group, where a pacemaker is mounted but turned off. The primary outcome is the time from surgery to first stool. Secondary outcomes include whole gut and regional transit times, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, need for interventions, 30-day re-hospitalization, time to initiation of adjuvant chemotherapy, and 90-day mortality.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the effects of aromatherapy and music therapy on pain, anxiety, and vital parameters in palliative care patients with cancer. The participants are divided into four groups: music therapy, aromatherapy, combined aromatherapy and music therapy, and a control group. 

The music therapy group listens to specially composed relaxing music with headphones for 20 minutes per day for three consecutive days. The aromatherapy group uses a diffuser with 5% lavender oil for 15-20 minutes. The combined group receives both music therapy and aromatherapy. 

The primary outcome measures are the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, the Facial Anxiety Scale (FAS) for anxiety, the Distress Thermometer, the Edmonton Symptom Diagnostic Scale (ESAS), and vital parameters (blood pressure, pulse, respiratory rate). These measures are assessed before and after the interventions over three consecutive days.

The study aims to test the effectiveness of the Somatosensation Device (SD) in enhancing feedback for individuals with lower extremity amputation or neuropathy. The study is a non-randomized crossover trial, where participants will perform outcome measures both with and without wearing the SD. The primary outcome measure is the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA), which evaluates postural stability and mobility during various walking tasks. Secondary outcome measures include the 10-Meter Walk Test, Mini-BESTest, Activities-specific Balance Confidence Scale, and Vestibular Disorders Activities of Daily Living Scale. The study includes participants aged 18-65 years with below-knee amputation or lower limb neuropathy, and excludes those with severe back/knee pain or poor skin integrity. The study aims to assess the impact of the SD on gait, balance, and functional abilities in this population.

This is a decentralized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the OtoBand device in providing temporary relief for the symptoms of vertigo in a real-world setting. The study will enroll up to 108 participants with vestibular vertigo caused by conditions like BPPV, Meniere's disease, or vestibular migraine. Participants will be randomized to either use the OtoBand experimental device or a sham device during vertigo episodes. The study has two arms: the Moderate or Worse (MoW) arm and the Quality of Life (QoL) arm. The primary outcome measures are the change in vertigo severity for the MoW arm and the change in Vertigo Symptom Scale scores for the QoL arm. The secondary outcome measure is the percent change in mean vertigo episode severity during the treatment phase compared to baseline. The study is expected to last up to 49 days for each participant, with virtual visits at various timepoints. Otolith Labs has received Therapeutic Breakthrough Device designation from the FDA for the OtoBand.

This was a randomized, placebo-controlled, quadruple-masked clinical trial that evaluated the effect of the multistrain probiotic OMNi-BiOTiC® Active on upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs) in older adults aged 65 years and above. 

The primary outcome was the incidence of acute URTIs, which was compared between the probiotic and placebo groups over a 12-week supplementation period. 

The secondary outcomes included the duration of URTIs, changes in serum concentrations of leukocytes, neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, basophils, and immunoglobulin A (IgA) from baseline to 12 weeks.

The study enrolled healthy older adults and excluded those with exacerbations of chronic diseases, metabolic diseases, mental incapacity, long-term antibiotic use, recent probiotic consumption, or markedly abnormal blood test results.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques in treating patients with adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder). The study will randomly assign participants to two groups: Group A will receive Gong's mobilization, and Group B will receive Kaltenborn's mobilization. Both groups will also receive routine physical therapy, including electrical stimulation and heat therapy. The primary outcome measures are the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI), Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS), and range of motion measured using a universal goniometer. The study will assess these outcomes at baseline, 1.5 weeks, and 3 weeks. The study aims to provide evidence-based insights into the relative effectiveness of the two mobilization techniques for clinicians treating patients with adhesive capsulitis.

This is a randomized, open-label, phase 3 clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin in combination with pembrolizumab versus standard-of-care chemotherapy (gemcitabine plus cisplatin or carboplatin) in previously untreated patients with locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma that expresses HER2 (IHC 1+ or greater). 

The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival (PFS) per RECIST v1.1 by blinded independent central review (BICR) and overall survival (OS). Secondary outcome measures include objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (DOR), disease control rate (DCR), PFS by investigator assessment, safety, and quality of life assessments.

Eligible patients must have histopathologically confirmed locally advanced unresectable or metastatic urothelial carcinoma, measurable disease, no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic disease, and HER2 expression of 1+ or greater on immunohistochemistry.
