Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of lactoferrin compared to placebo in improving clinical outcomes in ICU patients. 

The primary outcome measures are the 28-day all-cause mortality rate and the incidence of any allergic or hypersensitivity reactions. The secondary outcome measures include day of death, need for invasive mechanical ventilation, duration of oxygen support and ICU stay, and various laboratory parameters.

A total of 650 ICU patients (325 in each group) will be randomized to receive either lactoferrin 400 mg per day orally or placebo, in addition to standard of care. The study will use an intention-to-treat analysis strategy.

The trial aims to determine if lactoferrin can improve clinical outcomes in critically ill ICU patients compared to placebo, and also assess its safety profile.

This is a 10-week randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study evaluating the efficacy of a chitin-glucan based formulation (BK003) versus placebo in patients with Crohn's disease in remission and having irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)-like symptoms. The primary outcome is the subject's global assessment of relief responder rate at week 4 of each treatment period. Secondary outcomes include changes in individual IBS-like symptoms, stool consistency and number, IBS-related quality of life, anxiety and depression, and biomarkers. The study will enroll male and female patients aged 18-75 years with long-standing steroid-free remission of Crohn's disease and presence of IBS-like symptoms. Patients will undergo a 2-3 week run-in period followed by two 4-week treatment periods separated by a 2-3 week washout, with participants crossing over between BK003 and placebo.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to develop a novel biomarker, virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA), for evaluating response and prognosis in hepatitis B virus (HBV)-related hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients undergoing radiotherapy (RT).

2. The study will retrospectively analyze the consistency of HBV-human junction clones and quantify the serial changes in vh-DNA copy numbers in pre- and post-RT serum samples from HBV-related HCC patients.

3. The study will prospectively test the concordance of vh-DNA copies between serum and plasma samples, and analyze the association of serial changes in plasma vh-DNA copies with treatment response and overall survival.

4. The study will also explore the clonality of recurrent HCC tumors to differentiate between recurrence from the original tumor or a de novo tumor.

5. The primary outcome measures include analyzing the HBV-human junction clones, quantifying vh-DNA levels, and correlating them with treatment response and survival in HBV-related HCC patients undergoing RT.

The study aimed to develop and evaluate the effectiveness of an online individual intervention program, called the Meaning-Centered Coping Program (MCCP), for women diagnosed with breast cancer. The MCCP was designed to enhance meaning in life, post-traumatic growth, situational meaning, automatic meaning-making efforts, psychological flexibility, and psychological distress.

The study used a randomized controlled trial design, with participants assigned to either the MCCP intervention group or a waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures included changes in meaning in life, post-traumatic growth, stress appraisal, global meaning violations, and automatic meaning-making efforts. Secondary outcome measures assessed changes in psychological flexibility and psychological distress.

The study enrolled 44 women diagnosed with stage I-III breast cancer, aged 18-65 years, who were randomly assigned to the MCCP intervention or waitlist control group. The MCCP intervention consisted of 8 weekly individual online sessions, each lasting approximately 60 minutes.

The study aimed to test the following hypotheses: 1) the MCCP group would show greater improvements in meaning in life and post-traumatic growth compared to the control group; 2

The study aims to investigate the nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level in people who have undergone a major dysvascular lower limb amputation (LLA), and their association with clinical outcomes. The study will assess participants at multiple time points (during hospital admission 2-10 days post-LLA, 5 weeks, 6 months, and 9 months post-LLA) by measuring nutritional intake, diet quality, nutritional status, muscle mass, muscle strength, body mass index, and physical activity level. Secondary outcomes include mortality, wound healing, quality of life, functional level, and physical functioning. The study does not involve any intervention, as it is an observational study.

This is a single-center, prospective, open-label, decentralized, crossover pilot study that aims to determine the feasibility and advantages of remote clinical trial conduct with multiple medications in patients with type 2 diabetes and elevated albuminuria. 

The primary objective is to assess the feasibility and advantages of remote clinical trial conduct, including participants' perspectives, remote data collection, and treatment adherence. 

The secondary objectives are to determine the individual responses to the SGLT2 inhibitor empagliflozin and assess if suboptimal responses can be overcome by adding or switching to the MRA finerenone.

Eligible participants will receive a 3-week treatment with empagliflozin 10 mg/day. Based on the albuminuria response, they will either continue empagliflozin, add finerenone, or switch to finerenone. 

The study will evaluate outcomes such as questionnaire results on feasibility, remote data collection, and treatment adherence. Secondary outcomes include changes in UACR, blood pressure, body weight, eGFR, and fasting plasma glucose with empagliflozin and the additive

This study aims to investigate the effects of a 12-week high-intensity interval training (HIIT) program on the physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance of college male ice hockey players in China. The study uses a randomized controlled trial design with an experimental group receiving HIIT and a control group receiving traditional on-ice training. 

The primary outcome measures include:
1. Maximal oxygen uptake (VO2 max)
2. Endurance performance (Yo-Yo Intermittent Recovery Test)
3. Power performance (countermovement and squat jump)
4. Agility and skill performance (Illinois Agility Test, 20/30m skating, 20m skating with puck)
5. Passing and shooting performance (number of passes, successful shots)
6. Tactical performance (shots, goals, passing success rate, coordination fluency)

These measures are assessed at baseline and at the 6-week midpoint. The study aims to provide evidence on the effectiveness of HIIT in improving the physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance of college ice hockey players compared to traditional training methods.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a double-blind, randomized, crossover trial investigating the effect of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash on the oral microbiome, salivary pellicle proteins, and vascular function in individuals with dental erosion compared to healthy controls. 

The study will recruit 24 participants - 12 healthy controls and 12 with dental erosion. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either a CHX mouthwash or a placebo mouthwash for 7 days, followed by a 12-week washout period and then crossover to the opposite treatment for another 7 days.

The primary outcome measures are:
1. Identification of salivary proteins via SDS-PAGE and proteomics analysis
2. Microbiome diversity using 16S rRNA analysis

Secondary outcome measures include:
1. Blood pressure
2. Endothelial function tests (iontophoresis, flow-mediated dilation)
3. Nitrate/nitrite levels in saliva and plasma
4. Oxidative stress markers

This study is a prospective randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to explore if a Pain and Coordination Plan (PAC-plan) for patients after accidental injury can reduce opioid use and improve quality of life. The PAC-plan consists of three main elements: an opioid management plan upon discharge from the hospital, an appointment with the participant's regular general practitioner (GP) within 2-4 weeks after discharge, and increased collaboration between the GP and hospital specialists.

The primary outcome is oral morphine equivalent (OMEQ) consumption 6 weeks after discharge. Secondary outcomes include OMEQ at 52 weeks, registry-based OMEQ, pain, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), and other patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) at 6 and 52 weeks.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years and older who have undergone acute orthopedic surgery following accidental injury, were discharged on opioid medication, and can read, speak, and write Norwegian. Participants with severe cognitive impairment, unable to consent, or currently in cancer treatment are excluded.

This is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study that aims to compare the efficacy of a guided antiplatelet therapy approach versus a standard antiplatelet regimen in patients with unruptured intracranial aneurysms who undergo intracranial stenting. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of ischemic events, including ischemic stroke, transient ischemic attack, and stent thrombosis, within 30 days after stent implantation. Patients in the experimental group will receive a guided antiplatelet regimen based on light transmission aggregometry (LTA) testing, while the control group will continue the center's standard dual antiplatelet therapy. The study excludes patients with certain medical conditions, bleeding tendencies, and those using anticoagulants.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between bone mineral density (BMD), gross motor function, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy (CP). The study will include two groups: Group 1 (ambulant) with children classified as GMFCS levels I-III, and Group 2 (non-ambulant) with children classified as GMFCS levels IV-V. The primary outcome measures are:

1. Bone mineral density (BMD) assessed using dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scans.
2. Gross motor function assessed using the Gross Motor Function Measurement (GMFM) scale.
3. Quality of life assessed using the Quality of Life Questionnaire for Children with Cerebral Palsy (CP QOL-Child).

The study will be conducted in a single day, with all assessments performed on the same day for each participant.

This is a within-subjects, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study investigating the effects of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist sulpiride (400 mg) on working memory gating, cognitive effort, and decision-making in healthy volunteers aged 18-45 years. 

The primary outcome measures include:
- Reaction time and accuracy during a working memory gating task, as well as the associated BOLD response, to assess the ability to selectively input and output-gate working memory representations.
- Accuracy and reaction time during high and low reward rate conditions in a Simon task and a perceptual decision-making task, to assess cognitive effort investment.

Secondary outcome measures include various cognitive and personality assessments at baseline and during the intervention sessions.

The study uses a crossover design, where all participants receive both the sulpiride and placebo interventions, with a washout period of at least 14 days between the two sessions. The primary outcomes are measured approximately 115-250 minutes after the pharmacological intervention.

The study aims to determine the prevalence of obesity and hypertension in a cohort of Italian adolescents, investigate the genetic factors associated with hypertension, and explore the relationship between urinary markers of inflammation, oxidative stress, and cardiovascular risk in participants with specific genotypes. The study will enroll adolescents aged 13-19 years from high schools in northern, central, and southern Italy. Participants will undergo blood pressure measurements, anthropometric assessments, and provide urine and saliva samples for genetic analysis. The study will focus on 15 genetic variants in 13 candidate genes related to hypertension and cardiovascular disease. Urinary markers, including sodium, potassium, albumin, creatinine, inflammatory cytokines, and oxidative stress markers, will also be analyzed. The primary outcome is to establish a link between specific polymorphisms in adducin and endogenous ouabain-related genes with hypertension, sodium, and potassium intake.

The EPigenetic Consequences in Children of Intravenous vs Volatile Anaesthesia for Surgery (EPIVA) is a randomized, feasibility clinical trial that aims to explore whether general anesthesia can cause epigenetic changes in children and whether the type of anesthetic used (intravenous vs. inhalational) impacts these changes.

The trial will enroll children aged 6 months to 3 years undergoing hypospadias surgery. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either intravenous (TIVA) or inhalational anesthesia maintenance. Blood samples will be collected before and after the surgery to assess epigenetic changes.

The primary objectives are to evaluate the feasibility of conducting a pediatric perioperative epigenetics study, including assessing recruitment, retention, protocol compliance, and acceptability to participants and staff. The secondary objectives are to explore whether anesthesia and surgery are associated with epigenetic changes in whole blood, and whether the anesthesia strategy impacts any observed epigenetic changes.

This trial is designed as a feasibility study to determine if a larger-scale trial investigating the epigenetic consequences of pediatric anesthesia is

This study aims to investigate whether additional laboratory markers can improve the assessment of thyroid hormone status in hypothyroid patients receiving levothyroxine (L-T4) treatment, particularly in cases where thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) cannot reliably reflect thyroid hormone status, such as in central hypothyroidism.

The study will enroll four groups of hypothyroid patients receiving L-T4 treatment (100 patients each with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, hypothyroidism after thyroidectomy for thyroid carcinoma, central hypothyroidism, and hypothyroidism during Graves' disease treatment) and 100 healthy controls. Participants will undergo a single blood draw and complete a questionnaire.

The primary outcome measures are TSH, free T4 (fT4), free T3 (fT3), and the fT3/fT4 ratio. Secondary outcome measures include total T4 (TT4), total T3 (TT3), reverse T3 (rT3), sex-hormone binding globulin (SHBG), acylcarnitines, and amino acids.

The study

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to implement palliative non-operative management (PNOM) in all Dutch hospitals as part of shared decision-making for a select group of frail elderly patients with limited life expectancy who sustain a hip fracture.

2. The target population is frail (institutionalized) elderly aged 70 years or older who either live in a nursing home, receive similar level of care at home or in another institution, and have characteristics like malnutrition, mobility issues, or severe comorbidities.

3. The study design is a multi-center prospective cohort study with mixed methods, consisting of 4 phases. It involves interviews, development of educational modules, and implementation of the PNOM protocol in selected hospitals.

4. The primary outcome is the rate of non-operative treatment in the target population. Secondary aims include enriching the PNOM protocol, developing educational modules, creating awareness, and facilitating the scaling up of PNOM implementation.

5. The interventions are non-operative treatment and operative treatment, with the decision made through shared decision-making between the patient/family and medical specialists.

This study aims to generate proof-of-concept for using a physiological clinical target volume (CTV) for radiotherapy treatment planning in patients with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma, a type of brain tumor. The key aspects are:

1. Objective: To generate a physiological CTV that better captures microscale tumor invasion, compared to the standard CTV, by using advanced MRI techniques to assess tumor oxygenation and cell proliferation.

2. Study Design: 10 glioblastoma patients will undergo an extended MRI scan during their standard radiotherapy planning, which will include advanced MRI techniques. The physiological CTV generated from this scan will be compared to the standard CTV in terms of volume and location. Pattern-of-failure analysis will also be done to compare the two CTVs.

3. Outcomes: The primary outcome is the volume and location analysis of the physiological CTV versus the standard CTV. The secondary outcome is the pattern-of-failure analysis, hypothesizing that the physiological CTV will be smaller while having similar or better overlap with the tumor recurrence volume.

4. Significance: Generating a more accurate physiological CTV

This study aims to assess the acceptance and effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients who have undergone autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT) compared to non-AHSCT SSc patients. The primary outcome is the cumulative incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection after AHSCT versus non-AHSCT patients. Secondary outcomes include the proportion of patients who refused vaccination, the cumulative incidence of symptomatic COVID-19, time to first COVID-19 infection, severity of symptomatic COVID-19, proportion of patients with grade ≥3 adverse events after vaccination, and humoral response to mRNA vaccines. The study will follow participants for up to 18 months.

The CONNECT study is a multicentre stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of the Chez NICU Home (CNH+) intervention in improving parental self-efficacy and other psychosocial and infant health outcomes in the NICU setting, compared to standard care.

The primary outcome is the change in parental self-perceived self-efficacy, measured using the Perceived Maternal Parenting Self-Efficacy (PMPS-E) tool, at the infant's discharge from the NICU, 21 days after birth, and 6 months after discharge. 

Secondary outcomes include changes in parental stress, depression, quality of life, and perceptions of family-centered care and engagement. Infant outcomes such as weight and head growth, length of stay, feeding, and various medical complications will also be assessed.

The study will enroll parents of infants admitted to the NICU across 4 Canadian sites. Families in the intervention group will receive access to the CNH+ platform, which provides educational modules, virtual communication tools, and text message support targeting factors associated with improved self-efficacy. The control group

The study investigated the effects of physical activity on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age, and quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis. The participants were women aged 54-75 years who were at medium to high risk of osteoporosis, as determined by the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Women (OST). The experimental group participated in the Otago Exercise Program, which included strengthening and balance exercises, as well as moderate-intensity walking for 30 minutes, 2 days per week, for a total of 12 weeks. The control group received no intervention. The primary outcome measures were lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance, upper extremity flexibility, agility, and quality of life. The secondary outcome measure was dynamic balance. Measurements were taken before and after the 12-week intervention period.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a digital-based diet quality intervention for adolescents with overweight or obesity. The primary outcome is the change in overall Healthy Eating Index (HEI) 2020 score, which measures adherence to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans. The secondary outcomes are changes in urinary sodium (Na) and potassium (K) concentrations, which provide objective measures of dietary sodium and potassium intake. Adolescents aged 14-17 years with a history of overweight or obesity and poor diet quality (HEI < 80) will be randomized to either the intervention or usual care control group. The intervention includes personalized goals, meal timing strategies, nutrition education, home food environment guidance, and engagement techniques delivered via text messages over 4 weeks.

The study aims to analyze the incidence of postoperative complications such as cerebral hyperperfusion (CH) and cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome (CHS) within 1 month after carotid artery stenting (CAS), and to identify the risk factors for CH. The study will enroll 400 patients with carotid artery stenosis and perform transcranial Doppler (TCD) to detect CH, defined as an increase in middle cerebral artery (MCA) mean velocity by more than 100% within 48 hours after CAS. CHS is defined as the appearance of symptoms such as ipsilateral headache, seizures, and neurological deficits within 1 month after surgery, with an increase in cerebral blood flow in the MCA by more than 100% compared to the preoperative value. The study will also measure the incidence of major stroke, defined as new onset or worsening of neurological symptoms lasting at least 24 hours, within 7 days after CAS. The study will analyze various parameters, including plaque imaging, hemodynamic parameters, and characteristics of the stent, to predict the risk of

This study aims to examine the effects of a group-based, videoconference-delivered expressive writing (EW) program on the emotional, social, and physical well-being of informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer. The primary outcome measures are changes in psychological distress, general quality of life, and caregiver-specific quality of life at 6 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include changes in depression and perceived stress at 6 weeks. The study uses a randomized, waitlist-controlled, crossover design, where participants in the experimental group receive the 4-week EW intervention immediately, while the waitlist control group receives the same intervention after a delay. The EW intervention involves 4 weekly group-based videoconference sessions, where participants write about their deepest thoughts and feelings regarding their loved one's cancer and their role as a caregiver, followed by group discussions.

This is a prospective, randomized, controlled single-surgeon trial that investigates the use of intravenous tranexamic acid (IV TXA) in patients undergoing gender-affirming mastectomy (GAM). Patients who meet the eligibility criteria will be randomized to either the experimental group receiving IV TXA or the control group receiving standard care without TXA. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of clinically significant hematomas and seromas, total drain output, and time to drain removal. Secondary outcomes include thromboembolic events and wound complications. Patients will be followed for up to 3 months postoperatively, with a 1-year follow-up review of patient charts. The study aims to determine the effect of IV TXA on postoperative bleeding, hematoma, seroma, and drain output in patients undergoing GAM.

This is a randomized, controlled trial investigating the efficacy of smell training (ST) and trigeminal nerve stimulation (TNS) in treating COVID-related persistent smell loss. The study has three arms: 1) Active ST, 2) Placebo ST, and 3) Active TNS plus Active ST. The primary objectives are to determine the efficacy of ST versus natural recovery, the TNS-enhanced effects of ST on smell loss, and whether TNS+ST is more effective than ST alone in treating other long COVID symptoms. The study will measure changes in psychophysical olfactory function, perceived odorant intensity and hedonic ratings, olfactory-related quality of life, and impact of olfactory loss. Secondary outcomes include changes in long COVID symptoms, sustained attention, cognitive function, mood, sleep quality, daytime sleepiness, depression, and anxiety. The study aims to enroll 180 adults aged 18-65 years with COVID-related persistent smell loss.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical effect of Tiaoshen acupuncture therapy on primary insomnia. It is a randomized, placebo-controlled, triple-blind clinical trial. The study will enroll participants aged 18-70 years old who meet the diagnostic criteria for chronic insomnia. 

The primary outcome measure is the change in Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) scores before, during, and after 4 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in Fatigue Scale-14, Epworth Sleepiness Scale, Self-Rating Anxiety Scale, Self-Rating Depression Scale, polysomnography, and heart rate variability.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the acupuncture group or the placebo acupuncture group. The acupuncture group will receive Tiaoshen acupuncture, while the placebo group will receive non-insertive sham acupuncture using a Park device. The treatments will be performed 3 times per week for 4 weeks.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This is a randomized phase III study evaluating shorter anthracycline-free chemo-immunotherapy versus the usual taxane-platinum-anthracycline chemo-immunotherapy in patients with early-stage triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). 

The primary objective is to assess whether the anthracycline-free regimen has non-inferior breast cancer event-free survival (BC-EFS) compared to the standard regimen. Secondary objectives include comparing pathological complete response (pCR) rates, residual cancer burden (RCB) rates, distant relapse-free survival, overall survival, and safety between the two arms. 

Patient-reported outcomes on fatigue, physical function, and other quality of life measures will also be compared between the two treatment groups.

The study will randomize patients to receive either:
- Arm I (usual chemo-immunotherapy): Paclitaxel, carboplatin, pembrolizumab, followed by doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, pembrolizumab
- Arm II (shorter chemo-immunotherapy

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Study Overview:
   - The study evaluates a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP-1), an intensive case management intervention for pregnant and postpartum individuals who have used substances during their current or most recent pregnancy.
   - The study aims to establish causal evidence of the effectiveness of PCAP-1 in preventing the need for foster care, promoting reunification, and achieving other key goals related to recovery, access to services, and prevention of subsequent substance-exposed pregnancies.
   - The study will also estimate cost savings associated with PCAP-1 from the perspective of the state's child welfare agency.

2. Participation Criteria:
   - Inclusion criteria: Pregnant or parenting individuals who have used alcohol, opioids, or other drugs during pregnancy and reside within a 40-mile radius of the study sites.
   - Exclusion criteria: Incarcerated individuals and those enrolled in similar services.

3. Study Design:
   - The study uses a quasi-experimental design with a control group.
   - The treatment group will receive the one-year

This study is a comparative evaluation of three optical measurement devices: the Tomey OA-2000, Tomey CASIA2, and the LenStar LS900. The study aims to assess the agreement between the test devices and a predicate device, the precision of the test devices, and the safety of the test devices.

The study includes three participant groups: a normal cohort, a cataract cohort, and a special eyes cohort (eyes without a natural lens or containing artificial materials). Eligible participants are male or female subjects 22 years of age or older who meet the specific inclusion and exclusion criteria for each cohort.

The primary outcome measures are:
1. Agreement between the test devices and the predicate device, evaluated by mean difference, standard deviation, 95% limits of agreement, Bland-Altman plots, and Deming regression.
2. Precision of the test devices, assessed using a crossed two-way random-effects ANOVA model to estimate repeatability and reproducibility limits.
3. Safety of the test devices, evaluated by reporting any adverse events.

The study is expected to be completed in approximately 4 months.

This is a Phase III, open-label, randomized clinical trial comparing the efficacy and safety of rituximab plus zanubrutinib versus rituximab monotherapy in patients with previously untreated splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL). 

The primary objective is to evaluate whether the combination of rituximab and zanubrutinib improves progression-free survival (PFS) compared to rituximab alone. Secondary objectives include assessing complete remission rates, best response, time to next anti-lymphoma treatment, duration of response, overall survival, and safety.

Approximately 120 patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either rituximab plus zanubrutinib or rituximab monotherapy. The study includes a screening phase, treatment phase, and follow-up phase. An independent data monitoring committee will review interim safety data.

The primary endpoint is PFS rate at 3 years. Secondary endpoints include complete remission rates, best response, time to next anti-lymphoma treatment, duration of response, overall survival, and safety.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To compare the effectiveness of perioperative continuous serratus anterior plane block (SAPB) versus continuous thoracic epidural in pain management during thoracic surgeries for malignancy resection.

2. Study Design: Controlled randomized double-blinded comparative study.

3. Participants: 74 patients undergoing thoracotomy for cancer surgery (Lobectomy, Pneumonectomy, and Decortication), aged 18-65 years, ASA II-III.

4. Interventions: 
   - Experimental group: Continuous SAPB with bupivacaine infusion.
   - Control group: Thoracic epidural with bupivacaine and lidocaine with epinephrine.

5. Primary Outcome: Postoperative total morphine requirement.

6. Secondary Outcomes: 
   - Intraoperative fentanyl requirement
   - Time to first analgesia request
   - Postoperative pain scores
   - Length of hospital stay
   - Patient satisfaction

7. The study

This study aims to evaluate the impact of a PICU journal intervention on parent/caregiver stress, care engagement, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress in the context of a child's critical illness and hospitalization in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU). The study will enroll 75 parent/caregiver participants whose children meet the eligibility criteria and are admitted to the PICU at Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt. Participants will be provided with a customizable PICU journal and will complete surveys at three time points: within 72 hours of admission (T1), around the time of discharge (T2), and 3 months post-discharge (T3). The primary outcome measures include parent/caregiver reported stress, care engagement, depression, anxiety, and impact of events. The study will also assess parent/caregiver use of and satisfaction with the PICU journal, child-reported impact of events, and PICU staff perceptions of the intervention. This pilot study aims to evaluate the feasibility and potential benefits of the PICU journal in supporting parent/caregiver well-being and engagement during a child's

This study aims to compare two stakeholder engagement methods, Design Thinking (DT) and Focus Groups (FG), to determine which is more effective at obtaining input from Hispanic and Latino families of autistic children on the facilitators and barriers to accessing therapy services. The study uses a randomized mixed-methods design with two phases. 

Phase 1 compares the DT and FG methods using the PCORI stakeholder engagement principles and qualitative data. Phase 2 uses the data from Phase 1 to culturally adapt an occupational therapy intervention (Ayres Sensory Integration) into two separate protocols, one based on FG data and one on DT data. Stakeholder input on the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the adapted protocols is then obtained.

The primary outcome is the Stakeholder-Centric Engagement Evaluation, which measures stakeholder engagement using a Likert scale. Secondary outcomes include the Acceptability of Intervention Measure, Intervention Appropriateness Measure, and Feasibility of Intervention Measure, also using Likert scales.

The study aims to improve access to evidence-based autism interventions for Hispanic and Latino

This is a randomized study to evaluate harm reduction products as a second-line intervention for adult smokers who do not quit with nicotine replacement therapy (NRT). The study aims to assess the change in smoke exposure and smoking abstinence rates for NRT non-responders when they switch to either nicotine pouches or electronic cigarettes.

The key aspects of the study are:

1. Participants: Adult smokers aged 22-65 years who smoke at least 10 cigarettes per day and are interested in switching to electronic cigarettes or nicotine pouches.

2. Interventions:
   - Group I (NRT Responders): Participants who successfully quit smoking with NRT in the first 4 weeks can either remain on NRT or switch to nicotine pouches or electronic cigarettes for the next 5 weeks.
   - Group IIa (NRT Non-Responders - Pouch Preferrers): Participants who were unsuccessful with NRT in the first 4 weeks and prefer to try nicotine pouches are randomized to either switch to nicotine pouches or remain on NRT for the next 5

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the flipped classroom model on nursing students' asepsis knowledge and learning skills. The study will be conducted with first-year nursing students at Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University. The experimental group will receive pre-recorded videos on asepsis principles 2 weeks before the infection control course, while the control group will receive traditional lectures. Both groups will undergo the same 4-week course period. At the end of the study, students' asepsis knowledge will be assessed through a test, and the results will be evaluated 2 weeks later. The primary outcome measure is the effect of the flipped education model on the course success of nursing students.

This is a prospective study to evaluate the ability of Epitel's Remote EEG Monitoring System (REMI) to record electroencephalography (EEG) data and identify ictal events in patients with a history of seizures over an extended period of 14-28 days. The primary outcome measure is the number of ictal events identified in the first 14 days of monitoring, and the secondary outcome measure is the number of ictal events identified over the full 28-day monitoring period. The study aims to demonstrate that the REMI system can effectively capture extended clinical EEG data that is valuable for the diagnosis and treatment of seizure-related symptoms.

This study aims to analyze and compare the effects of a Multi-Component Training (MCT) program versus a Continuous Cardiovascular Training (CVT) program on blood pressure levels in adult hypertensive subjects. 

The study is a controlled, randomized, longitudinal, and prospective clinical trial with three groups: two intervention groups (MCT and CVT) and one control group. The study will recruit 75 adult hypertensive subjects (40-65 years old) who are sedentary. 

The MCT group will perform 60-minute sessions twice a week, consisting of 20 minutes of strength training and 20 minutes of cardiovascular training. The CVT group will perform 60-minute sessions twice a week of continuous aerobic exercise. 

The primary outcome is changes in systolic and diastolic blood pressure from baseline to 12 weeks. Secondary outcomes include changes in mean blood pressure, pulse pressure, double product, baseline heart rate, body composition, lipid profile, glucose, muscle strength, and cardiorespiratory capacity.

The study aims to determine the effects of multicomponent training versus cardiovascular training on hypertension in adult subjects.

This study aims to evaluate the impact of a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting guidelines on the observance of preoperative fasting time. The study will compare a "Before" group that undergoes preoperative fasting as standard care, and an "After" group that undergoes preoperative fasting after the sensitization campaign. The primary outcome measure is the fasting time (liquid and solid) before surgery. Secondary outcome measures include preoperative oral carbohydrate loading, rate of fasting exceeding 12 hours, preoperative anxiety and discomfort, feelings of thirst and hunger, preoperative and postoperative nausea/vomiting, patient satisfaction, postoperative quality of recovery, length of stay, and postoperative surgical complications. The study will enroll adult patients undergoing a surgical procedure, excluding those who are already intubated, have a medical indication for fasting, or are unable to answer the questionnaire.

This study is a community-based randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effects of the Mentored Planning to be Active + Family (MPBA+F) intervention on physical activity and health outcomes among rural Appalachian children with overweight or obesity. The study will recruit 288 7th grade students, with half receiving the MPBA+F intervention and the other half receiving a self-guided comparison program. The MPBA+F intervention involves 10 weekly peer-mentoring sessions and a 6-month family reinforcement program, while the comparison group receives 10 self-guided modules. The primary outcome is the change in daily moderate and vigorous physical activity, and the secondary outcome is the change in body composition. The study will follow participants from the start of 7th grade through the middle of 8th grade to assess the longer-term effects of the intervention.

The study aimed to evaluate the effect of virtual reality animation and ice massage on the Hoku point on labor pain, duration of labor, and satisfaction in term primiparous women with singleton pregnancies. The study used a randomized, parallel-assignment, open-label design. Participants were assigned to one of three groups: ice massage, virtual reality animation, or a control group receiving standard care. The primary outcome measures were labor pain (assessed using the Visual Analogue Scale), labor duration (assessed using a Personal Information Form), and birth satisfaction (assessed using the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised). The study included healthy women aged 18-35 years with a BMI below 30 and cervical dilatation of 0-3 cm. Participants with a high-risk pregnancy, those using pharmacological interventions, and those with ice allergy or visual impairment were excluded.

This is a study that aims to investigate the epidemiology of cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease in pediatric and adult liver transplant recipients in China. The study will enroll both children (age ≤18 years) and adults (age >18 years) who have received their first orthotopic liver transplant within the past 10 days. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of clinically significant CMV reactivation or CMV disease within 12 months of transplantation, the end of follow-up survey, and mortality. Secondary outcome measures include loss to follow-up and participants withdrawing from the study. The study will follow participants for up to 22 months after liver transplantation.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to develop a biomarker-based process to identify patients with right brain stroke who are most likely to benefit from prism adaptation therapy (PAT) for spatial neglect rehabilitation.

2. The study will be conducted in 180 veterans, 120 with spatial neglect and 60 without. It has three main objectives:
   a. Define and validate brain imaging biomarkers that predict the presence of "Aiming" spatial neglect, which is a strong predictor of functional recovery after PAT (Aim 1).
   b. Examine the correlation between the brain imaging biomarkers predicting Aiming spatial neglect and improvements in daily life function after PAT (Aim 2).
   c. Determine if adding behavioral predictors to biomarker predictors accounts for additional variance in the trajectory of functional recovery (Aim 3).

3. The primary outcome measures are the type of spatial neglect (Aiming vs. Where) and the trajectory of functional independence measure (FIM) improvement. 

4. The secondary outcome measures are the severity of spatial neglect as assessed by the Behavioral

The study aims to evaluate the use of liquid biopsy as a diagnostic tool for gliomas by analyzing circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) in blood samples of glioma patients. The primary objective is to detect and quantify ctDNA in the blood samples of patients with brain lesions compatible with glioma, using digital droplet PCR (ddPCR). The study will correlate the results of the ctDNA analysis with the tissue biopsy findings and magnetic resonance imaging. It is a pilot study with a single-arm, open-label design. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years and above with a de novo primary brain lesion compatible with glioma on contrast-enhanced MRI, who are scheduled for the usual surgical procedure. The study will measure the detection of circulating free DNA in the blood samples of these patients over a 1-year period (2023-2024).

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This is a pilot study evaluating the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of the combination of zimberelimab, quemliclustat, and modified FOLFIRINOX chemotherapy in patients with borderline resectable (BRPC) or locally advanced (LAPC) pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

The primary objectives are to:
1. Evaluate the safety, tolerability, and resection rate (for BRPC) or progression-free survival (for LAPC) with the combination treatment.
2. Evaluate the development of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula in the post-operative period for the BRPC cohort.

The secondary objectives are to estimate the efficacy as measured by decreases in CA 19-9, objective response rate, pathologic complete response rate (BRPC), and overall survival.

Exploratory objectives include evaluating the effects of the treatments on the tumor microenvironment and investigating potential predictive biomarkers.

The study uses a single-arm, open-label design. Eligible patients will receive zimberelimab, quemlic

The study aims to investigate the effect of probiotics (MIYAIRI 588) on depression and cardiovascular disease risk factors in hemodialysis patients. It is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study. The primary outcome is the change in depression score, measured by the Beck Depression Inventory (Chinese version 2.0), from baseline to 3 months. The study includes adults aged 20 years or older undergoing hemodialysis for at least 3 months, 3 times per week, with a URR ≥65%. Participants with certain mental health conditions, allergies, or recent use of certain medications are excluded. The intervention group receives 1g of MIYAIRI 588 probiotics, 3 times per day with meals, for 3 months, while the control group receives no intervention.

This study aims to increase alcohol abstinence in young adults aged 18-24 with alcohol use disorder (AUD). The study has two phases:

1. Formative (K99) phase: A single-arm pre/post study to test the feasibility and acceptability of an integrated Contingency Management-Problem Solving Therapy (CM-PST) intervention delivered via videoconference. 

2. Preliminary efficacy (R00) phase: A 2-arm randomized controlled trial comparing CM-PST to a CM-only control group. 

The primary outcome is alcohol abstinence, measured by blood alcohol content, over 6 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in AUD severity, alcohol-related negative consequences, alcohol and drug use, reasons for drinking, affect, and neural measures of reward, negative affect, and cognitive control.

Eligible participants are young adults aged 18-24 with current AUD, who are not currently in AUD treatment or taking AUD medications. The study excludes those with certain psychiatric disorders or conditions that would interfere with the assessments.

This is a Phase 2, randomized, open-label study comparing the efficacy of a triplet therapy (encorafenib, binimetinib, pembrolizumab) versus a doublet/control therapy (nivolumab and ipilimumab) in patients with BRAF V600E/K-mutant metastatic or unresectable locally advanced melanoma who have progressed during or after prior treatment with an approved anti-PD-1 monotherapy. The primary outcome measure is Objective Response Rate (ORR), and secondary outcome measures include Progression-Free Survival (PFS), Overall Survival (OS), Duration of Response, Disease Control Rate, Time to Response, Progression-Free Survival 2, safety, and patient-reported outcomes. Approximately 150 participants will be randomized 1:1 to the triplet or doublet/control therapy.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the effect of high-fidelity simulation and virtual reality-based simulation on simulation-based learning, reflective thinking, and therapeutic communication skills in undergraduate nursing students at Hacettepe University Faculty of Nursing.

2. The study will be conducted with 76 second-year nursing students, who will be randomly assigned to two groups: one group receiving high-fidelity simulation and the other group receiving both high-fidelity simulation and virtual reality-based simulation.

3. The primary outcome measures are:
   - Simulation-Based Learning Scale
   - Reflective Thinking Skills for Problem Solving Scale
   - Therapeutic Communication Skills Scale

4. The interventions are:
   - High-fidelity simulation: 60-minute session including preliminary information, simulation time, and evaluation/analysis
   - Virtual reality-based simulation: 30-minute modular training followed by a virtual reality-based simulation application

5. The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial with a primary purpose of evaluating the interventions.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a newly developed air trap device called "Emboless" in reducing microemboli of air during hemodialysis, compared to the standard air trap used in clinical practice.

2. It is a randomized, crossover study where each patient will undergo hemodialysis twice, once using the Emboless device and once using the standard air trap, in a randomized order.

3. The primary outcome measure is the reduction in the number and size of air microemboli (20-500 μm diameter) entering the patient's bloodstream, as measured by ultrasound at the inlet and outlet of the air trap.

4. The secondary outcome measures include a comparison of air contamination between hemodialysis and hemodiafiltration, as well as monitoring for adverse events.

5. The study plans to enroll up to 30 chronic hemodialysis patients, with each patient undergoing a total of 4 dialysis sessions (2 with Emboless, 2 with standard air trap).

6. The study is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of

This study aims to determine how repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (theta burst stimulation) influences movement among individuals with and without a concussion history. The purpose is to improve injury risk biomechanics and reduce the risk of future musculoskeletal injury. 

Participants will complete two testing sessions separated by at least 7 days. During the first session, they will perform single-task serial subtraction, single- and dual-task jump landing, and receive theta burst stimulation to either the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (experimental) or the vertex (control). The jump landing will be assessed before and after the stimulation, under single- and dual-task conditions. 

During the second session, participants will repeat the jump landing before and after theta burst stimulation, under single- and dual-task conditions. Various outcomes will be measured, including reaction time, joint angles, and self-reported workload and fear of movement. 

This is a single-blinded, cross-over study, where participants are unaware of whether they receive the experimental or control theta burst stimulation condition. The concussion history group and control group will be counterbalanced for the stimulation conditions.

The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial that compares extended pancreatic neck transection versus conventional pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPDEXCEPT). The primary outcome is the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula within 3 months postoperatively. The secondary outcomes include the location of the pancreatic duct in the pancreatic transverse section, the surgical performance of pancreaticojejunostomy, postoperative morbidity, and postoperative mortality within 3 months. The study includes patients with benign or resectable malignant tumors of the lower common bile duct, Vater ampulla, head or uncinate process of the pancreas, aged 18 to 80 years old, with no gender limit. Patients with borderline resectable, unresectable malignancies, or those undergoing neoadjuvant therapy are excluded.

This study aims to investigate the effects of two types of concurrent training on functional performance, cognitive function, and quality of life in older adults. The two interventions are:

1. Traditional concurrent training: Consisting of strength exercises followed by aerobic exercise (walking outdoors or on a treadmill).

2. Concurrent training with strength and dance classes: Consisting of the same strength training as the traditional group, but with dance classes instead of aerobic exercise.

The study will measure changes in dynamic balance, cognitive function, quality of life, static balance, sit-to-stand capacity, stair climbing capacity, leg strength and power, hand grip strength, and cardiorespiratory capacity. Secondary outcomes include changes in quadriceps muscle thickness, affectivity, lipid profile, quadriceps specific tension, and depressive symptoms.

The study is a randomized controlled trial with a control group that maintains their usual routine. The participants are healthy older adults aged 65-75 years.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of a virtual reality-based sensory stimulation intervention in preventing delirium in intensive care unit (ICU) patients. The study will recruit ICU patients aged 18-90 years who meet the inclusion criteria and exclude those with pre-existing conditions like dementia, acute psychiatric illness, or severe hearing impairment. 

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving the VR-based sensory stimulation intervention or the control group receiving usual care. The primary outcome measures are delirium incidence, duration, and severity. Secondary outcome measures include sleep quality, post-traumatic stress disorder, ICU memory, patients' clinical outcomes, quality of life, independence, and cognitive function. These outcomes will be assessed during the 14-day intervention period or until the patient is discharged from the ICU, whichever comes first.

The study aims to evaluate the outcome of surgical fixation of multiple fractured ribs at Sohag University Hospital. It is a randomized, parallel-assignment, open-label study comparing surgical rib fixation (intervention group) with conservative treatment (control group). The primary outcome measures are the need and duration of mechanical ventilation, as well as the severity of thoracic pain, assessed over a 1-year follow-up period. The study includes patients with multiple fractured ribs, excluding those requiring pre-ventilation. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

The study is a comparison of acute psychobiological responses to the Mannheim Multicomponent Stress Test (MMST) and the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) in healthy, recreationally active men and women aged 18-35 years. The primary outcome measure is the change in salivary cortisol levels from 5 minutes pre-stress to the peak post-stress. Secondary outcome measures include changes in state anxiety, heart rate, and salivary alpha-amylase in response to the stress tests. Participants are randomly assigned to either the MMST or TSST group, with stratification based on sex and trait anxiety. The study aims to assess and compare the psychobiological responses to these two laboratory stress tests.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, triple-blind clinical trial to assess the efficacy and safety of probiotic lysate (postbiotic and metabiotic) supplementation in adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

The study will include 3 periods:
1. Screening period (up to 1 week) to assess eligibility.
2. Treatment period (3 months) where participants will receive either probiotic lysate (100 mg twice daily) or placebo.
3. Follow-up period (up to 3 months).

The primary outcome measures are changes in hepatic fat content measured by MRI-PDFF and ultrasound attenuation coefficient, as well as changes in fatty liver index (FLI). 

Secondary outcome measures include changes in hepatic steatosis index, liver enzymes, liver stiffness, lipid profile, inflammatory markers, and body composition parameters.

The study aims to evaluate the short-term efficacy and safety of probiotic lysate supplementation in improving liver fat content and other metabolic markers in adults with NAFLD.

The study aims to examine the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) as an adjuvant therapy to standard medical care in reducing pain, hospital admission rates, length of stay, and time to disposition for pediatric patients aged 6-21 years with sickle cell vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) presenting to the emergency department. 

The study has two arms: a control arm with a retrospective chart review of 100 patients receiving standard medical care, and an intervention arm with a prospective, convenience sample of up to 100 patients receiving VR therapy in addition to standard medical care. 

The primary outcome measures are patient pain scores and disposition (admitted or discharged). The secondary outcome measures are length of stay in the emergency department and time to emergency department disposition. The study is non-randomized with sequential assignment of participants to the control or intervention arm.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of a web-based empowerment program for secondary cardiovascular prevention in patients after acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The intervention group will receive personalized, multidisciplinary support through a web platform, including educational, motivational, and coaching actions. The control group will receive usual care. The primary outcomes are changes in measurable risk factors (BMI, blood pressure, lipid levels, glycemia) at 12 months. Secondary outcomes include lifestyle changes (physical activity, diet, smoking), self-efficacy, medication adherence, and long-term maintenance of risk factor control (48 months). The study also explores the incidence of secondary cardiovascular events. The intervention is designed to empower patients through behavioral change models and leverage digital tools for remote support and monitoring.

The study aims to investigate the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound (PsUS) in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures, compared to radiography. The study consists of two parts: a feasibility phase and an active study phase. 

The feasibility phase will assess whether novice PsUS users can obtain accurate and adequate imaging for interpretation. Providers will receive PsUS training and then perform 3 elbow exams on participants aged 1-16 years. The images will be reviewed to ensure the providers are obtaining the correct standardized views.

The active study will recruit children aged 1-16 years with acute elbow pain. Participants will undergo bilateral standardized elbow exams using PsUS. The PsUS results will be categorized as positive, negative or equivocal for signs of fracture, before reviewing any radiographic imaging. Participants will then receive standard clinical care, which may include X-ray or bedside nursemaid reduction. The primary aim is to compare the test performance characteristics of PsUS performed by bedside physicians to standard radiography in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures.

The secondary outcome is to assess the feasibility and

The study aims to compare the effects of two different orthoses, a toe separator orthosis and a dynamic orthosis, on individuals with hallux valgus. The primary outcome measures are the hallux valgus angle and plantar pressure, which will be evaluated before using the orthosis, when first wearing the orthosis, and one month after using the orthosis. The secondary outcome measures are the Manchester-Oxford Foot Questionnaire (MOXFQ) to assess the functional and social effects of hallux valgus, and an evaluation of orthosis satisfaction. Participants will be randomly assigned to use either the toe separator orthosis or the dynamic orthosis for an average of 8 hours per day for one month. The study includes individuals aged 18-65 with mild to moderate hallux valgus deformity, and excludes those with cognitive, mental, or psychological problems, previous orthosis treatment, foot surgery history, rheumatoid arthritis, or rigid hallux valgus deformity.

This is a prospective clinical trial that aims to evaluate speech function through patient- and parent-reported outcome measures in children with isolated or combined cleft palate and velopharyngeal insufficiency who undergo pharyngeal flap surgery. The primary outcome measures are changes in speech function assessed using the CLEFT-Q patient-reported outcome and the Intelligibility in Context Scale parent-reported outcome, evaluated preoperatively and 1 year postoperatively. The study includes children under 18 years of age with isolated or combined cleft palate and velopharyngeal insufficiency who will undergo pharyngeal flap surgery, as well as their parents, across 6 specialized cleft centers in Sweden. Patients with cognitive impairment that would make it difficult to understand the study are excluded.

This is a single-blind, randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of probiotics (Lactobacillus sp.) compared to placebo and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) for the treatment of alcohol use disorder in adult male patients. 

The primary outcome measures are changes in alcohol use disorder severity, alcohol withdrawal severity, and alcohol craving at 4 time points (baseline, 8 weeks, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks). 

The secondary outcome measures include changes in depression and anxiety symptoms, EEG characteristics, and serum levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α) at the same 4 time points. Changes in gut microbiota profiles will also be assessed at 3 time points (baseline, 2 weeks, and 8 weeks).

The study will be conducted at two sites in China and Malaysia, with an estimated total sample size of 120 participants (40 per group). Eligible participants will be randomly assigned in a 1:1:1 ratio to receive either probiotics, ACT, or placebo in addition to conventional drug therapy.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the use of barbed sutures versus standard sutures for vaginal cuff closure after total laparoscopic hysterectomy. The primary outcomes are the incidence of vaginal cuff dehiscence at 30 and 90 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes include vaginal cuff complications, hospital stay, operative time, intraoperative blood loss, 30-day post-surgical morbidity, quality of life, and sexual function. Eligible participants are women undergoing elective total laparoscopic hysterectomy for benign conditions, aged 18 years or older. The study has a parallel assignment design with two intervention groups: one receiving barbed sutures and the other receiving standard sutures for vaginal cuff closure.

The study aims to test a new neurobiological model of gambling addiction that reconciles inconsistencies in previous neuroimaging studies. The primary objective is to investigate two opposite brain phenotypes in gambling addiction: striatal hyper-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hypo-reactivity to emotional stimuli, and striatal hypo-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hyper-reactivity to emotional stimuli. These phenotypes are hypothesized to characterize two distinct subpopulations of gamblers, impulsive and emotional, respectively. The secondary objective is to determine whether these brain phenotypes can predict gambling behavior and its relationship with emotions in everyday life, using Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA). The study will recruit 60 individuals with gambling problems and 60 healthy controls, and will use fMRI to measure striatal reactivity to reward and amygdalar reactivity to emotional stimuli. The study will also combine fMRI measures with EMA data collected on participants' smartphones to assess the relationship between emotions and gambling behavior in daily life.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the use of 2D 4K and 3D HD laparoscopic imaging systems in bariatric gastric bypass surgery. The primary outcome measure is the operation time, while secondary outcomes include intraoperative complications, workload of the operating surgeon, and postoperative complications. Eligible participants are patients with an indication for gastric bypass surgery according to SMOB guidelines, aged 18 years and above. The study has a parallel assignment design, with participants randomly assigned to receive gastric bypass surgery using either the 2D 4K or 3D HD laparoscopic imaging system. The interventions are performed by three defined surgeons.

This is a single-center, prospective, single-arm study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Huaier granule in patients with stage I primary ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer after surgical treatment. The primary objective is to assess the 1-year progression-free survival rate. Secondary objectives include evaluating progression-free survival, 1-year overall survival rate, quality of life, pain score, and the rates of adverse events and serious adverse events. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older with histopathologically confirmed stage II-IV primary ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer who have undergone primary or interval tumor reduction surgery with satisfactory results. Patients will receive oral Huaier granule 20 g three times daily continuously until disease progression or intolerable toxicity, for up to 24 months.

This is a non-invasive observational study investigating the prevalence of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) in critically ill, mechanically ventilated patients in the intensive care unit (ICU). The primary objective is to assess the prevalence of SIBO in this patient population. Secondary outcomes include the effects of SIBO on ventilator-associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality. The study uses a modified hydrogen breath test technique to diagnose SIBO, with measurements performed at specific time points during the patient's ICU stay. Patients with abnormal hydrogen breath test results on the first day of admission are excluded from the study. The study aims to provide insights into the impact of SIBO on the clinical outcomes of critically ill, mechanically ventilated ICU patients.

This study investigated the effect of exercises with different intensities on exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) in patients after total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Thirty-eight patients were randomly assigned to either a low-intensity exercise (LIE) group or a high-intensity exercise (HIE) group. The exercise programs were conducted for 5 days during the hospitalization period. Pain severity was assessed using a visual analog scale (VAS), and pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) were measured over the quadriceps and biceps brachii muscles before and after the exercises. The study aimed to determine whether EIH is present following exercise in patients after TKA and if it changes with exercise intensity.

The Nigerian Breast Cancer Risk-Reduction Study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to assess the effects of individualized breast cancer risk assessment and counseling on adherence to risk reduction recommendations among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwestern Nigeria. The study will compare a standard care group to an experimental group that receives the risk assessment and counseling intervention. The primary outcomes are the effects of the intervention on adherence to breast screening practices and lifestyle risk reduction recommendations, as well as predictors of breast self-examination and time to first breast cancer screening. Secondary outcomes include determining the perception, knowledge, and attitudes towards familial breast cancer risk and genetic testing among the participants. The study will enroll female participants aged 20 to 75 years who are first-degree relatives of breast cancer patients.
