This is an open-label, two-period, fixed-sequence study in healthy volunteers genotyped for CYP2B6 alleles (*6 and *18). The study investigates the effect of CYP2B6 genotype and efavirenz (600 mg/day for 16 days) on the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of a single oral dose of tizanidine (4 mg) and methadone (10 mg). 

The study will enroll normal metabolizers (CYP2B6*1/*1), intermediate metabolizers (CYP2B6*1/*6 and *1/*18), and poor metabolizers (CYP2B6*6/*6, *18/*18, and *6/*18). 

In the control phase, the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of tizanidine and methadone will be assessed at baseline. In the treatment phase, the participants will receive the same doses of tizanidine and methadone after 16 days of ef

The study aims to evaluate the serum magnesium (Mg) level in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). It is a diagnostic test study that compares the serum Mg levels between a T2DM group (cases) and a control group. The study includes female participants aged 30 years and above. Patients with renal failure, type 1 diabetes, acute pancreatitis, hyperthyroidism, hyperparathyroidism, malignancies, and those on loop/thiazide diuretics, Mg supplements, or Mg-containing antacids were excluded. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of magnesium, which will be evaluated over a 1-year time frame.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of Ophiochepalus striatus extract on serum IGF-1 and IL-6 levels in elderly patients with sarcopenia. The study will enroll elderly patients diagnosed with sarcopenia based on the AWGS criteria, including low muscle mass, low muscle strength, and low physical performance. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either Ophiochepalus striatus extract or a placebo for 14 days. The primary outcome measures are changes in serum IGF-1 and IL-6 levels after 2 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in SARC-F score, muscle mass, muscle strength, and physical performance.

This study is a 2-arm randomized control feasibility study to evaluate the use of a mobile app-based digital therapeutic, the 2Morrow Chronic Pain Self-Management Program, for improving pain self-management and function in patients with chronic pain. The primary outcome is the PROMIS Pain Interference Scale, and secondary outcomes include measures of depression (PHQ-9) and anxiety (GAD-7). The intervention arm will receive access to the mobile app in addition to usual care, while the control arm will receive usual care only. The study aims to assess the feasibility of using the mobile app and conducting a larger efficacy trial, as well as estimate the effect size for the primary outcome.

The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial evaluating the Stentless Florence Robotic Intracorporeal Neobladder (FloRIN) procedure compared to the Stented FloRIN procedure in patients with bladder cancer. The primary outcome measure is the mid-term complication rate at 6 months, while the secondary outcome measure is the perioperative complication rate within 7 days. The study aims to assess the impact of using ureteral mono J stents during the uretero-neobladder anastomosis in the robotic-assisted radical cystectomy with intracorporeal neobladder reconstruction.

This is a randomized crossover clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of different storage conditions (dry vs. wet) on removable orthodontic retainers, including Hawley retainers and vacuum-formed retainers (VFRs). 

The primary objective is to compare the microbial colony counts of removable retainers stored in wet and dry conditions. The secondary objectives are to compare the surface roughness, color stability, compressive strength, and oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) of the retainers under the two storage conditions.

The study will recruit 24 participants who meet the inclusion criteria. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: 1) Hawley retainers in dry storage, 2) Hawley retainers in wet storage, 3) VFRs in dry storage, and 4) VFRs in wet storage. After 3 months, the storage conditions will be crossed over for each group.

The primary outcome is the microbial colony counts of the retainers, measured at baseline, 3 months (T1), and 6 months (T

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a stepped-wedge cluster-randomized trial that aims to test the feasibility and impact of a new model of continuity of nutrition care between acute care hospitals and community meal provision organizations for older adults (aged 60+) diagnosed with malnutrition. 

The primary objectives are to:
1) Test the feasibility of a patient identification, cross-referral, and data reporting/communication process from hospital to community.
2) Increase the rate of malnourished older adults receiving nutrition care (medical nutrition therapy, medically tailored meals) in the community.
3) Improve food security, determinants of malnutrition, and quality of life in malnourished older adults post-hospital discharge.

The study will enroll 1,120 patients across 8 sites, with a focus on recruiting from vulnerable populations (racial/ethnic minorities, rural areas). All sites will start in a control condition (usual care) and then be randomly assigned to sequentially implement the new care model over 5 time periods. 

The primary outcome is change in quality of life (CASP-19

This is a randomized, single-blind, crossover study investigating the hemodynamic effects of modulating circulating ketone bodies with 1,3-butanediol in patients with chronic heart failure (NYHA class II-III, LVEF <40%). The primary outcome measure is cardiac output, as measured by LVOT VTI and heart rate, over a 6-hour period. Secondary outcome measures include stroke volume, heart rate, LVEF, changes in circulating 3-OHB, and changes in free fatty acids (FFA). Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years and older with chronic heart failure, excluding those with diabetes, significant cardiac valve disease, severe stable angina pectoris, or severe comorbidities. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either 1,3-butanediol or a placebo supplement in a crossover design.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial investigating the use of subpectoral bupivacaine injection for pain management in adolescent patients undergoing reduction mammaplasty. Patients will be randomized to receive either 20 mL of subpectoral bupivacaine or 20 mL of subpectoral saline injection. The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain score, which will be assessed by patient-reported pain ratings on a 1-10 scale. Secondary outcome measures include narcotic use, length of stay in the post-anesthesia care unit, return to full activity, and patient demographics. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of subpectoral bupivacaine injection in reducing post-operative pain in this patient population.

This study aims to evaluate the radiobiological effects and skin toxicities in breast cancer patients receiving pencil beam scanning proton therapy, with a focus on the effectiveness of the Spot Delete technique in reducing radiation dermatitis. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Intervention: Pencil Beam Scanning Proton Therapy, with the use of the Spot Delete technique to minimize protons stopping in the skin.

2. Primary Outcome: Reduction in radiation dermatitis, assessed through photographs, patient-reported questionnaires, and clinician evaluation using the CTCAE and Radiation Dermatitis Severity scoring systems. The results will be compared to historical data from patients who underwent regular proton therapy without the Spot Delete technique.

3. Secondary Outcome: Investigation of the relationship between the linear energy transfer (LET) of the proton beam and the location and severity of skin reactions. The actual location of any skin reactions will be compared to the predicted location from the computer model.

4. Study Design: Single-group assignment, open-label study involving 100 breast cancer patients (stages 0-III) over a 3-year period.

This is a multicenter, non-inferiority, randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of generic cetrorelix acetate compared to reference cetrorelix acetate for ovarian stimulation using a GnRH antagonist protocol in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The primary outcome measure is the cumulative live birth rate for the first live birth (gestation ≥ 24 weeks) in one IVF/ICSI egg retrieval cycle (fresh and frozen-thawed embryo transfer cycle), assessed over an average of 18 months. The study includes infertile women under 43 years old who are planning to undergo IVF/ICSI treatment, and excludes those with certain medical conditions or reproductive factors that may affect the outcomes. Participants are randomly assigned to receive either the generic or reference cetrorelix acetate.

This is a phase 1 clinical trial evaluating the safety and tolerability of the combination of peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin in patients with metastatic or unresectable leiomyosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas. 

The primary objectives are to:
1. Evaluate the safety and tolerability of the combination, as measured by the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) rate.
2. Determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) and the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of the combination.
3. Obtain a more precise determination of adverse events at the selected dose.

The secondary objectives are to:
1. Assess the pharmacokinetics of the combination.
2. Estimate the objective response rate (ORR) and progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with leiomyosarcoma.

The study has a dose escalation phase followed by a dose expansion phase. Patients receive oral peposertib twice daily and intravenous liposomal doxorubicin once daily, with cycles repeating every 28

The study aims to examine the feasibility and potential benefits of a free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program in reducing back pain and improving sleep and quality of life among individuals with chronic back pain. 

The study is a prospective, randomized controlled trial with two groups: a t'ai chi and qigong exercise (treatment) group and a waitlist control group. The primary objective is to determine if the t'ai chi and qigong program improves pain levels, sleep, and quality of life. The secondary objective is to explore whether improvements in pain levels differ between smokers/those with unhealthy BMI and others.

The study will recruit a maximum of 300 participants with chronic low back pain, with 150 in each group. The treatment group will receive the 12-week, twice-weekly t'ai chi and qigong program starting in September 2022, while the waitlist control group will receive the same program starting in January 2023. 

The primary outcome measure is the change in Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) scores at 3 months after the intervention. Secondary outcome measures include changes in visual analog scale (

The EMBOL-AF study is a multicenter, international, observational retrospective registry that aims to investigate the characteristics, management, and outcomes of systemic arterial embolic events, particularly stroke and transient ischemic attack (TIA), that occur after catheter ablation of atrial fibrillation (AF) or related procedures.

The primary objectives are to:
1. Study the acute clinical profile, symptoms, signs, and results of imaging techniques of stroke/TIA associated with AF ablation.
2. Study the acute therapeutic management of these embolic events.
3. Study the sequelae and clinical consequences at 3 months of follow-up.

The secondary objectives are to:
1. Assess whether the risk and severity of stroke/TIA are associated with specific AF ablation techniques.
2. Evaluate the impact of other procedural factors, such as transesophageal echocardiography, discontinuation of oral anticoagulants, target intraprocedural anticoagulation, and use of general anesthesia, on the incidence and severity of stroke/TIA.

The study will retrospectively collect data on all cases of arterial

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) during the acceleration of en-masse retraction of upper anterior teeth using a low-intensity direct electrical current. The study will include adult patients aged 17-25 years with Class II Division 1 malocclusion. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, where they will receive electrical stimulation during the retraction, or the control group, where traditional retraction using coil springs will be performed. The primary outcome measures are changes in the perception of pain and discomfort, while secondary outcome measures include changes in the perception of burning, swelling, chewing ability, speech ability, analgesic consumption, patient satisfaction, ease of the procedure, the possibility of repeating the procedure, and recommendation of the procedure to a friend. Patients will report these outcomes using visual analog scales at various time points during the 5-month study period.

This is a single-site, non-randomized prospective observational study of men with prostate cancer. The primary objective is to evaluate whether baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 (Aβ42/40) ratio is associated with cognitive decline in men upon starting androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). The secondary objectives are to evaluate whether ADT is associated with a decline in plasma Aβ42/40 ratio, and whether intensified ADT (iADT) receipt is associated with greater cognitive decline compared to ADT.

The study will recruit two cohorts: an ADT cohort of men with hormone-sensitive prostate cancer who are starting ADT, and a prostate cancer control (PC) cohort of men in remission who have never received ADT. The study will measure the proportion of participants with cognitive decline, mean cognitive decline, and proportion of participants with cognitive impairment after ADT in the ADT cohort. It will also measure the change in mean plasma Aβ42/40 ratio, mean cognition score, and mean study partner-reported cognition score in both cohorts.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. This is a multicentre, parallel-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled trial comparing high-dose (1000 mg QID) cephalexin to standard-dose (500 mg QID) cephalexin for the treatment of adult patients with non-purulent cellulitis in the emergency department.

2. The primary outcome is oral antibiotic treatment failure, defined as a change in antibiotic (change in class of oral antibiotic or step up to IV therapy) within 7 days due to worsening infection.

3. Secondary outcomes include clinical cure, clinical response, unplanned healthcare visits, unplanned hospitalizations, adverse events, antibiotic intolerance, antibiotic allergy, medication adherence, and health-related quality of life.

4. The study aims to enroll 446 patients (223 per group) across 8 Canadian emergency departments.

5. The study interventions are a 7-day course of either high-dose or standard-dose oral cephalexin, with both the patients and the research team blinded to the treatment allocation.

The study aims to determine the Turkish validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) and to evaluate the effect of a diabetes health literacy board game on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children with type 1 diabetes aged 8-12 years. 

The study will be conducted in two stages. In the first stage, the current situation will be determined by quantitative analysis of the data obtained with the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 years). In the second stage, an intervention group will receive the diabetes health literacy board game, while a control group will not. The primary outcome measures are the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) in Turkish, and the evaluation of the Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Diabetes for Children with Type 1 Diabetes (8-12 years) at baseline, 4 weeks, and 12 weeks after randomization.

This is a randomized controlled pilot clinical trial that aims to compare the biofilm accumulation on the surface of zirconia versus titanium dental implants. The study will enroll 30 participants (15 in each group) who will receive either a zirconia or titanium implant to replace a single missing tooth. The primary outcome is the total amount of biofilm and the amount of specific bacterial species on the implants, measured by culturing samples taken from the peri-implant sulcus at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months after final crown placement. Secondary outcomes include implant survival, probing depth, bleeding on probing, plaque index, and marginal bone loss. The study will be conducted at the Faculty of Dentistry of the Complutense University of Madrid, Spain, and is designed as a triple-masked, randomized, parallel-group trial.

The study aims to investigate the impact of aromatherapy using rosemary and lemongrass oils on alleviating dental anxiety in children aged 6 to 9 years old. It is a randomized, parallel-group study with three arms: a control group with no intervention, a rosemary group where children inhaled rosemary oil for 3 minutes before dental procedures, and a lemongrass group where children inhaled lemongrass oil for 3 minutes before dental procedures. The primary outcome measures are pulse rate, oxygen saturation, blood pressure, and pain level, which will be assessed at baseline, during the procedure, and immediately after the procedure. The study excludes medically compromised and allergic children.

The study aims to investigate the effect of using puzzles on the concept learning of nursing students, specifically related to the topic of vital signs. The study will be conducted with first-year nursing students at Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University. The experimental group will use puzzles for two weeks during the theoretical lesson on vital signs, while the control group will receive the standard course instruction. The primary outcome measure is the students' knowledge test scores, which will be assessed before and after the intervention. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the impact of using puzzles on the students' learning of vital signs concepts.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of a motivational interview-based intervention program, grounded in the Transtheoretical Model, on smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels among nursing students. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Study Design: A quasi-experimental study with pre-test and post-test, with intervention and control groups randomly assigned.

2. Participants: Nursing students from Aksaray University Faculty of Health Sciences who score above the cut-off on the Smartphone Addiction Scale-Short Form (31 for men, 33 for women) and meet other inclusion criteria.

3. Intervention: The intervention group will receive a motivational interviewing program based on the Transtheoretical Model, with a varying number of sessions (up to 6) depending on the participant's stage of change. The control group will receive no intervention.

4. Outcome Measures: 
   - Primary: Smartphone Addiction Scale-Short Form, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, Stages of Change Classification Scale
   - Secondary: Same as primary outcomes, measured at 16 weeks.

5. Rationale: Smartphone addiction and poor sleep quality are significant public health issues,

This is a randomized, split-face, single-blind clinical trial comparing the efficacy of Potassium-titanyl Phosphate (KTP) laser alone versus KTP laser combined with Ivermectin 1% cream for the treatment of facial rosacea. The primary outcome measure is the relative decrease in erythema as assessed by the Normalized Erythema Index (NEI) at 16 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include assessments of erythema, skin lesions, telangiectasia, papules/papulopustules, face swelling, redness, and purpura at various timepoints up to 16 weeks. The study enrolled adults with Fitzpatrick skin type I-IV and facial erythematous or mild papulopustular rosacea. Participants were randomized to receive KTP laser alone on one side of the face or KTP laser plus Ivermectin 1% cream on the other side.

This is a retrospective study that aims to analyze cerebral glucose metabolism using FDG PET in patients with neurodegenerative diseases. The primary objective is to characterize the distribution pattern of FDG tracer and identify brain regions with altered function specific to each clinical condition. The study will include patients aged 18 years and above with a diagnosis of neurodegenerative disease, and will measure brain areas of hypo or hyper regional metabolism over a 4-year period.

The key aspects of the clinical trial document are:

1. This is a prospective, longitudinal cohort study in people with Cystic Fibrosis (pwCF) to provide comprehensive information on SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence changes over time and the subsequent clinical impact on pwCF.

2. The primary outcome measures are:
   a. SARS-COV-2 seroprevalence in pwCF over a 3-year period.
   b. Association of SARS-CoV-2 seropositivity with clinical symptoms, exacerbations, and mortality in pwCF over a 3-year period.
   c. Longitudinal comparison of anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody levels following natural infection and vaccination in pwCF over a 3-year period.

3. The secondary outcome measure is to assess serum proteomic and genomic responses in pwCF who are SARS-CoV-2 seropositive and seronegative, anticipated over 5-10 years.

4. The study will be conducted at participating

The study aims to evaluate the use and reproducibility of duplex ultrasound in measuring the diameter of the left common iliac vein (CIV) to aid in the diagnosis of May-Thurner Syndrome (MTS) in patients presenting with unexplained left leg swelling. The primary outcome is the measurement of the left CIV diameter, and the secondary outcome is the inter- and intra-operator variation in the diameter measurement using duplex ultrasound. The study includes two participant groups: a symptomatic group with unexplained left leg swelling and an asymptomatic group without leg swelling. All participants will undergo a vascular ultrasound scan of the left CIV, and the measurements will be assessed over a 6-month period.

This study aimed to evaluate the health-related quality of life (HRQoL) of patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency. The study included participants aged 8-15 years old with specific criteria related to visual acuity, near exophoria, near point of convergence, positive fusional vergence, stereogram, and scores on the Convergence Insufficiency Symptom Survey (CISS) or the Concomitant Deviation Questionnaire (COVD). Participants were divided into two groups: a training group that received visual training in the hospital, and a non-training group that did not receive the training. The primary outcome measures were changes in the EuroQol five dimensions questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) score and the Short Form 6D (SF-6D) questionnaire score between baseline and 3 months.

This is a pilot clinical trial that aims to evaluate the use of indocyanine green (ICG) dye and a handheld camera system (Spy-Phi) for sentinel lymph node (SLN) mapping in patients with early-stage vulvar cancer. The primary objectives are to compare the detection rate of SLNs using ICG dye versus the standard blue dye, both at the patient level and when accounting for the clustering effect at the hemi-pelvis level. The secondary objective is to assess the sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value of ICG dye compared to the standard blue dye. Eligible patients are 18 years or older with early-stage squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva (diameter <4 cm) and clinically negative inguinofemoral lymph nodes. The study will be conducted at Tufts Medical Center.

This is a crossover, experimental, randomized, double-blind trial that aims to compare the effects of different neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) protocols on the triceps surae muscle. The study will evaluate the impact of four NMES protocols (Russian current 10%, Aussie current 10%, pulsed current 500 μs phase, and pulsed current 200 μs phase) on evoked torque, muscle fatigue, sensory discomfort, and peripheral oxygen extraction in apparently healthy participants aged 18-40 years. The primary outcome measures include submaximal and maximum voluntary isometric contraction, maximum evoked torque, torque evoked during the fatigue protocol, and muscle fatigue assessment before, during, and after the fatigue protocol. The secondary outcome measures are sensory discomfort during maximum evoked torques and the fatigue protocol, electromyographic signals, and peripheral oxygen extraction. The study consists of a total of 5 sessions, with the NMES protocols being randomly applied in a double-blind manner from the second to the fifth session.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover clinical trial investigating the metabolic effects of a four-week supplementation with a lactate-ketone ester (LaKe Ester) in individuals with obesity. The primary outcome measure is insulin sensitivity, assessed using a hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamp. Secondary outcome measures include lipolysis rate, body composition, gastric emptying, cardiac function, and various blood biomarkers related to metabolism, inflammation, and mood. The study aims to enroll participants aged 30-60 years with a BMI between 30-40 kg/m2 and HbA1c less than 48 mmol/mol. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the LaKe Ester supplement or a placebo for 28 days, followed by a washout period and then crossover to the other treatment. The study will evaluate the effects of the lactate-ketone ester supplementation compared to placebo over the course of approximately 12 weeks.

This is a 6-week study to explore the impact of FitnessGenes' platform on the health and wellbeing of NHS staff. Participants will complete questionnaires to assess their baseline mental and physical wellbeing using the WHO-5 scale. They will then undergo genetic testing provided by FitnessGenes and receive personalized recommendations based on their genetic and lifestyle data. Participants will provide feedback on their experiences 3 weeks after receiving the results, and a 3-month follow-up will assess any long-term impacts on their wellbeing. The primary outcome is changes in WHO-5 scores, and secondary outcomes include perceptions of DNA testing and the sustainability of the personalized recommendations.

This is a single-center, non-randomized, prospective cohort study that aims to identify volatile organic compound (VOC) profiles in breath samples that are predictive of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or planned hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. 

The study will enroll patients newly diagnosed with AML or planned for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, who have undergone a chest CT scan within 30 days of enrollment. Breath samples will be collected at baseline (within 7 days of the initial chest CT), at the time of any suspected IPA (leading to a new chest CT), and within 7 days of discontinuation of antifungal treatment. 

The diagnosis of IPA will be defined according to the EORTC criteria as confirmed, probable, or possible. VOC profiles in the breath samples will be analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. The study aims to identify VOC profiles that are predictive of IPA diagnosis

This is a clinical trial studying the use of ultrasound-guided psoas tenotomy as a treatment for ilio-psoas conflict in patients after total hip replacement. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Intervention: Ultrasound-guided psoas tenotomy procedure.
2. Primary Outcome: Evaluate the success rate of the ultrasound-guided tenotomy technique in resolving the ilio-psoas conflict.
3. Secondary Outcomes: Assess pain, hip function scores, technical difficulty of the procedure, operative time, blood loss, hospital stay, scarring, quality of life, patient satisfaction, and complications.
4. Participants: Patients 18 years or older with indication for psoas tenotomy after total hip replacement.
5. Study Design: Single-group, open-label intervention study.
6. Follow-up: Participants will be assessed at 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months post-operatively.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to compare the analgesic efficacy of different volumes of thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) in patients undergoing thoracotomy surgery. The study will enroll patients aged 18 to 80 years old with American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I-II-III and a BMI between 18 to 40 kg/m2. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of three intervention groups: TPVB with 20 ml, 25 ml, or 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine, all administered under ultrasound guidance. The primary outcome measures are pain scores at rest and during coughing, assessed at various time points up to 48 hours after surgery. The secondary outcome is 24-hour morphine consumption. The study aims to determine the optimal volume of local anesthetic for TPVB to provide effective post-thoracotomy analgesia.

The study aims to investigate the effects of muscle vibration on fatigue and mobility in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study is an interventional, non-randomized, parallel-group trial. Eligible patients with MS will undergo a 4-week intensive multidisciplinary rehabilitation program, with the experimental group receiving additional vibration therapy using the "vibra plus" device. The primary outcome measures are changes in mobility, postural control, and fatigue, assessed through various clinical scales and tests. Secondary outcome measures include changes in quality of life and coping strategies. The study will compare the outcomes between the experimental group receiving vibration therapy and the control group receiving standard rehabilitation alone.

This is a phase I clinical trial evaluating the combination of osimertinib, cetuximab, and tucatinib in patients with EGFR-mutant stage IV or recurrent non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have acquired resistance to EGFR-tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).

The primary objective is to estimate the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of the three-drug combination. Secondary objectives include evaluating the toxicities, assessing preliminary anti-tumor activity in the dose escalation cohort, and obtaining preliminary assessment of anti-tumor activity in the dose expansion cohort.

Eligible patients will receive tucatinib 200mg orally twice daily, osimertinib 80mg orally daily, and cetuximab 250mg/m^2 intravenously every 2 weeks in 28-day cycles. The study will assess dose-limiting toxicities, incidence of adverse events, objective response rate, and progression-free survival.

This is a clinical trial study that aims to evaluate the diagnostic efficacy of transbronchial cryobiopsy (TBCB) compared to traditional transbronchial lung biopsy (TBLB) for diagnosing lung transplant rejection. The study will enroll patients aged 18-65 years old who have undergone lung transplantation and are experiencing unexplained pulmonary function decline, acute/chronic clinical lung injury, or new pulmonary infiltrates. Participants will be randomly assigned to undergo either TBCB or TBLB. The primary outcome is the diagnostic yield of TBCB versus TBLB for diagnosing lung transplant rejection, with the reference standard being the result of multidisciplinary treatment (MDT). Secondary outcomes include the incidence of complications, sample size, number of alveoli and blood vessels in the biopsy sample, percentage of lung parenchyma without artifacts, and the number of attempts to obtain five samples. The study has an open-label, parallel assignment design.

This is a clinical trial investigating selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) in monochorionic twin pregnancies. The study aims to:

1. Improve outcome prediction at the time of sFGR diagnosis by testing various predictors.
2. Evaluate if additional ultrasound parameters can enhance the current diagnostic classification system.
3. Examine the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms through placental histological analysis.
4. Assess the impact of sFGR on neurodevelopment, parental mental health, and parent-infant attachment.

The study will enroll monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies diagnosed with sFGR before 28 weeks of gestation. The primary outcome is a composite of fetal single or double demise, including selective fetal reduction and/or iatrogenic preterm birth before 32 weeks due to fetal distress. Secondary outcomes include analysis of ultrasound parameters, prenatal and postnatal attachment, post-traumatic stress, and neurodevelopmental assessment.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an interactive educational digital platform (called "THE GUIDE") in improving mental health outcomes for transgender and gender-diverse (TGD) youth aged 15-25 years and their caregivers. The primary outcome is a reduction in suicidal ideation, measured using the Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS). Secondary outcomes include changes in depression (PHQ-9), anxiety (GAD-7), perceived family acceptance (TransFATE), family communication and acceptance (FACES IV), and non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI). Participants will be randomized to either immediate access to the digital platform plus usual care, or deferred access (usual care only for the first 6 months, then access to the platform). Assessments will be conducted every 3 months over an 18-month period. The study aims to have at least 80% retention and detect a reduction in suicidal ideation from 40% at baseline to 26.3% or lower at 12-month follow-up.

This study aims to phenotype patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) and cannabis use disorder (CUD) using the Addictions Neuroclinical Assessment. The study involves a 12-week treatment program with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) for both AUD and CUD groups. The primary outcome measures include changes in alcohol and cannabis use, as well as changes in craving, during the treatment period. Secondary outcome measures include treatment retention, changes in depressive and anxiety symptoms, and changes in quality of life. The study uses a non-randomized, single-group assignment design and does not include healthy volunteers.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the short-term impact of positive, neutral, or negative speech on pain intensity, global perceived effect of improvement, patient's expectations regarding spinal manipulative therapy (SMT), and perception of empathy in the therapeutic encounter in patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

The study will have three parallel groups: 
1) Positive expectation group - Patients will watch a positive video about SMT and then receive one session of SMT.
2) Neutral expectation group - Patients will watch a neutral video about SMT and then receive one session of SMT. 
3) Negative expectation group - Patients will watch a negative video about SMT and then receive one session of SMT.

The primary outcome is pain intensity measured by the Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS) one hour after the baseline assessment. The secondary outcomes include global perceived effect of improvement, patient's expectations regarding SMT, and perception of empathy in the therapeutic encounter.

Ultimately, patients will also undergo a semi-structured interview to investigate their perceptions about the videos and whether the content impacted their expectations.

The main hypothesis is that the positive

This study aims to evaluate the effects of transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) on fronto-striatal resting-state functional connectivity in healthy individuals. The study is a randomized, single-blind, parallel-group design, where participants will receive either active tFUS or sham tFUS targeting the nucleus accumbens. The primary outcome measure is the change in resting-state functional connectivity between the stimulation target (nucleus accumbens) and connected brain regions, including the prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, amygdala, and sensory areas, before and after the tFUS intervention. The study will enroll healthy individuals aged 18-65 years old and exclude those with contraindications for MRI, neurological or psychiatric conditions, and other exclusion criteria.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial investigating the effects of semaglutide on intracranial blood flow and blood-brain barrier permeability in individuals with type 2 diabetes. The primary outcome measures are changes in intracranial blood flow, measured as total length and number of distal vessels, and changes in blood-brain barrier permeability, measured by dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI. The secondary outcome measure is changes in inflammatory markers (hsCRP, interleukin-6, and tumor necrosis factor-α). The study will enroll men and women aged 40-65 years with type 2 diabetes for at least 3 years and HbA1C between 7-10%. Participants will be randomized to receive either semaglutide or placebo for 1 year, with a designated diabetes care specialist managing glucose control to achieve HbA1C <7.5% in both groups.

This was a retrospective cross-sectional study that aimed to investigate whether esophagogastric histopathology could guide younger patients (under 50 years old) to undergo colonoscopy earlier. The study included patients younger than 50 years old who underwent simultaneous gastroscopy and colonoscopy. Patients with poor bowel preparation, incomplete examinations, gastrointestinal resection, prior gastrointestinal cancer, hereditary polyposis, or inflammatory bowel diseases were excluded. The primary outcome measure was the prevalence or occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases, including Helicobacter pylori, atrophic gastritis/intestinal metaplasia, reflux esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, peptic ulcer, gastric polyps, low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (LGIN), and high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGIN), within a 1-year time frame.

This study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the outcomes of the screw tent pole technique and the autogenous bone block technique for the augmentation of atrophic anterior maxilla. The primary objective is to assess the amount of bone gain, while the secondary objective is to evaluate the bone quality. The study will include patients with atrophied anterior maxillary area (with initial ridge width of ≤ 5 mm and moderate bone height) and will have two parallel groups: the experimental group receiving the screw tent pole technique and the active comparator group receiving the autogenous bone block technique. The outcomes will be measured at 6 months post-operatively, including bone gain and histomorphometric evaluation of bone quality.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the performance of a CD4/CD8+ interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) for monitoring the response to anti-tuberculosis (TB) treatment. The study will enroll patients with pulmonary TB and healthy controls. The primary outcome is to define the correlation between changes in IFN-γ response in the TB1 and TB2 antigen tubes of the IGRA and the reference standard of treatment response (culture conversion) in smear-positive and smear-negative/culture-positive pulmonary TB cases. The IGRA will be performed at diagnosis, 30 days, 2 months, and at the end of 6-9 months of anti-TB treatment.

The study aims to evaluate the accuracy and reliability of using radiofrequency (RF) and mechanical pinprick stimuli to objectively measure brain responses and assess the state of the nociceptive system. The study will measure the latency and amplitude of evoked potentials (EPs) elicited by RF and pinprick stimuli, as well as changes in pinprick sensation thresholds and conduction velocity of RF stimuli. The study will be conducted in a single group of healthy volunteers aged 18-60 years, using an open-label, non-randomized design. The primary outcome is the latency and amplitude of EPs evoked by RF and pinprick stimuli, measured over a 2-hour period during each experimental setting. Secondary outcomes include changes in pinprick sensation thresholds and conduction velocity of RF stimuli.

The study aims to characterize the biomechanical coupling between the brain and skull in individuals with and without a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) using magnetic resonance elastography (MRE). The study will recruit 25 subjects with a history of mild TBI and traumatic meningeal enhancement (TME+), 25 subjects with a history of mild TBI but no TME (TME-), and 35 healthy controls. The primary outcome is to obtain MRE images and use them to estimate global differences in the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation between the brain and skull. The secondary outcome is to measure local skull-brain coupling using MRE-derived measures of octahedral shear strain, with a focus on the cortical surface. The study will help understand how TBI and associated meningeal injury affect the biomechanical coupling between the brain and skull.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This is a randomized controlled trial to determine the impact of home blood pressure monitoring when used in addition to pharmacist care, compared to usual care, in women with elevated blood pressure. The study aims to recruit 320 women aged 18 and older with uncontrolled hypertension or at risk of hypertension. 

Participants will be randomized to one of two groups:

1. Intervention group: Participants will receive a home blood pressure monitor and enhanced pharmacist care, including monthly follow-ups to review home readings and provide recommendations to the prescribing clinician.

2. Control group: Participants will receive usual pharmacist care, with blood pressure assessments at the pharmacy at baseline, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks. After 24 weeks, they will be offered a home monitor and the opportunity to cross over to the intervention group.

The primary outcome is the difference in change in systolic blood pressure between the two groups at 24 weeks. Secondary outcomes include proportion of participants at blood pressure target, adherence to medications, changes to antihypertensive regimens, lifestyle changes, and patient satisfaction.

This is a multicentre randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of moderate alcohol consumption on heart function in patients who have recently experienced a myocardial infarction. The study will randomize 220 patients to either moderate alcohol consumption (1 standard unit per day) or abstinence (no alcohol) for 12 months. The primary outcome is the change in left ventricular ejection fraction between baseline and 12-month follow-up.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of lactulose for bowel preparation in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-blind trial that compares lactulose oral solution to 3L-polyethylene glycol for bowel preparation. The primary outcome measures are the effective preparation rate (Boston Bowel Preparation Scale ≥ 6 with a partial score ≥ 2 in each colon segment), the incidence of adverse events, and the taste score evaluated by patients. The secondary outcome measures are the effects of the bowel preparation drugs on liver function and serum electrolytes. The study includes patients aged 16-75 years with confirmed or suspected IBD who require a colonoscopy. Patients with active ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease, gastrointestinal obstructions, severe medical conditions, or allergies to the study drugs are excluded.

This study aims to explore the effects of aromatherapy using lavender essential oil on the sleep quality and quality of life of older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community. It is a longitudinal, prospective randomized controlled trial involving 64 elderly participants from two community bases in Hsinchu City, Taiwan. The experimental group received aromatherapy with lavender essential oil, while the control group received a placebo (sweet almond oil). The primary outcome measures are the participants' sleep quality, as assessed by the Chinese version of the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (CPSQI), and their quality of life, as measured by the World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire - Taiwan Version and the World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire - old. The study expects that the older adults in the experimental group using aromatherapy will have better sleep and quality of life compared to the control group using the placebo.

This study aimed to perform a comparative clinical analysis of soft tissue augmentation using a connective tissue graft (CTG) versus a collagen matrix (CM) in patients requiring dental implant placement. 

The study enrolled 32 patients with partial tooth absence and soft tissue thickness deficiency in the distal mandible. Patients were randomly assigned to two groups: Group 1 (n=16) received CTG from the maxillary tuberosity area, and Group 2 (n=16) received the collagen matrix Fibro-Gide. 

The primary outcome was the amount of soft tissue thickness gain at 90 days, measured using an intraoral scanner. Secondary outcomes included soft tissue thickness gain at 180 days, pain assessment, edema, analgesic consumption, quality of life, width of keratinized attached mucosa, and soft tissue aesthetics.

The study used a randomized, parallel-group design with an open-label approach. Patients were followed for 180 days after the surgical procedures.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of intraoral and transcutaneous trigger point injections of botulinum toxin (Botox) in the treatment of myofascial pain. The study will randomize participants to receive either intraoral or transcutaneous injection of Botox into the masseter muscle. The primary outcome measure is pain score assessed on a 10-point visual analogue scale at 6 weeks post-injection. The secondary outcome measure is the Oral Health Impact Profile (OHIP-14) scale, which assesses self-reported discomfort, disability, and functional limitation due to oral conditions, also measured at 6 weeks. The study includes adults aged 18-60 years with a definite diagnosis of myofascial pain and the presence of trigger points in the masseter muscle, excluding those with other factors that can cause orofacial pain or systemic diseases affecting the masticatory system.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This study aims to determine the optimal treatment approach for patients with moderate to severe depression in a primary care setting in a low-resource setting. The study will compare the effectiveness of a brief psychological treatment called the Healthy Activity Program (HAP) and antidepressant medication (fluoxetine) using a precision treatment rule (PTR) developed through machine learning. 

The primary outcome is depression severity measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) at 3 months. Secondary outcomes include cost-effectiveness, depression remission, anxiety, functioning, and well-being at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months. 

The study will enroll adults aged 18 and above with moderate to severe depression attending primary care clinics. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either HAP or fluoxetine. The study aims to optimize treatment by determining which patients are more likely to respond to each intervention.

This study aims to investigate the pulmonary immune cell-microbiome interactions in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will enroll 20 patients with none-to-mild ARDS and 20 patients with moderate-to-severe non-COVID-19 ARDS. Within 72 hours of intubation, and again after 7-10 days if the patient is still intubated, the researchers will collect endotracheal aspirates, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF), oral and nasal swabs, and blood samples. The study will assess the composition of the immune cell population, function and differentiation of various cell lines using single-cell RNA sequencing and bulk RNA sequencing. The composition of the pulmonary microbiome will be evaluated by 16S rRNA gene sequencing. The study will also measure cell differential counts, cytokines, respiratory pathogens, and microorganisms in the collected samples. The goal is to elucidate the relationship between the pulmonary immune cell profile, microbiome, and disease severity in ARDS.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a randomized controlled study that aims to compare the effects of 3D printed foot orthoses and prefabricated foot orthoses in individuals with flexible flatfoot. Healthy adult subjects with flatfoot symptoms will be recruited and randomly assigned to receive either 3D printed orthoses or prefabricated orthoses. Subjective feedback on pain levels and user satisfaction will be collected at baseline and after 4 weeks of use. The primary outcome measures are the Visual Analog Scale for pain and the Quebec User Evaluation of Satisfaction with Assistive Technology questionnaire. Statistical analysis will be used to determine if there is a significant difference in the responses between the two groups, which will help identify which type of orthoses is more effective.

This is a single-center cross-sectional study that aims to compare the pulmonary ventilation function between patients with primary and recurrent incisional hernia. The study included patients diagnosed with abdominal incisional hernia based on physical examination and abdominal CT imaging. Patients were divided into two groups: primary and recurrent, based on whether the incisional hernia recurred after repair. The primary outcome was the recurrence rate after surgical repair. Pulmonary function tests, including pulmonary ventilation function, were the main observation indices. The study excluded patients with other types of abdominal hernias, those with primary incisional hernia less than one year old, and those with incomplete data. Statistical analysis was performed to compare the pulmonary ventilation function between the two groups.

This clinical trial aims to determine the frequency and characteristics of unstable coronary plaques in patients presenting to the emergency department with chest pain suspected of coronary artery disease. The study will use 18F-Na PET scans to identify and monitor the evolution of these unstable plaques in patients categorized as intermediate or high risk based on their coronary artery calcium score. The primary outcomes include describing changes in the calcium score, plaque size, density, morphology, and stenosis diameter, as well as changes in 18F-Na PET binding, over an 8-month period. Secondary outcomes will evaluate the effectiveness of initiating a primary cardiovascular prevention strategy, compare symptom evolution and cardiovascular event rates between the study cohort and a historical control cohort, over 24 months. The study aims to improve the identification and management of patients at risk of rapid coronary disease progression or unstable plaques.

This is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the association between white matter hyperintensity (WMH) shape and abnormalities in small vessel morphology, as well as the relationship between WMH shape, cognition, and novel MRI markers of glymphatics in patients with cerebral small vessel disease (SVD).

The primary objective is to study the association between a more complex WMH shape and structural and functional markers of cerebral SVD, such as lacunes and microbleeds. The secondary objectives are to investigate the association between WMH shape and cognition, as well as the association between SVD markers/cognition and novel glymphatics markers (e.g., size of perivascular spaces, CSF mobility, and 4th ventricle CSF flow dynamics).

The study will include patients from the memory or geriatric clinic, aged 65 years and older, who undergo 3T and 7T MRI scans and neuropsychological assessments. The investigators will analyze the data by performing association analyses to explore the relationships between WMH shape, SVD markers, glymphatics markers, and cognitive function.

The study does not involve any

This is a single-center, case-control, diagnostic study that aims to evaluate the role of an artificial intelligence (AI) system in the endoscopic diagnosis of esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma. The study will compare the diagnostic performance of the AI system with that of endoscopists of different levels. The primary outcome measures include sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value, and accuracy. The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years who meet the inclusion criteria, including pathologically confirmed esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma in the case group and clear benign endoscopic findings in the control group. The study will use an AI-based endoscopic diagnosis system developed and verified using deep learning techniques.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of recombinant human coagulation factor VIII-Fc fusion protein (FRSW107) for injection in pediatric patients with severe hemophilia A.

2. Study Design: Open-label, multicenter, phase III clinical study with a single treatment group. Participants will receive prophylactic treatment with FRSW107 administered every 3 days.

3. Participant Criteria: Children under 12 years old, male, weighing over 10 kg, with clinically confirmed severe hemophilia A. Exclusion criteria include history of allergic reactions, presence of factor VIII inhibitors, and other medical conditions that may increase bleeding or thrombosis risk.

4. Primary Outcome: Annualized bleeding rate (ABR) during the treatment period.

5. Secondary Outcomes: Annualized joint bleeding rate, incidence of adverse events/adverse drug reactions, incidence of positive factor VIII inhibitors, pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax, Tmax), and time to factor VIII activity decline to 10%, 5%,

This study aims to assess the differences in acceptability and feasibility between live music therapy sessions and recorded music therapy sessions in palliative care patients at the University Hospital Zurich. The primary outcome measure is an intervention-specific acceptability questionnaire, while secondary outcome measures include subjective assessments of symptoms, quality of life, anxiety and depression, as well as objective autonomic measures like heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity, and temperature. Patients will be randomized to receive either live music therapy followed by recorded music therapy, or recorded music therapy followed by live music therapy, with assessments conducted immediately before and after each intervention. The study is designed as a monocentric, prospective, repeated measures trial with an open-label approach.

The study aimed to investigate the effect of reusing operative supplies during cataract surgery on the rate of postoperative endophthalmitis and the impact on climate change. The study had two arms:

1. In one arm, the surgeon changed the gown and gloves between each case, with hand sterilization using alcohol before and after. Reusable instruments like keratome, MVR, IOL cartridge, and OVD cannulas were immersed in alcohol between cases. The phaco machine tip was also reused and immersed in alcohol. The same cassette was used for multiple surgeries.

2. In the other arm, the surgeon only changed the gloves, using alcohol for hand sterilization. One gown was used for all cases. For intracameral antibiotic prophylaxis, a diluted solution of Vigamox was used.

The primary outcome measure was the rate of postoperative complications, specifically the occurrence of infection, assessed over a 6-month period.

This is a randomized controlled study investigating the use of deep transcranial magnetic stimulation (dTMS) targeting the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) as a new neuroregulatory treatment for anorexia nervosa (AN). The study aims to evaluate the near-term and long-term efficacy and safety of dTMS treatment in adult patients with AN. 

Patients with AN are randomly assigned to either the dTMS treatment group or the pseudo-stimulation (sham) group in a 1:1 ratio. The dTMS treatment group receives real dTMS targeting the ACC 5 times per week for 6 weeks, while the sham group receives sham dTMS with the same parameters but without the magnetic field. Both groups also receive basic nutritional therapy.

The primary outcome measure is the change in body mass index (BMI) from baseline to various time points during and after the 6-week treatment period. Secondary outcome measures include changes in eating disorder symptoms, depression, anxiety, and obsessive-compulsive symptoms.

The study also plans to explore factors that may predict the efficacy of dTMS treatment in AN patients, using baseline demographic

The study aims to assess the acceptability of expanded newborn screening to parents in France, with or without the use of genetics as the first-line approach. The study involves four participant groups:

1. Parents or co-parents of a newborn child, who will complete an online questionnaire and participate in semi-structured interviews.
2. Parents or co-parents whose youngest child is between 1 week and 3 years old, who will complete an online questionnaire.
3. Parents or co-parents whose child had a suspicious newborn screening result that was confirmed at the diagnosis phase (except hearing), who will participate in semi-structured interviews.
4. Parents or co-parents whose child was diagnosed later based on clinical signs for diseases not included in the French newborn screening list but included in other countries, who will participate in semi-structured interviews.

The primary outcome measure is a mixed matrix of parental acceptability dimensions of expanded newborn screening, using a mixed-method design with quantitative and qualitative data. Secondary outcome measures include parental acceptability scores, a typology of acceptability scores, the importance of different modalities of information about newborn screening, parent opinions on screening for specific conditions, and parents

This is a randomized trial investigating the effects of remote Tai Chi and Qigong rehabilitation on low back pain. The study will enroll adults aged 18 and older who have experienced low back pain for at least 6 weeks. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the Tai Chi and Qigong rehabilitation group or the usual care group. The primary outcome is the change in Oswestry Disability Index at 3 months after the intervention. Secondary outcomes include changes in visual analogue scales for low back and leg pain, the SF-36 health survey, and the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The study is an open-label, parallel-assignment design with a primary purpose of treatment.

This is an observational study that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CD19-directed chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy in people living with HIV (PLWH) who have been treated for B-cell lymphoid malignancies. The study will capture clinical information on PLWH who received CAR19 therapy outside of a clinical trial between August 2017 and August 2021. 

The primary outcome measure is the rate of toxicities related to CAR19 therapy, which will be reported using the Common Terminology for Adverse Events (CTCAE) criteria and the American Society for Transplantation and Cellular Therapy (ASTCT) criteria for cytokine release syndrome. 

The secondary outcome measures include changes in CD4 count, absolute lymphocyte count, and HIV viral load at various time points (day of leukapheresis, 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months post-CAR19 therapy). The study will also assess overall response and complete remission rates at 3 and 6 months.

The study aims to provide important safety and efficacy data on

This is a UK-based observational study that aims to discover novel predictive biomarkers to guide treatment decision-making and improve outcomes in patients with advanced triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). Patients will undergo a mandatory biopsy or fine needle aspiration of their tumor, and the research sample will be analyzed using Pear Bio's test. The study will not use the test results to inform treatment choice, which will be determined by the treating oncologist. The study will evaluate the ability of Pear Bio's organ-on-a-chip platform to predict treatment response, progression-free survival, and overall survival. Key outcome measures include establishing the optimal dose of approved therapies in the Pear Bio system, and assessing the accuracy of the platform in predicting complete response, progression-free survival, and overall survival.

The study aims to conduct a health economic analysis, including quality of life, on the impact of delayed elective surgery in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study will compare two groups: patients waiting for elective surgery and those who have already undergone surgery at Sahlgrenska University Hospital between 2017 and 2021. The primary outcome measure is to assess how health economics, including quality of life, are affected when surgery is delayed. The secondary outcome measures include evaluating socioeconomic differences in delayed surgery and the impact of waiting for surgery on complications and failures. The study excludes patients undergoing cancer surgery and only includes individuals aged 18 years and above.

This clinical trial aims to better characterize the non-immunological pro-tumor functions of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study will assess in vitro the effects of MDSCs extracted from resected NSCLC tumors on the phenotype and function of lung cancer cell lines. The study will enroll consecutive patients with lung carcinoma who underwent surgical treatment without prior chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or immunotherapy. Tumor samples will be collected during surgery, and the primary outcome measure is the comparative analysis of the modifications of phenotype and functions of lung cancer cell lines when exposed to the extracted MDSCs.

This study aims to investigate the impact of substituting unsweetened flavored sparkling water for sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) on sweetness perception, glycemic control, and other metabolic outcomes in overweight and obese adolescents at risk for type 2 diabetes. The study is a prospective, before-and-after cohort study where participants will be provided with unsweetened sparkling water to replace their SSB intake over a 12-week period. The primary outcome measures include changes in 2-hour glucose concentration, dietary consumption of SSBs and sparkling water, insulin sensitivity, and glycemic variability. Secondary outcomes include changes in flavor perception of beverage sweetness, blood pressure, blood triglycerides, and waist circumference. The study aims to provide evidence on the potential benefits of reducing added sugar intake through substitution with unsweetened sparkling water in an adolescent population at high risk for type 2 diabetes.

This is a randomized, double-blinded, prospective study to evaluate the early wound healing after the use of NOVOSYN® Quick versus MONOSYN® Quick suture materials in resective periodontal surgery. The primary outcome measure is the early wound healing score (EHS) assessed at 10 ± 5 days postoperatively. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of postoperative complications such as wound dehiscence, dentinal hypersensitivity, oral candidiasis, angular cheilitis, swelling, bleeding, and infection. Other secondary measures are the assessment of pain, patient satisfaction, bacterial contamination of the suture, and the handling of the suture material. Adult patients undergoing resective periodontal surgery are eligible, and they will be randomly assigned to receive either NOVOSYN® Quick or MONOSYN® Quick sutures.

This is a small, single-center, randomized, controlled clinical study investigating the use of Coenzyme I for Injection in the treatment of sudden sensorineural hearing loss. 

The study recruited patients with sudden hearing deafness and randomly divided them into an experimental group receiving Coenzyme I for Injection plus conventional treatment, and a control group receiving conventional treatment alone for 14 days. 

The primary outcome measures were pure tone average (PTA) at baseline and on days 3, 7, 14, 30, and 90 of treatment. Secondary outcome measures included speech recognition rate, Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) for tinnitus, and VAS for ear fullness, assessed at the same timepoints.

The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Coenzyme I for Injection in improving hearing outcomes and reducing tinnitus and ear fullness in patients with sudden sensorineural hearing loss.

This study aims to establish the scientific basis for including genetic newborn screening for cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria (PH) in the routine newborn screening program in Germany. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Cystinosis: Nephropathic cystinosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by renal Fanconi syndrome and progressive kidney failure. Early diagnosis and treatment with cysteamine can help preserve kidney function. The study will use multiplex PCR and next-generation sequencing to screen for common CTNS mutations.

2. Primary Hyperoxaluria (PH): PH is a group of rare genetic disorders leading to the accumulation of oxalate crystals in the kidneys and other organs. The study will screen for the most common mutations in the AGXT and HOGA1 genes associated with PH1 and PH3.

3. Study Design: This is a single-arm, open-label pilot study that will screen newborns whose parents provide informed consent. The primary outcomes are the number of newborns identified with confirmed cystinosis and PH, as well as those with heterozygous mutations.

This is a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of negative pressure drainage on reducing surgical site infection (SSI) in patients undergoing intra-abdominal surgery. Patients will be randomly assigned to either receive negative pressure drainage or no drainage. The primary outcome is the rate of SSI at postoperative days 3, 5, 7, and 14. Secondary outcomes include length of hospital stay and quality of life. Patients aged 18 years or older undergoing clean-contaminated or contaminated abdominal surgery will be eligible for the study. The negative pressure drainage will be placed in the surgical wound after completion of surgery and before skin closure, and will be removed if fluid content is less than 20 ml per day. The study will evaluate and collect data through physical examination and follow-up at 14 and 30 days after discharge.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study that aims to compare the immune modulation effects of three FDA-approved CDK4/6 inhibitors (palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib) in combination with the endocrine therapy letrozole in patients with early-stage, estrogen receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer. The primary outcome is the assessment of changes in immune-related gene expression signatures in tumor samples collected before, during, and after treatment. The secondary outcome is the evaluation of adverse events. Eligible patients will be randomly assigned to receive one of the three CDK4/6 inhibitor regimens in combination with letrozole in a neoadjuvant setting. The study will collect tumor, blood, and stool samples to comprehensively evaluate the immune modulation effects of the different CDK4/6 inhibitors.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The overarching goal is to develop and test the feasibility of implementing a dementia care intervention called "Dementia Care Quality at Home" in two home-based primary care (HBPC) practices. The intervention aims to improve outcomes for people living with dementia (PLWD) and their caregivers.

2. The study will evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity of implementing the intervention in the HBPC practices, as well as the feasibility of caregivers engaging with the intervention and its impact on caregiver well-being.

3. The intervention includes a standardized assessment tool, seven educational modules for PLWD and caregivers, and a team-based approach to address care challenges.

4. The primary outcome measures are focused on assessing the feasibility of caregiver engagement, practice identification of eligible participants, and use of patient/caregiver assessments.

5. The study will enroll adult caregivers (18+ years) who live with and provide care for individuals with Alzheimer's disease or related dementias, and are part of the HBPC practices.

The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of resistance training and flexibility training on self-efficacy, symptoms, and maternal quality of life in postpartum women with depression. The study will recruit 36 postpartum women aged 20-40 years, 6 weeks to 8 months after childbirth, and divide them into two groups: one receiving resistance training and the other receiving flexibility training, both twice a week for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measures are exercise self-efficacy, depression symptoms, and maternal postpartum quality of life, which will be assessed at baseline and after 8 weeks of intervention. The study aims to determine the comparative effectiveness of these two exercise interventions in improving the physical, mental, and quality of life outcomes in postpartum women with depression.

This is a cross-over clinical study that aims to evaluate the surface hardness and wear resistance of prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth used in complete dentures. The study includes completely edentulous participants aged 55-65 years with Angle's class I maxillomandibular relations. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either a complete denture with prefabricated artificial teeth or a complete denture with CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth. After 3-6 months of use, the surface hardness will be measured using the Vickers test, and the wear resistance will be assessed through 2D, 3D, and volumetric wear measurements using denture scanning and software analysis. The primary outcome measures are the wear resistance and surface hardness of the denture artificial teeth at 6 months of use.

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy of trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd) versus standard neoadjuvant treatment (TCHP or PCHP) for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. 

The primary outcome is the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate in the HER2-enriched molecular subtype population. Secondary outcomes include pCR rates in other molecular subtypes, event-free survival, overall survival, objective response rates, residual cancer burden, rates of breast-conserving surgery, and safety/tolerability.

Patients will be randomized to receive either T-DXd or standard neoadjuvant therapy (TCHP or PCHP) for the first 3 cycles. Further treatment from cycles 4-6 will be determined based on the molecular intrinsic subtype of the tumor (HER2-enriched, ER-positive/luminal, ER-negative/luminal/basal-like/normal-like).

The study aims to evaluate whether T-DXd can improve pCR and other clinical outcomes compared to standard

The study aims to compare the effects of intraoperative use of intravenous anesthetic propofol and inhaled anesthetic sevoflurane on the prognosis of patients undergoing surgery for primary brain, liver, lung, and ovarian cancer tumors, and to investigate the underlying mechanism of action.

The study is a randomized, triple-masked, parallel-assignment clinical trial. Eligible patients aged 20-80 years with ASA class I-III undergoing elective surgery for the specified cancer types will be randomly assigned to receive either propofol or sevoflurane anesthesia. 

The primary outcome measures are overall survival at 6 months, 1 year, and 3 years, and the presence of disease progression. Secondary outcomes include postoperative complications, Karnofsky performance status score, and length of hospital stay.

The study aims to provide insights into the potential differential effects of propofol and sevoflurane anesthesia on cancer prognosis and survival, which may have important implications for anesthetic management in oncological surgeries.

This is a cluster-randomized controlled trial (cRCT) that aims to disseminate physical activity-related health competence (PAHCO) in the vocational education of nursing care. The study will evaluate three different approaches to implementing PAHCO curriculum content in nursing schools in Bavaria, Germany:

1. Cooperative planning for promoting PAHCO, where a participative intervention concept is developed with actors from science and practice.

2. Expert-based intervention for promoting PAHCO delivered by external physical activity specialists.

3. Expert-based intervention for promoting PAHCO delivered by teachers.

The primary outcomes are short-term and medium-term changes in PAHCO, psychological movement quality, and quality of physical activity. Secondary outcomes include general health status, work ability, musculoskeletal complaints, and physical job stress in nursing. The study will involve 16 nursing schools and their first-year students, with measurements taken at baseline, post-intervention (1 year), and follow-up (2 years).

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial evaluating the effects of a combination of Diosmin/Hesperidin (Daflon) with or without Metformin and combined oral contraceptives on clinical outcomes in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The primary outcome measures are the improvement of inflammation (IL-6) and glycemic index (fasting insulin, HOMA-IR) at 4 months. The secondary outcome measures are the improvement of PCOS status (signs, symptoms, hormone levels) and patient's quality of life at 4 months. The study includes three intervention arms: 1) Metformin + combined oral contraceptive, 2) Diosmin/Hesperidin + combined oral contraceptive, and 3) Diosmin/Hesperidin + Metformin + combined oral contraceptive.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

The study aims to develop a fluorescent visualization system using the near-infrared (NIR) dye Cetuximab-IRDye800 to improve the detection of non-visible lung cancer nodules during minimally invasive surgical procedures. The primary objective is to evaluate the proportion of patients with detection of lung nodules during surgery using the NIR camera, compared to pathology findings. 

Secondary objectives include evaluating the detection of lymph node metastases, unexpected cancer localizations, negative surgical margins, detection speed, and incidence of toxicity. The study is an open-label, single-arm trial enrolling patients with clinical stage I non-small cell lung cancer who are candidates for minimally invasive surgical resection. Participants will receive an infusion of Cetuximab-IRDye800 2-5 days prior to surgery.

The key aspects captured in this summary are the study objectives, design, intervention, and outcome measures. The summary provides a concise overview of the critical elements of the clinical trial.

The key aspects of the SPARROW clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To evaluate the additional value of pre-emptive antibiotic treatment on clinically relevant organ/space surgical site infections (OSIs) in patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy with a high risk for contaminated bile.

2. Study Design: Multicenter, randomized controlled, superiority trial comparing perioperative versus pre-emptive antibiotic treatment during five postoperative days after pancreatoduodenectomy in high-risk patients.

3. Participants: Adult patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy with a high risk for contaminated bile (preoperative biliary drainage or ampullary malignancy).

4. Interventions: 
   - Experimental arm: Perioperative prophylaxis plus 5 days of cefuroxime and metronidazole.
   - Control arm: Perioperative prophylaxis only.

5. Primary Outcome: Rate of clinically relevant OSIs within 90 days after surgery requiring therapeutic intervention.

6. Secondary Outcomes: Rates of OSIs, isolated OSIs,

This is a Phase 2 basket trial that evaluates the efficacy of a combination of the oral drug sotorasib and the intravenous monoclonal antibody panitumumab in patients with advanced solid tumors carrying the KRAS G12C mutation. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate based on RECIST v1.1 criteria, assessed at imaging time points after Cycle 1 Day 1 (each cycle is 14 days). Eligible patients must have consented to the KOSMOS-II observational master study, be 19 years or older, have histologically confirmed locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors (excluding non-small cell lung cancer and colorectal cancer) with the KRAS G12C mutation, have measurable lesions, and meet certain criteria for adequate bone marrow, liver, and renal function. Patients with active brain metastasis, significant cardiovascular events, or other malignancies within the past 2 years are excluded.

This is a randomized clinical trial that evaluates the use of a novel volume-stable collagen matrix (VCMX) in the treatment of single gingival recession associated with non-carious cervical lesions that are partially restored. 

The study has two treatment arms:
1. Partial restoration (PR) + Coronally Advanced Flap (CAF)
2. PR + CAF + VCMX

The primary outcome measure is recession reduction (RecRed) at 180 days. Secondary outcome measures include dentine hypersensitivity, patient-centered esthetic evaluation, Oral Health Impact Profile, patient discomfort, number of analgesics used, percentage of complete combined defect coverage, modification of the root coverage esthetic score, and various clinical parameters.

The study includes adult participants (20-60 years old) who are systemically healthy, have no active periodontal disease, and have a specific type of gingival recession associated with a non-carious cervical lesion on a vital canine or premolar tooth. Patients with a history of periodontal surgery in the study area, smokers, pregnant/lactating women, and those
