This is a non-randomized, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effects of different nutritional support methods based on nutritional risk screening on the postoperative nutritional status of patients with gastrointestinal cancer. 

The study enrolled 302 patients with gastrointestinal tumors, who were divided into an intervention group (NRS2002≥3 and PG-SGA≥4, n=204) and a control group (NRS2002<3 or PG-SGA<4, n=98) based on nutritional risk screening. 

The intervention group received a malnutrition five-step treatment model plus conventional nutritional intervention, while the control group received only conventional nutritional intervention. 

The study measured primary outcomes of nutritional risk screening (NRS2002) and patient-generated subjective nutrition assessment (PG-SGA) at baseline and through study completion (average of 1 year). Secondary outcomes included dietary energy and protein intake, total energy and protein intake, laboratory markers (prealbumin, albumin, hemog

This is a randomized, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effect of the abutment-prosthesis connection on marginal bone loss and gingival sealing around dental implants. The study will compare the use of a Connect® abutment versus a conventional multi-unit abutment in the restoration of multiple implants. The primary outcome measure is the marginal bone level around the implants at 1 year. Secondary outcomes include the peri-implant microbiome and inflammation. The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years with partially edentulous mandibles requiring at least 2 implants to restore posterior teeth. Patients with certain medical conditions and those requiring simultaneous bone augmentation will be excluded.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the clinical feasibility of a wearable ultrasound patch for non-invasive monitoring of blood flow in the brain, in comparison to the conventional transcranial Doppler probe.

2. The study will recruit 60 participants with a broad range of physiological parameters, and measure the blood flow spectrum in various arterial segments using both the wearable ultrasound patch and the conventional transcranial Doppler probe.

3. The primary outcome measure is the agreement between the two devices on the peak systolic velocity, mean flow velocity, and end diastolic velocity, which will be evaluated using Bland-Altman plots.

4. The study population includes adults aged 18 years and above, and accepts healthy volunteers. Exclusion criteria include history of certain medical conditions such as heart attack, low blood pressure, and eye diseases.

5. The study duration is 1.5 years.

This is a single-arm clinical trial that aims to evaluate the clearance rate of uremic toxins by hemodiafiltration with endogenous reinfusion (HFR) in maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients. The primary outcome measures are the concentrations of β2-microglobulin (β2-MG), indoxyl sulfate, and λ-free light chain (λFLC) before and after HFR treatment. The secondary outcome measures include single-compartment urea clearance index (spKt/V), urea reduction ratio, concentrations of other middle molecules and macromolecular uremic toxins, serum albumin, branched-chain amino acids, vitamins A/C/E, and the comfort of HFR treatment. Eligible participants are MHD patients aged 18-75 years with stable vascular access and adequate dialysis adequacy (spKt/V≥1.2). Patients with severe comorbidities or recent acute events are excluded. The study has a single-group assignment design with an open-label intervention of HFR treatment.

This is a randomized, controlled, open-label, multi-center clinical trial investigating the effect of multi-kinase inhibitors (including sorafenib, lenvatinib, and donafenib) combined with bevacizumab on recurrence, survival, and safety in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) at high risk of recurrence after liver transplantation.

The primary outcome measure is the one-year recurrence-free survival rate. Secondary outcome measures include recurrence-free survival duration, overall survival, two-year and three-year recurrence-free survival rates, graft survival, quality of life, and the incidence of adverse events and serious adverse events.

The study includes patients aged 18 to 75 years who have undergone liver transplantation within the preceding 4 to 8 weeks and have a confirmed diagnosis of HCC with at least one high-risk factor, such as exceeding the Milan criteria, major vascular invasion, microvascular invasion, satellite nodules, or recurrence after prior liver resection.

Eligible participants will be randomized to receive either multi-kinase inhibitors (sorafenib, len

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a pragmatic trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a weekly supportive-expressive group therapy (SEGT) intervention for improving mental health outcomes in inpatients with limb loss at a rehabilitation hospital in Toronto, Canada. The trial will compare the SEGT intervention to treatment as usual (TAU), which may include referrals to social work and/or psychiatry. 

The primary outcome measures are changes in depression (Patient Health Questionnaire-9) and anxiety (Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item) scores from baseline to discharge and 3-month follow-up. Secondary outcomes include changes in PTSD symptoms (PTSD Checklist-5) and self-efficacy (Generalized Self-Efficacy Scale).

Over 2 years, 130 inpatients will be recruited and randomized to either the SEGT intervention or TAU. The SEGT intervention is a 6-session program delivered by an interprofessional team and adapted to address the needs of limb loss patients. Participants will complete assessments at baseline, discharge, and

The key aspects of the clinical trial document are:

1. Aim and Objective: To study the effects of 20% human albumin infusions on coagulation parameters in patients with decompensated cirrhosis of the liver.

2. Study Design: Single-center, open-label, randomized controlled trial.

3. Participant Eligibility: Inclusion criteria - Age ≥ 18 years and ≤ 70 years, decompensated cirrhosis of any cause, serum albumin ≤ 2.5 g/dl, and written informed consent. Exclusion criteria include patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure, advanced hepatocellular carcinoma, and other medical conditions.

4. Interventions: Experimental group - 20% human albumin solution infusion to maintain serum albumin levels above 3.0 g/dl. Control group - Standard of care.

5. Primary Outcome Measures: Changes in coagulation parameters based on ROTEM, including clotting time, clot formation time, and maximum clot formation.

6. Secondary Outcome Measures: Changes

This is a prospective study that enrolled 65 patients with potentially resectable stage III non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) without EGFR/ALK mutations. The study aims to evaluate the significance of minimal residual disease (MRD) monitoring in these patients. Patients underwent neoadjuvant therapy, surgery (if applicable), and adjuvant therapy, with blood samples collected at multiple timepoints for MRD analysis using a personalized monitoring test. The primary outcome measure is disease-free survival (DFS), and secondary outcomes include overall survival (OS), the ability of MRD to predict recurrence, pathological complete response (pCR) rate in MRD-negative patients, and 2-year DFS in MRD-negative patients. The study enrolled patients over 1 year and followed them for 2 years.

This is a single-center, prospective cohort study that compares the use of ciprofol and propofol for sedation in hypotensive ICU patients. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients meeting the RASS sedation target within 24 hours. Secondary outcome measures include dosage of propofol or ciprofol and norepinephrine, duration of mechanical ventilation, incidence of adverse events, length of ICU stay, and mortality rate. The study includes adult ICU patients (age ≥18 years) requiring vasopressors to maintain mean arterial pressure ≥65 mmHg and sedation for comfort, safety, and life support. Patients with certain neurological conditions, allergies, or prior long-term use of benzodiazepines or opioids are excluded. Participants are assigned to either the ciprofol or propofol group for sedation management.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a pilot, multicenter, randomized, controlled, superiority trial that evaluates the short-term inflammatory response in premature infants with complicated necrotizing enterocolitis (ECUN) who undergo either laparoscopy plus laparotomy or laparotomy alone. 

The primary outcome is the change in C-reactive protein levels between day 0 and day 2 after surgery. Secondary outcomes include postoperative inflammatory markers, mortality, intestinal morbidity, reoperation rate, length of hospital stay, and neurological outcomes. The tolerance of laparoscopy is also evaluated through intraoperative cardiorespiratory parameters and the presence of local lesions.

Premature infants (<37 weeks gestation) with complicated ECUN requiring surgical treatment will be randomized 1:1 to the two treatment groups. The trial aims to determine if the addition of laparoscopy to laparotomy can reduce the inflammatory response compared to laparotomy alone in this patient population.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of intense pulsed light (IPL) and diode laser for hair removal in the axillary region of women. The study will involve 4 monthly treatment sessions, with follow-up assessments at 30 days and 6 months after the last session. The primary outcome measures are hair count and Global Aesthetic Improvement Scale (GAIS). Secondary outcome measures include hair thickness, pain score, quality of life, satisfaction level, and self-esteem. Eligible participants are women aged 18 and older with Fitzpatrick skin phototypes I to IV and dark hair in the axillary region. Patients with certain medical conditions or who have used certain medications or hair removal methods recently are excluded. The study uses a parallel assignment design with double-blinding.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to assess the evolution of plasma brain-derived tau (BD-tau) levels in patients with acute ischemic stroke due to large- or medium-vessel occlusion within 9 hours of symptom onset.

2. The primary outcome is to characterize the time point when plasma BD-tau levels start to rise after onset, the type of rise (linear, exponential, or logarithmic), and until when plasma BD-tau levels continue to rise.

3. Secondary outcomes include imaging-based metrics of brain injury (ASPECTS, ischemic core volume, collateral score), final infarct volume, infarct progression, functional outcomes at 7 and 90 days, and occurrence of early recurrent ischemic stroke, secondary intracerebral hemorrhage, and hemorrhagic transformation.

4. The study will enroll 100 patients and measure plasma BD-tau levels every hour from admission to 48 hours after stroke onset.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in accelerating the learning curve for radiologists in interpreting contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) of thyroid nodules. The study includes a training set, an internal test set, and an external test set of patients with thyroid nodules who underwent CEUS and fine-needle aspiration biopsy. The primary outcome measures are the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve, the number of cases assessed by faculty, and the time taken to assess the cases, all measured at 1, 3, and 6 months of the trainees' rotation. The study aims to determine if AI can assist radiologists in extracting relevant ultrasound features of thyroid nodules and improve their learning curve in interpreting CEUS.

This study aims to quantify the perceptual experiences of patients with retinal and cortical visual prostheses. The investigators will produce visual percepts in these patients either by directly stimulating electrodes or by converting computer/projector screen images into electrical pulse trains. They will test different stimulus encoding methods, including computer vision and machine learning techniques, to support simple perceptual and behavioral tasks such as object recognition and navigation. 

The primary outcome measures are: 1) the effect of stimulation strategy on the shape of phosphenes (perceived light spots) elicited by electrical stimulation, 2) the effect of stimulation strategy on the ability to discriminate patterns, and 3) the effect of stimulation strategy on the ability to locate objects of interest and describe the visual scene. 

The study will include both visual prosthesis users and sighted control subjects. Eligible participants must be at least 18 years old, have the cognitive and communication ability to participate, and be able to travel to the testing facility for 3-5 days of testing.

This is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the use of ultrasound surveillance of regional lymph node basins in patients with primary high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) of the head and neck. The study includes three participant groups based on the Brigham and Women's Hospital (BWH) staging of their cSCC:

1. BWH stage T2a tumors in patients who are on chronic immunosuppression (organ transplant, hematologic malignancy, autoimmune disease): These patients will undergo ultrasound surveillance of lymph node basins every 6 months.

2. BWH stage T2b tumors: These patients will first undergo CT imaging of the nodal basin, and if negative, they will undergo sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB). If the SLNB is negative, they will be enrolled in the ultrasound surveillance group.

3. BWH stage T3 tumors: These patients will also first undergo CT imaging of the nodal basin, and if negative, they will undergo SLNB. If the SLNB is negative, they will be enrolled in the ultrasound

This is a diagnostic study that aims to investigate salivary biomarkers of gastroesophageal reflux (GER) in infants. The study will enroll infants with reflux symptoms who are undergoing 24-hour esophageal multichannel intraluminal impedance and pH (MII-pH) monitoring. Saliva samples will be collected from these infants at defined time points during the MII-pH procedure to analyze the biochemical profile, including pepsin, pepsinogen, electrolytes, and potential circadian variations. A control group of healthy infants will also provide a single saliva sample. The primary outcome is to identify the prevalence of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in the cohort of infants with reflux symptoms. The secondary outcomes are to detect differences in the salivary biochemical profile between healthy, GER, and GERD infants, and to correlate any changes in the profile with the onset of symptoms and nutrition.

The study aims to compare the effect of the antidiabetic medications Dulaglutide (a GLP-1 receptor agonist) and Empagliflozin (an SGLT2 inhibitor) on liver fat fraction in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). 

The primary outcome measures are:
1. Change in liver fat fraction as measured by MRI-PDFF after 52 weeks of treatment.
2. Percentage of participants in each group who achieve >30% reduction in liver fat fraction.

The secondary outcome measures include changes in HbA1c, body mass index, and various liver fibrosis indices (FLI, FIB-4, APRI, NFS) after 52 weeks of treatment.

The study is a prospective, open-label, observational trial with three arms: Empagliflozin group, Dulaglutide group, and a control group receiving other optimal antidiabetic treatment (excluding GLP-1 agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors). The study will be conducted in Greece

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to assess the feasibility and compare the outcomes of two surgical techniques for the exposure of palatally impacted upper canines:

1. Surgical exposure using a custom-made surgical template (test group)
2. Conventional free-hand surgical exposure (control group)

The primary outcome measures are the success of the intervention (ability to bond an attachment to the impacted tooth) and the success of the open eruption technique (whether the canine erupts in the correct position). 

Secondary outcome measures include the additional costs of the surgical planning and manufacturing the template, the duration of the surgical intervention, postoperative pain, and intra- and postoperative complications.

The study includes patients aged 11-18 years old who require surgical exposure and orthodontic eruption of palatally impacted canines. Patients with certain medical conditions, dental abnormalities, and non-compliance are excluded.

The study uses a parallel assignment design with single masking, where the examiner evaluating the outcomes is blinded to the surgical technique used.

The key aspects of the CAVEAT trial are:

1. This is a feasibility study to determine if the manualized brief psychotherapy "Clinician Assisted Videofeedback Exposure Approach Therapy (CAVEAT)" can be administered to violence-exposed mothers and their young children (ages 1-5 years) in an outpatient clinic setting.

2. The study aims to assess the feasibility of recruitment, treatment adherence, appropriateness of evaluation measures, and feasibility of administering CAVEAT for therapists.

3. CAVEAT is a 16-session psychotherapy that combines elements from existing evidence-based therapies for traumatized parents and children, including video-feedback techniques.

4. The study population is biological mothers of infants and young children (12-54 months) who have experienced interpersonal violence, with the goal of improving maternal sensitivity, perspective-taking, and parent-child relationships.

5. This is an open-label, single-arm feasibility study without a control group. The primary outcome is treatment satisfaction, and secondary outcomes include parenting stress and maternal attributions.

This study aims to reduce the risk of Type 2 diabetes (T2D) and pre-diabetes in Asian women with a history of gestational diabetes (GDM) and their children in Singapore. It is a 1-year randomized controlled trial with 3 years of follow-up. 

The primary outcome is the incidence of T2D confirmed by oral glucose tolerance test over 4 years. Secondary outcomes include changes in cardiometabolic variables, mental well-being, and health of the participants' children.

Eligible women will be randomized to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will receive a smartphone-based holistic lifestyle program (diet, physical activity, mental well-being) delivered by a conversational agent, along with an activity-tracking wearable and an app to monitor health data. The control group will receive the activity-tracking wearable and health monitoring app only.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of the digital lifestyle intervention in improving glucose regulation, cardiometabolic health, and mental well-being in post-GDM women, as well as the potential impacts on their children's health.

The study examined the effects of dry heat and dry cold application on pain, anxiety, and fear levels in school-age children during blood sample collection. The study had three groups: a dry heat application group, a dry cold application group, and a control group. In the dry heat group, a 42°C dry heat was applied to the blood draw site for 5 minutes. In the dry cold group, dry cold was applied to the site for 3 minutes. The control group received routine care without any temperature application. The primary outcome was pain measured by the Wong Baker Faces Pain Rating Scale. Secondary outcomes included fear measured by the Child Fear Scale, anxiety measured by the Child Anxiety Scale, and overall fear of medical procedures measured by the Medical Procedures Fear Inventory. Measurements were taken before and after the blood draw. The study included healthy children aged 7-12 years and used a randomized, parallel-group design.

This is a phase I clinical trial that evaluates the safety and efficacy of intra-arterial melphalan chemoreduction followed by ruthenium-106 plaque brachytherapy in patients with large choroidal melanomas (≥8 mm thickness). 

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Intervention: Patients will receive 7.5 mg of intra-arterial melphalan, followed by ruthenium-106 plaque brachytherapy 4±1 weeks later.

2. Primary Outcome: Determination of treatment safety through electroretinography (ERG) at baseline, 1, 3, and 6 months.

3. Secondary Outcomes: Tumor size reduction, best corrected visual acuity (BCVA), signs of intraocular inflammation, treatment-related adverse events, and globe salvage rate.

4. Eligibility: Patients aged ≥18 years with choroidal melanoma ≥8 mm thick, excluding those with tumors >18 mm in diameter or with medical/psychological conditions preventing informed consent.

5. Study Design: Single

The study aims to establish a trauma registry in a general hospital in Villavicencio, Colombia, during the first semester of 2023. It is an observational retrospective trial that will collect data on patients admitted to the emergency ward due to trauma, including both blunt and penetrating injuries. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients who died, either during hospitalization or within the first 28 days. Secondary outcome measures include the length of hospital stay, the need for and duration of ICU admission and mechanical ventilation. The study does not involve any therapeutic or diagnostic interventions, as it is purely observational in nature. The goal is to gather essential information about the incidence, mechanisms, and outcomes of trauma in the local population, which can inform policies, resource allocation, and clinical practice guidelines to improve trauma care and prevention.

The study is a feasibility trial of a non-invasive postural therapy (NIPT) for older adult veterans with lumbosacral spinal stenosis. The primary outcome measure is the change in mobility as measured by actigraph at week 6 compared to baseline. Eligible participants are veterans aged 60-80 years with lumbar spinal stenosis who have not had prior back surgery. Participants will receive a coordinated suite of durable medical equipment and training to support continuous maintenance of a flexed posture during the 6-week trial. All participants will wear actigraphs and pedometers and complete questionnaires and mobility assessments.

This is a pilot study to assess the effects of self-administered nitrous oxide (SANO) on urodynamic study (UDS) parameters. The study will enroll participants aged 21 to 85 years who are scheduled for a UDS procedure. Participants will be randomized to receive either SANO during the first UDS run and oxygen during the second run, or oxygen during the first run and SANO during the second run. The primary outcome measure is bladder capacity, measured at the time of maximum fill during each UDS run. Secondary outcome measures include intra-UDS pain and anxiety, post-void residual, maximum flow rate, detrusor overactivity, and detrusor pressure at maximum flow. Participants will also be interviewed about their experience with the UDS procedure. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of using SANO to improve patient comfort and experience during the UDS procedure.

This study aims to investigate the relationship between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), adaptation, and quality of life in women with breast cancer in remission. The primary outcome is the quality of life of these women, assessed using the Short Form Survey 12 (SF-12) scale. The secondary outcomes include fear of cancer recurrence, fatigue, anxiety and depression, attachment styles, resilience, and biological measures such as gene expression and epigenetic markers related to chronic stress. The study includes an exploratory biological component to identify gene expression variations and epigenetic changes associated with vulnerability or protection in relation to ACEs. Eligible participants are women over 18 years old who have had breast cancer, are in remission, and are able to complete the study questionnaires independently. The study does not include healthy volunteers.

The study aims to assess the real-world effectiveness of the Discovery AI-assisted polyp detector system in improving polyp and adenoma detection rates during screening colonoscopy, and to compare the results between expert and non-expert endoscopists.

The study is a single-center, crossover trial involving adults aged 45 years or older referred for screening colonoscopy. Participants will undergo two consecutive colonoscopies: one with standard high-definition (HD) colonoscopy, and one with HD colonoscopy assisted by the AI-based polyp detector. The order of the interventions will be randomized.

The primary outcome measures are the adenoma detection rate (ADR) and polyp detection rate (PDR), which will be compared between expert and non-expert endoscopists. The diagnostic performance of the AI-assisted polyp detector, including sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive values, and observer agreement, will also be assessed.

The secondary outcome measure is the adenoma miss rate (AMR), determined by the number of missed adenomas on the initial examination.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to investigate the tolerability, seizure frequency, gut microbiome, and metabolic changes in pregnant people with epilepsy who follow a low-glycemic index (LGI) diet compared to those on a standard diet.

2. Pregnant participants up to 20 weeks gestation with a diagnosis of focal or generalized epilepsy will be enrolled. They will either follow the LGI diet with dietitian support or continue their standard diet.

3. The primary outcome is the tolerability of the LGI diet, measured by the number of participants able to continue the diet during pregnancy.

4. Secondary outcomes include seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolic pathway alterations, which will be assessed through questionnaires, stool and blood samples collected during the intervention and up to 3 months postpartum.

5. The study has a non-randomized, parallel assignment design, with an experimental group on the LGI diet and a control group on a standard diet.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. This is a feasibility study to evaluate the use of mesothelin (MSLN)-targeted chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy as a neoadjuvant treatment in patients with resectable pancreatic cancer.

2. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of major pathologic response in the resected pancreatic tumor specimen after the MSLN-targeted CAR-T cell treatment.

3. Secondary outcome measures include radiological response, rate of R0 surgical resection, incidence of serious adverse events, and disease-free and overall survival.

4. The study will enroll patients aged 18-70 years with histologically confirmed resectable pancreatic cancer and adequate organ function. Patients with certain exclusion criteria such as active infection, severe organ dysfunction, or prior malignancies will be excluded.

5. This is an open-label, single-arm study where all enrolled patients will receive endoscopic ultrasound-guided injection of MSLN-targeted CAR-T cells as the intervention.

The study aims to assess the efficacy of a web-based decision support system (DSS) called TREAT in promoting adherence to oral anticancer treatments among a sample of 100 metastatic breast cancer (MBC) patients over a 3-month period. The primary objective is to evaluate the effectiveness of the DSS and a machine learning web application in enhancing adherence to oral anticancer treatments. The secondary objectives are to identify clinical, psychological, and quality of life factors that predict adherence to oral anticancer treatments among MBC patients, and to enhance an initial version of a machine learning model developed in a previous retrospective study. The study is designed as a 3-month randomized controlled trial, with 50 patients in the experimental group receiving the TREAT DSS and 50 patients in the control group receiving standard medical advice. Adherence is assessed by calculating the number of pills taken divided by the prescribed amount. The study also collects data on clinical, psychological, and quality of life variables using validated questionnaires.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of weight-bearing exercises and Jaffrey's core stability exercises on dynamic balance and trunk muscle strength in children with Down Syndrome. The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial. Eligible participants are children aged 4 to 10 years with a medical diagnosis of Down Syndrome, who are able to stand and walk. The primary outcome measures are the Pediatric Balance Scale and the Trunk Control Measurement Scale, assessed at 4 weeks. The two experimental arms involve either weight-bearing exercises or Jaffrey's core stability exercises.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, quadruple-masked clinical trial investigating the effects of melatonin supplementation on various cardiovascular, bone metabolism, and quality of life parameters in patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis. The primary outcome measures include serum levels of lipoprotein-a, malondialdehyde, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1, glucose, pentosidine, carboxy-methyl lysine, procollagen 1 intact N-terminal propeptide, osteoprotegerin, tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b, receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B ligand, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, triglycerides, total cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, and scores on quality of life, depression, and sleep quality questionnaires. Secondary outcome measures include serum albumin, calcium, phosphorus, and intact parathyroid hormone levels. The study will be conducted over 10 weeks, with participants randomized to receive either melatonin (5 mg daily) or a placebo.

This is a clinical trial that aims to optimize oxygen delivery during cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The study will enroll patients aged 18 years and above who are scheduled for elective cardiac surgery at the University Hospital of Lille, France. The primary outcome is the measurement of oxygen delivery (DO2) calculated using the CONNECT software and hemoglobin values during CPB. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of postoperative acute kidney injury, delirium, and vital status up to 28 days. The study will use a standard CPB protocol, and patient management will be left to the discretion of the anesthesiologist.

The study aims to investigate the changes in skin surface temperature of the lumbar region during auricular acupressure at the Kidney point in healthy volunteers. The study uses a crossover design, where participants are randomly assigned to two groups: one receiving auricular acupressure (AA) first followed by sham auricular acupressure (SA), and the other group receiving SA first followed by AA. The primary outcome measures are the changes in temperature of the left and right lumbar regions, which are recorded using an infrared thermal imaging camera. The secondary outcome measure is the proportion of auricular acupuncture side effects. The study includes healthy volunteers aged 18 to 30 years old and excludes individuals with certain medical conditions or recent treatments that may affect body temperature.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial to compare three different strategies of mean arterial pressure (MAP) management during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) in cardiac surgery. The three treatment groups are:

1. Standard MAP: MAP values between 50-60 mmHg (control group)
2. High MAP: MAP values between 70-80 mmHg 
3. Patient-tailored MAP: MAP comparable to the patient's pre-operative MAP

The primary outcome is the peak serum lactate value (Lmax) measured during CPB, as an indicator of tissue hypoperfusion. Secondary outcomes include the area under the curve of serum lactate, number of cases with lactate >3 mmol/L, intraoperative cerebral and pulmonary perfusion, low cardiac output syndrome, postoperative left ventricular ejection fraction, acute kidney injury, gastrointestinal ischemia, and in-hospital and 30-day mortality.

The study plans to enroll 999 patients (333 per group) across four participating

This is a prospective observational study investigating the acute and subacute effects of intravenous furosemide administration on hemodynamics and pulmonary congestion in patients with acute decompensated heart failure. The study will enroll 80 patients and administer a single dose of 80 mg of intravenous furosemide. The primary outcome measure is the change in pulmonary fluid content, as measured by a non-invasive remote dielectric sensing (ReDS) device, from baseline to 30 minutes after furosemide administration. Other measurements include blood pressure, peripheral oxygen saturation, ultrasound examination of the heart and lungs, and assessment of cardiac filling pressures using Doppler and strain analysis. These measurements will be repeated at several time points up to 6 hours after furosemide administration.

This is a national randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a smartphone application in reducing binge drinking behavior among university students aged 18 to 25 years. The study will compare an experimental group using the smartphone application with a control group receiving standard care. The primary outcome measure is the change in the number of standard drinks per week over 30 months. The secondary outcome measures are the changes in phosphatidylethanol (PEth) concentration, a biomarker of alcohol consumption, at multiple time points over 30 months. The study uses a parallel assignment design with triple masking.

This is a randomized, open-label clinical study evaluating the potential benefit of nitazoxanide as an adjuvant therapy in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study will enroll 70 patients with type 2 diabetes, who will be randomly assigned to two groups. Group 1 (35 patients) will receive standard treatment with metformin and DPP-4 inhibitors, while Group 2 (35 patients) will receive nitazoxanide 500 mg orally twice daily in addition to the standard treatment. The primary outcome measure is glycemic control, assessed by fasting blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) at 12 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include insulin resistance, lipid profile, and serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1 and asprosin, also evaluated at 12 weeks.

The study aims to investigate the clinical risk factors of autism and elucidate the changes in gut microbiome and metabolome in Egyptian autistic children, as well as their correlation with disease severity and clinical outcomes. The study will include autistic children aged 3-9 years, without a history of seizures, neurological, or psychiatric illnesses. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of autism clinical risk factors through prenatal, natal, and postnatal history, followed by regression analysis. The secondary outcome measures are the investigation of the intestinal microbiome through stool sample collection and analysis, as well as the fecal metabolome analysis. The study does not involve any interventions, and it is designed to explore the potential associations between autism, gut microbiome, and metabolome.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an internet-based self-help money management program in improving financial self-efficacy and well-being among adults with severe mental illness. The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the money management program group to a waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures are changes in financial self-efficacy, financial behavior, financial attitude, and financial well-being from baseline to post-intervention and follow-up assessments. Secondary outcome measures include changes in psychological well-being, anxiety, depression, and quality of life. The money management program consists of 4 weekly online modules covering key aspects of money management and the Model of Human Occupation. The study also assesses treatment adherence, satisfaction, and acceptability of the internet-based delivery. The study aims to determine if the money management program can improve financial outcomes and associated mental health outcomes in adults with severe mental illness.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy (START) in enhancing upper extremity function in individuals with stroke.

2. Study Design: Randomized, single-blind, parallel, controlled trial comparing START intervention to a sham control group.

3. Participants: Adults (>18 years) with stroke at least 6 months prior, with severe-to-mild upper extremity impairment.

4. Interventions:
   - Experimental group: Functional reaching task practice with application of startling acoustic stimuli (START).
   - Control group: Functional reaching task practice without START.

5. Primary Outcomes:
   - Changes in electromyography (EMG) onset and amplitude, movement onset and linearity during the functional reaching task.
   - Changes in functional reaching task scores during and after training.
   - Changes in scores on untrained tasks (sorting and dressing) to assess skill transfer.

6. Secondary Outcomes:
   - Retention of functional reaching task, sorting task, and dressing task scores at 1-month follow-

This is a single-group, open-label study investigating the effects of endoscopic lung volume reduction (ELVR) using endobronchial valves on diaphragm function and conformation in patients with COPD. The study will evaluate changes in transdiaphragmatic pressure and diaphragmatic conformation (measured by diaphragmatic fiber length, area, and radius of curvature) before and 3 months after the ELVR procedure. The study includes COPD patients aged 18 years and older who meet the inclusion criteria, but excludes those with a target lobe volume reduction (TLVR) less than 50%.

This was a two-year randomized clinical trial that evaluated the clinical performance of three different bulk-fill resin composites (Fill-Up, QuiXfil, and Tetric N-Ceram Bulk Fill) for Class II restorations. The primary outcome measures were esthetic properties, functional properties, and biological properties, which were assessed using the FDI criteria. The study included participants aged 21 to 50 years old who required at least three permanent molars or premolars to be treated with Class II restorations due to primary carious lesions. Each participant received all three bulk-fill resin composite restorations in a randomized, double-blind manner. The study aimed to compare the clinical performance of these three bulk-fill resin composites over a two-year follow-up period.

The key aspects of the NET RETREAT clinical trial are:

1. Primary Objective: To evaluate the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE versus everolimus on progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with metastatic/unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) who have progressed following previous peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT).

2. Study Design: Randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment trial comparing 177Lu-DOTATATE (Arm I) versus everolimus (Arm II). Patients in Arm II may cross over to Arm I upon disease progression.

3. Key Outcome Measures:
   - Primary: Progression-free survival (PFS)
   - Secondary: Overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), post-progression survival (PPS), time to second objective disease progression (PFS2), and quality of life.

4. Eligibility Criteria: Patients must have metastatic, grade 1 or 2 well-differentiated midgut NETs, have received prior PRRT, and have

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of the Mulligan technique versus McKenzie extension exercises with manual traction in patients with chronic unilateral radicular low back pain. The primary outcomes measured are changes in pain intensity using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS), disability using the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), and lumbar range of motion. The study will be conducted over 4 weeks, with participants randomly assigned to either the Mulligan technique group or the McKenzie extension exercise group, receiving treatment twice weekly. The Mulligan technique group will receive Mulligan techniques such as sustained natural apophyseal glides (SNAGs) and spinal mobilization with leg movement, while the McKenzie group will perform active McKenzie extension exercises in prone position. The study includes patients aged 28-50 years with clinically diagnosed lumbar radiculopathy, and excludes those with a history of spinal surgery, recent corticosteroid use, osteoporosis, fracture, trauma, inflammatory disorders, or acute disc bulge.

This is a Phase 2, multicenter, long-term, open-label extension trial evaluating the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP in children and adolescents with achondroplasia. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events and changes in height z-scores over the course of the trial, which is expected to last an average of 10 years. The secondary outcome measure is annualized growth velocity. Eligible participants must have completed a previous clinical trial with TransCon CNP and meet certain inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study uses a single-group assignment design with an open-label intervention of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP.

This is a observational study that aims to explore the impact of illness perceptions and coping strategies on the quality of life in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study will use the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12) to measure the participants' physical and mental well-being at the start of the study and up to 24 weeks. The study will include patients aged 18-75 years old who have a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and will exclude those with severe complications, malignant diseases, psychiatric conditions, or cognitive impairment that interferes with participation.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of local excision (LE) for organ preservation in patients with early rectal cancer (cT1N0M0) without the use of adjuvant treatment. The primary outcome is the success rate, defined as the proportion of patients who do not require total mesorectal excision (TME) after follow-up. Secondary outcomes include the morbidity rate, radicality of resection, rate of histological poor outcome predictors, and quality of the TME specimen in patients requiring radical rescue surgery. The study will prospectively collect data on patient demographics, tumor characteristics, surgical details, pathological findings, and follow-up outcomes. A sample size of 145 patients is planned, with a recruitment period of 14 months and a follow-up period of 36 months.

This study aims to evaluate the outcomes of different surgical strategies for the repair of Type A Aortic Dissection (TAAD). The study includes patients aged 18-90 years who underwent primary surgical repair of acute TAAD within 7 days of symptom onset. The surgical interventions evaluated include:

1. Conservative root-sparing aortic valve resuspension with or without hemiarch repair
2. Extensive ascending aorta replacement (AAR) with aortic root replacement (ARR)
3. Extensive AAR with total arch replacement (TARP)
4. Extensive root and ascending aorta replacement with total arch replacement

The primary outcome measures are 30-day operative mortality, rates of mesenteric ischemia, permanent neurologic deficit, major adverse events, myocardial infarction, and acute heart failure. Secondary outcomes include transient neurologic deficit, spinal cord injury, acute kidney injury, perioperative bleeding, need for mechanical circulatory support, major adverse pulmonary events, rate of reintervention, and long-term survival up to 18 years. The study aims to identify predictors of outcomes and

The study aims to evaluate the effects of using virtual reality (VR) versus traditional guided visualization techniques on academic stress, perceived stress, and academic performance in physiotherapy and nursing students at the University of the Balearic Islands.

The study will randomly assign participants to one of three groups: 
1) Experimental group 1 (VR): Participants will undergo a 4-week program of 30-minute guided visualization sessions using VR glasses to simulate the experience of an exam.
2) Experimental group 2 (Traditional): Participants will undergo a 4-week program of 30-minute traditional guided visualization sessions using only audio.
3) Control group: Participants will not receive any intervention.

The primary outcome measures are changes in academic stress and perceived stress over the 4-week period. Secondary outcome measures include the level of perceived stress, blood pressure, heart rate, salivary cortisol, and exam performance immediately before an exam. The study will compare the outcomes between the three groups.

The study aims to compare the use of remimazolam versus propofol as an anesthetic induction agent for patients with morbid obesity undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The primary outcome measure is the rate of hypotension events during anesthesia induction. Secondary outcome measures include induction time and total vasopressor (ephedrine) dose. The study is a randomized, parallel-group, single-blind trial. Eligible participants are adults aged 20 years or older who are scheduled for general anesthesia for sleeve gastrectomy. Patients with a history of adverse effects or hypersensitivity to benzodiazepines, acute alcoholic intoxication, coma, or narrow-angle glaucoma are excluded. The study plans to enroll 44 participants in each group, accounting for a 10% dropout rate.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a phase II study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination of the drugs darolutamide, leuprolide acetate, and exemestane in patients with recurrent adult-type ovarian granulosa cell tumors. 

The primary objective is to determine the objective response rate of this drug combination. Secondary objectives include assessing the duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and toxicities. An exploratory objective is to identify biomarkers predictive of response.

Eligible patients will receive oral exemestane daily, oral darolutamide twice daily, and intramuscular leuprolide acetate on day 1 of each 28-day cycle. Patients will undergo imaging, biospecimen collection, and safety monitoring throughout the study.

The study is designed as a single-arm, open-label trial. The primary outcome is the objective response rate, with secondary outcomes including duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and incidence of adverse events.

This is a phase 2 clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of combining the immunotherapy drug nivolumab with chemotherapy (cisplatin and gemcitabine) in the treatment of newly diagnosed nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) in children, adolescents, and young adults.

The primary objective is to evaluate the safety of this chemoimmunotherapy combination by assessing the rate of grade 3 or higher immune-related adverse events. 

The secondary objectives are to:
1. Estimate the 2-year event-free survival (EFS) of patients treated with induction chemoimmunotherapy, consolidation chemoradioimmunotherapy, and nivolumab maintenance.
2. Evaluate the objective response rate (ORR) to the induction chemoimmunotherapy.
3. Assess the feasibility of combining chemotherapy and nivolumab in this patient population.

Exploratory objectives include evaluating long-term outcomes, comparing imaging modalities, assessing toxicity, and collecting biospecimens for future research.

Eligible patients are ≤21 years old with newly diagnosed stage II-IV

This is an observational cohort study using MRI to measure gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function, and liver endpoints in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) aged 6 to 11 years. The study aims to identify whether these measures change before and after starting elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor (ETI) treatment. The primary outcome measure is the delta small bowel water (DeltaSBW), which is the change in small bowel water content between 240 and 300 minutes post-meal. Secondary outcome measures include small bowel water content, liver volume, liver elastography, and lung ventilation. The study will be conducted in two phases: a pilot phase with 3 CF children and 3 healthy controls, followed by the main phase with 12 additional CF children. Participants will undergo MRI scans at baseline, 240 minutes, and 300 minutes after a standardized high-fat meal, as well as complete questionnaires and a food diary.

This is a randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center study that aims to compare the postoperative analgesic efficacy of dexamethasone and methylprednisolone when added to bupivacaine for caudal block in children undergoing hypospadias surgical repair. The primary outcome measure is the duration of analgesia, defined as the time to first need for rescue analgesia. The secondary outcome measures are the severity of postoperative pain using the FLACC score and the incidence of side effects such as nausea, vomiting, respiratory depression, and hyperglycemia. Male patients aged 1 to 6 years with American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status I-II scheduled for hypospadias repair surgery will be randomly assigned to receive either a caudal block with bupivacaine plus dexamethasone or bupivacaine plus methylprednisolone. The investigators hypothesize that methylprednisolone will provide superior postoperative analgesia compared to dexamethasone when used as an adjunct to bupivacaine in caudal block.

This is a prospective randomized pilot study evaluating the addition of hemodiafiltration (HDF) to ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) and its impact on the regeneration of marginal donor lungs. The study aims to assess the suitability of lungs for transplantation after 6 hours of EVLP with HDF, as well as the incidence of primary graft dysfunction (PGD) grade 3 at 72 hours post-transplantation. Secondary outcomes include survival, length of mechanical ventilation, ICU and hospital stay, and lung function parameters up to 24 months after transplantation. The study will enroll marginal donor lungs according to ISHLT criteria and randomize them to either the EVLP + HDF group or the EVLP-only control group.

The study aimed to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examinations on premature infants. Premature infants were randomly assigned to three groups: control, white noise, and multisensory stimulation. The white noise group received auditory stimulation, while the multisensory stimulation group received additional visual and tactile stimuli during the examination. The study measured the infants' physiological responses, behavioral indicators, and overall examination success rate. The findings of this study have the potential to inform healthcare professionals about the benefits of auditory stimulation (white noise) and the additional advantages of multisensory stimulation during retinopathy examinations, with the goal of enhancing the quality of care and improving visual outcomes for premature infants.

The study aimed to evaluate a modified calculation formula for grading meibomian gland (MG) dysfunction. The study included participants aged 18 to 80 years, excluding contact lens wearers, those with a history of eye surgeries, systemic health conditions affecting ocular health, and those unable to cooperate with examinations. The study measured the area of the MGs and the whole eyelids, as well as the white-to-white (WTW) distance of the cornea at baseline. The participants were divided into two groups: one using the previous calculation formula and the other using the modified calculation formula.

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the prevention of oral mucositis in patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy. The study compares the use of a zinc gluconate spray (experimental group) versus a sodium bicarbonate solution (control group) for 63 days during radiotherapy. The primary outcome is the presence or absence of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. Secondary outcomes include the time of onset and severity of oral mucositis. The study includes patients aged 18 years and older with a diagnosis of head and neck cancer who are undergoing local radiotherapy for curative or adjuvant purposes. Patients with contraindications to the study products or with neurological/psychiatric conditions that could affect their ability to self-apply the treatment are excluded.

This is a cross-sectional clinical study that aims to determine the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva for differentiating between healthy and periodontally affected subjects. The study will evaluate a combination of 12 salivary biomarkers, including C-reactive protein (CRP), TREM-1, IL-1beta, MMP-8, IL-10, IL-6, MCP-1, MIP-1, IFN-gamma, OPG, RANKL, and TNF-alpha. The study will enroll adults aged 18 years and older, categorizing them into groups based on their periodontal health status (healthy, gingivitis, treated periodontitis, periodontitis stages I & II, and periodontitis stages III & IV). In addition to the salivary biomarkers, the study will collect various secondary outcome measures, such as age, gender, HbA1c, Finn-risk, blood pressure, temperature, habits, plaque index, bleeding on probing, suppuration on probing, probing depth, recession, radiographic bone loss, and microbiological analyses.

This study aims to evaluate the performance of a dual-hormone artificial pancreas system (dHmG) compared to a single-hormone system with rescue carbohydrate recommendations (sHC) in adults with type 1 diabetes. The primary objectives are to assess the time spent below the target glucose range (70-180 mg/dL) and the occurrence of level 1 (<70 mg/dL) and level 2 (<54 mg/dL) hypoglycemic events. The study will involve two 12-hour inpatient sessions, each including an unannounced 30-minute aerobic exercise session and a 60g carbohydrate meal challenge. Participants will be randomly assigned to the order of the two interventions (dHmG and sHC). The study will enroll 15 adults with type 1 diabetes, with an initial feasibility assessment of the dHmG system in 5 participants, followed by a comparative study of dHmG versus sHC in 10 participants. The study aims to determine whether the dual-hormone configuration can better minimize time spent below the target range and reduce hypoglycemic events

The study aimed to determine the effect of white noise, heart sound, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance procedures. It was a randomized controlled experimental study involving 84 infants with a gestational age of 28-42 weeks. The infants were exposed to one of the three interventions (white noise, heart sound, or music the mother listened to during pregnancy) for 10 minutes before, during, and 20 minutes after the heel lance procedure. The primary outcome measure was the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS) score, and the secondary outcome was the infant's crying time. The study evaluated the pain intensity, duration of the procedure, and crying time in the three intervention groups.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of two different training and supervision methods for clinicians delivering a Caregiver Skills Training (CST) program. One group of clinicians will receive 15 hours of remote training and 12 weeks of remote supervision, while the other group will receive 15 hours of in-person training and 12 weeks of in-person supervision. 

The primary outcome measure is the change in caregiver skills and knowledge from baseline to week 12, as assessed by the Caregiver Skills and Knowledge Measure. Secondary outcome measures include changes in parenting stress, child adaptive behavior, and social communication abilities, as well as the extent to which caregivers use the strategies they learned.

The study will enroll parents of children aged 2-9 with developmental disabilities or autism who are able to attend the 12 CST sessions, which may be conducted virtually or in-person. The study uses a parallel assignment design to compare the two clinician training and supervision approaches.

This is a randomized, triple-blind clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) combined with a strengthening exercise program in improving pain, disability, and functional outcomes in individuals with subacromial pain syndrome.

The study will recruit 64 participants (with a potential 15% increase to account for dropouts) between the ages of 18 and 65 years with unilateral shoulder pain of at least 3 months duration. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (strengthening exercises plus real TES) or the control group (strengthening exercises plus sham TES).

The primary outcome measures are changes in pain and disability (SPADI), quality of life (WORC), and pain intensity (VAS) at baseline, immediately post-intervention (8 weeks), and 3-month follow-up. Secondary outcome measures include changes in shoulder muscle strength, range of motion, proprioception, posture, subacromial space width, scapulohumeral rhythm, and electromyographic activity of the scapulothoracic muscles, as well as changes in the mean signal amplitude of the primary motor

This was a retrospective study that aimed to evaluate the association between hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) and changes in verbal scores in children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Children aged 2-17 years with ASD who received applied behavioral analysis at Oxford Recovery Center were included. Some of these children had also elected to receive HBOT (at least 40 sessions for 60 minutes at 2.0 ATA). The primary outcome measures were the change from baseline in verbal scores at 6 months, as assessed by the Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program (VBMAPP) and the Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills (ABLLS), comparing the HBOT group to the control group who did not receive HBOT. The secondary outcome measure was the number of participants with HBOT-related adverse events.

The study aims to compare the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound-guided adductor canal block versus 4-in-1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. It is a comparative randomized double-blinded study. The primary outcome measures are postoperative pain scores at rest and during movement at 6, 12, 18, and 24 hours. The secondary outcome measures include changes in blood pressure and heart rate, as well as postoperative opioid requirements. The study includes patients aged 20-60 years, of both sexes, with ASA grade 1 or 2, who will undergo knee surgeries under neuraxial anesthesia. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either the adductor canal block or the 4-in-1 block, with both groups receiving 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine with 4 mg of dexamethasone.

The study aims to investigate whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) with lymphatico-venous anastomosis can reduce the occurrence of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection. It is a prospective, randomized, controlled trial. The study will enroll female breast cancer patients aged 20-75 years who are scheduled to undergo axillary lymph node dissection or sentinel lymph node biopsy with suspected axillary metastasis. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the ILR group, where they receive axillary lymph node dissection and immediate lymphatic reconstruction, or the non-ILR group, where they receive only axillary lymph node dissection. The primary outcome is the occurrence of arm lymphedema over a 2-year follow-up period. Secondary outcomes include drainage amount, seroma or lymphocele, patient-reported outcomes, and subclinical lymphedema.

This study is a descriptive investigation of the cosmetic and functional outcomes in patients who received releasing incisions for the management of acute upper limb burns. The study enrolled adult patients with acute hand burns (less than 3 days) that required skin grafting. Participants underwent various assessments, including the QuickDASH score, visual analog scale for burn severity, scar quality evaluation by a surgeon, and the number of surgical procedures required. The primary outcome measures were functional recovery, healing time, scar quality, and burn severity at 3 and 6 months after the burn injury. The study aimed to evaluate the long-term cosmetic and functional sequelae in patients with deep hand burns who required releasing incisions as part of their treatment.

The Stanford Plant-based Educational Study (PLANT) is a randomized, delayed intervention trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 6-week multimodal educational program on whole-food plant-based diets (WFPBD) for healthcare providers at Stanford. The study will assess changes in participants' diet quality (measured by Diet ID score), mindset about WFPBD, and motivation/confidence to adopt and prescribe a WFPBD. The intervention group will receive the educational program, which includes interactive sessions, cooking classes, and weekly resources, while the control group will receive the delayed intervention. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with an open-label approach, and the primary purpose is health services research.

This is a multicenter study aimed at translating, adapting, and validating a Patient-Reported Outcome (PRO) questionnaire to assess rehabilitation needs in early-stage breast cancer patients. The PRO questionnaire, consisting of 17 items evaluating various survivorship concerns, will be administered to at least 280 patients. The primary outcome is the translation and validation of the PRO questionnaire, which will be assessed through the Interclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC) to determine the level of agreement between two assessments conducted 15 days apart. The study will exclude patients with cognitive or memory impairment and is limited to female participants aged 18 years and older.

This study is a postpartum adaptation of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE) parenting program. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the 12-session CARE program on postpartum depression, postpartum anxiety, parenting stress, parent-child relationships, and parental reflective functioning in birthing parents of infants aged 3-12 months. 

The primary outcome measures include changes from baseline to post-treatment in postpartum anxiety, postpartum depression, parenting stress, parental reflective functioning, and parent-infant bonding. Secondary outcomes include changes in infant temperament. Participants will also provide feedback on the acceptability and feasibility of the CARE program. The study uses a single-group assignment design with no masking.

This study aims to investigate the effects of electroencephalography-based neurofeedback (EEG-NFB) training on cognitive function in healthy young men. A total of 50 healthy male students aged 20-25 years will be randomly assigned to either the training (TR) group or the control (CO) group. 

The TR group will undergo 9 sessions of EEG-NFB training over 3 weeks, while the CO group will not receive any training. Before (PRE) and after (POST) the training period, all participants will undergo cognitive testing, including the Trail Making Test (TMT) to assess processing speed and executive function, and the Stroop Test (ST) to measure processing speed, selective attention, and inhibition. 

The primary outcome measures are the performance times on the TMT-A, TMT-B, ST-I, and ST-II, which will be compared between the TR and CO groups, as well as within each group before and after the training period. The study also aims to assess whether the 3-week EEG-NFB training leads to a decrease in the theta/beta ratio (TBR) value,

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy of endovascular recanalization via radial approach versus femoral approach in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion within 24 hours of symptom onset. The primary outcome measure is favorable neurological function, defined as modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score ≤ 3, at 90 days post-operation. The secondary outcome measure is the procedure time of the endovascular thrombectomy. Eligible patients are those aged 18 years or older with acute ischemic stroke in the posterior circulation, confirmed basilar artery occlusion, and a baseline NIHSS score ≥ 10 before randomization. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive endovascular recanalization via either the radial or femoral approach.

The BUNDLE study is a prospective mixed-methods study that aims to develop and evaluate an integrated prenatal care model involving community doulas and medical providers. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Aim 1: Develop an integrated prenatal care model through focus groups with Black/African American pregnant individuals and prenatal healthcare providers, and input from a community advisory panel.

2. Aim 2: Compare the effectiveness of the integrated prenatal care model (BUNDLE) to standard prenatal care in a two-arm randomized controlled trial. The primary outcome is healthcare engagement, and secondary outcomes include trust in provider, perceived discrimination, stress, depression, maternal morbidity, and breastfeeding.

3. Aim 3: Disseminate the findings and leverage partnerships to advocate for policy changes to support the integrated prenatal care model.

The study population includes Black/African American pregnant individuals aged 18-65 years, and the study design is an open-label, parallel-assignment randomized controlled trial.

This is a Phase 1, open-label, dose-escalation study to evaluate the safety and determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of IBRX-042 in subjects with HPV-associated tumors. Up to 18 subjects will receive IBRX-042 by injection once every 3 weeks for a total of 3 injections. The study will utilize a 3+3 dose escalation design, with 3 dose cohorts: 1e11 virus particles (VP)/dose, 5e11 VP/dose, and a de-escalation cohort of 5e10 VP/dose if needed. The primary objective is to determine the MTD of IBRX-042, while secondary objectives are to assess the safety profile, reactogenicity, and HPV-specific humoral and cellular immune responses. Subjects will be followed for up to 2 years.

This was a 3-arm randomized controlled trial that compared the effects of connective tissue massage (CTM), classical massage (CM), and a control group receiving standard physiotherapy on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. 

The study included 30 participants aged 18-65 years, who were randomly assigned to the CTM group (n=10), CM group (n=10), or control group (n=10). The interventions were administered 3 times per week for 4 weeks, with each session lasting 15-20 minutes. 

The primary outcome measures were pain intensity (Visual Analog Scale), lumbar mobility (Modified Schober Test and Sit and Reach Test), functional status (Back Pain Functional Scale and Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire), and quality of life (Short Form-36 Questionnaire). These were assessed at baseline and 4 weeks after the completion of the interventions.

The study aimed to compare the effects of CTM and CM on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain.

This clinical trial aims to compare the clinical outcomes between cataract surgery with OMNI canaloplasty alone versus cataract surgery with OMNI canaloplasty and Hydrus microstent in patients with mild to moderate open-angle glaucoma. The primary outcome measure is the change in unmedicated intraocular pressure from baseline to 12 months. The secondary outcome measures are the reduction in number of medications needed to control intraocular pressure and the percentage of patients with greater than 20% reduction in intraocular pressure from baseline, both at 12 months. Approximately 80 subjects aged 18 years and older will be randomly assigned to undergo either OMNI canaloplasty alone or OMNI canaloplasty with Hydrus microstent in one eye, with the contralateral eye receiving the other treatment. The study will evaluate the differing pressure lowering effects between the two surgical approaches.

This was a multicenter, prospective, open-label, randomized, comparative, controlled, parallel-arm study evaluating the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops (20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL) versus Cosopt eye drops (20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL) in 110 patients (55 per group) with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).

The primary objective was to demonstrate sufficient similarity of the efficacy profiles between the test (Dorzotimol) and reference (Cosopt) products. The primary endpoint was mean IOP change from baseline at 12 weeks. Secondary endpoints included IOP reduction rates to ≤18 mmHg, >20%, and >30%.

The study found no statistically significant differences between the Dorzotimol and Cosopt groups in the primary or secondary efficacy endpoints, demonstrating the non-inferiority of Dorzotimol compared to the reference

This is a pilot study that aims to evaluate the use of text messaging to improve adherence to repeat colonoscopy in a Veterans Affairs (VA) hospital setting. The study will randomize participants to receive a series of instructional and motivational text messages or no intervention. The primary outcome is participant satisfaction with the text message intervention, measured using the National Annie Colonoscopy Survey. Secondary outcomes include the percentage of participants who attend their scheduled colonoscopy appointment and the percentage who have adequate bowel preparation. The study includes adults aged 45-85 years who are due for a repeat screening or surveillance colonoscopy at the VA, excluding those with a personal or family history of colorectal cancer or related conditions.

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, two-arm, parallel therapeutic clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after spontaneous miscarriage. The primary objective is to compare the efficacy of management by endouterine aspiration versus hysteroscopy in achieving uterine vacuity at 6 weeks after surgery, as assessed by endovaginal ultrasound. The secondary objectives are to compare the rates of complications, need for second-line surgical management, uterine synechiae, time to conception, and fertility rates at 2 years between the two arms. A total of 220 patients (110 per arm) will be randomized to receive either hysteroscopy or endouterine aspiration. The primary outcome is uterine vacuity at 6 weeks, and secondary outcomes include complication rates, need for second-line management, synechiae, time to conception, and fertility rates.

The study is a behavioral experiment that investigates human inference strategies using an online crowdsourcing platform. The study involves adult participants who meet specific eligibility criteria, including a minimum approval rating and pre-test score. The participants will be presented with pairs of jars filled with different ratios of red and blue balls and asked to perform various inference tasks, such as identifying the current jar in use, predicting the subsequent jar, or combining short-term and long-term inferences. The primary outcome measure is the participants' binary behavioral decision responses, which will be recorded during the task trials over an approximate 30-minute session.

This is an N-of-1 trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of lemborexant for the treatment of insomnia in a patient with early-onset dementia. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks, with the patient receiving lemborexant 5 mg, lemborexant 10 mg, and placebo in an alternating ABBABAAB sequence. 

The primary outcome measures are:
- Total sleep time
- Sleep onset latency 
- Wake time after sleep onset
- Number of night awakenings
- Quality of sleep

The secondary outcome measures are:
- Presence and severity of adverse drug reactions (ADRs)
- Willingness to drop out due to ADRs

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness, tolerability, and safety of lemborexant in an individual patient with early-onset dementia and insomnia. The results will help understand the details of the effect and effectiveness of lemborexant in this patient population.

This is a prospective, double-blind, randomized, multicenter clinical trial that aims to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of sinomenine versus glucocorticoid for the treatment of early knee osteoarthritis. The primary outcome measures are the change in total WOMAC score and tibial cartilage volume from baseline to 24 months after the first injection, with the goal of determining if sinomenine is non-inferior to glucocorticoid. The secondary outcome measures are the change in Timed Up and Go test and 20-meter walking time from baseline to 24 months, also evaluating non-inferiority of sinomenine compared to glucocorticoid. The study includes participants aged 40 to 70 years with bilateral knee pain, Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2 or 3 knee osteoarthritis, and excludes those with more severe or other joint/medical conditions. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either intra-articular injections of sinomenine or glucocorticoid every 4 months for 24 months.

This study aims to investigate the effect of breathing exercises using virtual reality (VR) glasses on dyspnea, anxiety, and quality of life in patients with COPD. The study will use a single-blind, pre-test post-test, parallel group, randomized controlled experimental design. 

The experimental group will receive breathing exercises through VR glasses, while the control group will receive routine treatment and care. The exercises will be performed 3 times per week for 8 weeks, with each session lasting 20 minutes. 

The primary outcome measures include oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, lung function parameters (FVC, FEV1, PEF, FEV1/FVC), and COPD-related health status (CAT, mMRC). The secondary outcome measures are anxiety (HADS), quality of life (SGRQ), and patient satisfaction with the VR experience.

The study will enroll 48 COPD patients (GOLD stage II-III) who meet the inclusion criteria. Participants will be randomly assigned to the experimental or control group. Data will be collected at baseline, week 4, and week 8 of the study.

This study aims to understand the multilevel determinants of cardiovascular health in Black women. It is an observational study that involves a series of lab-based assessments to evaluate the participants' vascular health, followed by a 10-day free-living monitoring period using mobile and wearable devices.

The primary outcome measures include:
1. Macrovascular function, assessed as brachial artery vasodilation and microvascular function.
2. Arterial stiffness, measured using the SphygmoCor Xcel device.
3. Blood flow measurements in large blood vessels (brachial, femoral, and carotid arteries) and cerebral blood vessels.

The secondary outcome measure is daily physical activity level, assessed via a wrist-worn accelerometer.

The study includes Black women aged 18-49 years who are healthy and do not have any diagnosed cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic, or neurological disorders, or take certain medications.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel, phase 2 clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of RCN3028 in the treatment of drug-induced moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms (VMS) in breast cancer subjects.

The primary objectives are to assess the mean change in frequency and severity of moderate to severe VMS from baseline to weeks 4 and 12. 

Key secondary objectives include evaluating the impact on quality of life, responder rates, time to onset of efficacy, and safety.

The study will enroll female subjects (aged 20-80 years) with a confirmed diagnosis of breast cancer who have completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy, and are on a stable dose of tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. Eligible subjects must report at least 7 moderate to severe hot flashes per day or 50 per week at baseline.

Subjects will be randomized to receive either RCN3028 0.8 mg capsule or placebo for 12 weeks, following a 14-day placebo run-in period.

The primary outcome measures are the mean change in frequency and severity

This is a retrospective cohort study that aims to investigate whether higher doses of tranexamic acid (TXA) are associated with a lower incidence of postoperative delirium after cardiac surgery. The study will include all patients undergoing elective or urgent cardiac surgery at the Royal Perth Hospital between May 2018 and August 2022, excluding those with deep hypothermic circulatory arrest, thoracic vessel operations other than the ascending aorta, solid organ transplantation, mechanical assist device implantation, or emergency operations. The primary outcome measure is the Richmond Agitation Sedation Score up to 48 hours after surgery, and the secondary outcome measure is 30-day mortality. The statistical methods will be determined once the data distribution is known, and the interdependence of primary and secondary outcome measures will be assessed using multivariate regression analysis.

The study aims to compare the effects of myofascial decompression therapy (MDT) and positional release therapy (PRT) on pain, range of motion, and functional disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain. 

The study is a randomized, parallel-group trial. Participants aged 25-50 years with mild to moderate chronic non-specific neck pain (>6/10 on the Numerical Pain Rating Scale) for at least 12 weeks will be included. Patients with systemic, metabolic, neurological disorders, or neuropathic pain will be excluded.

Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either MDT or PRT. MDT involves the application of suction cups along the spine, while PRT involves positioning the head and shoulder in a specific manner to release tender points. Both interventions will be provided for 3 sessions per week over 4 weeks.

The primary outcome measures are pain intensity (Numerical Pain Rating Scale) and functional disability (Neck Disability Index) at 6 weeks. Secondary outcomes include cervical range of motion (flexion, extension, side flexion, rotation) at 6 weeks.
