This is a randomized parallel-controlled study comparing the ileostomy dumpling suture method with the traditional suture method in rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma. The primary outcome measure is the complication rate of the stoma at 30 days after surgery. The secondary outcome measures include the stoma DET (Discoloration, Erosion and Tissue overgrowth) score, stoma pain score, and quality of life scale score for patients with a stoma, all assessed at 30 days after surgery. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the dumpling suture method in reducing stoma complications compared to the traditional suture method.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to assess the progression in cognition and associated activities of daily living (ADL) impairment in Parkinson's disease over 6-8 years.

2. The primary outcome measures are the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) and the level of mild cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease (PD-MCI), which will be determined using a detailed neuropsychological test battery.

3. The secondary outcome measures include:
   - Baseline and follow-up comparison of instrumental ADL function using the Pfeffer Activities of Daily Living scale, assessed by both patient self-impression and informant-rating.
   - Follow-up score in global cognition, measured by the overall mean z-score of the neuropsychological tests.
   - Follow-up performance in specific cognitive domains, measured by the mean z-score of tests assigned to each domain.

This clinical trial aims to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for preventing myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study includes participants aged 18 to 80 years, divided into three age groups: 18-44 years, 45-59 years, and 60-80 years. The intervention involves the intravenous administration of rocuronium prior to the injection of succinylcholine. The primary outcome measure is the appearance of myofibrillation, which is assessed within an average of 45 seconds. The study uses a randomized, open-label, parallel assignment design to determine the appropriate dose of rocuronium for each age group.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel-group study investigating the effects of a 12-week supplementation with bioactive whey protein concentrate containing phospholipids on measures of human brain health and psychological wellbeing.

The study will recruit 220 healthy participants aged 25-49 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the active supplement (40g per day of bioactive whey protein concentrate powder containing phospholipids) or a matched placebo (40g per day of pea protein powder) for 12 weeks.

The primary outcome measure is the effect of the supplementation on cognitive function, specifically memory performance, assessed using a battery of computerized cognitive tasks. Secondary outcome measures include mood states, perceived stress, physical symptoms, sleep quality, and changes in blood plasma phospholipid profiles.

Participants will attend the research center on four occasions (screening/training, pre-intervention, mid-point, and end of intervention) to complete the cognitive assessments, questionnaires, and optional blood sampling. The study aims to determine the potential benefits of dietary phospholipids on brain health and psychological wellbeing.

This is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the presence of environmental pollutants, such as volatile organic compounds and microplastics, in human carotid atherosclerotic plaques and their relationship with the plaque phenotype and clinical outcomes.

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Enrollment of 300 patients with asymptomatic carotid stenosis undergoing carotid endarterectomy.
2. Collection of carotid plaque specimens to assess the presence and amount of pollutants using chromatographic analyses and electron microscopy.
3. Evaluation of inflammatory and plaque stability markers in the plaque specimens to explore the association between pollutants and plaque phenotype.
4. Follow-up of patients for 24 months to assess the incidence of a composite outcome of non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke, and all-cause mortality.
5. Comparison of the incidence of the composite outcome between patients with polluted plaques (having detectable levels of at least one pollutant) and those with non-polluted plaques, adjusting for relevant clinical factors.

This is a clinical trial study that evaluates the use of transarterial radioembolization (TARE) with Therasphere device in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases. The primary outcome measure is to compare the mean effective tumor doses between patients with or without response to TARE at 3 months after treatment. The secondary outcome measures are to investigate the dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships at 6 months after TARE. The study includes patients over 18 years old with histopathologically proven colorectal cancer diagnosis and liver metastases treated with TARE. Patients with poor image quality or previous local treatment/surgery for the liver are excluded.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to clinically evaluate the performance of chemically cured conventional glass ionomer cement (GIC) restorations with and without light-emitting diode (LED) radiant heat enhancement. The study will enroll 18 healthy patients aged 21-45 years, each with two occluso-mesial carious lesions in their second molars. One tooth will be restored with chemically cured conventional GIC (M1 group), while the other tooth will be restored with the same GIC material but with LED radiant heat enhancement (M2 group). The clinical performance of the restorations will be evaluated immediately after placement (T0), at 6 months (T1), and at 12 months (T2) using the Federation Dentaire Internationale (FDI) criteria for assessing dental restorations. The primary outcome measures are the clinical performance of the biological and functional properties of the restorations at 12 months.

The key aspects of the provided clinical trial document are:

1. Study Overview:
   - This was an interventional study conducted at the Heart Institute of the Clinics Hospital of the Medical School of the University of São Paulo.
   - It was a single-center study divided into six phases, including preoperative care, hospitalization, surgery, postoperative care, a 30-day telemonitoring period, and a final outpatient visit.
   - The study aimed to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF).

2. Participation Criteria:
   - Inclusion criteria: Age ≥ 22 years, presence of heart disease, and ability to consent to the study.
   - Exclusion criteria: Not having undergone cardiac surgery, presence of post-surgical complications, and certain medical conditions that may interfere with the use of the wearable device.

3. Study Design:
   - This was a randomized, parallel-assignment, interventional study.
   - The telemonitored group received interventions and telemonitoring through the FAPO

This is a pilot study within the HSMonitor project, a pre-commercial tender for developing telematics solutions to optimize patient health status and disease management. The aim is to test whether the adoption of two digital solutions (HSmartBPM and HyperHealth) by healthcare professionals and patients improves the management of patients with hypertension. This will be a randomized controlled trial where patients with hypertension will be randomized to one of the two digital solutions or to standard care. The primary outcome measure is the changes in systolic and diastolic blood pressure at 2 and 6 months. The secondary outcome measure is the user satisfaction measured with a visual analog scale (VAS) at 2 and 6 months.

The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled study that aims to screen for liver disease in individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder. The study will randomize participants to either receive an invitation for a liver stiffness measurement using transient elastography (the intervention group) or an invitation for blood sampling with Fib-4 (the control group). The primary outcome is alcohol abstinence or light consumption (≤ 10 units/week) in the last 30 days, assessed 6 months after randomization. Secondary outcomes include the number of heavy drinking days in the last 30 days and changes in AUDIT-C scores since randomization, also assessed at 6 months. The study excludes participants with severe liver disease known to the participant and only includes those attending outpatient treatment for alcohol use disorder.

This is a clinical trial studying the value of trio exome sequencing in identifying the genetic causes of specific non-syndromic language and learning disorders (SLLD). The study aims to enroll index cases aged 3 to 40 years old suffering from severe learning disorders, along with their biological parents. The primary outcome is the identification of a genetic cause defined by the presence of at least one ACMG class 4 or 5 variant, assessed through study completion which takes an average of 4 months. The study involves collecting blood samples from the index case and parents, providing consultation for results delivery, and conducting interviews with families with positive and negative results.

The study is a five-day small group-based lifestyle modification program aimed at promoting weight loss in overweight and obese adults. The program involves coherent groups of 7-10 motivated participants and is led by a multidisciplinary team including endocrinologists-diabetologists, a nutritionist, a psychologist, and a kinesiologist. The program provides education and practical workshops on nutrition, physical activity, and psychological support. Participants are encouraged to stay in contact between the meetings using an instant messaging platform. The primary outcome measure is weight loss at 12 months, and secondary outcome measures include changes in body composition and metabolic parameters at 12 months.

This is a phase I clinical trial to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and antitumor activity of the investigational drug Bio-008 in patients with advanced or metastatic solid tumors. 

The study has a dose escalation phase (Phase Ia) and a dose expansion phase (Phase Ib). In the dose escalation phase, patients with advanced solid tumors will receive increasing doses of Bio-008 administered intravenously every 3 weeks. The primary objectives are to assess the safety, tolerability, and determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of Bio-008. 

In the dose expansion phase, patients with advanced solid tumors positive for CLDN18.2 expression will receive the RP2D of Bio-008 to further evaluate safety and antitumor activity. Key outcome measures include adverse events, dose-limiting toxicities, MTD, RP2D, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and tumor response.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of different music (rain stick and "The Happiest Baby" music) on the pain and comfort levels of premature infants during retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) examinations. 

The study will include premature infants with a gestational age ≤34 weeks and birth weight ≤2000 grams, who are undergoing their first ROP examination. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) rain stick music, 2) "The Happiest Baby" music, or 3) control (no music). 

The primary outcome measures are the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) score and the Premature Behavioral Indicators of Comfort (PBIC) score, which will be assessed before, during, and after the ROP examination. Secondary outcomes include oxygen saturation and heart rate. 

The study aims to determine if the use of specific music interventions can help reduce pain and improve comfort in premature infants undergoing the stressful ROP examination procedure.

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III study to assess the safety and efficacy of sovateltide in patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke. 

The primary objective is to determine the efficacy of sovateltide in improving functional outcomes, as measured by the proportion of patients with a modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score of 0-2 at day 90 post-randomization.

The secondary objectives include assessing excellent functional outcomes (mRS 0-1), improvements in National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS), Barthel Index (BI), and overall clinical outcomes. The study will also evaluate changes in quality of life, incidence of recurrent stroke, mortality, and safety.

Eligible patients are adults aged 18-80 years with acute ischemic stroke presenting within 24 hours of symptom onset, with NIHSS score ≥8 and <20, and level of consciousness <2. Patients will be randomized to receive either sovateltide or placebo (normal

This is a 2-year ambispective cohort study that aims to investigate the prognosis and influencing factors of borderline personality disorder (BPD). The study will collect demographic data, comorbidities, treatment history, and other relevant information from electronic medical records retrospectively. Prospectively, patients will be followed up every 6 months to assess psychiatric diagnosis, social function, and quality of life. 

The primary outcome measure is the remission rate of BPD, defined as the proportion of patients who no longer meet the diagnostic criteria for at least 6 months. The secondary outcome measures are social disability, assessed using the Social Disability Screening Schedule (SDSS), and quality of life, assessed using the WHOQOL-BREF. Cox Proportional Hazard Model and Generalized Estimating Equation Model will be used to analyze the influencing factors of BPD remission, social function, and quality of life.

The study includes patients aged 12 years and above with a diagnosis of BPD based on ICD-10 (F60.3), and excludes those with severe physical, neurological, or intellectual disabilities.

This study aims to assess the management of dry eye disease (DED) by combining intense pulsed light (IPL) and diquafosol (DQS) eye drops. The study includes three experimental arms: IPL+DQS, IPL alone, and DQS alone. The primary outcome measures are non-invasive tear break-up time (NIBUT) and Ocular Surface Disease Index (OSDI). Secondary outcome measures include conjunctival and corneal staining, meibomian gland function and secretion quality, tear film lipid layer score, tear meniscus height, and conjunctival hyperemia. The study will evaluate changes in these parameters at day 14 and day 28 compared to baseline, as well as differences between the three treatment groups.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of two different mental health interventions, Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT), in improving mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment among autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depressive disorders. The study also explores patient characteristics that may influence the outcomes of these interventions and compares the acceptability and feasibility of CBT and MBCT as reported by patients and clinicians. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two active treatment arms: CBT and MBCT, delivered via telehealth. The primary outcome measure is the change in anxiety and depression symptoms, while secondary outcomes include changes in mental health, psychiatric diagnosis, quality of life, well-being, self-acceptance, functional impairment, disability, potential negative effects of the intervention, and participant and therapist satisfaction with the interventions.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of methotrexate in treating immune-related arthritis or arthralgias (irAA) in patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy.

2. The study is a single-arm, open-label trial where all participants will receive methotrexate 20 mg orally weekly, folic acid 1 mg daily, and a tapering dose of prednisone.

3. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients who are able to discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without recurrence of grade 2 or higher irAA.

4. Secondary outcomes include total steroid usage, development of immune-related adverse events other than irAA, adverse events, re-initiation of ICI therapy, and progression-free survival.

5. The study population includes patients aged 18 years and older who have developed recurrent grade ≥2 irAA or remain on glucocorticoids for irAA at 3 months, and have a performance status of ECOG 0-2.

The study aims to compare the effects of general anesthesia and regional anesthesia on sleep quality in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The primary outcome measure is subjective sleep quality, evaluated using the Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale (PIRS-20), assessed preoperatively one month before surgery, the day before surgery, and one week postoperatively. The secondary outcome measures are subjective anxiety level, evaluated using the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI), and subjective pain level, evaluated using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), assessed at the same time points. The study is a randomized, parallel-group trial with a triple-blind design, comparing a general anesthesia group and a regional anesthesia group.

This is a Phase 2/3, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study with an active treatment extension to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral atogepant for the prevention of migraine in Japanese adults with episodic migraine. The study will assess the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days, mean monthly headache days, mean monthly acute medication use days, percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in the 3-month average of monthly migraine days, and changes in migraine-specific quality of life and activity impairment measures. Eligible participants will be randomized to receive one of three doses of atogepant or placebo for 12 weeks, followed by a re-randomization of the placebo group to receive one of the three atogepant doses for an additional 12 weeks.

This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, controlled, single-site clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of efgartigimod in patients with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). Patients will be randomized to receive either efgartigimod (20 mg/kg on days 1 and 5) or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg, 0.4 g/kg daily for 5 days), the standard-of-care treatment for GBS. The primary outcome measures are the GBS Disability Scale (GBS-DS) at 12 weeks and the number and seriousness of adverse events. Secondary outcome measures include the GBS-DS, Neuropathy Impairment Scale (NIS), Inflammatory Rasch-Built Overall Disability Scale (I-RODS), and pulmonary function tests (FVC, MIP, MEP) at 4, 24, and 48 weeks. The study aims to enroll adults aged 18 and older with a diagnosis of GBS and onset of weakness within 14 days prior to infusion

This is a Phase 2b, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel group, dose-ranging study to evaluate the virological response and safety of oral PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized, symptomatic adult participants with COVID-19. The study aims to understand the effect and safety of the study drug PF-07817883 in adults who have symptoms of COVID-19 but are not hospitalized. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level from baseline to day 5. Secondary outcome measures include changes in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level at other timepoints, incidence of treatment-related adverse events, serious adverse events, clinically significant abnormal laboratory values, adverse events leading to discontinuation, clinically significant abnormal vital signs, and clinically significant abnormal ECGs.

This is a prospective cohort study evaluating the therapeutic effect of adding letrozole to the protocol of combined treatment of cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP). The study includes two arms:

1. MTX monotherapy: Women receive a single dose of 100 mg MTX intravenously and 50 mg MTX in intra-amniotic injection (day 0), along with 30 mg potassium chloride if there is a positive fetal heartbeat, followed by hysteroscopic evacuation of products of conception (POC).

2. MTX + letrozole add-on: Women receive the same MTX regimen as the first arm, plus letrozole 5 mg orally twice daily for 10 days from day 0, followed by hysteroscopic evacuation of POC.

The primary outcome measures are:
- Decrease in hemoglobin concentration as a measure of blood loss during the procedure
- Volume of blood loss during the procedure
- Conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to hemorrhage

This is a feasibility pilot study that aims to evaluate the use of blood salvage from liver donors for intraoperative transfusion support during liver transplantation. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Intervention: The study involves collecting and processing blood from liver donors, and then transfusing the donor's red blood cell concentrates to the liver transplant recipients during the surgery, if necessary.

2. Eligibility: The study includes adult patients (≥18 years) receiving a liver transplant from deceased donors at the study site. Exclusion criteria include age <18 years, D-negative recipient with D-positive donor, and cytomegalovirus-negative recipient with cytomegalovirus-positive donor.

3. Outcomes: The primary outcome is the number and percentage of liver transplant recipients who successfully received donor red blood cell concentrates for intraoperative transfusion support. The secondary outcomes are the blood product need in enrolled patients compared to a control group, and the rate of graft failure in the study group compared to controls.

4. Study Design: This is a single-group, open-label pilot study with the primary purpose of supportive care.

This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sublingual (SLIT) versus subcutaneous (SCIT) allergen immunotherapy in patients with bronchial asthma. The study was conducted at Mansoura University Hospitals, Egypt, and included 100 asthmatic patients. Fifty patients received SLIT and 50 received SCIT. The primary outcome measures were changes in total IgE levels and sputum eosinophil counts at 6, 12, and 18 months after starting immunotherapy. The study used a randomized, open-label, parallel-group design. Patients were eligible if they had new-onset allergic asthma, were partially controlled on medications, and were between 18-35 years old. Patients with comorbidities, acute exacerbations, or severe persistent asthma were excluded. The study aimed to determine the comparative efficacy of the two immunotherapy approaches in improving asthma-related biomarkers over the 18-month follow-up period.

The study aims to determine the minimum number of contrast-enhanced stereotactic biopsy (CESB) samples needed to establish a reliable histopathological diagnosis for "recombined-only lesions" (ROLs) detected on contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM). This is a prospective, single-center, observational cohort study involving non-pregnant women over 18 years old with a recently detected ROL on CEM. Participants will undergo CESB, where 18 biopsy samples will be collected in 6 separate cassettes. The diagnostic yield per biopsy sample will be calculated to determine the minimum number of samples required for a reliable diagnosis. Secondary outcomes include complication rates, diagnostic results, and patient comfort during the procedure.

The study aims to compare the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening exercises and facilitatory kinesiotaping on gait parameters in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial. Participants aged 50-60 years with knee osteoarthritis will be randomly assigned to either a concentric quadriceps strengthening group or a facilitatory kinesiotaping group. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of temporospatial gait parameters, including gait velocity, cadence, step length, step width, and single support time. Secondary outcome measures include pain intensity using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale, functional status using the WOMAC questionnaire, and quadriceps strength measured with a hand-held dynamometer. The interventions will be administered for 6 weeks, and the outcomes will be evaluated at the end of the study period.

The key aspects of the clinical trial document are:

1. The study aims to collect qualitative data from 20 randomly selected trainees and 16 agency leaders participating in the parent CIFFTA study. 

2. The objectives are: 1) to gather perceptions and experiences of the trainees about the process of learning and practicing specific CIFFTA competencies from the therapy training platform, and later about their experiences with implementation, delivery of competencies, and application of the evidence-based treatment (EBT) in real-world settings; and 2) to gain a deeper understanding from agency leaders about their experiences in facilitating EBTs, identifying barriers, and their agencies' experiences with the platform, consultation process, perceived cost-benefit, and readiness.

3. The study involves qualitative interviews with the trainees and agency leaders at two time points - initially after the training, and later after 4 months of treatment implementation.

4. The key outcomes measured are the trainees' and agency leaders' perceptions, experiences, and perspectives related to the therapy training platform and implementation of the EBT.

This was a preliminary clinical study that investigated the use of a freshly manufactured 35kDa hyaluronan fragment (HA35) for the treatment of pain associated with herpes zoster, shoulder, neck, back, and temporal regions. The study enrolled 26 patients with shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain, as well as 10 patients with herpes zoster pain. HA35 was prepared by mixing hyaluronidase injection and high-molecular-weight hyaluronan injection. The HA35 solution was then locally injected at the pain points or areas innervated by the pain points. The primary outcome measure was the pain score, which was assessed on a scale of 0 to 10 at 30 seconds and 3 hours after the injection. This was an open-label, single-group, investigator-initiated study.

This is a prospective randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the outcomes of hysteroscopic septoplasty using two different techniques - scissors versus resectoscope. The study will enroll women of reproductive age with a diagnosis of septate or subseptate uterus who are seeking conception and have a history of recurrent pregnancy loss or subfertility. 

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:
1. Scissors group: Hysteroscopic septoplasty using scissors and saline as the distension medium.
2. Resectoscope group: Hysteroscopic septoplasty using a monopolar resectoscope, cervical dilation, and glycine 1.5% as the distension medium.

The primary outcome measures are operative time, fluid deficit, operative and post-operative complications, and need for a second intervention. The secondary outcome measures are pregnancy rate and live birth rate.

The study will be conducted for at least 24 months at the Obstetrics and Gynecology department of Mansoura University Hospital. A sample

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a breathing control technique, specifically cardiac coherence, on reducing long COVID symptoms. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: an experimental group receiving cardiac coherence training for 6 months in addition to usual care, and a control group receiving usual care only. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Long COVID Symptom Tool (ST) score over 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the change in specific symptoms such as fatigue, dyspnea, anxiety, depression, cognitive disorders, and post-traumatic stress disorder, as well as the impact of the disease on daily life. The study includes patients over 18 years old living in Reunion with a diagnosis of long COVID, and excludes those with certain respiratory or cardiac conditions or taking specific medications.

This is a single-center cohort study investigating the cardiovascular complications of ibrutinib therapy. The study aims to determine the rate of patients developing atrial fibrillation (AF) during ibrutinib treatment and to compare biomarkers between patients who develop AF and those who do not. Eligible participants are patients aged 18 and above with an indication for ibrutinib treatment for hematologic reasons. The study interventions include ophthalmological examinations with OCT-retinal angiography at inclusion, 3 months, and 6 months, as well as blood tests at inclusion to assess biomarkers predisposing to cardiovascular complications. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients developing AF within 12 months of starting ibrutinib.

This study investigated the effect of bicarbonate profiling in dialysis fluid on phosphate removal and blood pH during hemodialysis. The study enrolled 20 chronic hemodialysis patients and compared three different dialysate bicarbonate (Dbic) profiles:
1) Constant Dbic of 35 mmol/L
2) Dbic of 35 mmol/L for the first 2 hours, then 30 mmol/L for the remaining 2 hours
3) Dbic of 30 mmol/L for the first 2 hours, then 35 mmol/L for the remaining 2 hours

The primary outcome was the change in blood phosphorus concentration during hemodialysis using the different Dbic profiles. The secondary outcome was maintaining acid-base balance within recommended levels. The study had a non-randomized, single-group assignment design, with participants receiving the different Dbic profiles over 4 weeks.

The study aims to evaluate the potential effectiveness of a multimodal intervention for the treatment of unipolar depression. The intervention involves the use of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) combined with metacognitive therapy (MCT). The study is a randomized, double-blind trial with three treatment arms: 1) tDCS alone, 2) MCT alone, and 3) tDCS followed by MCT. The primary outcome is to assess the potential superiority of the combined tDCS and MCT approach compared to tDCS or MCT alone, as measured by changes in the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale during follow-up. The secondary outcomes include evaluating the TMS-EEG correlates of changes in depressive symptomatology and changes in various other depression-related scales and neuropsychological tests.

The study aims to compare the gastrointestinal and cardiovascular events in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) who underwent percutaneous coronary angioplasty and were taking dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), with or without the use of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) for moderate gastrointestinal bleeding risk. 

The study is a randomized, open-label trial that will enroll patients aged 19 years or older with CAD who are scheduled to receive or are already taking DAPT after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Eligible patients will be randomly assigned to either the PPI group (receiving lansoprazole 15 mg once daily) or the non-PPI group. 

The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of upper gastrointestinal clinical events, including upper gastrointestinal bleeding with clear or unclear origin, potential upper gastrointestinal bleeding, or perforation. The secondary outcome measure is the occurrence of a cardiovascular clinical complex, including cardiovascular death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, coronary artery reopening, or ischemic stroke.

This study aims to investigate the influence of "hot" (emotional) and "cold" (cognitive) cognition on prospective memory in HIV-positive patients compared to healthy controls. The primary outcome measure is prospective memory, assessed using the Memory for Intentions Screening Test (MIST). The secondary outcome measures include the influence of global cognitive performance (Montreal Cognitive Assessment, MoCA), hot cognition (Interpersonal Reactivity Index, IRI), and cold cognition (Modified Five Point Test) on prospective memory. The study includes HIV-positive patients on antiretroviral therapy and healthy control subjects, all of whom are native Italian speakers over the age of 18. The study duration is 1 year.

The study aims to determine the effects of vertical sitting versus supine lying traction on pain, range of motion, and function in patients with chronic radicular low back pain (CRLBP). The study will randomize participants into two groups: Group A will receive 30 minutes of continuous mechanical traction in the vertical sitting position 5 times per week for 12 weeks, while Group B will receive 20 minutes of traction in the supine lying position 5 times per week for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures are the Oswestry Disability Index and the Numeric Pain Rating Scale, which will be assessed at the 12-week follow-up. The study excludes patients with indications of spinal cord involvement, pregnant females, and those with a history of spinal trauma or systemic disease. The study aims to provide physiotherapists with an optimal traction treatment protocol for CRLBP.

This is a randomized, double-blind clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of dry needling versus laser therapy in the treatment of greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS). The primary outcome measure is the change in pain intensity using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) at baseline, immediately after treatment, and 12 weeks post-treatment. The secondary outcome measures include changes in hip function (VISA-G questionnaire), lower limb function (Timed Up and Go Test and 30-second Sit to Stand Test) at the same time points. The study will include female participants aged 35-60 years with lateral hip pain for at least 3 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the dry needling or laser therapy group and receive 6 weeks of treatment, 2 times per week. The study aims to determine the efficacy of these interventions in reducing pain and improving function in individuals with GTPS.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a rapid technique for detecting intestinal anti-transglutaminase antibodies to enable real-time diagnosis of celiac disease. The study will assess the sensitivity and specificity of an endomysial antibody (EMA) assay and a rapid anti-transglutaminase (anti-TG2) test performed on mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimens, compared to the reference standard of serology and histopathology. The study will also evaluate the concordance of these rapid tests with the culture-EMA results. The study population includes patients undergoing esophagogastroduodenoscopy for suspected celiac disease or other gastrointestinal conditions, excluding those with bleeding disorders or who meet the criteria for a serology-based celiac disease diagnosis.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effects of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia in nurses with post-COVID-19 condition. The study aims to evaluate the impact of a 6-week CBT intervention on insomnia severity, sleep quality, and sleep efficiency, as well as secondary outcomes of anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life. Eligible participants are nurses aged 20-65 years with post-COVID-19 condition, excluding those with a history of sleep apnea, narcolepsy, pregnancy, seizures, or having a pacemaker. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the CBT intervention group or the usual care control group. The primary outcome measures are insomnia severity, sleep quality, and sleep efficiency, assessed at baseline, post-intervention, and 1, 2, and 3 months after the intervention. Secondary outcomes include anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life, measured at the same timepoints.

This is a pilot study to evaluate the acceptability and impact of the RAPID AFib decision aid on shared decision-making for stroke prevention therapy in patients with recent onset atrial fibrillation (AF). The primary objective is to assess the acceptability of the RAPID AFib tool and its impact on the shared decision-making process, compared to standard care. The study is a prospective, randomized pilot trial. Eligible patients with non-valvular AF diagnosed within 12 months will be randomized 1:1 to receive either the RAPID AFib decision aid or standard information before their clinic visit. The primary outcome is the 9-Item Shared Decision Making Questionnaire (SDM-Q-9) completed by patients immediately after the clinic visit. The study aims to determine if the RAPID AFib decision aid can improve shared decision-making for stroke prevention therapy in patients with AF.

This is a Phase I, randomized, placebo-controlled study to assess the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a new drug called NNC0491-6075 in healthy participants and participants with dyslipidemia.

The study is divided into three parts:

Part A: Single ascending dose (SAD) cohorts in healthy participants
Part B: Multiple ascending dose (MAD) cohorts in participants with dyslipidemia
Part C: Single ascending dose (SAD) cohorts in healthy Japanese participants

The primary outcome measure is the number of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) in each part of the study. Secondary outcome measures include various pharmacokinetic parameters of NNC0491-6075, such as area under the curve (AUC), maximum concentration (Cmax), half-life (t1/2), and time to maximum concentration (tmax).

Participants will be randomized to receive either NNC0491-6075 or placebo, with the drug administered either subcutaneously or intravenously. The study will evaluate the safety and tolerability of the new drug in both healthy individuals and those with

The study aimed to evaluate the efficiency of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) versus non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure. The study included 100 adult patients admitted to the ICU, with 50 patients in each group (HFNC and NIV). The primary outcome measure was the failure of the treatment modality, defined as the failure to improve pH within 1 hour. The secondary outcome measures were mortality during the ICU stay and the duration of ICU stay. The study found that HFNC and NIV were both effective in treating acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure, with no significant difference in the primary and secondary outcome measures between the two groups.

The study aims to implement and evaluate a digital-first care delivery model for heart failure management in Uganda. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Intervention:
   - Enhanced heart failure (HF) clinical care (Core-HF): Includes a care protocol, self-care training for patients and providers, and medication stock management.
   - Digital health intervention (Medly Uganda): A patient-facing mobile app for self-care and a clinician-facing dashboard for monitoring and management.

2. Study Design:
   - Randomized, open-label trial with a single group assignment.
   - All sites will receive the Core-HF intervention first, followed by the Medly Uganda digital intervention at different start points within the first six months.

3. Outcomes:
   - Primary outcomes: Change in self-care of heart failure index (SCHFI) and clinical effectiveness (composite of mortality and HF hospitalization).
   - Secondary outcomes: Participant and facility fidelity to the interventions, changes in clinical parameters (blood pressure, weight, pulse), quality of life, and depression.

This was an open-label, balanced, randomized, single-dose, two-treatment, two-sequence, two-period, two-way crossover study to compare the pharmacokinetics of a compound ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablet (400 mg/50 mg) from Overseas Pharmaceuticals, Ltd. with the reference products (Motrin IB ibuprofen 200 mg tablets and Benadryl diphenhydramine hydrochloride 25 mg tablets) in healthy adult subjects under fasting conditions.

The primary outcome measures were the area under the curve from time zero to the last quantifiable concentration (AUC0-last), the area under the curve from time zero to infinity (AUC0-inf), and the peak concentration (Cmax) at each treatment period. The secondary outcome measures included the peak concentration of the first dose (Cmax), time to reach peak concentration (Tmax), terminal half-life (T1/2), and mean residence time (MRT).

This is a multicentre prospective observational study evaluating the impact of apalutamide in patients with metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC). The primary outcome measure is the undetectable PSA rate (defined as PSA <0.2ng/ml) at the end of year 1 and year 2 in mHSPC patients receiving apalutamide. The secondary outcome measures include the impact of apalutamide on fatigue, cognitive function, and health-related quality of life. Eligible participants are male patients aged 18 years or older with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate and metastatic hormone-sensitive disease, who have a treatment decision for apalutamide by their clinician. The study will be conducted from August 2023 to April 2027.

This clinical trial aims to demonstrate the hair and scalp benefits of Duobrii (0.045% tazarotene/0.01% halobetasol) lotion in the treatment of moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. The study will enroll male and female subjects aged 18 and above with plaque-type moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. Subjects will apply the Duobrii lotion to the affected scalp once daily for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures are improvement in hair growth and reduction in scalp itch. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, week 4, week 8, and week 12, including evaluations by the investigator and self-assessments by the subjects. A consumer perception survey will also be administered at week 12.

This is a phase 1b clinical trial evaluating the combination of idasanutlin and selinexor in children with progressive or relapsed atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT) or extra-CNS malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRT). 

The primary objectives are to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination, as well as to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of idasanutlin in this patient population. 

Secondary objectives include assessing the objective response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival in patients with AT/RT and MRT treated with the combination.

The study has a dose-finding/safety phase to determine the MTD and RP2D, followed by an expansion phase with separate cohorts for patients with AT/RT, MRT, and those with synchronous/metachronous AT/RT and MRT. Patients will receive idasanutlin daily on days 1-5 and selinexor on day 4 of weeks 1-3 of each 28-day cycle.

This is a comparative study between radius and capitate shortening in patients with Kienbock's disease and ulna minus variance. The study aims to evaluate the outcomes of two surgical interventions: radial shortening using a Henry or volar approach, and capitate shortening using a dorsal approach. The primary outcome measure is the Modified Mayo Wrist Score, which assesses wrist pain, hand grip, work status, and range of motion at 1 year follow-up. The study includes patients aged 18-65 years with Kienbock's disease stages II and III and ulna minus variance. Patients with serious medical conditions, stage I or IV Kienbock's disease, or severe osteoporosis are excluded. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, open-label trial.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the impact of a 4-week multimodal prehabilitation program on functional capacity, nutritional status, and patient-reported quality of life in patients with localized pancreatic or periampullary cancer undergoing surgery. 

Patients will be randomized 1:1 to either the multimodal prehabilitation group or a usual care control group. The prehabilitation program includes physical exercise, nutritional therapy, and anxiety-reducing techniques. 

The primary outcome is the Comprehensive Complication Index (CCI) at 90 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes include functional capacity, levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and cancer cachexia-related factors, time to functional recovery, length of hospital stay, body composition changes, and generic and disease-specific quality of life.

Patients will undergo detailed assessments at baseline, the day before surgery, and at 30, 60, and 90 days after surgery to evaluate the impact of the prehabilitation program.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of dual task exercise training, in addition to conventional rehabilitation, on balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy aged 5-12 years. The study is a randomized, parallel-group trial, with an intervention group receiving dual task exercise training (e.g., simple math during stretching, carrying a ball without dropping) along with conventional rehabilitation, and a control group receiving only conventional rehabilitation. The primary outcome measures include the Pediatric Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go Test, One Leg Standing Test, 3-Meter Backward Walk Test, 6-Meter Walk Test, and the Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire (KINDL), assessed at baseline and 12 weeks after the interventions.

This is a pilot study in Belgium that aims to conduct active surveillance for zoonotic influenza virus transmission events. The study involves four participant groups:

1. Avian Influenza Outbreak Farms: People involved in outbreak management will provide respiratory specimens (via self-swabbing) every 2 days for 2 weeks, and blood samples.

2. Poultry Farm Sentinel Network: People working on poultry farms will provide respiratory specimens (via self-swabbing) every 2 weeks.

3. Wild Bird/Life Rehabilitation Centre Sentinel Network: People working at wild bird/life rehabilitation centers will provide respiratory specimens (via self-swabbing) every 2 weeks.

4. Pig Industry Veterinarian Sentinel Network: Veterinarians working in the pig industry will provide respiratory specimens (via self-swabbing) every 2 weeks.

The primary outcome measures are the number of participants in each group who test positive for non-seasonal influenza viruses, as detected by RT-qPCR. The secondary outcome measure is the number of outbreak participants who show seroconversion against non-seasonal influenza viruses, as

This study is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the effect of myofascial release using a foam roller in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity performance in young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. The study will have two parallel groups: one group will receive foot core exercises only, while the other group will receive both foot core exercises and myofascial release using a foam roller. The primary outcome measure is change in balance, assessed using the Y-Balance test. Secondary outcome measures include changes in flexibility (sit-and-reach test), power (vertical jump test), and gait (10-meter walk test). The study will be conducted over 6 weeks, with participants in the myofascial release group performing foam rolling on the thoracolumbar fascia, iliotibial band, hamstring, gastrocnemius-soleus, peroneals, and plantar fascia twice per week in addition to the foot core exercises performed by both groups.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether an 8-week daily arm training program can reduce pain experienced during the insertion of a peripheral venous catheter (PVC) in patients undergoing chemotherapy. The primary outcome measures are the level of pain assessed using the Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) at baseline, after 5 weeks, and after 8 weeks of the training/control period. The secondary outcome measures are the vein status, assessed by the number of usable veins via ultrasound, at the same time points. The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment trial, with one group receiving the arm training intervention and the other group receiving normal care. The study population includes female patients aged 18 years and older who are planned for neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy via intravenous PVC insertion.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to determine whether decidual leukocyte subpopulations and their associated activation markers differ between women having a miscarriage of a trisomy 16 conceptus compared to a chromosomally normal male conceptus, and compared to gestationally age-matched decidual tissues.

2. The study will use product of conception (POC) derived from ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) to perform genetic and immunological analyses. 

3. The primary outcome measures are:
   a. Histopathologic diagnosis of chorionic villi to detect site-to-site heterogeneity, cryptic structural rearrangements, absence of heterozygosity (AOH), and single-nucleotide variants (SNVs).
   b. Immunohistochemistry staining of maternal decidua.

4. The study will enroll women 18 years and older who are undergoing miscarriage or termination of pregnancy in the first trimester and are suitable candidates for USG-MVA.

This is a single-arm, open-label, exploratory clinical trial investigating the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamic properties of Lu AF28996 in Japanese adults with Parkinson's disease (PD). The study will enroll participants aged 45 to 75 years who have idiopathic PD, well-recognizable and predictable motor fluctuations, and a good response to levodopa. Participants will receive ascending oral doses of Lu AF28996 for 14 days, followed by down-titration as per the investigator's judgment. The primary outcome measures are the number of participants with treatment-emergent adverse events and the pharmacokinetic parameters of Lu AF28996, including area under the plasma concentration-time curve, maximum observed plasma concentration, and oral clearance.

This is a quasi-experimental study to assess the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and required capacity of a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program targeting high-risk groups in Bangladesh. The study has three main objectives:

1. To assess the acceptability, health beliefs, barriers, and intention to receive the influenza vaccine among high-risk groups (children 6 months to 8 years, pregnant women, elderly ≥60 years, and adults with chronic diseases).

2. To determine the cost-effectiveness of seasonal influenza vaccination among high-risk groups in Bangladesh. This will involve assessing vaccine efficacy and the costs associated with influenza illness.

3. To estimate the required capacity (vaccine doses, injection equipment, storage) for a hospital-based influenza vaccination program.

The study will be conducted in two public tertiary-level hospitals in Bangladesh. One hospital will offer free influenza vaccination to high-risk patients (intervention arm), while the other will not provide vaccination (control arm). Data will be collected through surveys, follow-up of vaccinated and unvaccinated participants, and costing of influenza illness. Secondary

The study is a single-arm, prospective study that evaluates the performance characteristics and technical outcomes of single-use duodenoscopes in patients undergoing endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) or other duodenoscope-based procedures. The primary outcome measures are the technical performance and procedural performance of the single-use duodenoscopes over a 24-month period. The study includes adult patients (18 years or older) who are willing and able to comply with the study procedures and provide informed consent. Potentially vulnerable subjects, such as pregnant women, and those for whom endoscopic techniques are contraindicated are excluded from the study.

This study is a feasibility trial that aims to evaluate a technology-enabled hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) program compared to standard in-person PR. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Study Design: Real-world study design using a single group assignment, with a propensity-matched control group that received standard PR.

2. Intervention: The hybrid PR program uses the Active+me REMOTE App, which includes remote tracking, online exercise classes, educational content, and personalized care plans. Participants will attend an 8-week hybrid PR program.

3. Outcomes: The primary outcomes are feasibility measures, including recruitment and retention rates, availability of data, success of propensity matching, integration into routine practice, acceptability, and safety. Secondary outcomes include uptake, adherence, changes in exercise capacity, symptoms, knowledge, quality of life, and healthcare resource use.

4. Participants: Adults aged 18 and older with respiratory disease (e.g., COPD, bronchiectasis) referred for PR, who are willing and able to consent.
