This is an observational, cohort study that will use secondary data to describe the baseline demographics and clinical characteristics of immunocompromised patients who received EVUSHELD (tixagevimab/cilgavimab) as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) against SARS-CoV-2 infection/COVID-19 in Japan. The study will include all patients who have a record of EVUSHELD administration in the database, with the index date being the date of first EVUSHELD administration. Patients will be followed up for 6 months after the index date. The primary outcome is to describe the proportion of patients by age, gender, and clinical characteristics of interest (e.g., comorbidities, concurrent medications) between 360 days before and the index date. The secondary outcomes include the event rate and time to event for medically attended COVID-19, COVID-19 hospitalization, in-hospital mortality due to COVID-19, and all-cause mortality up to 180 days after the index date.

This is a Phase 4, multicenter, randomized, double-blind study to assess the safety and efficacy of subcutaneously injected risankizumab in adult participants with moderate to severe genital or scalp psoriasis. The study has two parts: Study-G for participants with moderate to severe genital psoriasis and Study-S for participants with moderate to severe scalp psoriasis.

In Study-G, participants will receive either risankizumab or placebo for risankizumab during the 52-week treatment period, followed by an 8-week follow-up period. In Study-S, participants will receive either risankizumab or placebo for risankizumab during the 52-week treatment period, followed by an 8-week follow-up period.

The primary outcome measures are the percentage of participants with achievement of static Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 or 1 at Week 16 in Study-G, and the percentage of participants with achievement of Scalp Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1 at Week

The study aims to determine the prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock variation (LCV) in patients with symptomatic thumb CMC arthritis. It is a descriptive, cross-sectional study that will recruit 500 male and female patients over the age of 35 with a diagnosis of thumb CMC arthritis. Participants will undergo a 5-second clinical examination by the recruiting physicians to assess for the presence of the LCV in one or both hands. The study will collect demographic data and dichotomous data on whether the LCV is present or absent. The study will take place at the Bone and Joint Center and its satellite offices over a period of up to 2 years. There are no risks to participants, and no compensation will be provided. The primary outcome measure is the presence or absence of the LCV, which will be assessed during the 10-second clinical examination.

This is a Phase 3, multicenter, 12-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of oral atogepant tablets for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in pediatric participants aged 6-17 years. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. Secondary outcome measures include changes in mean monthly headache days, acute medication use days, percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in average monthly migraine days, and changes in pediatric quality of life and disability assessments. The study includes an open-label pharmacokinetic substudy in participants aged 6-11 years to determine appropriate dosing, as well as double-blind treatment arms with low, high, and placebo doses for both age groups.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To examine the effects of a 2-week home-based targeted touchscreen training program on the learning potential of patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).

2. Intervention: The experimental group will receive 10 training sessions (5 days/week, 10 min/session) of a Swipe Slide Pattern (SSP) task on a tablet, while the control group will receive no intervention.

3. Outcomes:
   - Primary outcome: Average slide duration (in ms) on the SSP task after 2 weeks of training.
   - Secondary outcomes:
     - Performance accuracy (in %) on the SSP task at baseline, post-training (2 weeks), and retention (4 weeks).
     - Retention effects on average slide duration (in ms) after 4 weeks.
     - Consolidation effects of training, including dual-task interference and transfer to an untrained mobile phone task.

4. Study Design:
   - Randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment.
   - 36 PD patients will be randomized to the experimental or control

The study aimed to investigate the influence of intensified tactile contact between a mother and her newborn on the emotional transformation of the mother after a physiological delivery. The study used a non-randomized quasi-experimental design, with an experimental group receiving an intervention of Shantali massage (at least 2 sessions per day, 10 minutes each) starting on the 3rd day after birth and lasting until the 12th week postpartum, and a control group receiving no such intervention. 

The primary outcome measures were changes in the levels of postpartum depression, anxiety, positive and negative affects, and parental satisfaction and effectiveness, as assessed using standardized self-reported questionnaires administered at 3 days and 13 weeks postpartum. The study aimed to determine if the direction of the mother's emotional transformation differed between the experimental and control groups.

This is a non-comparative randomized phase II trial evaluating the combination of paclitaxel-bevacizumab with or without atezolizumab in patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have progressed after immunotherapy and chemotherapy. 

The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months as determined by independent review. Secondary outcome measures include PFS, objective response rate, overall survival, time to definitive health-related quality of life score deterioration, incidence and severity of adverse events, and overall health status.

Eligible patients must have advanced non-squamous NSCLC that has progressed after prior treatment with immunotherapy (anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1) and platinum-based chemotherapy. Patients are randomized to receive either paclitaxel-bevacizumab or paclitaxel-bevacizumab-atezolizumab until disease progression.

This pilot prospective cohort study aims to evaluate the feasibility and potential benefits of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) in managing persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study will enroll adults (≥18 years) who have experienced at least one new symptom (e.g., fatigue, dyspnea, anosmia) that has persisted for at least 4 weeks after COVID-19 diagnosis. The primary outcome measures are patient recruitment rate and data completion rate, which will assess the feasibility of the study. The secondary outcome measures include changes in neurocognitive, psychological, and physical symptoms, global health, and return to work status over time. Participants will receive OMT at the discretion of the treating physician, and outcomes will be assessed at regular intervals for up to 6 months after enrollment.

This is a pilot study that aims to prospectively compare the use of indocyanine green (ICG) microangiography and conventional angiography in the assessment of severe frostbite. The primary outcome is to assess the concordance between these two imaging modalities in demonstrating the ischemic tissue present in severe frostbite, as scored by the Hennepin Frostbite Score. The secondary outcome is to evaluate the safety of administering ICG dye in close association with the contrast dye used in conventional angiography, by monitoring for adverse events. The study will enroll adult patients (aged 18 and above) diagnosed with severe frostbite and undergoing thrombolysis with catheter-directed lytics. Pregnant patients and those with iodine allergy will be excluded. The study is expected to be completed within an average of 2 years.

This is a randomized, open-label controlled study that aims to assess the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in a Perioperative Geriatrics Unit (GPOU) on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over who underwent colorectal cancer surgery. The study compares the GPOU group, which receives specialized geriatric care, to a control group receiving standard management in the digestive surgery department. 

The primary outcome measure is the change in Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score between the two groups at baseline and 3 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in basic functional status, motor ability, patient satisfaction, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, discharge destination, weight change, quality of life, overall survival, and early unscheduled re-hospitalizations. The study includes patients aged 70 and over with a diagnosis of colorectal cancer who are scheduled for colorectal surgery.

This is a pilot clinical trial that aims to evaluate the toxicity and changes in tumor uptake of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) PET imaging in patients with metastatic solid tumors receiving stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT). 

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Primary Objectives:
   - To describe the toxicities of 64CDP PET, including type, frequency, severity, attribution, time course, and duration.
   - To identify changes in 64CDP uptake in radiated metastatic lesions before and after SBRT.

2. Intervention:
   - Patients receive standard-of-care pembrolizumab at baseline.
   - Patients then receive 64CDP intravenously on days 1 and 29, and undergo PET scans on days 2 and 30.
   - Patients also undergo standard-of-care SBRT between days 8-18.

3. Outcome Measures:
   - Primary outcomes include dose-limiting toxicities, changes in 64CDP uptake, changes in standard-uptake

This is a non-randomized, open-label, multi-country, cohort study to describe the safety of study participants who received the RSVPreF3 maternal vaccine or control (placebo, Tdap, or influenza vaccine) during any pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination/control in previous RSV MAT studies. The primary objectives are to assess the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy outcomes, pregnancy-related adverse events of special interest (AESIs), and infant AESIs up to 42 days post-delivery or birth of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination/control. Secondary objectives include assessing these outcomes for any pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination/control, as well as stratifying the results by selected risk factors. The study includes both retrospective and prospective cohorts of adult/adolescent participants from the previous RSV MAT studies.

This is a cross-sectional pilot study that aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of using 19F MRI to assess lung ventilation in healthy children and children with mild cystic fibrosis (CF) lung disease. The study will measure the participation rate, completion rate, and parental and child acceptability scores. It will also assess MRI-defined ventilation defect parameters and the fraction of lung volume with slow gas washout time in both healthy children and children with CF. The study will enroll participants aged 6-17 years, including both healthy volunteers and those with a diagnosis of CF. All participants will undergo 19F MRI with inhalation of the contrast gas perfluoropropane during both breath-hold and free-breathing techniques.

This study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of open kinetic chain exercises (OCKE) and closed kinetic chain exercises (CCKE) on pain, function, and balance in athletes with patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS). The study will be conducted in Pakistan, with a sample size of athletes aged 18-40 years who have experienced recurrent knee pain for at least 8 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to two groups: Group A will receive OCKE, and Group B will receive CCKE, both in addition to general training. The participants will be assessed for pain (using the Numerical Pain Rating Scale), function (using the Lower Extremity Functional Scale), and balance (using the Y Balance Test) at baseline and after 6 weeks of treatment. The data will be analyzed using SPSS software.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players. The study will include 36 male American football players, with 18 in the MIND diet group and 18 in the control group. 

The MIND diet group will be provided with the main components of the MIND diet (berries, fish, and hardaliye) and will be supported to adhere to the diet. The control group will maintain their usual eating habits. 

The primary outcome measures include biomarkers associated with neurodegenerative risk (tau protein, NfL, S100B, BDNF, telomere, zonulin) and oxidative stress (NOX2, 8-OHdG, F2-isoprostanes). The secondary outcome measures are sleep quality, quality of life, and dietary inflammatory index.

The study will last for 9 weeks, and all outcome measures will be assessed before and after the intervention period.

This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) in heart failure patients with ejection fraction below normal. The study includes two cohorts: a prospective LBBAP-HF cohort and a retrospective LBBAP-HF cohort. The primary outcome measures are the acute success rate of LBBAP and the incidence of acute procedure-related complications. The secondary outcome measures include the incidence of repeat procedures, pacemaker upgrade to cardiac resynchronization therapy, heart failure hospitalization, cardiovascular death, all-cause death, and changes in echocardiographic parameters and lead parameters over one year. The study will enroll patients aged 19 years and older with left ventricular ejection fraction less than or equal to 50%, and who have indications for cardiac pacing or cardiac resynchronization therapy.

This was a Phase 1a, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single-site, single ascending dose study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 injection in healthy adult participants. The study enrolled healthy adults aged 18-50 years and excluded those with positive drug screens or significant medical conditions. Participants were randomized to receive either single doses of CSX-1004 or placebo. The primary outcome measures were treatment-emergent adverse events, clinical laboratory assessments, vital signs, ECG, physical examination, and infusion site examination. The secondary outcome measures were pharmacokinetic parameters including Cmax, AUCinf, AUClast, Tmax, and t1/2.

The study aims to evaluate the concordance between joint fluid aspiration (JFA) and perioperative samples in patients with dysfunctional hip, knee, or shoulder prostheses. The study is a prospective cohort study where all included patients reporting prosthesis complications will undergo JFA. The primary outcome measure is the analysis of the bacteriological concordance between JFA and perioperative samples. The study includes patients aged 18 years and above with hip, knee, or shoulder joint prostheses who have an indication for JFA, regardless of the cause of revision (mechanical or septic). Patients with acute prosthesis infection with less than one-month symptoms' duration, those receiving antibiotic therapy between preoperative JFA and intraoperative samples, and pregnant or breastfeeding women are excluded.

This clinical trial aims to quantify and spatially register airway dysfunction in individuals with cystic fibrosis using dynamic 19F MRI. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Participants: Adults (≥18 years) with a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, who are non-smokers and have stable lung function.

2. Intervention: Inhalation of a biologically inert contrast gas, perfluoropropane, combined with 19F-tuned MRI during breath-hold and tidal breathing.

3. Primary Outcomes:
   - Change in Ventilation Defect Parameter (VDP) and Functional Lung Volume (FLVlongtau2) over 14 days and 365 days.
   - Changes in VDP and FLVlongtau2 during cystic fibrosis pulmonary exacerbations.

4. Secondary Outcomes:
   - Change in MRI severity score over 365 days.
   - Correlation of MRI severity score with VDP and FLVlongtau2 at baseline.

The study aims to evaluate

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a randomized, open-label, two-sequence, two-cycle, double-cross design bioequivalence study of a single oral dose of the drug STI-1558 in 32 healthy Chinese subjects under fasting conditions. The study aims to compare the pharmacokinetic parameters, including Cmax, AUC0-t, AUC0-inf, Tmax, t1/2, λz, and %AUCex, between the test preparation and the reference preparation of STI-1558 to establish the relative bioavailability. The subjects will be randomly assigned to two groups (TR and RT) and will receive either the test or reference preparation on different days, with a washout period of at least 7 days between doses. The study will evaluate the safety and tolerability of STI-1558 as well.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of disengaging the breathing circuit when transitioning patients from the supine to lateral position during thoracic surgery requiring a left-sided double-lumen endotracheal tube. The primary outcome is the rate of double-lumen tube malposition, defined as more than 5 mm away from the optimal position or severe malposition. Secondary outcomes include the quality of lung collapse, blood oxygen saturation, and post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) length of stay. Eligible patients are adults aged 18-65 years undergoing elective thoracic surgery, with exclusions for certain medical conditions. Participants are randomized to either have the breathing circuit disengaged or maintained in the normal connected state when the patient's position is changed. The study measures outcomes immediately after the position change and at various time points during the surgery.

This is a randomized, open-label clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of personalized comprehensive diabetes support on families of children (aged 16 years or younger) with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes. The primary outcome measures are the Diabetes Distress Scale (DDS) and the Problem Areas in Diabetes (PAID) scale, which assess diabetes-related stress and distress. Participants will be randomized to receive either personalized comprehensive diabetes support for 6 months following diagnosis or no intervention (control group). The study will follow participants for 24 months.

This is a randomized, multicenter clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of telemedicine monitoring, added to usual care, on the management of major depressive disorder (MDD) in patients hospitalized in medicine, surgery, or obstetrics (MSO) departments. 

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Objective: To assess the efficacy of telemedicine monitoring on depressive symptoms and treatments, added to the out-of-hospital downstream care pathways for MDD patients initially hospitalized in MSO, compared to usual care.

2. Intervention: Patients in the intervention group will receive usual care plus telemedicine sessions led by a nurse/psychologist under the supervision of a psychiatrist. The sessions follow a standardized protocol with evaluations of treatment tolerance/efficacy, depressive symptoms, daily difficulties, and therapeutic recommendations.

3. Outcomes: The primary outcome is the treatment response rate (≥50% reduction in HADS-Depression score) at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include incremental cost-utility ratio, quality of life, relapse episodes, medication compliance, therapeutic efficacy, feasibility and satisfaction of telemedicine, and clinical variables associated

The study aims to develop an AI algorithm that can differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses using quantitative MRI data. Patients with a soft tissue mass who are undergoing standard-of-care MRI will be asked to participate. The participants will undergo an additional 10 minutes of quantitative MRI sequences during their scan. A subset of patients will be invited back for a repeat MRI scan to assess the reproducibility of the quantitative scans and the AI algorithms. The primary outcome is the diagnostic accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity of the AI algorithms in distinguishing between benign and malignant soft tissue lesions. The secondary outcome is the classification accuracy of the AI algorithms in categorizing malignant lesions into different pathological grades.

Summary:

This is a split-mouth randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to comparatively evaluate the effects of microneedling alone versus microneedling along with hyaluronic acid on thin gingival phenotype. The study will be conducted on 20 systemically healthy patients with thin gingival phenotypes. Each patient will have one side of the anterior mandible randomly assigned to either the microneedling alone group or the microneedling with hyaluronic acid group. The primary outcome measure is the change in gingival thickness, which will be assessed at baseline, 1 month, 6 months, and 9 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in keratinized tissue width and periodontal indices such as gingival index, bleeding on probing, and probing depth. The study aims to determine if the addition of hyaluronic acid to microneedling can provide greater improvements in gingival thickness compared to microneedling alone in patients with thin gingival phenotypes.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial (RCT) investigating the effects of preoperative immunonutrition on patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. The study aims to evaluate changes in adipose tissue inflammation and its correlation with surgical outcomes, with the goal of informing future ERAS (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery) guidelines.

The study includes two arms: 
1) Active Comparator: Patients receive the oral supplement Oral Impact for 10 days before colorectal surgery.
2) Placebo Comparator: Patients receive a placebo for 10 days before colorectal surgery.

The primary outcome measure is the number of participants developing surgical site infections (SSI) within 30 days after the surgical procedure. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of anastomotic leakage, length of hospital stay, and changes in inflammatory infiltration, fibrosis, and adipocyte cross-sectional area in subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissue samples.

The study population includes adults aged 20 to 85 years with primary colorectal neoplasms eligible for elective, minimally invasive colorectal

The study aims to investigate the impact and potential additional benefits of adding an oculomotor treatment to a cervical manual therapy protocol in patients with migraine. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two parallel groups: a control group receiving cervical treatment only, and an experimental group receiving both cervical and oculomotor treatments. The primary outcome measure is the change in the impact of migraine using the Headache Impact Test (HIT-6) questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include changes in pain, disability, depression, anxiety, sleep quality, kinesiophobia, catastrophizing, central sensitization, neck disability, head repositioning, deep cervical flexor strength, ocular movement, range of motion, and quality of life. These outcomes will be assessed at baseline, 6 weeks, and 3 months after the intervention.

The key aspects of the CRATOS clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To evaluate the Cratos™ Branch Stent Graft System in the treatment of descending aorta lesions, including aortic dissection type B, intramural hematoma, and penetrating aortic ulcer.

2. Intervention: Patients will undergo thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) procedure using the Cratos™ Stent Graft device.

3. Primary Outcome: The study will measure all-cause mortality at 30 days.

4. Eligibility Criteria: Key inclusion criteria include presence of thoracic aortic pathology requiring surgical repair, appropriate aortic landing zones, and age ≥18 years. Key exclusion criteria include concomitant ascending aortic disease, previous endovascular repair, active infection, and renal failure.

5. Study Design: This is a single-arm, open-label study with a primary purpose of treatment.

This is a comparative study that aims to describe the level obtained with the Shamrock technique and compare the depth of the lumbar plexus, image quality, and presence of vessels between the Trident and Shamrock techniques for ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus block. The primary outcome measure is the projection of the C line (obtained with a probe placed on the iliac crest) on the costal processes. The secondary outcome measures are the depth of the lumbar plexus, image quality, and presence of vessels, which will be analyzed for both the Trident and Shamrock techniques.

This is a prospective randomized trial to investigate the efficacy of standardized preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) in reducing stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and improving patient quality of life following Holmium Laser Enucleation of the Prostate (HoLEP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). 

The study will randomize patients into two groups: 
1) Preoperative PFPT group - patients will start PFPT 1 month before HoLEP surgery.
2) Postoperative PFPT group - patients will start PFPT after HoLEP surgery (standard of care).

The primary outcome is time to recover from transient postoperative SUI, measured at 6 months after surgery. Secondary outcomes include uroflow, post-void residual, International Prostate Symptom Score, operative time, length of hospital stay, catheter duration, infectious complications, and emergency room visits.

The study aims to determine the role of preoperative PFPT in managing HoLEP-associated SUI and improving patient outcomes

The DETECT-IP study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) in reducing adverse drug events (ADEs) such as acute renal failure and hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients. The study has a prospective, multicenter, controlled, single-blind, and randomized cluster design with a stepped-wedge approach. Eligible participants are hospitalized patients aged 65 years or older who have been admitted for at least 3 days. The intervention group will receive the CDSS, which will provide pharmaceutical validation and interventions based on the alerts generated, while the control group will receive routine care. The primary outcome is the number of ADEs, and secondary outcomes include the presence of adverse events related to the intervention, therapeutic adaptations implemented in case of acute renal failure or hyperkalemia, the relevance of CDSS alerts, the number of pharmaceutical interventions accepted, changes in ADE prevention/management work processes, and the cost-effectiveness of the intervention.

This is a clinical trial studying the role of mesenteric bacterial translocation in Crohn's disease. The study aims to compare the bacterial composition and function in the mesentery, ileal tissue, and blood between Crohn's disease patients requiring ileocecal resection and a control group requiring ileocecal resection for other reasons. The primary outcome measures are the differences in bacterial taxa and metagenome function between Crohn's disease patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. The secondary outcome measure is the association between genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile in Crohn's disease patients.

This is a clinical trial study to evaluate the effect of injection site on the relative bioavailability of a single dose of LY3437943 in healthy participants with a high body mass index (BMI). The study has two parts:

Part A: Participants will receive a single subcutaneous (SC) dose of LY3437943 administered in either the thigh, upper arm, or abdomen. The primary outcome measures are the pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters of area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to infinity (AUC[0-∞]) and maximum concentration (Cmax) of LY3437943.

Part B: Participants will receive a single intravenous (IV) dose of LY3437943. The primary outcome measures are the PK parameters of AUC(0-∞) and Cmax of LY3437943.

The study enrolls healthy male and female participants aged 18 to 70 years with a BMI between 27.0 and 45.0 kg/m².

This is a research registry study on aggressive pituitary neuroendocrine tumors (PitNETs). The study aims to characterize the aggressiveness of pituitary tumors through transcriptome analysis, with the goal of identifying molecular and transcriptomic signatures that can predict prognosis. The study includes adult patients with a diagnosis of pituitary tumor whose case has been presented to the national HYPOcare multidisciplinary team. There is only one participant group, and no interventions or treatments are provided as part of the study. The primary outcome measure is the characterization of the aggressiveness of pituitary tumors through transcriptome analysis, which will be assessed over a 3-year period.

The key aspects of the OPTI-DOSE clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To investigate whether a lower starting dose with step-up approach of oral anticancer drugs leads to better treatment tolerability in older patients (≥65 years) compared to standard dosing.

2. Design: Randomized, open-label pilot study with 1:1 allocation to either the control group (standard dosing) or the intervention group (lower starting dose with dose escalation).

3. Participants: 30 older adult patients (≥65 years) with indications for pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib or palbociclib.

4. Interventions: 
   - Control group: Standard starting dose as per the drug label, with dose adjustments for toxicity.
   - Intervention group: Lower starting dose with dose escalation every 2 weeks if well tolerated.

5. Primary Outcome: Feasibility of the study design, measured by patient recruitment, completion rates, and data collection.

6. Secondary Outcomes: Overall treatment utility, progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study (PRECAM-R) that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of preoperative short-course radiation followed by envafolimab plus CAPEOX (oxaliplatin and capecitabine) in patients with mismatch repair proficient (MSS) locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma.

The primary outcome is the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate following the treatment regimen. Secondary outcomes include tumor regression grade, overall survival, progression-free survival, treatment-related adverse events, surgical complications, and quality of life.

Eligible patients are 18 years or older with histologically confirmed rectal adenocarcinoma, clinical stage cT2-4a N+ or cT3/T4a N0, and confirmed mismatch repair proficient (pMMR) or microsatellite stable (MSS) status. Patients will be randomized to receive either the experimental arm of short-course radiation followed by envafolimab plus CAPEOX, or the control arm of short-course radiation followed by CAPEOX alone, prior to total meso

This is a two-stage clinical trial studying the efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of various doses of the drug levilimab administered intravenously and subcutaneously to healthy subjects and subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis.

Stage 1 is an open-label, single-center, non-randomized cohort study evaluating the safety and tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of single doses of levilimab in healthy subjects.

Stage 2 is a randomized, comparative, double-blind, controlled study assessing the efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of repeated doses of levilimab in combination with methotrexate in subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis resistant to methotrexate monotherapy.

The primary outcome measures are:
- Safety profile of levilimab in healthy subjects (Stage 1)
- Proportion of subjects with low disease activity (DAS28-ESR <3.2) at Week 24 (Stage 2)

Key secondary outcome measures include assessments

This was a randomized, double-blind, crossover clinical trial that evaluated the efficacy of white kidney bean on oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) in healthy adults aged 25-45 years. The study enrolled 35 participants, with 30 completing the trial. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either white kidney bean extract (Wonderlab Product) or placebo in two phases, with a 72-hour washout period between phases. The primary outcome measure was the change in blood glucose level during OGTT after the intervention. The secondary outcome measure was the change in fasting blood glucose level during OGTT after the intervention. The study aimed to assess the impact of white kidney bean extract on glucose tolerance and metabolism in healthy adults.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the implementation of evidence-based facility and community interventions to reduce the treatment gap for depression. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Intervention:
   - Experimental arm: Facility-based Healthy Activity Program (HAP) plus community intervention delivered by community volunteers (Sangathis).
   - Control arm: Facility-based HAP alone.

2. Outcomes:
   - Primary outcomes:
     - Contact coverage: Proportion of adults with PHQ-9 score >4.
     - Effectiveness coverage: Mean PHQ-9 score.
   - Secondary outcomes:
     - Sustained effectiveness, remission, response to treatment, costs, disability, depression awareness, social support, and treatment completion.

3. Eligibility:
   - Inclusion: Adults (>18 years) residing in the trial clusters, speaking English or local languages, and intending to stay for at least 3 months.
   - Exclusion: Significant speech/hearing/language impairment, presenting for emergency care, and active psychotic symptoms.

4. Study design:
   -

This study investigates the acute and chronic effects of low-intensity blood flow restriction training in normoxia (normal oxygen) and hypoxia (low oxygen) conditions on muscle strength, thickness, catecholamine, and inflammatory responses in physically active adults.

The study has five participant groups:
1. Low-Intensity Normoxia: Participants perform low-intensity resistance training in normal oxygen conditions.
2. High-Intensity Normoxia: Participants perform high-intensity resistance training in normal oxygen conditions.
3. Low-Intensity Normoxia with Blood Flow Restriction: Participants perform low-intensity resistance training combined with blood flow restriction in normal oxygen conditions.
4. Low-Intensity Hypoxia: Participants perform low-intensity resistance training in hypoxia (low oxygen) conditions.
5. Low-Intensity Hypoxia with Blood Flow Restriction: Participants perform low-intensity resistance training combined with blood flow restriction in hypoxia conditions.

The primary outcome measures include force output, one-repetition maximum, maximum number of repetitions, countermovement jump height and power output, catecholamine response, muscle stiffness, and muscle thickness

This is a Phase II, open-label, single-arm clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of subcutaneous mosunetuzumab monotherapy in patients with follicular lymphoma who have experienced early relapse or progression within 24 months of starting first-line treatment (POD24). The primary objective is to investigate the progression-free survival (PFS) at 2 years after initiation of second-line treatment with mosunetuzumab. Secondary objectives include assessing overall response rate, complete response rate, duration of response, time to next treatment, overall survival, safety, and rate of transformation to higher-grade lymphoma. Eligible patients must have received one prior line of systemic therapy and have at least one measurable lesion. The study will enroll patients in the Nordic countries and follow them for a minimum of 2.5 years and a maximum of 5 years.
