This is a phase I/II clinical trial evaluating the combination of the BRD4 inhibitor PLX2853 and the MEK inhibitor trametinib in the treatment of advanced uveal melanoma. 

The primary objectives are:
1) To determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase II dose of the combination (phase I).
2) To evaluate whether the combination demonstrates a clinical activity rate of at least 25% compared to a historical rate of 10% (phase II).

The secondary objectives are to evaluate the overall response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, and safety profile of the combination treatment. The pharmacokinetics of the combination will also be assessed.

Eligible patients must have advanced, unresectable or metastatic uveal melanoma, with measurable disease. Patients may have received prior systemic or liver-directed therapies. The study uses an open-label, single-group assignment design.

The primary outcome measures are the MTD and recommended phase II dose (phase I). The secondary outcome measures include overall response rate, progression-free

The ASCERTAIN study is a 2-arm, multicenter, phase IV, randomized, open-label study designed to evaluate the implementation and utility of a primary care model in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated LDL-C. 

The study will include approximately 600 participants aged 18 years or older with a history of ASCVD or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated LDL-C (≥1.8 mmol/L). Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to either the usual care model or the new model of care.

In the usual care arm, the general practitioners (GPs) will be educated on the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines and Guideline Directed Management Therapy (GDMT), and inclisiran will be available for use at the treating physician's discretion.

In the new model of care arm, the GPs will receive the same education, and participants will additionally receive monthly SMS messages regarding cardiovascular health and appointment reminders, as well as telephone-based support calls from

This was a randomized, controlled, single-blinded study that compared the efficacy of ultrasound-guided erector spinae block, thoracic paravertebral block, and quadratus lumborum block in patients undergoing open renal surgeries. The study enrolled 48 patients aged 21-65 years, who were randomly assigned to one of three groups: erector spinae block, thoracic paravertebral block, or control group (receiving intravenous morphine). The primary outcome measure was the total morphine requirements in the first 24 hours postoperatively.

This is a mixed methods study that aims to describe and evaluate the musculoskeletal health of adult hematological cancer survivors and its impact on them. The study will use questionnaires and interviews to:

1. Measure the prevalence of musculoskeletal conditions, related symptoms, sarcopenia, frailty, and assess quality of life and musculoskeletal function in adult lymphoma and leukemia survivors.

2. Calculate the 10-year probability of hip fracture and major osteoporotic fracture in these survivors.

3. Describe the experiences of adult lymphoma and leukemia survivors regarding their musculoskeletal health, related care, and information provision.

4. Identify potential risk factors associated with poor musculoskeletal health in these survivors.

The study includes participants of different age groups (18-30, 31-50, 51-70, 70+) and time since cancer treatment (5-10 years, 11-20 years, 21-30 years, 30+ years), both male and female. It is not an intervention study.

This is a phase 2 basket study evaluating the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin in adult patients with previously treated, locally advanced unresectable or metastatic solid tumors that express HER2. The study includes four cohorts: head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), ovarian cancer, and endometrial cancer. The primary outcome is the confirmed objective response rate (ORR) per RECIST v1.1 as assessed by the investigator. Secondary outcomes include safety, disease control rate, duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and pharmacokinetics. Eligible patients must have received prior therapies and have measurable disease with HER2 expression. The study uses a single-arm, open-label design, with disitamab vedotin administered intravenously every 2 weeks.

This study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of using in-vehicle driving assessments and neurocognitive evaluations to characterize driving behaviors and safety in older adults who have survived critical illness and developed Post-Intensive Care Syndrome (PICS). The study will enroll 24 older adults (aged 55 and above) who have had an ICU stay with delirium and are expected to survive hospital discharge. Participants will undergo neurocognitive assessments and have their driving data collected via in-vehicle sensors over a 6-month period after hospital discharge. The study will evaluate the relationship between neurocognitive function and driving behavior, as well as conduct stakeholder advisory panels to understand priorities and data presentation needs for driving assessments in this population. The goal is to develop an evidence-based, in-vehicle driving assessment system to provide actionable driving safety data and rehabilitation strategies for ICU survivors, their care partners, and clinicians.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a brief (approximately 4-hour) Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) workshop for promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors in women with obesity. 

The study will recruit 70 women with a BMI over 30 kg/m2. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the ACT workshop intervention group or a waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures are changes from baseline in psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, and valued living at 1 week and 1 month post-intervention. Secondary outcomes include changes in weight self-stigma, body image, emotional eating, physical activity, and diet quality at 1 week and 1 month.

Participants in the intervention group will receive the ACT workshop, which aims to facilitate the development and maintenance of healthy lifestyle behaviors using ACT principles. The waitlist control group will not receive the intervention until after the intervention group has completed the workshop.

This is a one-arm prospective observational clinical study that aims to evaluate the value of minimal residual disease (MRD) detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence of high-risk gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) and investigate the effect of a drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection on disease recurrence and patient survival. The study will enroll GIST patients at high risk of recurrence who have received 3 years of imatinib adjuvant therapy after surgery and have no detectable disease. Eligible patients will stop imatinib treatment and be monitored for disease progression using MRD detection and imaging. The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival after entering the drug holiday, the rate of drug re-use due to disease progression, and the response rate to re-treatment. Secondary outcomes include overall survival, genetic mutation profiling of ctDNA-MRD, and the comparison of MRD conversion and disease progression by imaging. The study aims to explore whether a drug holiday approach based on MRD monitoring can delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations in high-risk GIST patients.

This study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. Participants with Down syndrome meeting the inclusion and exclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to two groups. One group will receive Dohsa hou exercises, while the other group will receive standard treatment protocol, including soft tissue massage, task-specific training, bicycle training, and aerobic exercises. The primary outcome measures are the Trunk Impairment Scale and the Time Up and Go test, which will be assessed at the end of the 6-week intervention period. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Dohsa hou exercises in improving functional mobility in children with Down syndrome.

The Supporting Physical Literacy at School and Home (SPLASH) study is a group randomized controlled trial that aims to increase physical activity (PA) in elementary school children through a multilevel, comprehensive physical literacy (PL) program. The study will test the effectiveness of the Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program, which includes a school-based physical education curriculum and a family engagement component. The primary outcomes are changes in children's total daily PA volume and moderate-to-vigorous PA (MVPA) from baseline to end-point, measured using accelerometers. The secondary outcomes are changes in children's fundamental movement skills, assessed using the Physical Literacy Assessment for Youth tool. The study will also examine whether the program effects differ by sex or weight status, and whether changes in PL mediate changes in PA. The study will enroll 400 third to fifth grade students from low-income schools, with half receiving the RNYRR program and half serving as delayed-intervention controls.

This is a Phase III, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, 76-week clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of BI 456906 (survodutide) administered subcutaneously compared to placebo in Japanese patients with obesity. The primary outcome measures are the percentage change in body weight and the achievement of at least 5% body weight reduction from baseline to week 76. Secondary outcome measures include additional body weight reduction thresholds, changes in body composition, cardiometabolic parameters, and patient-reported eating behavior. Eligible participants are adults with a BMI ≥35 kg/m² or BMI ≥27 kg/m² with at least two obesity-related comorbidities. The study has three arms: BI 456906 3.6 mg, BI 456906 6.0 mg, and placebo, all administered as once-weekly subcutaneous injections.

The study aims to evaluate the gastric volume in pediatric patients undergoing adenotonsillectomy surgery using ultrasound. The primary outcome measure is the gastric volume (ml/kg) measured during the operation. The secondary outcome measures include the cross-sectional area of the stomach (ACSA) at different time points (preoperative, after intubation, and postoperative), the presence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), the blood volume in the suction system, and the duration of surgery. The study is a prospective cohort study with a single group assignment, and it will include ASA 1-3 patients aged 1-18 years undergoing elective adenotonsillectomy surgery.

This is a randomized controlled study investigating the effect of pituitrin on postoperative outcomes in patients with pulmonary hypertension undergoing cardiac surgery. Patients aged 18-80 years with pulmonary hypertension scheduled for elective cardiac surgery will be randomly assigned to receive either pituitrin or normal saline. The primary outcome is a composite endpoint of mortality or severe postoperative complications within 30 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes include incidence of postoperative infection, septic shock, duration of mechanical ventilation, pulmonary complications, time to hemodynamic stability, use of vasoactive drugs, and various other clinical outcomes. The study also aims to evaluate changes in serum antidiuretic hormone and copeptin levels over time. This trial aims to provide evidence on the potential benefits of pituitrin in improving postoperative prognosis for cardiac surgery patients with pulmonary hypertension.

This is a single-site feasibility and safety study that evaluates the feasibility and safety of initiating noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) in the home environment for children with medical complexity, compared to the standard of care which is initiation during an in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) study.

The study will randomize participants 1:1 to either home initiation of NiPPV using remote telemonitoring, or standard in-hospital PSG-based initiation. The primary outcomes are recruitment and retention rates, and the proportion of eligible patients randomized and the proportion that crossover based on safety criteria. Secondary outcomes include adherence to NiPPV, quality of life, caregiver sense of mastery, and differences in NiPPV settings between home titration and PSG-based titration.

The study aims to determine the feasibility and safety of a home-based model of NiPPV initiation compared to the standard in-hospital PSG-based approach for children with medical complexity who require chronic respiratory support.

This is a single-blind randomized clinical trial that aims to investigate the effects of dry needling on latent myofascial trigger points (MTPs) in the gastrocnemius muscle on vertical jump performance in female volleyball players. Healthy female volleyball players with no lower limb injuries in the last 6 months and presence of latent MTPs in the gastrocnemius will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group (receiving dry needling) or a control group. All participants will perform a standard warm-up and 3 countermovement jump (CMJ) tests at baseline (T0), immediately after the intervention (T1), 72 hours (T3), and 7 days (T4) later. The primary outcome measure is the CMJ performance. The study is designed to be single-blind, with the assessor blinded to the group allocation.

This study aimed to investigate the clinical features and outcomes of using mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) in pediatric patients with refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). The study enrolled patients aged 3 to 18 years old who met the diagnostic criteria for HSP with gastrointestinal involvement, and who were refractory to intravenous corticosteroid treatment. The primary outcome measure was the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools, assessed by checklist over a 6-month period. The secondary outcome measure was the count of red blood cells in stool, tested weekly over 6 months. This was an open-label, single-group assignment study, with the intervention being the administration of MMF to treat the refractory gastrointestinal HSP.

This is a staged, open-label, Phase II/III clinical trial investigating the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of adjunctive, midline prefrontal, lower intensity, shorter session, EEG-enhanced, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (eTMS) for the treatment of chronic trauma and stressor-related disorders (TSRD) in veterans. The primary outcome measures are the number of participants with device-related serious adverse events and the rate of participants completing 80% of scheduled visits. The secondary outcome measure is the mean change in mental component scores on the Veterans RAND 36-item health survey. The study will initially enroll 30 participants, with an interim analysis after 6 weeks, and if safety benchmarks are met, an additional 270 participants will be enrolled using randomization to multiple baselines for efficacy analyses.

This is a retrospective study that evaluates the efficacy of combining radiotherapy (3DCRT or IMRT) with EGFR-TKI therapy in patients with stage III EGFR-mutant lung cancer. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) at 2 years. Eligible patients must have EGFR-mutant lung cancer, stage IIIA-IIIC, and an ECOG performance status of 0-2. Patients who underwent prior surgery or chemotherapy were excluded. The treatment regimen involves radiotherapy (54-66 Gy in 27-33 fractions) combined with an EGFR-TKI (gefitinib, erlotinib, osimertinib, or amivantamab) taken until disease progression or intolerance.

The study aims to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute head and neck infections. It will enroll patients over 18 years old who are suffering from acute head and neck infections caused by Streptococci, with samples collected from Northampton General Hospital. The primary outcome is the identification of Streptococci species through DNA analysis and biochemical testing. The secondary outcomes include patient characteristics (age, sex, site of infection) and clinical outcomes (length of hospital stay, antibiotic treatment, diabetic status). The study will be conducted over a 4-year period.

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of functional magnetic stimulation (FMS) and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) on pelvic floor muscle function, urinary incontinence symptoms, and quality of life in women with stress urinary incontinence. 

The study included 48 women aged 29-49 years with stress urinary incontinence for at least 4 weeks. Participants were randomly assigned to either the FMS group (n=24) or the PFMT group (n=24). Outcomes were assessed before and after 6 weeks of intervention. 

The primary outcome measures were:
1. Urinary incontinence symptoms and quality of life assessed using the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire (IIQ-7).
2. Pelvic floor muscle strength and endurance measured by perineometry.

The study was a randomized, parallel-group design with single-blinding.

This clinical trial aims to optimize the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies for patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA) and seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The study will generate a comprehensive cellular and molecular atlas of the synovium in different PsA and RA patient populations, including those at risk of PsA development, treatment-naive PsA, TNF-inhibitor resistant PsA, IL-17-inhibitor resistant PsA, TNF-inhibitor induced remission PsA, IL-17-inhibitor induced remission PsA, and cDMARD-resistant PsA and RA. The primary outcome measures are the achievement of minimal disease activity status, PsA development in patients with psoriasis and arthralgia, and remission maintenance in PsA patients in sustained remission. The study will utilize techniques such as CITE-Seq (single-cell protein and transcriptomics) and spatial transcriptomics to analyze the synovial immune and stromal cells.

This is a randomized, open-label clinical trial investigating the use of artificial tears to prevent nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) in patients treated with radioactive iodine for thyroid cancer. Eligible participants will be randomized to either receive artificial tears (methylcellulose) or no intervention in the 4 days following radioactive iodine therapy. The primary outcome is the incidence of post-radiotherapy NLDO, assessed by tear duct irrigation by an ophthalmologist, over a 2-year follow-up period.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase II clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of atorvastatin in preventing disease metastasis in patients with resected high-risk stage IIA melanoma. The primary objective is to compare recurrence-free survival (RFS) between patients treated with atorvastatin and those receiving placebo. Secondary objectives include comparing distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS) and overall survival (OS) between the two treatment arms. The study will also assess the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma. Eligible patients will be randomized to receive either atorvastatin or placebo orally once daily for up to 5 years, and will undergo regular CT and/or MRI imaging throughout the study. After completion of study treatment, patients will be followed for an additional 5 years.

This clinical trial aims to determine the impact of three implementation strategies (training, coaching, facilitation) on improving clinic fidelity to an outpatient hypertension bundle in 20 outpatient clinics in central North Carolina. The study will compare usual clinic care for severe hypertension to the care provided after 12 months of implementation support from the ACHIEVE Nurse Coordinator. The primary outcome measures are the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible scores for blood pressure measurement technique and documentation of patient education on hypertension. Secondary outcome measures include the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible scores for recognition and response to simulated and actual episodes of severe hypertension. The study uses a hybrid type III, multiple baseline design, with the 20 clinics divided into three consecutive and overlapping cohorts receiving the intervention. The study aims to improve maternal health outcomes for rural, low-income, and minority populations who are at greatest risk for complications of high blood pressure in pregnancy and postpartum.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of three text-messaging programs using gain-framed, loss-framed, or combined gain and loss-framed messaging to reduce drinking among older adults (aged 50-85) with hazardous drinking. The study will randomize 150 participants to one of the three conditions, each lasting 8 weeks. Participants will undergo assessments at baseline, week 4, week 8, and week 16 to measure the primary outcomes of weekly sum of standard drinks and weekly sum of heavy drinking days. Secondary outcomes include adherence to daily and weekly drinking assessments via text and web, and willingness to continue the program for another 8 weeks. The study will also explore the impact of gender and age on the effects of the interventions.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the radiotracer 18F-Fluselenamyl for PET imaging in individuals with Alzheimer's disease and healthy volunteers. The primary objectives are to assess the biodistribution, kinetics, and human dosimetry of 18F-Fluselenamyl, as well as its ability to detect amyloid-beta in the brain compared to the established tracer 11C-PIB. The study will enroll healthy participants and those with mild cognitive impairment, and will measure safety outcomes and PET imaging results over a 1-2 year period.

This is a randomized, triple-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the long-term effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) combined with language therapy in patients with primary progressive aphasia (PPA). Eligible participants will be randomly assigned to receive either active TMS plus language therapy or sham TMS plus language therapy for 6 months. The primary outcome measure is changes in brain metabolism assessed by FDG-PET imaging at baseline and 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in spontaneous language, language assessment, daily living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms at 0, 3, and 6 months. The study aims to evaluate the long-term therapeutic potential of TMS combined with language therapy in improving language and cognitive function in patients with PPA.

This is a phase 2a, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial investigating the effects of methylprednisolone on cognitive deficits in patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS). The primary objective is to demonstrate improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) in PCS patients treated with methylprednisolone compared to placebo. 

The study will enroll adults with a history of confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and ongoing PCS symptoms, including self-reported cognitive deficits, for at least 3 months. Participants will be randomized 1:1 to receive either methylprednisolone or placebo for 6 weeks, followed by an additional 6 weeks of open-label methylprednisolone treatment. 

Key secondary outcomes include long-term improvement in memory satisfaction, memory ability, and memory strategy (MMQ), neurocognitive function (Montreal Cognitive Assessment, Symbol Digit Modalities Test), quality of life (PROMIS), fatigue (Chalder Fatigue Scale, Fatigue Severity Score

This is a clinical trial that aims to analyze the aetiological factors of malnutrition, specifically focusing on the role of inflammation and oral intake. The study will evaluate the effects of an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols on various biochemical, body composition, functional, and dietary parameters in patients with disease-related malnutrition and an inflammatory component. The primary outcome measures include changes in blood biochemistry data such as albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, and others over a 3-month period. Secondary outcome measures include changes in bioelectrical impedance data, functional parameters, and detailed dietary intake. The study will enroll adult patients diagnosed with disease-related malnutrition based on the GLIM criteria, with the presence of an inflammatory component. Patients with certain medical conditions, such as advanced liver disease, cancer, or renal insufficiency, will be excluded.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Study Design:
   - Randomized, parallel-group study
   - Intervention group receives financial support and free home delivery of healthy foods (e.g., fruits and vegetables) for 6 months
   - Control group receives only free home delivery of foods for 6 months

2. Primary Outcome:
   - Change in glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level at 6 months

3. Secondary Outcomes:
   - Change in HbA1c at 12 months
   - Percentage of participants with HbA1c < 7.5% at 6 and 12 months
   - All-cause hospitalizations or emergency department visits at 3, 6, and 12 months
   - Changes in self-reported food security, nutrition security, dietary habits, diabetes-related quality of life, and readiness to change at 6 and 12 months

4. Participant Eligibility:
   - Adults aged 18 years or older with type 2 diabetes, active Kaiser Permanente membership, and Medi

This is a four-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the effect of prolonged evaporation time of the solvent in two universal adhesives on the quality of non-carious cervical lesion restorations.

The study has four groups:
1. Experimental group 1: Composite resin restorations using an alcohol- and water-based universal adhesive with 25-second solvent evaporation.
2. Experimental group 2: Composite resin restorations using an acetone-based universal adhesive with 25-second solvent evaporation. 
3. Control group 1: Composite resin restorations using an alcohol- and water-based universal adhesive with 5-second solvent evaporation.
4. Control group 2: Composite resin restorations using an acetone-based universal adhesive with 5-second solvent evaporation.

The primary outcome is the retention of the restorations, and the secondary outcomes are the marginal adaptation and marginal staining of the restorations, measured using the World Dental Federation (FDI) criteria. The study will

This is a Phase II/III, randomized, double-blinded, parallel-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy of SWIM816 vaccines for SARS-CoV-2 in previously vaccinated adults.

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Objectives:
   - Evaluate the immunogenicity of SWIM816 vaccines in terms of geometric mean titers (GMT) and geometric mean fold rise (GMFR) of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron and reference strain neutralizing antibodies.
   - Assess the safety of SWIM816 vaccines in terms of local and systemic adverse events.
   - Evaluate the efficacy of SWIM816 vaccines in preventing symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection.

2. Study Design:
   - Phase II: Two groups (SWIM816 and SW-BIC-213), 100 participants each, aged ≥18 years.
   - Phase III: Two groups (SWIM816 and Pfizer Bivalent vaccine), 300 participants each, aged ≥18

The Esbjerg Cohort is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the relationship between ergonomic exposure, physical capacity, work ability, and musculoskeletal pain in workers aged 55 to 70 years old. The study involves a health examination that includes physical tests, questionnaires, and a blood test. The primary outcome measure is work ability, assessed using the Work Ability Index (WAI) questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include anthropometric measurements, sensory testing, physical activity, musculoskeletal pain, and various physical performance tests. The study population consists of 336 participants from the Esbjerg municipality in Denmark, stratified by gender, age, and occupational group (white-collar or blue-collar). The goal is to provide knowledge about the consequences of high physical workload on the musculoskeletal system in older workers, which can inform better treatment, counseling, and guidelines for optimizing the balance between physical work demands and worker capacity.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This is a phase I, open-label, single-arm study evaluating the safety and feasibility of autologous T cells lentivirally transduced to express L1CAM-specific chimeric antigen receptors (CAR) in patients with locally advanced, unresectable or metastatic small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer (SCNPC). 

The main objectives are to assess the incidence of adverse events, including dose-limiting toxicities, as well as to evaluate objective response rate, radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.

Eligible patients undergo leukapheresis to obtain peripheral blood mononuclear cells for manufacturing of the autologous L1CAM-specific CAR T cells. Patients then receive lymphodepleting chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and fludarabine or bendamustine, followed by infusion of the CAR T cells on day 0. Patients may receive additional lymphodepletion and CAR T cell infusions based on disease response and CAR T cell persistence.

Patients undergo various assessments throughout the study, including imaging

This study aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of a new surgical technique called Whipple over the Splenic Artery (WOTSA) as an alternative to total pancreatectomy (TP) for the treatment of pancreatic ductal cell adenocarcinoma (PDCA). The study included 40 consecutive patients who underwent WOTSA and compared their clinicopathological characteristics and survival outcomes to a historical control group of 30 patients who underwent TP. The primary outcome measures were the measurement of remnant pancreatic volume before and 1 week after the operation. The secondary outcome measures included postoperative chemotherapy, follow-up, and measurement of remnant pancreatic volume and physiological parameters 1 month after the operation. The study concluded that most total pancreatectomies for ductal adenocarcinoma can be replaced by the WOTSA procedure.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of breastfeeding education provided to fathers via WhatsApp messaging application on breastfeeding. The study will be conducted as an experimental design with four groups (two experimental and two control groups). Fathers in the experimental groups will receive breastfeeding education for 39 days starting from the 3rd postpartum day, while the control groups will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures are the Breastfeeding Support Scale and the Partner Breastfeeding Influence Scale, which will be administered to fathers and mothers, respectively, on the 3rd and 42nd postpartum days. The study aims to assess the impact of breastfeeding education provided to fathers on their support for breastfeeding and the mothers' perception of their partners' influence on breastfeeding.

This is a non-interventional study that aims to evaluate biomarker testing and treatment patterns among patients with PIK3CA mutation in advanced breast cancer. The study includes patients newly diagnosed with advanced breast cancer between January 2015 and June 2020, who were evaluated for PIK3CA mutation status. The primary outcome measures include the number of patients with PIK3CA mutations, timing of PIK3CA evaluation, and characteristics of the PIK3CA testing. Secondary outcome measures include patient demographics, disease characteristics, and treatment patterns. The study will analyze data for up to approximately 6 years.

This is a single-group, open-label study investigating the effects of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) aged 12-18 years. Participants will receive a 5mg melatonin gummy 30 minutes before bedtime for 2 consecutive nights. The primary outcome is the change in sleep spindle density during non-REM sleep between baseline and melatonin nights, measured by portable EEG. The secondary outcome is the change in sleep quality between baseline and melatonin nights. The study will be conducted over 5 nights of sleep across 2 weeks.

The DETERMINE Trial Treatment Arm 04 is a non-randomized, open-label study evaluating the efficacy of trastuzumab in combination with pertuzumab in adult, teenage/young adult, and pediatric patients with cancers harboring HER2 amplification or activating mutations. The primary outcome measures are objective response rate and durable clinical benefit at 24 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and safety. The study aims to translate positive clinical findings to provide new treatment options for rare adult, pediatric, and teenage/young adult cancers with HER2 alterations.

This is a non-randomized, parallel assignment, double-masked study that aims to investigate the etiology of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) in children aged 7-12 years with operated isolated cleft lip or isolated velopalatal cleft. The study will use real-time MRI to analyze velopharyngeal motor skills in these children. The primary outcome measures are the ratio between the diameter of the pharynx at rest and during phonation, the closure distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall, and the distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall. The study will enroll children with different types of cleft and VPI severity, including those with isolated cleft lip, isolated operated velopalatal cleft with severe VPI and normal velum anatomy, isolated operated velopalatal cleft with soft VPI and abnormal velum anatomy, and isolated operated velopalatal cleft with normal anatomy and soft VPI.

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a remotely-delivered, home-based exercise training program for improving cognition and mobility in older adults with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study will randomly assign participants to either an aerobic and resistance exercise program (GEMS) or a flexibility and stretching program (FLEX-MS) for 16 weeks. The primary outcome measures are changes in cognitive function, physical function, and mobility-related measures from baseline to post-intervention and follow-up. Secondary outcomes include changes in physical activity levels, exercise behavior, and vascular function. The study targets older adults (age 50+) with MS, mild-to-moderate cognitive impairment, and walking impairment. If successful, this study could provide the foundation for larger trials using remotely-delivered exercise interventions to manage the consequences of aging and MS.

This is a pilot, non-interventional study that aims to measure the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration membrane in critically ill patients with vasoplegic shock. The primary outcome is a 50% reduction in vasoinotropic score within 24 hours of initiating oXiris treatment. Secondary outcomes include:

1. Evolution of the vasoinotropic score over 72 hours.
2. Quantitative determination of angiotensins and regulatory enzymes at baseline, 24 hours, and 72 hours.
3. Clearance of endothelial permeability markers at baseline, 24 hours, and 72 hours.
4. Markers of sepsis-induced immunosuppression at baseline, 24 hours, and 72 hours.
5. 90-day mortality.
6. Hemodynamic response (concentrations of angiotensin metabolites) at 24 hours of oXiris treatment.

The study will enroll critically ill patients admitted to the intensive care unit with vasoplegic shock who require extracorporeal blood purification. Patients will be monitored

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of two different approaches for urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy (TLH) in patients with previous cesarean section.

2. The two approaches are:
   a. Central urinary bladder dissection: Using a metal catheter to stretch the bladder and dissect it with monopolar scissors.
   b. Lateral urinary bladder dissection: Dissecting the broad ligament laterally to reach the cervical margins and separate the bladder.

3. The primary outcome measure is the rate of urinary bladder injury during the bladder dissection.

4. Secondary outcome measures include operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications such as genitourinary fistula and ureteric injury.

5. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment design, where patients will be randomly assigned to either the central or lateral bladder dissection group.

6. The study population includes female patients undergoing TLH for benign conditions with a history of previous cesarean section.

This is a 6-month observational study that aims to investigate the association between the asthma microbiome and disease characteristics, severity, and treatment response. The study will include patients referred with a possible or established diagnosis of asthma. Key aspects of the study include:

- Detailed medical history, symptom questionnaires, and pulmonary function testing at multiple visits over 6 months.
- Collection of various biological samples (blood, oral, nasal, sputum, stool, exhaled breath) for microbiome and host immune profiling.
- A subset of patients will undergo bronchoscopy for lower airway sampling.
- The study has two participant groups: a "Biologic Naïve Group" and a "Biologic Group" who will be started on biologic therapy if clinically indicated.

The primary objectives are to:
1. Describe the microbiome signature across the spectrum of asthma severity.
2. Establish any association between asthma phenotype and microbiome signature.
3. Determine if the microbiome signature can predict treatment response or resistance.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of split-body and full-body resistance training on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players. The study will recruit 28 male cricketers aged 20-30 years with no history of systemic disease or recent surgery/rehabilitation. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a split-body resistance training group or a full-body resistance training group. The split-body group will perform targeted exercises for different muscle groups over 4 days, while the full-body group will perform a comprehensive resistance training routine over 2 days. The training will be conducted for 6 weeks, and the primary outcome measures will be bench press test, leg press test, and 30-second sit-to-stand test. Data will be analyzed using SPSS version 25.

This study aims to evaluate the effect of providing breastfeeding education to fathers, in addition to mothers, on breastfeeding, parent-baby bonding, and breastfeeding self-efficacy levels. The study has three groups: 1) Experimental group 1 where both mothers and fathers receive breastfeeding education, 2) Experimental group 2 where only mothers receive breastfeeding education, and 3) Control group that receives routine hospital care without any additional intervention. 

The primary outcome measures include:
1. Breastfeeding self-efficacy of mothers and fathers
2. Mother-infant bonding
3. Paternal-infant attachment

The study will assess these outcomes at 3 months after birth. Additionally, the study will collect data on infant growth parameters and feeding practices. The study population includes healthy, term infants born to parents who are at least 20 years old and provide consent to participate.

This is a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial to investigate the effects of an Amway bundle combination of products on osteoarthritis and sarcopenia in Chinese adults aged 50-70 years. The study has four participant groups: 
1) Bundle Group 1 with Nutrilite Lifestyle (all-plant protein booster, calcium, magnesium, glucosamine, and EMS training with Nutrilite Lifestyle guidance)
2) Bundle Group 2 without Nutrilite Lifestyle (all-plant protein booster, calcium, magnesium, glucosamine, and EMS training)
3) Control Group 1 (placebo) 
4) Control Group 2 with Nutrilite Lifestyle (placebo with Nutrilite Lifestyle guidance)

The primary outcome is the change in Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score from baseline to day 180. Secondary outcomes include changes in WOMAC questionnaire scores, visual analogue scale, Chalder Fatigue Scale, body composition, grip strength, and bone density from baseline to day 90 and day 180.

This study aims to evaluate the implementation of Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) for alcohol and substance use in family planning clinics, a novel and high-impact setting. The study is a randomized Type 1 Hybrid Effectiveness-Implementation Trial that will compare SBIRT to usual care in a large network of family planning clinics. 

The primary outcomes include measures of alcohol and substance use, depression, incidence of sex under the influence, and SBIRT fidelity and implementation. Secondary outcomes assess additional substance use, sexual and reproductive health, and well-being measures. 

The study seeks to address the significant health disparities associated with alcohol and substance use among reproductive-aged individuals, particularly those from structurally marginalized groups, by integrating evidence-based SBIRT services into family planning clinics - a trusted and widely accessible source of care for this population. The findings will inform the development of an evidence-based, stakeholder-driven model for scaling up alcohol and substance use services in sexual and reproductive health settings nationwide.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial investigating the effects of habitual consumption of three different herbal tea blends (rhubarb root, senna, and green tea) on blood lipid markers and gut microbiome in adults.

The primary outcome measures are changes in total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, and HDL-cholesterol levels after 21 days of consuming the herbal tea blends compared to baseline and between the intervention groups. 

The secondary outcome measures include changes in plasma triglycerides, non-HDL cholesterol, diet quality score, BMI, and short-chain fatty acid concentrations.

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three intervention groups - rhubarb root tea, senna tea, or green tea (control). They will be asked to consume one cup of the assigned tea daily for 21 days. Fasted blood and stool samples will be collected at baseline and after the 21-day intervention period to assess the outcome measures.

The study aims to evaluate the potential health benefits of the herbal tea blends, particularly the effects on blood lipid profiles and gut microbiome, compared

The study aims to investigate the effect of adding strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises on pain, function, muscle strength, and knee proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study is a triple-blinded randomized controlled trial with two parallel groups. The experimental group will receive strengthening exercises for the hip rotators and ankle muscles in addition to quadriceps strengthening and stretching exercises for the hamstring and calf muscles. The control group will receive only quadriceps strengthening and hamstring and calf stretching exercises. The primary outcome measures are pain level, functional level, and knee proprioception, while the secondary outcome measures are the strength of the hip rotators, ankle muscles, and quadriceps. All measurements will be taken at baseline and after 4 weeks of the intervention.

This is a clinical study to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent (Novabel) for the treatment of chronic sinusitis. The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-assignment trial comparing the Novabel stent to a marketed bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent. The primary outcome measure is the non-reintervention rate at 30 days, which assesses the need for further medical or surgical interventions. Secondary outcome measures include Lund-Kennedy endoscopic scores, Lund-Mackay CT scores, visual analog scale (VAS) for pain, sinus patency rate, and implantation success rate at various time points up to 1 year. The study is enrolling adults diagnosed with chronic rhinosinusitis who are scheduled for primary or revision bilateral endoscopic sinus surgery.

This study is a natural experiment that examines the impact of providing cancer care closer to home for patients with multiple myeloma. The study has two arms: 1) Experimental arm where patients transition their care to a satellite site, and 2) Active comparator arm where patients maintain their care at the primary site. 

The primary outcome is the proportion of eligible patients who successfully transfer their care to a satellite location. Secondary outcomes include the types of factors providers consider when deciding on care transition, as well as patient-reported outcomes such as treatment burden, satisfaction with provider interactions, financial toxicity, and rationales for their care transition decision. 

The study uses a non-randomized, parallel assignment design and is open-label. Eligible participants are at least 18 years old, diagnosed with multiple myeloma, receiving care at the primary cancer center site, and reside within the catchment area of a satellite site. The study aims to explore the impact of providing cancer care closer to home for this patient population.

This is a prospective, randomized controlled, interventional study that aims to compare the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) goggles and nitrous oxide (N2O) for pain and anxiety management during dental procedures in pediatric patients aged 4-12 years. The study will evaluate the rate of effectiveness of VR goggles in reducing pain using the FLACC (Faces, Legs, Arms, Cry, Consolability) scale and the Wong-Baker FACES pain scale. It will also assess the rate of effectiveness of VR distraction compared to N2O using the Houpt Behavioral scale. Participants will be randomized into two groups: the control group will receive N2O first and then VR goggles, while the treatment group will receive VR goggles first and then N2O. The study aims to determine if VR goggles can be as effective as the standard N2O for managing pain and anxiety during dental procedures in pediatric patients.

This is a prospective study aimed at identifying patients at high risk of developing recurrent colorectal lesions and designing optimal surveillance colonoscopy intervals based on mutation profiles and clinical-pathological phenotypes. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Determination of mutation profiles and mutation burden in 200 patients by examining index and synchronous lesions found during the initial colonoscopy.

2. Clinical, histopathological, and mutational profiling of all metachronous lesions detected during the 5-year surveillance period.

3. Correlation of clinical-pathological parameters with the mutational phenotype of patients.

4. Correlation of patients' mutational phenotypes with the occurrence of metachronous lesions during the surveillance period.

5. Comparison of mutation profiles between index and metachronous lesions.

6. Analysis of the similarity of mutation profiles in lesions found in the same or nearby colorectal areas.

The primary outcome is to develop and evaluate the clinical utility of a new method to identify high-risk patients for recurrent colorectal lesions and personalize their surveillance based on mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype.

The SAM Project is a clinical trial that aims to characterize malnutrition through the identification of specific biomarkers. The study involves the collection of clinical, anamnestic, and lifestyle data, as well as the collection of fecal, blood, and saliva samples from patients affected by malnutrition due to deficiency or excess, and sex- and age-matched healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include:

1. Characterization of malnutrition through the identification of specific biomarkers.
2. Untargeted microRNA expression profile in blood and saliva samples.
3. Analysis of plasmatic and salivary extracellular vesicles.
4. Metagenomic and metabolomic analysis of fecal and salivary samples.

The study is designed to last for 36 months and involves participants of Caucasian ethnicity, both sexes, and aged between 0 and 85 years.

This study aims to evaluate the impact of different exercise support strategies on physical activity levels in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD). The study will enroll participants into one of three conditions over three consecutive years: (1) standard care, (2) written exercise guidance by neurologists, and (3) a consultative model of physical therapy. Participants will be tracked using activity trackers and patient-reported outcomes over 12 months, with the primary outcome being minutes per day of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) measured by accelerometer. Secondary outcomes include steps per day. The study seeks to understand how different levels of exercise support from the healthcare team can influence physical activity in people with PD.

This study aims to evaluate the use of multi-channel time-resolved functional near-infrared spectroscopy (tr-fNIRS) for the early detection and prevention of perioperative brain injury in patients undergoing elective shoulder surgery in the beach-chair position under general anesthesia. The key aspects of the study are:

1. The study will use a state-of-the-art full head coverage tr-fNIRS device to monitor regional cerebral oxygenation (ScO2) in the entire brain, unlike the limited spatial coverage of current commercial cerebral oximeters.

2. The primary outcome is to assess the impact of intraoperative hemodynamic parameters on regional differences in cerebral oxygenation between brain regions during surgery.

3. Secondary outcomes include evaluating regional differences in cerebral autoregulation and assessing the association between cerebral desaturation events in multiple brain regions and clinical outcomes such as stroke and delirium.

4. The study is observational in nature, and no interventions will be administered based on the tr-fNIRS monitoring results.

5. The study aims to address the limitations of current cerebral oximetry techniques and

This is a randomized clinical feasibility trial investigating the use of Mechanical Insufflation-Exsufflation (MI-E), also known as Cough Assist, in critically ill adults receiving invasive mechanical ventilation. The primary outcome is the proportion of complete MI-E sessions (two sessions per day with 3 cycles of 2-second insufflation and 2-second exsufflation at 40 cmH2O) delivered over a maximum of 7 days. Secondary outcomes include safety measures such as incidence of pneumothorax, endotracheal tube obstruction, hypoxemia, hypotension, and hypertension, as well as feasibility and acceptability measures. The study also aims to collect data on potential efficacy outcomes like ventilator-associated pneumonia, duration of mechanical ventilation, and mortality to inform a future larger trial. Patients will be randomized to receive either MI-E or standard airway care.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to assess the effects of the SGLT2 inhibitor enavogliflozin on outcomes in patients with functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (HFpEF).

2. The primary objective is to evaluate the effect of enavogliflozin compared to placebo on a composite outcome of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for heart failure, or worsening of tricuspid regurgitation over 18 months.

3. The secondary objectives include evaluating the effects on all-cause mortality, cardiovascular events, renal outcomes, changes in TR severity, and changes in right ventricular strain.

4. The study will enroll patients aged 20-80 years with moderate to severe functional TR, HFpEF, and elevated natriuretic peptides. Key exclusion criteria include current use of SGLT2 inhibitors, significant left-sided valve disease, and severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction.

5. Patients

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to investigate the relationship between daily physical activity, measured by the number of steps using a SenseWear armband device, and the pharmacokinetics (PK) of infused recombinant factor VIII (rec-FVIII) in patients with severe hemophilia A on prophylactic FVIII treatment.

2. The primary outcome measures are:
   a. The association between physical activity (mean number of daily steps) and the area under the curve (AUC) PK parameter.
   b. The association between the FVIII PK parameter and the mean number of daily steps.

3. The study is a proof-of-concept, single-group, open-label study involving patients with severe hemophilia A aged 12-60 years who are on FVIII concentrate prophylaxis.

4. Exclusion criteria include patients with malignant tumors, those on anticoagulant/antiplatelet agents, and those with other congenital coagulation disorders.

5. The study duration is 12 months.

This is a randomized, double-blind clinical trial investigating the effects of early versus delayed locomotor training on recovery outcomes in individuals with acute and traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) with AIS classification B, C, or D between C5 and T12. Participants will be randomized into one of four intervention groups: early intervention (within 60 days of injury), sub-acute intervention (3 months post-injury), chronic intervention (6-12 months post-injury), or standard of care control. The primary outcome measure is the 10-meter walk test to assess walking speed, while secondary outcomes include the 6-minute walk test, Walking Index for Spinal Cord Injury, and daily step counts. The study aims to determine the critical time window for optimal locomotor rehabilitation following incomplete SCI.

This study aims to evaluate the effect of education based on the health promotion model, delivered using the Philips 66 technique, on premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior, and perceived stress in women. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with a pretest-posttest design. Participants will be women aged 18-30 who score over 110 on the Premenstrual Syndrome Scale and meet other inclusion criteria. The experimental group will receive the educational intervention, while the control group will not. Primary outcomes include changes in premenstrual syndrome, emotional eating, and perceived stress, measured using validated scales. Secondary outcomes include feedback on the educational intervention and changes in eating habits during the premenstrual period. The study aims to provide a resource for nurses and contribute to the literature on managing premenstrual symptoms through health promotion.

The AMP SCZ® Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC is a non-interventional study that aims to develop a deep biomarker-informed functional characterization and longitudinal clinical profiling of individuals at clinical high risk (CHR) for psychosis. The study is part of the Accelerating Medicines Partnership (AMP) Schizophrenia program, a multi-continent consortium. The study is being conducted by the Data Processing, Analysis and Coordination Center (DPACC) based at Brigham and Women's Hospital and Mass General Brigham, in collaboration with two CHR research networks (ProNET and PRESCIENT).

The study will assess the CHR cohort and healthy controls (HCs) with a core set of measures at baseline and 2 months post-baseline, with additional assessments at other time points. CHR subjects will be followed longitudinally for 2 years, and participants who develop first-episode psychosis during the study will continue to be assessed as scheduled. The study aims to capture data in a uniform manner, build flexible infrastructure to accommodate multiple data types, develop and refine data processing and quality assurance pipelines, provide data

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of implementing the Problem Management Plus (PM+) intervention for individuals with elevated psychological distress who are imprisoned in Dutch prisons. This is a single-blind pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a qualitative component. The study will include 60 Dutch-speaking adults (18 years or older) who are imprisoned in the Netherlands and have at least 15 weeks remaining in their sentence. Participants will be randomized to receive either PM+ plus care-as-usual or care-as-usual alone. The primary outcomes are measures of feasibility and acceptability, including PM+ fidelity, stakeholder perceptions, intervention delivery indicators, retention rates, and recruitment/consent rates. Secondary outcomes include preliminary indications of pre- to post-intervention changes in symptoms of depression, anxiety, self-identified problems, quality of life, trauma, and suicidal vulnerability.

This is a phase I clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of the drug xevinapant in combination with radiation and chemotherapy (carboplatin and paclitaxel) for patients with locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck. The primary objective is to determine the maximum tolerated dose of xevinapant when given with chemoradiotherapy. Secondary objectives include assessing progression-free survival, overall survival, locoregional failure, distant failure, and response rate. Patients will receive xevinapant for 2 out of every 3 weeks, along with weekly carboplatin and paclitaxel during 7 weeks of radiation therapy, followed by an additional 3 cycles of xevinapant alone. The study will enroll patients ineligible for cisplatin-based chemoradiotherapy due to comorbidities or other factors.

This is a Phase 1, open-label study evaluating the pharmacokinetics, safety, and tolerability of ARV-471 (PF-07850327) as a single agent in Chinese participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer. The primary objectives are to assess the single-dose and multiple-dose pharmacokinetics of ARV-471, including maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the concentration-time curve (AUC), and other PK parameters. Secondary objectives include evaluating the objective response rate, clinical benefit rate, duration of objective response, presence or absence of blood biomarkers, and safety and tolerability. Eligible participants must have a histological or cytological diagnosis of ER+/HER2- locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer, have received at least one prior line of standard-of-care endocrine therapy with or without a CDK4/6 inhibitor, and meet other inclusion/exclusion criteria. Participants will receive oral ARV-471 once daily with food at the recommended Phase 3 dose determined in a previous study.

This is a phase 2 clinical trial evaluating the combination of the PARP inhibitor olaparib and the PI3K inhibitor alpelisib (BYL719) in patients with metastatic HER2-negative breast cancer. 

The primary objectives are:
1. To determine if the combination improves progression-free survival (PFS) compared to olaparib alone in PARP-inhibitor naive patients (Cohort 2).
2. To determine the objective response rate (ORR) of the combination in PARP-inhibitor resistant patients (Cohort 3).

Secondary objectives include assessing other efficacy endpoints like overall survival, clinical benefit rate, and safety, as well as evaluating biomarkers and concordance between tumor mutation profiles.

The study has 3 cohorts:
- Cohort 1: PARP-inhibitor naive patients receive the combination (olaparib + alpelisib)
- Cohort 2: PARP-inhibitor naive patients are randomized to the combination or olaparib alone

This is a multi-center, two-arm, parallel group, assessor-blinded, randomized controlled superiority study investigating whether Schema Therapy (ST) of longer duration (up to 30 sessions) outperforms the current treatment as usual (TAU) for patients with chronic and treatment resistant depression (CTRD) on depression outcomes at 12 months after baseline, as well as at 6 and 24 months. 

The primary outcome is change in depression symptoms on the Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression at 12 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in depression, functioning, well-being, recovery, anger, and other measures at 6, 12, and 24 months. The study also aims to expand understanding of successful therapy for CTRD and refine the Maudsley Staging Model for CTRD.

Participants will be randomized 1:1 to receive either 30 sessions of ST or TAU, which can include psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, and other standard care. The study plans to recruit 129 participants across four psychiatric outpatient

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III, cluster trial with sequential permutation to evaluate a paramedical protocol for ventilation in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will compare the impact of ventilatory adjustments by nurses according to a pre-established protocol versus usual care on mortality and number of days without mechanical ventilation at 28 days. Secondary outcomes include measures of ventilator settings, oxygenation, duration of mechanical ventilation, and other clinical outcomes. The study will enroll adults (≥18 years) with ARDS evolving for less than 72 hours, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. Patients with ARDS refractory to optimization of ventilation or severe acidosis will be excluded. The primary endpoint is a composite of mortality and number of days without mechanical ventilation at 28 days.

The study aims to test a culturally tailored engagement and retention intervention called Haitian immigrant iENGAGE (H-iENGAGE) for Haitian immigrants living with HIV (HILWH) in the U.S. It is a sequential mixed-methods formative pilot research designed to examine engagement and retention in care, and viral suppression (VS) for HILWH. The study will be conducted as a prospective, quasi-experimental single arm with a sample of newly diagnosed or nonvirally suppressed HIWLH adults drawn from 2 Federally Qualified Health Centers in Miami. The primary outcome measures are the change in Engagement in Care score and viral suppression (HIV load measurement less than 200 copies/ml) from baseline to post-intervention and 6-month follow-up.

This is a prospective, 3-arm randomized, non-blinded, single-center clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device for root canal debridement, compared to passive ultrasonic irrigation (PUI) and conventional root canal preparation methods.

The primary objective is to test the effectiveness of the Endoclean device for root canal debridement up to 12-month follow-up, defined as successful healing of periapical lesions. The secondary objectives are to test the extended effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device up to 24-month follow-up.

The study will enroll a total of 109 participants, with 40 in the PUI group, 40 in the Endoclean group, and 29 in the conventional group. Key inclusion criteria are patients aged 18-75 years with symptomatic or asymptomatic apical periodontitis, mature teeth with closed apices, and no prior root canal treatment. Key exclusion criteria include pre-existing health conditions, generalized periodontal disease, and teeth with poor prognosis.

The primary effectiveness endpoint is successful healing of periap

The FRACT-AI study aims to evaluate the impact of artificial intelligence-enhanced image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in detecting fractures on plain X-rays. The study involves 18 readers from five clinical specialty groups (emergency medicine, trauma and orthopaedic surgery, emergency nurse practitioners, physiotherapy, and general radiology/radiographers) at different levels of experience. The readers will review 500 X-ray cases in two phases, with and without AI assistance, separated by a washout period. The primary outcome measures include the performance of the AI algorithm (sensitivity, specificity, and area under the ROC curve) as well as the performance of the readers with and without AI assistance (sensitivity, specificity, area under the ROC curve, and reader speed). Two consultant musculoskeletal radiologists will establish the ground truth findings on the X-rays, with a third senior radiologist providing arbitration in case of disagreement. The study aims to assess the impact of AI-assisted image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in detecting fractures on plain X-rays.

The study aims to examine the fine motor skills, hand grip strength, and hand and forearm anthropometric characteristics of children with Specific Learning Disorder (SLD) compared to typically developing children. It also investigates the effect of fine motor skills on quality of life and participation in activities at home, school, and community environment for children with SLD.

The study will assess the participants using the following measures:
- Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-2 (BOT-2) to evaluate gross and fine motor skills
- Purdue Pegboard Test to assess manual dexterity and bimanual coordination
- Hand Dynamometer to evaluate hand grip strength
- Pinch Gauge to assess finger strength
- Participation and Environment Measurement Child & Youth (PEM-CY) to assess participation and environment factors
- Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PEDS-QL) to evaluate health-related quality of life

The study includes children aged 6-12 years old, with a diagnosis of SLD, and typically developing children as a control group. Participants with other psychiatric, neurological, or orthopedic disorders

The IM-ZBULLE study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind, controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of combining the Z-track and Airlock techniques during intramuscular injection of haloperidol decanoate in adult patients with schizophrenia or related disorders. The primary outcome measure is pain reduction, assessed using a visual analog scale (VAS) 5 minutes after the injection. Secondary outcome measures include reduction in drug leakage, impact on potential complications, patient satisfaction, therapeutic alliance, and identification of levers and obstacles to changing nursing practices. The experimental group will receive the intramuscular injection using the Z-track and Airlock techniques, while the control group will receive the standard injection technique. An interim analysis of futility and efficacy is planned once 50% of the planned sample has completed the study.

This is a feasibility trial of preoperative 5-day hypofractionated radiotherapy (HFRT) for primary soft tissue sarcoma (STS) of the extremity or trunk. The primary objective is to assess the feasibility of this approach, measured by the uptake rate of the 5-day HFRT regimen among eligible patients. Secondary objectives include evaluating the rate of favorable pathologic response, major wound complications, local control, acute toxicity, and 1-year late toxicity. The study will also explore the use of serum SFRP2 levels as a predictive biomarker for response to HFRT. Eligible patients will receive 30 Gy of HFRT over 5 consecutive weekdays, followed by standard-of-care wide local excision 2-6 weeks later. The study aims to address disparities in access to radiotherapy and increase clinical trial participation, particularly among rural populations.

This is a randomized controlled study that aims to evaluate the postoperative analgesia outcomes of a Pericapsular Nerve Group (PENG) block combined with a Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve (LFCN) block compared to intravenous morphine patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) in patients undergoing hip replacement surgery.

The study enrolled patients aged 18-80 years old with American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I-III who were scheduled for hip replacement surgery. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either the PENG and LFCN nerve blocks or intravenous morphine PCA for postoperative pain management.

The primary outcome measures were:
1. Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) pain scores at rest and with movement, assessed from the time of catheterization/PCA insertion (H0) up to 72 hours (H72) postoperatively.
2. Incidence of side effects such as vomiting/nausea, itching, urinary retention, and respiratory failure during the same time period.

The study used ultrasound

This study aims to evaluate pelvic organ mobility using dynamic MRI in patients with and without pelvic endometriosis. The primary outcome measure is the mean vertical displacement of the anterior vaginal wall between rest and maximum pushing force during dynamic MRI. Secondary outcome measures include the mean vertical displacement of the cervix and posterior vaginal wall, the variation in mean vertical displacement of pelvic organ walls, and the association between patient symptoms and pelvic organ mobility. The study includes two participant groups: patients with pelvic endometriosis confirmed on initial MRI, and patients referred for suspected endometriosis but without endometriosis found on diagnostic MRI. Both groups will undergo dynamic MRI with the addition of a dynamic sequence to the routine MRI examination.

This is a retrospective, observational study that aims to evaluate the uptake of the childhood live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV) and its impact on influenza-related healthcare resource use in England during the 2012 to 2022 flu seasons. The study will use data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) and Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) databases.

The primary objective is to evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines, including LAIV, QIV, and unspecified influenza vaccines, in children aged 2 to 18 years in England between 2012 and 2020. The secondary objectives are to describe usage patterns of LAIV, HCRU associated with laboratory-confirmed influenza and/or influenza-like illness (ILI), demographics and clinical characteristics of individuals vaccinated with LAIV or unvaccinated, and to estimate a model for LAIV uptake based on demographic and clinical factors.

The study will include all research-eligible individuals aged 2 to 18 years with at least 6 months of history in CPRD before their first influenza vaccination. Logistic

This is a pilot pre-post interventional trial without controls, aimed at evaluating the feasibility and potential effects of fun activities for reciting Tang poems on promoting happiness and well-being in primary school ethnic minority students (grades 1-2, ages 6-9) in Hong Kong. 

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Intervention: The intervention comprises three 1.5-hour weekly sessions of Tang poem reciting and one session for participant performances, led by experienced instructors. Body language, sound, images, and videos will be used to enhance motivation and memory.

2. Outcomes: The primary outcomes are the number of successful recited poems (assessed objectively by observers and subjectively by students) and changes in self-reported happiness. Secondary outcomes include changes in acculturation, Chinese speaking ability, and attitude towards Chinese learning.

3. Assessments: Assessments will be conducted at baseline, after each session, and at 12-week follow-up to evaluate the sustainability of outcomes.

4. Participants: 10-20 South Asian children in primary schools (grades 1-2, ages 6-9) will be recruited, with parental consent.

This is a pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to test the impact of using the Vira digital platform in an intensive outpatient setting for adolescents (ages 13-18) at high risk for suicide. The study will include 200 participants randomized to either the Vira group (n=100) or a treatment as usual (TAU) control group (n=100). The Vira group will receive intensive outpatient DBT treatment supported by the Vira platform, which integrates mobile sensing, self-report assessment, and just-in-time nudges/notifications into the practitioner's workflow. The TAU group will receive intensive outpatient DBT plus a passive data monitoring app (EARS). 

The primary outcome measures are the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) and the Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI), assessed at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include measures of anxiety, risky behaviors, sleep quality, depression, and social anhedonia, assessed at 3 and 6 months. The overarching goal is to test whether using the Vira platform in the

This is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the impact of sex and age on non-visual light input that affects sleep and circadian rhythms. The study will use pupillometry and light box exposure to measure pupil size, melatonin levels for circadian timing assessment, and melatonin levels for hormone response. Participants will be 18-85 years old, have normal vision, and no history of certain medical conditions. The study has a single group assignment design, where all participants will undergo the same study procedures, except for the order of light stimuli during pupillometry testing. The primary outcome measures are pupil size, melatonin levels for circadian timing assessment, and melatonin levels for hormone response.

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating the efficacy of a new parent training program called "Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA)" for parents with ADHD. The study aims to examine the effects of IPSA on parental self-efficacy (primary outcome), as well as secondary outcomes including parental stress, household disorganization, and child behavior problems. 

The study design involves parallel groups, where eligible participants are randomly assigned (1:1 ratio) to either the IPSA intervention group or a control group receiving continued routine services. Assessments are conducted at baseline, immediately post-intervention, and at a 1.5-3 month follow-up. The feasibility of the IPSA program is also evaluated based on attendance, participation, and treatment satisfaction. Treatment integrity is monitored through session recordings.

The study is being conducted in Sweden by the Center of Neurodevelopmental Disorders at Karolinska Institutet, in collaboration with a local ADHD center. The target population is parents aged 18 years or older with a formal ADHD diagnosis, who have at least one child between 3-11

The Substance Use and Health Risk Intervention (SUHRI) for Justice-involved Youth is a 1-arm study that examines the preliminary efficacy of an adapted intervention for youth aged 14 to 18 who are on community supervision (deferred adjudication or probation) and have at least one indicator of substance use. The intervention is a technology-based application administered via tablet that addresses the interrelated topics of substance use and risky sexual practices within the context of personal relationships. The study measures the following primary outcomes at baseline, week 7, and week 15: problem recognition, decision making, intention to reduce personal risk, service initiation, substance use, and sexual/STI health risk. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the SUHRI intervention on these outcomes among justice-involved youth.
