This is a phase II, open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial evaluating the use of daily remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) to reduce progression of disability in patients with primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). The primary objective is to assess the non-futility of RIC for reducing disability progression, as measured by the timed 25-foot walk test, over 12 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in upper limb function, myelination on MRI, and processing speed. The study will follow a Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-65 years with PPMS, an Expanded Disability Status Scale score of 4.0-6.5, and a timed 25-foot walk of 5.5 seconds or more. Patients with active inflammatory disease, significant comorbidities, or using certain medications are excluded. Participants will undergo daily 40-minute RIC sessions at home for 12 months using an automated device.

This study aimed to evaluate whether prothrombin time at diagnosis can predict the response to steroid treatment in patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis. The study enrolled patients with a clinical diagnosis of severe alcoholic hepatitis, defined by a Maddrey's function score of 32 or higher, and without contraindications to corticosteroid therapy. The primary outcome was the response to steroid treatment, assessed using the Lille score at day 7. Secondary outcomes included death during hospitalization, early liver transplantation, and occurrence of opportunistic infections. The study used prothrombin time at diagnosis as a diagnostic test to assess its correlation with the Lille score and, therefore, the ability to predict response to medical treatment.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of functional task training and functional therapy program on gross motor function, range of motion, and balance in children with cerebral palsy. The study will include children aged 6-12 years with cerebral palsy and GMFCS levels 1-2. The experimental group will receive functional task training, while the control group will receive a functional therapy program (Bobath technique) for 8 weeks, 50 minutes per day, 3 times per week. The primary outcome measures are range of motion assessed by goniometer, balance assessed by the Pediatric Balance Scale, and gross motor function assessed by the Gross Motor Function Measure (GMFM-88). The study will use a randomized, parallel-group design with single-blinding.

This was a retrospective observational study that aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte-lymphocyte ratio (TLR) in predicting the outcomes of tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair. The study was conducted at the National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita between January 2020 and December 2022. The primary outcome measures were the number of patients requiring redo surgery, mortality, and complications (categorized as mild, moderate, or severe). The secondary outcome measures were hospital length of stay and postoperative length of stay. Patients with ToF and any other associated cardiac anomalies who underwent ToF primary repair and had a complete preoperative blood cell count with differential count were included. Patients were excluded if they underwent surgery other than ToF primary repair, had preoperative hemodynamic instability, or had suspected or confirmed infection with prior antibiotic administration.

This is a pilot randomized double-blind clinical trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of patient-applied aqueous lidocaine via tampon as a pre-treatment prior to intrauterine device (IUD) placement. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the lidocaine or saline placebo group. The primary outcome measures are procedure time and patient-reported pain level, while secondary outcome measures include patient-reported satisfaction, interest in subsequent procedures, and provider-reported procedural difficulty. The study will enroll female participants aged 18-54 years who are requesting IUD insertion, excluding those with known allergies to lidocaine or tampons, or current vaginal/cervical injury.

This is a pilot study that aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a universal capillary screening program for the early detection of chronic autoimmune, metabolic, and cardiovascular diseases in a general population. The study will enroll volunteers from the locality of Cantalupo, which has a population of 3,095 people. The participants will undergo capillary blood sampling to test for various disease markers, including blood glucose, lipid levels, autoantibodies for type 1 diabetes and celiac disease, and blood pressure. The primary outcome measures are the feasibility and acceptability of the screening program, as well as the measurement of the specific disease markers. Secondary outcomes include estimating the prevalence of the identified diseases within the population and across age classes, and correlating the study disease indicators with demographics, anthropometrics, and clinical data. The study has an open-label, single-group assignment design, and it accepts healthy volunteers.

The study is a randomized controlled trial investigating the impact of the "SMaRT Mom" intervention on breastfeeding mothers with smartphone addiction. The intervention aims to help mothers manage and reduce smartphone use during breastfeeding. The primary outcome measures are changes in infant temperament and maternal self-efficacy, assessed before and after the one-week intervention period. Secondary outcome measures include the rewarding experience of breastfeeding, maternal attention towards the infant, and changes in maternal neural activity, physiology, and behavior during breastfeeding and mother-infant interactions. The study includes an intervention group that receives the SMaRT Mom program and a control group that does not. The study population consists of healthy breastfeeding mothers aged 20-40 years with infants aged 3-6 months and smartphone addiction.

This is a single-blind randomized controlled trial investigating the use of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) for the treatment of plantar fasciitis. The study will recruit active duty military personnel with a diagnosis of plantar fasciitis. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either PBMT plus usual care (stretching and cryotherapy) or sham PBMT plus usual care. The primary outcome measures include the Foot and Ankle Ability Measure (FAAM), pain intensity using the Defense and Veterans Pain Rating Scale (DVPRS), and plantar fascia thickness measured by ultrasound. Outcomes will be assessed at baseline, 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months. The study aims to determine the efficacy of PBMT in improving physical function, reducing pain, and decreasing plantar fascia thickness in individuals with plantar fasciitis.

This was a single-center, open-label, randomized, single-dose, crossover bioequivalence study to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of a test formulation (T) and a reference formulation (R) of Entacapone, Levodopa, and Carbidopa tablets in the postprandial state in healthy Chinese subjects.

The study enrolled 36 healthy adult subjects who were randomly assigned to receive either the test or reference formulation in a crossover design, with a washout period of at least 2 days between doses. The primary outcome measures were peak plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time 0 to the last measurable concentration (AUC0-t), and area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time 0 to infinity (AUC0-∞), all measured over a 10-hour period.

The study aimed to assess the bioequivalence of the test and reference formulations of Entacapone, Levodopa, and Carbidopa tablets in the postprandial state in healthy Chinese subjects.

This is a single-center study that aims to use combined electroencephalography (EEG) and 7 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to map brain anatomy and function in healthy participants as well as patients with tremor, psychosis, and epilepsy. 

The study will enroll participants across the following groups:
- Healthy volunteers
- Essential tremor patients
- Psychosis patients
- Healthy controls matched to the psychosis group
- Epilepsy patients

The key interventions are:
- Simultaneous EEG-fMRI at 7 Tesla
- Structural MRI at 7 Tesla

The primary outcome measures are:
- Contrast-to-noise ratio between thalamic nuclei in 7T structural MRI
- Pearson correlation between thalamocortical brain regions in 7T functional MRI
- Microstate duration in EEG acquired concurrently with 7T functional MRI

The secondary outcome is the publication of the neuroimaging datasets in anonymized form in public data repositories.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This study aims to assess the impact of weight loss through calorie-restricted diets on hepcidin levels and iron status in individuals with obesity and iron deficiency. 

The study has two phases:

1. Phase 1 is a cross-sectional study to compare hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers between people with and without obesity.

2. Phase 2 is a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effect of two calorie-restricted diets (one with red meat, one without) on hepcidin, iron status, and other biomarkers in individuals with obesity and iron deficiency. 

The primary outcome is the change in serum hepcidin concentration between the two dietary intervention groups. Secondary outcomes include changes in various iron status markers, inflammatory markers, oxidative stress markers, lipid profile, body composition, and gut microbiota.

The study will enroll adults with obesity (BMI 30-40 kg/m2) and iron deficiency (serum iron < 50 mcg/dL). Participants will be randomly assigned to either a calorie-restricted

The study aims to evaluate the use of continuous non-invasive electrophysiological monitoring (eCTG) using the Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS) in high-risk pregnant women, compared to conventional intermittent cardiotocography (CTG) monitoring. The primary outcome is the incidence of perinatal mortality and major neonatal morbidity. Secondary outcomes include maternal mortality, neonatal morbidity, patient and caregiver satisfaction, duration of pregnancy, duration of hospital admission, timing and number of obstetric interventions, and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. The study is a single-center, prospective cohort intervention study with historical controls, involving 1911 pregnant women (including 1400 historical controls) aged 18 years or older with singleton pregnancies between 23+0 and 32+0 weeks of gestation requiring hospitalization for maternal or fetal surveillance. The study aims to assess whether continuous eCTG monitoring can improve perinatal and maternal outcomes compared to conventional intermittent CTG monitoring.

This is a clinical trial study that aims to investigate the genetic susceptibility to severe and rare infectious diseases. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Objectives: 
   - Identify chromosomal regions associated with severe infectious diseases through homozygosity mapping in affected families.
   - Identify candidate genes for genetic susceptibility to infectious diseases by sequencing the exome or genome.
   - Validate the pathogenic effect of identified mutations through functional and complementation tests.

2. Eligibility Criteria:
   - Inclusion criteria: Patients with proven rare and severe infections requiring hospitalization, recurrent/chronic infections, or infections leading to sequelae. Related family members up to the 3rd degree.
   - Exclusion criteria: Patients with acquired immunodeficiency or pregnant women.

3. Study Design:
   - Participants will provide blood samples and, in some cases, skin biopsies.
   - Genetic analyses will be performed, including whole-genome genotyping, exome sequencing, and assessment of genetic segregation of identified mutations in families.

4. Outcome Measures:

The study investigated the prevalence, type, and risk factors of urinary incontinence (UI) in married women and its effect on their quality of life. Urinary incontinence is a common condition that can have significant physical, psycho-social, and economic impacts on women. The study aimed to develop a comprehensive understanding of UI, raise awareness among women, and provide support for those affected. The study measured the incontinence quality of life of the participants, with higher scores indicating a higher quality of life. The study was conducted between October 2022 and July 2023.

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to compare the efficacy of bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) and minimally manipulated adipose tissue (MM-AT) for the infiltrative treatment of knee osteoarthritis (OA). 

The study will include 204 patients with symptomatic unilateral knee OA. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive a single intra-articular injection of either BMAC or MM-AT. 

The primary outcome measure is the Western Ontario and McMaster University Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) pain subscale at 6 months follow-up. Secondary outcome measures include other WOMAC scores, Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS), Tegner Activity Level Scale, range of motion, circumferences, Patient Acceptable Symptom State (PASS), Minimally Clinical Important Difference (MCID), expectations about treatment effectiveness, Kellgren-Lawrence score, 3T MRI, and analysis of circulating

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase III clinical study evaluating the efficacy and safety of cannabidiol (CBD) capsules in adults with insomnia disorder. The study aims to assess the mean change from baseline in insomnia severity index (ISI) score and subject sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks. Eligible participants will be randomly assigned to receive either placebo, 75mg CBD, or 150mg CBD capsules taken nightly before bed. The study excludes individuals with significant insomnia caused by other sleep disorders, depression, anxiety, or substance use.

The study aimed to investigate the pattern of intestinal parasitic infection among cirrhotic patients in Sohag University Hospital. It was a screening study with a parallel assignment design, where 100 cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal (GIT) complaints were compared to 100 non-cirrhotic patients with GIT complaints but no comorbidities. The primary outcome was to detect the prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients and compare it to non-cirrhotic patients, as well as to determine the most common risk factors of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients. The intervention was stool analysis, and the study duration was 12 months.

The REtinal Detachment Outcomes Study (REDOS) is a factorial, randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the outcomes of different surgical interventions for the treatment of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. The study will randomize participants to one of four treatment arms: 1) pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with sulfur hexafluoride gas tamponade, 2) PPV with scleral buckle and sulfur hexafluoride gas tamponade, 3) PPV with perfluoropropane gas tamponade, or 4) PPV with scleral buckle and perfluoropropane gas tamponade. The primary outcome is single surgery anatomic success, defined as freedom from reoperation for recurrent retinal detachment at 1 year. Secondary outcomes include visual acuity, time to recurrence, complications, and quality of life. The study excludes participants with certain retinal conditions and prior ocular surgeries. It is designed as a triple-masked trial.

This is a randomized, triple-blinded, parallel-group interventional study that aims to evaluate the differential effects of 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine on the onset time and duration of ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in patients undergoing forefoot surgery. The primary outcome is the difference in the duration of the sensory blocks, while the secondary outcomes are the difference in onset time of the sensory block, postoperative pain scores, and opioid consumption. The study includes patients aged 18 to 65 years, scheduled for elective forefoot surgery for hallux valgus repair under unilateral ankle block. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive 15 mL of either 0.25%, 0.5%, or 1% ropivacaine, administered strategically among the specific nerves.

The study aimed to evaluate the effect of compression stockings on the complaints, well-being, and sleep quality of pregnant women with restless legs syndrome (RLS). The study was a randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial. Eligible participants were pregnant women aged 18-40 years, at 27 weeks or more of gestation, with RLS of moderate to severe severity. The participants were randomized to either wear compression stockings or knee socks (placebo) for 3 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the change in RLS Severity Rating Scale score from baseline to the end of the 21-day intervention period. The secondary outcome measure was the change in Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index score from baseline to the end of the 21-day intervention period.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a home-based strength and Tai-chi exercise program, referred to as "exercise snacking and Tai-chi snacking", for improving physical function in older adults in Taiwan and the UK.

The study will involve 5 remote assessments over 12 weeks. A subset of 60 participants will also undergo in-person assessments. Participants will be randomized to either the home-based exercise intervention group or a waitlist control group.

The primary outcome is changes in the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score, measured every 4 weeks. Secondary outcomes include measures of strength, balance, agility, flexibility, quality of life, physical activity levels, mental health, and exercise self-efficacy and attitudes.

The exercise intervention consists of progressive, self-paced exercises and Tai-chi movements performed in short "snacking" bouts. Participants in the intervention group will receive exercise videos and instructions and will be asked to record their exercise sessions.

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of this home-based exercise approach for improving physical function in older adults.

This is a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia with ropivacaine with or without dexamethasone for postoperative pain relief in lumbosacral spine surgeries. 

Patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:
- Group RD: Caudal epidural injection with 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml containing dexamethasone 8 mg
- Group R: Caudal epidural injection with 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml

The primary outcome measures are postoperative Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) scores at immediate, 4, 8, 12, and 24 hours, as well as the time to first request for rescue analgesia. 

The study aims to compare the quality and duration of analgesia, hemodynamic effects, and adverse effects between the two groups.

The study is a randomized controlled experimental study that aims to determine the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on the comfort, satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The study will include 80 participants, with 40 in the intervention group receiving care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory and 40 in the control group receiving standard care. The primary outcome measures are the General Comfort Scale, the Comfort Behaviors Checklist, and the Richard-Campbell Sleep Scale, which will be assessed 24 hours after the intervention. The study is designed to be a double-blind, parallel assignment study.

The P-KIDs CARE study is a health systems intervention in Tanzania that aims to address delays in care for injured children. The study has three main aims:

1. Conduct formative research to inform the development of the P-KIDs CARE intervention, including enrolling 100 children into a pediatric injury registry, conducting capacity assessments, and performing in-depth interviews and focus group discussions.

2. Use the formative data to develop the P-KIDs CARE intervention, which includes two components: 1) the WHO Basic Emergency Care Course for training on patient assessment and stabilization, and 2) a decision support tool for mortality risk assessment and referral decisions. The intervention will undergo pre-implementation assessment and refinement.

3. Pilot the P-KIDs CARE intervention in two study facilities, enrolling approximately 200 pediatric injury patients. The study will assess implementation outcomes such as feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity, as well as patient-level outcomes including time to definitive care, disposition, morbidity, and mortality.

The primary outcome is mortality, and secondary outcomes include time to definitive care, disposition, and morbidity. The

This was a preliminary study that aimed to evaluate the effects of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education in women with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. The study was a randomized, triple-masked trial that compared two active treatment groups: 1) pelvic floor rehabilitation plus postural re-education, and 2) pelvic floor rehabilitation plus spinal mobilization. The primary outcome measure was the change in the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) score from baseline to after 5 weeks of treatment and 1 month after the end of training. Secondary outcomes included changes in pain (Visual Analogue Scale) and pelvic floor muscle strength (Modified Oxford Scale). The study included women aged 18-75 years with a diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. Participants received 10 sessions of the allocated intervention over 5 weeks.

The study aims to develop a pharmacodynamic model for propofol in older adults (aged 65 years and above) by using the pharmacokinetic parameters of the Eleveld model and new pharmacodynamic parameters derived from frontal electroencephalography (EEG). The primary outcome measure is the performance error (PE), which is the difference between the measured and predicted propofol concentrations. The secondary outcome measures include median absolute performance error (MDAPE), median prediction error (MDPE), time of loss of response (LOR), time of burst-suppression (BS), and time of return of response (ROR). The study is an open-label, single-group assignment trial, where patients older than 65 years undergoing non-cardiac elective surgery will receive a propofol infusion with pre-specified plasma targets. During the infusion, BIS values, frontal EEG, and clinical signs of consciousness will be monitored. Two models will be compared retrospectively: the BIS-based Eleveld model and a new model using the frontal EEG marker.

This is a multicenter, open-label, randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the non-inferiority of a very short-course (1 day) of antibiotic therapy compared to a standard course (4-7 days) in patients with acute cholangitis after adequate endoscopic biliary drainage.

The primary outcome is the clinical cure rate by day 14 after endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) without relapse by day 30. Secondary outcomes include all-cause 90-day mortality, relapse of cholangitis within 90 days, rate of subsequent infections requiring antibiotics, rate of infections with multidrug-resistant bacteria or Clostridioides difficile, adverse drug events, length of intensive care and hospital stay, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness.

Eligible patients are those with acute cholangitis due to common bile duct stones, benign or malignant distal biliary obstruction, or distal biliary stent dysfunction, who have undergone adequate biliary drainage by ERCP. Key exclusion criteria include other etiologies of cholangitis, recurrent chol

This is a prospective, randomized, double-blinded clinical study that aims to compare the effectiveness of conventional versus ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuvers in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The study will be conducted at Tanta University Hospitals in Egypt over one year, starting from August 2023.

The study will enroll 60 morbidly obese patients (BMI > 40 kg/m²) scheduled for laparoscopic bariatric surgery. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:

1. Conventional group (n=30): Patients will receive a recruitment maneuver with a pressure of 30 cmH2O for 30 seconds.
2. Ultrasound-guided group (n=30): Patients will receive a recruitment maneuver guided by real-time lung ultrasound, with a starting pressure of 10 cmH2O for 10 seconds, increased by 10 cmH2O every 10 seconds until no collapsed areas are visible, with a maximum pressure of 40 cmH2O.

This is a prospective randomized open-label trial aimed at optimizing the fractionation schedules for radiotherapy in the treatment of heel spurs (plantar fasciitis). The study compares the efficacy of a single fraction of low-dose radiotherapy (0.5 Gy, 1 Gy, 1.5 Gy, or 2 Gy) versus the standard fractionated regimen of 6 Gy in 4 fractions or 3 Gy in 2 fractions. The primary outcome is to determine whether single-fraction radiotherapy is non-inferior to fractionated radiotherapy in providing pain relief over a 3-month period. Secondary outcomes include comparing the different single-fraction regimens, the need for re-irradiation, quality of life, and pain scores. The study enrolled patients over 40 years old with a diagnosed painful unilateral plantar heel spur for at least 6 months, and excluded those with prior radiotherapy, corticosteroid use, or other medical conditions. The trial is designed as a binary outcome parallel group non-inferiority study with an open-label

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of a lifestyle intervention combining a behavioral weight reduction program with pain neuroscience education (PNE) and cognition-targeted exercise therapy (CTET) compared to PNE and CTET alone in overweight or obese individuals with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

The primary objective is to examine if the combined lifestyle intervention is superior to PNE and CTET alone in reducing pain intensity at 12 months follow-up. Secondary objectives include evaluating the effects on other pain-related outcomes, anthropometrics, energy balance-related behaviors, and health economics.

The study will randomize 252 adults (18-65 years) with overweight/obesity and CLBP to either the experimental intervention (lifestyle intervention with PNE and CTET) or the control intervention (PNE and CTET alone). The interventions will be delivered over 14 weeks with 18 treatment sessions.

The primary outcome is change in average pain intensity (Brief Pain Inventory) from baseline to 12 months. Secondary outcomes include other pain measures, body composition, physical activity, sleep, dietary intake, and health economic

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the clinical outcomes and efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy during gastric per-oral endoscopic myotomy (G-POEM) for the treatment of refractory and severe gastroparesis. The primary outcome measures are clinical success at 3, 6, and 12 months, Gastroparesis Cardinal Symptom Index (GCSI) scores before and after G-POEM at 3, 6, and 12 months, and technical success rate. Secondary outcome measures include total procedure time, adverse events, and recurrence of symptoms. Eligible participants are adults (≥18 years) with refractory and severe gastroparesis (GCSI >2) and confirmed impaired gastric emptying. Participants will be randomized to either single or double pyloromyotomy during the G-POEM procedure.

This was a single-arm, open-label study that evaluated the efficacy of the Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink with SOD on female nutritional anemia, skin condition, and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome. The study enrolled females aged 18 to 35 years with hemoglobin levels below 110 g/L. Participants consumed one 25 mL piece of the Minayo Yeast Drink product daily for 4 weeks. The primary outcome was the change in serum ferritin levels from baseline to week 4. Secondary outcomes included changes in hemoglobin concentration, superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione (GSH) levels, and skin condition (lines/wrinkles) over the 4-week period.

This study aims to test the effectiveness of combining acute intermittent hypercapnic hypoxia (AIHH) exposure with transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) to improve respiratory and hand function in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (SCI). 

The study has three specific aims:
1. To test if combining AIHH with tSCS-paired respiratory strength training will induce greater respiratory motor output compared to either treatment alone.
2. To test if combining AIHH with tSCS-paired upper extremity functional training will induce greater upper extremity motor output compared to either treatment alone. 
3. To identify biomarkers associated with diminished response to the combinatorial AIHH and tSCS treatments.

The study will use a randomized, crossover design with four experimental arms: 1) AIHH + tSCS-paired training, 2) Sham AIHH + tSCS-paired training, 3) AIHH + Sham tSCS-paired training, and 4

This is a prospective, 2x2 factorial design, blinded, randomized controlled study that aims to assess the cerebral hemodynamic and metabolic responses to different anesthetic maintenance agents (propofol vs. sevoflurane) and vasopressors (phenylephrine vs. ephedrine) in adult patients undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. 

The primary outcome is the difference in cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2) during surgery between the anesthetic and vasopressor groups. Secondary outcomes include the effects of anesthetic induction and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism.

The study will recruit 80 adult patients (age >18 years) who are ASA I-III and scheduled for surgery under general anesthesia. Patients will be randomized into one of four groups: 1) propofol-based anesthesia with phenylephrine, 2) propofol-based anesthesia with ephedrine, 3) sevoflurane-based anesthesia with phenylephrine, or

The study is a national cohort on imprinting disorders (IDs) and their metabolic consequences. It aims to investigate the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of IDs in pediatric and adult patients. The primary outcome measures include evaluating these characteristics over an average of 10 years. The secondary outcome measures focus on exploring the association between metabolic phenotype and biological profile, determining the prevalence of metabolic abnormalities, estimating the risk of metabolic complications, describing therapeutic approaches, analyzing quality of life, and examining the transmission of (epi)genetic mutations in probands and relatives. The study includes patients with various IDs, such as Silver Russell Syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome, and Prader-Willi Syndrome, and does not accept healthy volunteers.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial comparing unipolar versus bipolar interlocking in the treatment of humeral shaft fractures in adults. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years and above with a diagnosis of humeral shaft fracture requiring surgical treatment with intramedullary nailing. Participants will be randomized to either the unipolar interlocking group or the bipolar interlocking group and will undergo questionnaires (EQ-5D-5L and SF-12) and CT scans at specific timepoints to assess bone healing.

The key aspects of the EPI-MINN clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To address cognitive dysfunction and impaired motivation, which are core features of psychosis and strong predictors of functional outcomes, by combining cognitive plus social cognitive training delivered remotely with a mobile app called Personalized Real-time Intervention for Motivational Enhancement (PRIME).

2. Study Design: Randomized controlled trial with two arms - 1) Experimental group receiving cognitive and social cognitive training plus the PRIME app, and 2) Control group receiving standard coordinated specialty care.

3. Participants: Individuals aged 18-40 years enrolled in early psychosis coordinated specialty care programs, with stable clinical status.

4. Primary Outcomes: Changes in cognitive function, defeatist beliefs, quality of life, behavioral inhibition/activation, and motivation/pleasure at 18 months.

5. Secondary Outcome: Changes in depression and anxiety symptoms at 18 months.

6. Significance: The study aims to optimize coordinated specialty care for early psychosis by addressing unmet therapeutic needs related to cognition and motivation, which are critical for functional recovery.

This is a prospective, two-arm randomized parallel group clinical trial that aims to assess the use of wearable fitness trackers in prehabilitation programs for patients with non-metastatic oesophago-gastric (OG), hepatobiliary (HPB), or lung cancer (LC) scheduled for curative surgical resection.

The primary objective is to compare the total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise between the intervention group (prescribed exercise based on personalized heart rate zones) and the control group (prescribed exercise based on rating of perceived exertion) over an 8-week follow-up period.

The secondary objectives include comparing the volume of physical activity, weekly adherence, duration and intensity of exercise as measured by the fitness trackers versus self-reported, as well as assessing patient feedback on the acceptability, usability, and user experience of using the heart rate trackers in the prehabilitation setting.

Eligible patients will be randomized 1:1 to either the intervention or control group. All participants will be provided with a wearable fitness tracker to monitor their activity.

The study is a multicentre, single-blinded, randomized, controlled, superiority trial comparing two minimally invasive treatments for pilonidal disease: pit-picking surgery alone versus pit-picking surgery with sinus laser-assisted closure (SiLaC). The primary outcome is the success rate of treatment, defined as wound healing outcomes at 1 year, including closure of all pits, absence of symptoms, absence of persisting sinuses, and absence of recurrence. Secondary outcomes include long-term success rates, pain scores, patient-reported outcomes, wound healing and complications, work rehabilitation, return to daily activities, recurrence rates, need for secondary or revision surgery, patient satisfaction, and quality of life. The study aims to determine the optimal minimally invasive treatment for pilonidal disease.

The study aimed to identify the sociodemographic characteristics, personality traits, and patterns of substance abuse among patients with substance use disorder (SUD) admitted to the addiction treatment unit at Assiut University Hospital in Egypt. The study included all patients with SUD admitted to the unit, excluding those who refused to participate. Data was collected through a survey, psychiatric interview, and standardized assessments such as the Symptom Checklist-90-Revised and Severity of Dependence Scale. The primary outcome measures were to characterize the sociodemographic profile, personality traits, and substance abuse patterns of the patients. The study provided supportive psychotherapy as the intervention to help patients detox and rehabilitate.

This is a phase 2 single-arm clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of combining immune checkpoint inhibitors (durvalumab and tremelimumab) with radioembolization using yttrium-90 microspheres for the treatment of previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma.

The primary outcome measures are the best objective response rate and the rate of abscopal effect (tumor shrinkage at sites outside the radiation field). Secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of treatment-related side effects, local control rate, and distant control rate.

The study will enroll patients with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma who meet the eligibility criteria, including having an ECOG performance status of 0 or 1 and adequate organ function. Patients will receive durvalumab intravenously every 4 weeks for 7 cycles, tremelimumab intravenously on week 1 only, and yttrium-90 radioembolization on week 2 only.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this combination therapy approach for the treatment of metast

This is a Phase II clinical trial evaluating the use of neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab in combination with gemcitabine and cisplatin in patients with borderline resectable or resectable intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma at high risk of recurrence. The primary objectives are to assess the rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable disease after 4 or 8 cycles of treatment, and to evaluate the incidence of treatment-related adverse events. Secondary objectives include assessing objective response rate, pathological complete response, overall survival, progression-free survival, rate of R0 resection, relapse-free survival, patient-reported outcomes, and event-free survival. The study uses a single-arm, open-label design, with participants receiving durvalumab, tremelimumab, gemcitabine, and cisplatin. If the tumor is deemed resectable after 4 cycles, the patient may proceed to surgical resection; if unresectable, they will continue treatment for up to 8 cycles before reevaluation.

This study aims to establish normal reference values for the structure and hemodynamics of extremity arteries in healthy Chinese Han adults using high-frequency ultrasound. The primary outcome measure is the intima thickness of the dorsalis pedis artery and proper palmar digital artery, which reflects changes in vascular wall structure and can be used for early evaluation of arterial disease. The secondary outcome measure is the blood flow velocity of these arteries, which reflects hemodynamic changes and can also aid in early detection of arterial disease. The study will enroll healthy volunteers aged 18-79 years old without cardiovascular, metabolic, or connective tissue diseases. High-frequency ultrasound, a non-invasive imaging technique, will be used to assess the arterial structure and blood flow parameters. The results will provide quantitative reference values to support early diagnosis, evaluation, and monitoring of extremity arterial diseases.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of STERIFY GEL in promoting healing of periodontal pockets following scaling and root planing (SRP) compared to SRP alone in patients with grade III and IV chronic periodontitis. It is a pivotal, prospective, single-center, split-mouth, randomized, controlled study. 

The primary outcome measure is the change in periodontal pocket depth over 3 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in gingival recession, clinical attachment level, plaque index, bleeding index, furcations, and degree of tooth mobility. Bacterial contamination will also be quantified through quantitative PCR.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years and above with at least 20 teeth and at least 2 sites with periodontal pocket depth greater than 5mm. Patients with certain medical conditions, aggressive periodontitis, or recent dental procedures are excluded.

The study uses a split-mouth design, where one or two segments of the mouth receive SRP plus STERIFY GEL application, while the contralateral segments receive SRP alone as the control. Outcomes are assessed at baseline, 1,

The study aims to evaluate whether hippocampal training, combining physical and cognitive training, can augment the hippocampal neuroplasticity effect of hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) and further enhance recovery of inaccessible traumatic memories in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and peritraumatic amnesia. The study will recruit 40 male veterans aged 25-60 years with combat-associated PTSD and peritraumatic amnesia, who will be randomly assigned to receive either HBOT alone or HBOT plus hippocampal training. The primary outcome measures are changes in memory gaps and time to inaccessible memory surfacing. Secondary outcome measures include changes in brain activity assessed by fMRI, cognitive performance, and various memory tests. The study aims to elucidate the mechanism of PTSD-related memory impairment and contribute to the development of biological memory manipulations for treating PTSD and other memory-related conditions.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the use of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging for the diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis. This tracer targets macrophages, which are found in sarcoid granulomas, and may provide better specificity compared to the currently used 18F-FDG PET/CT.

2. The study includes four participant groups:
   - Group A: 22 patients with clinically suspected cardiac sarcoidosis
   - Group B: 22 patients with known cardiac sarcoidosis
   - Group C: Up to 10 patients with clinically suspected or confirmed acute lymphocytic myocarditis
   - Group D: 22 patients with neuroendocrine tumors (NET) without known inflammatory heart disease, who have previously undergone 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scans (control group)

3. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in the cardiac sarcoidosis and NET control groups.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single-center pilot/exploratory trial that aims to evaluate the effect of probiotics (Florajen Digestion) on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea in renal transplant recipients. The primary outcome measures are:

1. Reduction in immunosuppressive drugs-associated diarrhea, assessed using a gastrointestinal questionnaire and Bristol Stool Chart.
2. Analysis of inflammatory biomarkers, including TNF, IFN, Treg cytokines, and matrix metalloproteinases, through a general linear model analysis of variance.
3. Association between inflammatory markers and fecal microbiome, assessed through 16S PCR and next-generation sequencing.

The study will enroll renal transplant recipients (living or deceased donor) who have mild to severe diarrhea (>3 times loose stools/day) and are on immunosuppressive drug regimens. Participants will be randomized to receive either probiotics or placebo capsules daily for six months after the onset of post-surgical, non-infectious diarrhea

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to assess the efficacy of inhaled sedation with sevoflurane compared to current intravenous sedation practice for improving pulmonary function in ICU patients at high risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The primary outcome measure is the longitudinal evolution of the PaO2/FiO2 ratio within 5 days of randomization. Secondary outcomes include progression to ARDS, rate of pneumonia, ventilator-free days, organ failure, mortality, length of ICU stay, and various physiological measures. The study is a single-center, prospective, randomized, stratified, parallel-group trial with blinded outcome assessment and concealed allocation of patients to the two intervention groups.

This study aims to evaluate the outcomes of different treatment modalities for patients with massive rotator cuff tendon tears. The study will include patients aged 50-80 years with grade III massive rotator cuff tears, as defined by the Davidson and Burkhart classification. The primary objectives are to assess changes in shoulder strength, range of motion, and functional outcomes using the ASES, Constant-Murley, and DASH scores. Secondary objectives include evaluating the integrity of surgically repaired tendons on MRI, changes in quality of life and kinesiophobia scores.

The study design is a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with the following intervention groups:
1. Arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair with superior capsular augmentation using the long head of the biceps tendon (LHBBT)
2. Arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair
3. Arthroscopic complete rotator cuff repair
4. Conservative treatment

Patients with irreparable tears will be randomly assigned to either partial repair with LHBBT augmentation or partial repair alone. Outcomes will be assessed at baseline, 6, 12, and 24

The IRIS Program is a clinical trial that aims to optimize the treatment of injection-related infections among people who inject drugs in Hamilton, Ontario. The study uses a single-group assignment design to provide a holistic, low-barrier, combined care model to participants. The intervention includes diagnosis and treatment of injection-related infections, substance use treatment, peer support, and care coordination. The primary outcome measure is the number of emergency department visits and hospital readmissions within 30 days of initial hospital admission or program enrollment. Secondary outcome measures include completion of intended treatment, hospital readmissions, emergency department visits, initiation or continuation of substance use treatment, mortality rates, and program dropout rates. The study excludes healthy volunteers and is open to participants aged 16 years and older with a history of injection drug use and a confirmed or suspected injection-related infection.

This study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the use of a mobile app (CanImmunize) versus a web-based platform for surveillance of adverse events following influenza immunization. The primary outcome measure is the usability of the two platforms, assessed through a user experience survey completed by participants after the safety survey. Participants were randomized to either the mobile app arm or the web-based notification arm. The study enrolled adults aged 18 years and older who were eligible for the seasonal influenza vaccine. The study aims to evaluate the user experience and preferences between the mobile app and web-based platforms for reporting adverse events following influenza immunization.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the key aspects of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a case-control study that aims to:

1. Investigate the relationship between peri-implantitis and COX-2 gene polymorphisms.
2. Identify the pathogenic microbiota associated with peri-implantitis using next-generation sequencing.
3. Evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of an active MMP-8 (aMMP-8) point-of-care chair-side test for peri-implantitis.

The study will recruit a minimum of 100 patients diagnosed with peri-implantitis according to the latest criteria. Buccal swab samples will be collected to analyze COX-2 gene polymorphisms. Peri-implant crevicular fluid samples will be obtained to identify the associated microbiota using 16S rRNA sequencing and to measure aMMP-8 levels using the ImplantSafe rapid test.

The primary outcome measure is the evaluation of gene polymorphisms of MMP-8 over a 3-year period.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on pain, anxiety, and patient comfort during trigger point injection. Patients in the experimental group will be shown nature, seaside, and underwater videos with music through virtual reality glasses for 10 minutes during the procedure, while the control group will receive routine care. The primary outcome measures are the State Anxiety Scale, General Comfort Scale, and Visual Analog Scale for pain, which will be assessed 10 minutes after the procedure. The study includes patients aged 18-65 years who are able to understand and speak Turkish, have good cognitive abilities, and do not have visual, hearing, or cognitive impairments or epilepsy.

This is a prospective observational study that aims to investigate the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) in patients with achalasia. The study will compare the "wobble" of systolic arterial pressure (a measure of hemodynamic instability) between achalasia patients with and without autonomic dysfunction, as determined by preoperative heart rate variability testing. Patients will undergo POEM under standardized general anesthesia, and the primary outcome is the wobble of systolic arterial pressure during the intraoperative period.

This study evaluates the use of virtual reality (VR) glasses during inhaler treatment in children aged 2-5 years. It is a prospective, single-blind, randomized, controlled study conducted at the Pediatric Emergency Department. Children were divided into three groups: VR audio-visual users with roller coasters, VR audio-visual users with wild dolphins, and a control group without any additional equipment. The primary outcome measure is the change in pain scoring system, assessed using the FLACC Pain Assessment Scale and the Yale Modified Anxiety Scale. Secondary outcomes include changes in respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, heart rate, and duration of crying during the 15-minute inhaler treatment. The study aims to determine if the use of VR glasses can help reduce discomfort and anxiety in children during inhaler treatment.

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effect of a transdiagnostic psychological treatment called the Unified Protocol (UP-C/A) for children and adolescents (ages 7-17) with anxiety disorders, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and/or depression in a primary care setting. The study uses a single-group design, where participants receive the UP-C/A intervention in an 11-session group format, along with concurrent parent training. The primary outcome measure is the Emotion Regulation Index for Children and Adolescents (ERICA), and secondary outcome measures include the Revised Children's Anxiety and Depression Scale (R-CADS), Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ), Kidscreen-10 Index, Children's Global Assessment Scale (C-GAS), Client Satisfaction Questionnaire (CSQ-8), and clinician-reported measures of intervention acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility. The study aims to recruit approximately 30 participants across two primary care clinics, with the goal of informing a future randomized controlled trial of the UP-C/A intervention in primary care.

The PALISA study is a clinical trial that aims to assess pain and stress levels in preterm infants during less-invasive surfactant administration (LISA) using skin conductance measurement and video recording. The primary outcome is the median peaks per second of skin conductance at pre-specified time points, adjusted for baseline. Secondary outcomes include median Neonatal Pain, Agitation and Sedation Scale (N-PASS) scores, incidence of adverse events like apnea, desaturation, bradycardia, and hypotension, as well as differences in heart rate, oxygen saturation, and SpO2/FiO2 ratio before, during, and after the LISA procedure. The study includes preterm infants ≥27 weeks of gestation requiring surfactant therapy via LISA, and excludes infants with severe congenital malformations or those requiring immediate intubation. The study aims to provide insights into the pain and stress experienced by preterm infants during the LISA procedure.

This is a feasibility cluster randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the intervention for depression in underserved geriatric populations in Nigeria. The intervention, called emhGAP-Age, involves adapted problem-solving therapy, support/supervision of lay providers, and links to social support resources. The study will compare the adapted emhGAP-Age intervention to a generic emhGAP-IG intervention that provides psychoeducation and stress reduction. The primary outcome measure is depression remission, defined as a Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) score less than 6, at 6 months post-trial entry. The study will enroll participants aged 60 years and older who meet the inclusion criteria of a PHQ-9 score of 11 or greater during routine consultation, and exclude those with severe comorbidities, cognitive impairment, active suicidal intention, or severe mental disorders.

This is a prospective, single-center, single-blinded, randomized controlled study that aims to evaluate the efficacy of using a bone/platelet-rich plasma (PrP) composite to reduce tibial tunnel widening in anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction compared to standard ACL reconstruction technique.

The primary outcome measures are the changes in tibial tunnel diameter and volume at 10-14 months post-surgery, assessed by CT imaging. Secondary outcome measures include changes in femoral tunnel diameter and volume, graft maturity (subjective and objective), graft integration, and bone healing and integration, also assessed at 10-14 months.

The study will recruit 107 patients aged 18-50 years with primary ACL rupture, who will be randomly assigned 1:1 to either the experimental group (ACL reconstruction with bone/PrP composite) or the control group (standard ACL reconstruction). The study duration per patient is 24 months, with a total study duration of 48 months.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of high-flow nasal oxygen cannula (HFNOC) preoxygenation on oxygen saturation and heart rate during rapid sequence induction (RSI) in infants and small children requiring acute surgery.

The study will randomize participants into three groups: 1) RSI with face-mask preoxygenation, 2) RSI with HFNOC preoxygenation, and 3) RSI with combined HFNOC and face-mask preoxygenation. 

The primary outcomes are the incidence of desaturation below 90% and the incidence of manual ventilation during RSI. Secondary outcomes include incidence of desaturation below 80%, time to desaturation, time to optimal intubation conditions, time to successful intubation, first attempt intubation success rate, intubation conditions, and incidence of complications (aspiration, regurgitation, difficult intubation).

The study will enroll pediatric patients up to 6 years of age who require RSI for anesthesia induction. Healthy volunteers are excluded.

This is an open-label extension study to evaluate the long-term safety, tolerability, and efficacy of pozelimab and cemdisiran combination therapy in adult patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

The primary outcome measures are the incidence and severity of treatment-emergent serious adverse events (SAEs) and adverse events of special interest (AESIs), as well as the incidence and severity of adverse events leading to permanent treatment discontinuation. The study also aims to assess the percent change from baseline in lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.

Secondary outcome measures include maintenance of adequate control of hemolysis (LDH ≤1.5 × ULN), transfusion avoidance, breakthrough hemolysis, hemoglobin stabilization, changes in fatigue and physical function, normalization of LDH, rate and number of red blood cell transfusions, percentage of days with LDH ≤1.5 × ULN, changes in hemoglobin levels, complement activity, and pharmacokinetics and immunogenicity of the study drugs.

The study will en

This is a 24-week prospective study that aims to examine predictors of initial 6-month subscription and subscription renewal rates for the WayBetter health and fitness app. The study will also characterize app engagement over the first 24 weeks of use. The study sample will consist of approximately 400 new adult users who have completed a 7-day free trial of the app. The primary outcomes are the rates of initial 6-month subscription and 6-month subscription renewal. The secondary outcomes include various app engagement metrics such as app opens per week, time to joining first game, game adherence, games started and won, non-usage attrition, and re-engagement. The study will use a combination of survey data, user activity data, and app engagement metrics to identify predictors of subscription and engagement.

The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises on depression and sleep quality in primigravida (first-time pregnant) females. The study will be conducted at the Children's Hospital Sheikhupura and Mehmooda Hospital Sheikhupura, and will involve 42 participants randomly assigned to two groups: Group A will receive aerobic exercises, and Group B will receive Pilates exercises, with both groups receiving 16 sessions over 8 weeks. The primary outcome measures are the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) and the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), which will be assessed at baseline and after 8 weeks of treatment. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these two exercise interventions in improving depression and sleep quality in primigravida females.

This is a randomized controlled experimental study that aimed to determine the effect of swaddling and inhaling mother's breast milk odor on the pain and comfort during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter in term infants. The study population consisted of 120 term infants hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit, who were equally assigned to three experimental groups and a control group. During the procedure, the infants in the first experimental group were swaddled, the second group inhaled the mother's breast milk odor, the third group were both swaddled and made to inhale the breast milk odor, while the control group received no intervention. The pain and comfort levels of the infants were assessed before, during, and after the procedure using the Neonatal Infant Pain Scale and the Neonatal Comfort Behaviour Scale.

This study aims to investigate the biological mechanism underlying the efficacy of psychotherapy for depression using functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS). The study will randomize patients with depression into three groups: medication therapy, Interpersonal Psychotherapy (IPT), and a combination of medication and IPT. The primary outcome measures are changes in fNIRS data and remission rates on the Hamilton Depression Scale (HAM-D24) after treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in remission rates on the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), and Beck Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI). The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of psychotherapy, specifically IPT, and establish biological markers of psychotherapy efficacy in patients with depression.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of indium In 111 panitumumab (111In-panitumumab) as a molecular imaging agent for nodal staging in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). The primary objective is to assess the safety of 111In-panitumumab. The secondary objectives are to compare the sensitivity and specificity of identifying sentinel lymph nodes using systemic injection of 111In-panitumumab versus conventional local injection with an optical dye. Exploratory objectives include determining if systemic 111In-panitumumab can identify tumor-positive lymph nodes on preoperative SPECT/CT, and evaluating the performance of 111In-panitumumab SPECT/CT compared to preoperative MRI and PET/CT in identifying metastatic lymph nodes. Patients receive a loading dose of panitumumab followed by 111In-panitumumab, undergo SPECT/CT imaging, and then undergo standard-of-care surgery with local injection of optical dye and intraoperative/near-infrared imaging. Safety, sensitivity, and specificity

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial investigating the efficacy and mechanism of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation (tVNS) combined with medication in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

The study will enroll adults aged 18-65 years who meet the DSM-5 criteria for GAD. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either tVNS plus anti-anxiety medication or sham stimulation plus medication.

The primary outcome is the change in Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAMA) scores from baseline to week 2 of treatment. Secondary outcomes include changes in HAMA, Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD), and Generalized Anxiety Scale scores at weeks 2 and 4, as well as changes in brain function indicators and incidence of adverse events.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of tVNS combined with medication in improving anxiety symptoms in GAD patients and to explore the underlying neurophysiological mechanisms.

The study aimed to report the results of dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation (DLDI) for the management of nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO), and to identify factors associated with DLDI failure. The study included patients with confirmed NLDO or stenosis, recurrent or persistent symptomatic epiphora, and follow-up of at least 6 months after silicone stent removal. Patients were divided into three groups based on the level of obstruction: higher NLDO (group A), lower NLDO (group B), and nasolacrimal duct stenosis (group C). All patients underwent DLDI, where a dacryoendoscope was inserted through the lacrimal punctum, and laser dacryoplasty was performed to widen the stenotic or obstructed section, followed by silicone intubation. The primary outcome measure was the cumulative success rate of DLDI within 2 years of follow-up, assessed using the Kaplan-Meier estimator.

This study aims to investigate the immediate effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) with lower leg kinesio taping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that will include patients diagnosed with hemiplegia due to hemorrhagic or ischemic stroke for more than 6 months. Participants will be between 40 and 70 years old and will be able to walk independently for at least 10 meters without an assistive device.

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three intervention groups:
1. Lower leg kinesio taping
2. PNF
3. PNF with lower leg kinesio taping

The primary outcome measures are:
- Time up and go test
- Barthel Index
- Motor Assessment Scale
- Dynamic Gait Index

These measures will be assessed at baseline and 1 hour after the intervention.

The study aims to determine the immediate effects of the different interventions on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

This is a mixed (quantitative and qualitative), multicentre, non-randomised, quasi-experimental, before-and-after, open, cross-sectional study with control and experimental groups, designed to develop and evaluate an algorithm for vascular access management. 

The study consists of three phases:

1. Observational phase (4 months): Describes existing practices for peripheral venous catheter placement and collects pre-intervention data.

2. Interventional phase (4 months): Evaluates the impact of implementing the A-DIVA Scale (a classification score for difficult intravenous access) on practitioners' approaches to peripheral venous catheter placement.

3. Interventional phase (4 months): Evaluates the impact of implementing an algorithm composed of the A-DIVA Scale and a new decision-making tree (the A-DIVA Tool) on the quality of peripheral venous catheter placement.

The primary outcome is the number of venipunctures performed per patient after implementation of the algorithm. Secondary outcomes include acceptability and feasibility of the A-DIVA Scale and algorithm, patient pain scores, and various measures of operators' professional practices.

The study is an evaluation of the STARgraft-3 device for hemodialysis access in patients with end-stage renal disease. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of subjects without an occurrence of access thrombosis or an access procedure to maintain patency at 6 months post-implantation. Secondary outcome measures include primary unassisted patency, assisted primary patency, secondary patency, frequency of interventions, blood flow rates, and safety outcomes at various timepoints up to 12 months post-implantation. The study has a single-arm, open-label design, and participants will receive the STARgraft-3 implant in the upper arm for hemodialysis access.

The study is a randomized clinical trial called "Primary Care Online Emotion-regulation Treatment (POET)" that aims to determine the clinical efficacy of a digital emotion regulation treatment in adolescents with mental health problems. Participants aged 12-17 years will be randomized to either the POET intervention or an active control supportive treatment. 

The primary outcome is the Clinical Global Impressions-Severity scale (CGI-S) to assess symptom severity. Secondary outcomes include measures of symptom improvement, depression/anxiety, global functioning, emotion regulation, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, post-treatment, and 3, 12, and 60 months after treatment.

The POET intervention includes six guided digital treatment modules for the youth and six for the parents, focused on emotion regulation strategies and parental support. The active control is a supportive treatment with educational materials.

The study aims to test the effects of POET on mental health problems and emotion regulation, whether emotion regulation mediates treatment effects, and if POET is cost-effective and works better for some individuals than

This is a multicenter, randomized, open-label, phase III clinical trial evaluating the impact of hypofractionated radiotherapy strategies after surgery for non-melanoma skin cancer in older patients (aged ≥ 70 years). 

The primary objective is to evaluate the comparative efficacy of two radiotherapy modalities (moderate hypofractionation vs. extreme hypofractionation) versus surgery alone on local tumor control at 3-year follow-up. 

Patients with at least one unfavorable prognostic factor for non-melanoma skin cancer (SCC or BCC) will be randomized to one of three arms:
- Arm A: Surgery alone
- Arm B: Surgery + moderate hypofractionation radiotherapy (45Gy in 15 fractions over 5 weeks) 
- Arm C: Surgery + extreme hypofractionation radiotherapy (30Gy in 5 fractions over 5 weeks)

The key outcomes being measured are:
- Health-related quality of life (EORTC QLQ-C30 and QLQ-ELD14)

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to evaluate the risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) in older adults (age 75+) with a prior history of normal colonoscopy versus colonoscopy with polypectomy (Aim 1), and the effectiveness of surveillance colonoscopy in reducing CRC risk among older adults with prior polypectomy (Aim 2).

2. The study will also obtain multi-level stakeholder perspectives on CRC risk and the potential benefits and harms of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults to inform future VA policy (Aim 3).

3. The primary outcome is CRC incidence, and the secondary outcome is CRC mortality. The study will also characterize harms associated with surveillance colonoscopy.

4. The study population includes Veterans aged 75+ with a history of normal colonoscopy or colonoscopy with polypectomy prior to age 75. A case-cohort design will be used for Aim 2.

5. Qualitative interviews with older adult patients and healthcare providers, as well as an expert panel, will be conducted to obtain stakeholder perspectives on CRC risk and surveillance colon

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to assess the effect of early bedside cycling exercises on physical and psychological outcomes in patients after heart valve surgery. The study will be conducted on 50 patients with valvular heart disease undergoing valve replacement or intervention. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (25 patients) or the control group (25 patients). 

The intervention group will receive daily bedside cycling exercises in addition to the standard medical treatment and physiotherapy protocol, while the control group will receive only the standard physiotherapy protocol and medical treatment. The primary outcome measures include functional capacity (6-minute walk test), forced vital capacity, psychological status, activities of daily living, quality of life, and length of hospital stay. Secondary outcome measures include functional capacity, psychological status, quality of life, incidence of adverse events, and prothrombin international normalized ratio (INR) at 1-month follow-up.

The study aims to conduct a molecular analysis of screen-detected non-invasive breast cancer and atypical breast hyperplasias identified through the Sloane Project. The conditions being studied are DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma in situ), LCIS (Lobular Carcinoma in situ), Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia, and Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia. The study is open to female participants and the primary outcome measure is the progression of breast disease from diagnosis to the end of 2016.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, quadruple-masked clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of tirzepatide, a dual GLP-1/GIP receptor agonist, in the concurrent treatment of obesity and type 1 diabetes (T1DM). The study will enroll adults aged 18-70 years with a diagnosis of T1DM for less than 12 months and a body mass index (BMI) of 30 kg/m2 or higher. 

Participants will be randomized to either the tirzepatide treatment group or the control group, which will continue their standard insulin therapy. The primary outcome is the percent change in body weight at 32 weeks. Secondary outcomes include changes in HbA1c, time in glycemic range, insulin dose, waist and neck circumference, blood pressure, lipid parameters, and markers of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

The study aims to assess the potential benefits of tirzepatide in improving glycemic control, weight loss, and other cardiometabolic parameters in individuals with concurrent obesity and recent-onset T1DM.

This is a randomized, single-blind clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of losartan in preventing paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy in female breast cancer patients. The primary outcome measures are the incidence and grade of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy at 12 weeks. Secondary outcomes include patient-reported quality of life (FACT/GOG-NTX) and serum nerve growth factor (NGF) levels, also at 12 weeks. Eligible participants are females over 18 years old with early-stage breast cancer scheduled to receive paclitaxel chemotherapy. Patients will be randomized to either the control arm receiving standard-of-care management or the intervention arm receiving standard-of-care plus losartan 100mg. The study aims to determine if losartan can prevent the development and severity of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy in this patient population.
