This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind clinical study to evaluate the efficacy of Ginkgo Biloba Ketone Ester Tablets in patients with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment. 

The study enrolled 370 patients who were randomly assigned to either the experimental group (n=185) or the control group (n=185). The experimental group received Ginkgo Biloba Ketone Ester Tablets (0.5g, 3 times daily) combined with conventional hypoglycemic treatment for 6 months, while the control group received placebo plus conventional hypoglycemic treatment.

The primary outcome measure was cognitive function assessed by the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive section (ADAS-cog). Secondary outcomes included memory, daily living ability, functional evaluation, and attention assessed by various neuropsychological tests.

The study also collected blood samples to measure biomarkers such as C-reactive protein, interleukin-6, oxidative stress, ApoE4 genotype, phosphor

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial comparing the efficacy and safety of two treatment regimens for newly diagnosed severe aplastic anemia (SAA) in elderly patients (aged >60 years):

1. Ciclosporin (CsA) + anti-thymocyte immunoglobulin (ATG) + avatrombopag (AVA)
2. Ciclosporin (CsA) + avatrombopag (AVA)

The primary outcome measure is the overall response rate (partial or complete response) at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include complete response rate, relapse rate, and adverse event rate.

The study aims to determine whether the CsA+AVA regimen can achieve similar efficacy to the CsA+ATG+AVA regimen in the treatment of SAA in the elderly population, while potentially having fewer adverse effects.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab (89Zr-panitumumab) positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) imaging for the detection of indeterminate metastatic lesions in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. The primary objectives are to determine the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT, and to compare its performance to standard of care imaging modalities such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), CT, and/or 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) PET/CT. The study also explores the rate of intervention versus non-intervention by the treatment team in subjects with indeterminate metastatic lesions on standard of care imaging. Eligible patients will receive panitumumab and 89Zr-panitumumab intravenously and undergo PET/CT imaging. The study will assess the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT up to 7 years.

This is a prospective, open-label, multicenter, randomized controlled phase III study evaluating the effect of prophylactic central neck dissection in patients with low-risk papillary thyroid cancer. The primary outcome is to assess the excellent response rate at 1 year, while the secondary outcomes are to evaluate recurrence-free survival at 1 and 2 years. Eligible patients are 18-70 years old with cT1b-T2, cN0 papillary thyroid cancer without serious medical conditions or history of other malignancies. Patients will be randomized to either undergo prophylactic central neck dissection or no central neck dissection. The study aims to determine if prophylactic central neck dissection can improve outcomes in low-risk papillary thyroid cancer patients.

This is a three-arm, superiority, single-blinded, cluster-randomized trial to evaluate the efficacy of two next-generation long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs) for malaria control in Côte d'Ivoire. The intervention arms are:

1. Veeralin LLIN - a net combining the synergist PBO and the pyrethroid alpha-cypermethrin.
2. Interceptor G2 LLIN - a mixture LLIN incorporating two adulticides with different modes of action: chlorfenapyr and a pyrethroid (alpha-cypermethrin).
3. The control arm: MAGNet LLIN - an alpha-cypermethrin-only LLIN.

The primary outcome is the incidence of malaria cases (fever and positive rapid diagnostic test) in children aged 6 months to 10 years over one year of follow-up. Secondary outcomes include malaria infection prevalence in the overall population at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months, as well as vector density, sporozoite rate, and entomological inoculation rate over the

The PRECISION Study is a single-arm, two-stage Phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety of delivering 3 fractions of prostate stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) with the RayPilot HypoCath image guidance system in men with low-risk or intermediate-risk prostate cancer.

The primary outcome measures are the number of patients with acute (up to 12 weeks) grade 2 or worse urinary and bowel toxicity, as assessed by the Radiation Oncology Toxicity Grading (RTOG) and Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) scales.

The secondary outcome measures include the number of patients with late (up to 24 months) grade 2 or worse urinary and bowel toxicity, as well as various quality of life assessments using patient-reported outcome measures such as EPIC-26, IPSS, IIEF-5, and Vaizey score.

The study will enroll up to 100 patients with low-risk or favorable intermediate-risk prostate cancer, who will receive 3 consecutive daily fractions of prostate

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to investigate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing root resorption of the upper incisors during intrusion movement using mini-implants in adult patients with deep overbite. The study will compare two groups: a control group receiving traditional orthodontic treatment, and an experimental group receiving LLLT in addition to the orthodontic treatment. The primary outcome measures are the change in root volume and root length, which will be assessed using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images taken before and after the intrusion procedure, which is expected to last 4-5 months. The study includes adult patients aged 18-30 years with a deep overbite condition and specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

The key aspects of the provided clinical trial document are:

1. The study is a multicenter observational study in Italy that aims to analyze the lymphadenectomy performed during right hemicolectomy procedures for colon cancer.

2. The study will enroll 788 patients from high-volume specialist centers in Italy that perform at least 25 of these procedures per year. 

3. The primary outcome is to investigate how the extent of lymphadenectomy (e.g., tumor-free margin, length of terminal ileum, level of vascular ligation, integrity of the mesocolon, number of lymph nodes harvested and positive) correlates with the radicality of the surgical resection.

4. A secondary outcome is to study the vascular anatomical variability of patients and how it may affect the extent of lymphadenectomy, including the position of the superior mesenteric artery relative to the vein and the presence/variability of the middle and right colic arteries.

5. The study will collect patient data such as personal information, tumor stage, type of surgery, postoperative course, and complications over a 6-month observational period.

The study aims to investigate the effects of Cawthorne Cooksey exercises on balance and quality of life in children with hearing deficits. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two experimental arms: one receiving Cawthorne Cooksey exercises and the other receiving Swiss ball exercises. The primary outcome measure is the Pediatric Berg Balance Scale, which evaluates balance, and the secondary outcome measure is the Four-step square test, which assesses dynamic balance. The study includes children aged 7 to 12 years with sensorineural hearing deficits and normal vision, and excludes those with orthopedic, neurological, or medication-related conditions that could affect balance. The study duration is 12 weeks.

The study aims to explore the psychological impact on women with Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) who have completed chemotherapy treatment. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Objectives: 
   - Gain insight into the emotional impact of GTN on patients after treatment
   - Ascertain if health professionals are providing adequate psychological support
   - Identify sources of support that patients accessed post-treatment
   - Identify potential areas of improvement in follow-up support

2. Methodology:
   - Cross-sectional retrospective study with a sample of 20 women
   - Semi-structured telephone interviews conducted 6 weeks to 24 months post-treatment
   - Thematic analysis to generate in-depth descriptions of patient experiences

3. Outcomes:
   - Themes of psychological experiences post-chemotherapy
   - Common opinions of post-treatment support
   - Themes of suggested improvements in patient care

The study aims to provide healthcare professionals with a better understanding of the patient perspective and inform recommendations to improve the support and care provided to this patient population after their treatment has completed.

This study aims to evaluate the utility of bone grafts in open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation for patients with malunited distal radius fractures. Eligible patients will be randomized to either receive bone grafting from the iliac crest or no bone grafting during the open wedge osteotomy and plate fixation procedure. The primary outcome measures are the number and severity of complications, quality of life using the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire, and time to complete bone healing. Secondary outcome measures include subjective functional outcomes using the DASH and PRWE questionnaires, objective functional outcomes such as active range of motion, and cost-effectiveness analysis. The study will have a follow-up period of at least one year.

This is a two-armed randomized controlled trial to examine the short-term and longer-term effectiveness of a brief, individually-tailored behavioral teacher training program for teachers of children with disruptive behaviors in the classroom. 

The primary objective is to examine the short-term effectiveness of the teacher training on the severity of four daily rated target behaviors in specific classroom situations. Secondary objectives include examining the short-term and longer-term effectiveness on other classroom behaviors, behavioral difficulties at school and home, teacher-student relationship quality, teacher self-efficacy, and teacher behavior management strategies.

Teachers will be randomly assigned to either the 3-session brief teacher training program or practice as usual (PAU). The teacher training combines stimulus control and contingency management techniques tailored to the individual teacher and child. Outcomes will be assessed before randomization, 1 week after training completion (or 8 weeks after baseline for PAU), and 3 months after training completion (intervention group only).

The study aims to recruit 60 Dutch elementary school teachers of children aged 4-13 with disruptive behaviors in the classroom.

This study aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and usability of a tele-rehabilitation program that combines immersive virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education for individuals with chronic non-specific neck pain. The study is a mixed-methods pilot study, with a single-group intervention design. The intervention consists of 6 weeks of multimodal tele-rehabilitation, including 5 virtual reality sessions and 1 teleconsultation session with a physiotherapist per week, as well as therapeutic education materials. The primary outcome measures include feasibility (retention rate, adherence, safety, implementation at home, and online consultations), acceptability (satisfaction), and usability (of the virtual reality system and online consultations). Secondary outcome measures include changes in range of motion, neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, and global perceived effect. Participants' experiences with the intervention will also be explored through semi-structured interviews.

This is a single-blind, randomized, controlled trial that aims to assess whether a home-based implementation of the Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy Including Lower Extremities (HABIT-ILE) intervention is not inferior to the classic HABIT-ILE therapy delivered in a rehabilitation camp setting for children with bilateral cerebral palsy aged 5 to 18 years old. 

The study has four participant groups:
1) HABIT-ILE therapy at home without a follow-up
2) HABIT-ILE therapy at home with a 9-week follow-up
3) Classic HABIT-ILE therapy without a home follow-up
4) Classic HABIT-ILE therapy with a 9-week home follow-up

The primary outcome is the change in gross motor function (GMFM-66) at 2 and 12 weeks after baseline. Secondary outcomes include changes in bimanual performance, unimanual dexterity, endurance, activities of daily living, self-esteem, participation, physical activity, and brain

The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing digital exams versus speculum exams for patients with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM) between 22 weeks 0 days and 33 weeks 5 days gestation. The primary outcome is pregnancy latency, measured as the time from admission to delivery. Secondary outcomes include maternal complications (chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, sepsis, wound infections, ICU admission, mortality) and neonatal outcomes (composite morbidity, length of NICU stay, respiratory support, sepsis, intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, pneumonia, mortality). Patient satisfaction with the exams is also assessed. Patients are randomized to either the speculum exam or digital exam group.

The study aims to evaluate the overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS) of patients with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) treated with sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT). SALT involves performing hemihepatectomy combined with left lateral lobe liver transplantation first, followed by residual liver resection after the graft has grown to a sufficient functional liver volume. The study is a single-center, prospective, single-arm trial. Eligible patients are aged 18-75 years, have Child-Pugh A-B liver cirrhosis with HCC due to hepatitis B virus infection, and meet the up-to-seven criteria for tumor size and number. Key exclusion criteria include portal vein, vena cava or bile duct tumor thrombus, severe hepatic encephalopathy, pulmonary hypertension, and extrahepatic tumor burden. The primary outcome is OS at 3 years after the second liver resection, and the secondary outcome is DFS at various time points up to 3 years post-transplant.

The study aims to establish the validity and reliability of a Dexterity Assessment Tool in patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) and healthy individuals. The primary outcome measures include:

1. Dexterity measurements using the Dexterity Assessment Tool in patients with cervical myelopathy to define disease severity.
2. Correlation between the Dexterity Assessment Tool and the GRASSP-M tool (Graded Redefined Assessment of Strength, Sensation and Prehension-Myelopathy) to assess concurrent validity.
3. Correlation of dexterity measurements in healthy participants to assess inter-rater reliability.
4. Correlation of dexterity measurements in healthy participants at two time points to assess test-retest reliability.

The study includes both patient participants diagnosed with DCM and healthy volunteers. The Dexterity Assessment Tool, which measures finger dexterity using pressure sensor pads, is the intervention being evaluated.

This is a non-interventional, single-center, multi-surgeon, observational study to evaluate the effect of intraocular lens (IOL) centration and tilt on visual performance in patients who have undergone Clareon® Vivity® IOL implantation. The study population will include individuals implanted with Clareon® Vivity® and Vivity® Toric IOLs. The primary outcome measure is monocular best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA), and secondary outcome measures include IOL decentration, IOL tilt, monocular uncorrected distance visual acuity (UCDVA), monocular distance-corrected intermediate visual acuity (DCIVA), monocular uncorrected intermediate visual acuity (UCIVA), and manifest refraction/manifest refraction spherical equivalent (MRSE).

This is a randomized, prospective, controlled study that aims to investigate the efficacy of ultrasound-guided serratus posterior superior interfascial plane block (SPSIPB) for postoperative analgesia management in female patients undergoing mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection surgery.

The primary outcome is to compare postoperative pain scores (Numerical Rating Scale, NRS) between the SPSIPB group and the control group. The secondary outcomes include the need for rescue analgesia (meperidine), adverse events related to opioid use (nausea, vomiting, itching), and the dermatomal coverage of the SPSIPB.

Patients will be randomly assigned to either the SPSIPB group or the control group. The SPSIPB group will receive the block with 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine, while the control group will receive wound infiltration with 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine. Both groups will receive ibuprofen every 8 hours, and rescue analgesia (meperidine) will be administered

This is a clinical trial that aims to explore the optimization of the ductography technique and systematically describe the mammary duct structure in Chinese patients with pathological nipple discharge. The study will conduct contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) 4-6 hours after routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml-enhanced ductography to assess the clinical value of this delayed imaging protocol. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging. Secondary outcome measures include diagnostic accuracy of delayed ductal imaging, changes in imaging diagnosis in patients with dense breasts or non-palpable breast mass, inter-rater agreement, and radiologists' diagnostic confidence. The study has a single-arm, open-label design and will enroll female participants aged 18-65 years with suspected pathological nipple discharge.

This is a prospective clinical study investigating the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in heart transplant patients. The study will enroll heart transplant patients aged 18 years and older with a history of symptomatic heart failure for at least 6 months prior to screening. The primary outcome measures are blood lipid measurements (triglycerides, total cholesterol, HDL-C, LDL-C, ApoB) and graft/patient survival over a 4-year follow-up period. The secondary outcome measure is left ventricular ejection fraction at rest, determined by contrast echocardiography, also over 4 years. The study aims to explore the potential relationship between dyslipidemia and transplant outcomes in this patient population.

This is a prospective cohort study that aims to compare the effectiveness of virtual pelvic floor physical therapy with a pelvic floor trainer (Pelex Upp device) in the treatment of stress urinary incontinence in women aged 18 years and older. 

The study will randomize participants into three arms: 1) Pelex Upp device only, 2) Pelex Upp device plus pelvic floor physical therapy, and 3) pelvic floor physical therapy only. The primary outcome measure is the change in stress urinary incontinence symptoms as assessed by the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire - Urinary Incontinence Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) before and after the 4-week intervention period.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to identify strategies to improve attendance and reduce alcohol and substance misuse (ASM) in a behavioral intervention called Community Wise (CW) for individuals with substance use disorder (SUD) living in marginalized communities.

2. The study will use a 2^3 full factorial experiment to test the following intervention delivery strategies:
   a. Recruiting individuals under supervision (parole, probation, drug court, or methadone maintenance)
   b. Incentivizing intervention attendance
   c. Delivering the intervention in an open group format

3. The primary outcome is the number of intervention sessions attended, with a goal of at least 50% of participants attending at least 50% of the sessions.

4. The study will also compare the effect of the different strategies on reducing ASM and measure intervention satisfaction.

5. The study expands the eligibility criteria to include women and individuals with SUD living in marginalized communities who have not been previously incarcerated.

6. The study is a partnership between the research team and the Critical Consciousness Collaborative Board (3CB), and is funded by the National Institute for

The study aims to compare the efficacy of interpectoral plane block + serratus anterior plane block (IPSA) and erector spinae block (ES) as part of multimodal analgesia in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The primary outcome measure is postoperative pain scores (Numerical Rating Scale) up to 48 hours. Secondary outcome measures include opioid consumption, recovery criteria (extubation time, postoperative carbon dioxide levels, drainage amount), intraoperative changes in near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) values, and Critical Care Pain Observation Tool (CPOT) scores until extubation. The study is a randomized, double-blind clinical trial with parallel assignment. Eligible participants are adult patients (18-75 years) undergoing minimally invasive cardiac surgery for the first time, with an average bleeding profile and no history of open heart surgery or local anesthetic allergy.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of botulinum toxin (Botox) injection and internal sphincterotomy in pain relief after hemorrhoidectomy. It is a randomized controlled trial that will compare three groups: 1) Botox injection after hemorrhoidectomy, 2) Hemorrhoidectomy alone (control group), and 3) Hemorrhoidectomy plus internal sphincterotomy. The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain assessed using the visual analogue scale (VAS) at 2 weeks. The secondary outcome measure is the time taken to return to daily activities, measured at 4-6 weeks. The study includes patients aged 18-70 years with grade III or IV hemorrhoids who have failed conservative treatment. Patients with multiple comorbidities, emergency hemorrhoid operations, rectal prolapse, or rectal varices due to portal hypertension are excluded.

This is a phase II, single-arm, open-label clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of modified fruquintinib as maintenance treatment for colorectal cancer patients with liver metastases who have achieved no evidence of disease (NED) after initial treatment. The primary outcome is the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate. Secondary outcomes include 2-year disease-free survival rate and recurrence-free survival period. Eligible patients must be between 18-75 years old, have colorectal adenocarcinoma liver metastases, have achieved disease control with prior first-line chemotherapy, and have undergone curative local treatment to achieve NED. Patients will receive fruquintinib maintenance therapy for 6 months or until disease recurrence/progression or unacceptable toxicity. Imaging and biomarker assessments will be performed regularly to monitor for disease recurrence.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, crossover trial investigating the use of methylphenidate (MPH) for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with associated neurocognitive complaints in veterans. The study aims to assess the efficacy of MPH compared to placebo in reducing PTSD and depression symptoms, as well as improving neurocognitive functioning in this population. The study will enroll 70 veterans across two sites, who will receive 4-week periods of MPH and placebo in a randomized order, separated by 1-week washout periods. The primary outcome measure is the PTSD Symptom Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5), and secondary outcomes include the Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function short form and the Symbol Digit Coding task. The study also aims to characterize baseline predictors of treatment response to MPH, including whether veterans with a history of mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) show greater average treatment response.

The study aims to prospectively validate the capacity of coronary flow reserve (CFR) measured by continuous thermodilution as a predictor of the presence of angina in patients with ischemia and no obstructive coronary arteries (INOCA) at 3 months. The study also aims to identify hemodynamic and clinical factors related to the persistence of angina at 3 and 12 months, establish the prevalence of coronary microvascular dysfunction in the INOCA cohort, identify predictors of major cardiovascular events at 12 months, and validate the pathological values of minimal microvascular resistance (MMR) and absolute coronary flow (AF). The study will evaluate the concordance between continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution measures of coronary microvascular function, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics. The primary outcome is angina status assessed by the Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ) at baseline. Secondary outcomes include quality of life at 3 months and the accuracy of continuous thermodilution CFR in diagnosing coronary microvascular dysfunction.

This is a phase 2a clinical trial evaluating the addition of ruxolitinib to tacrolimus and methotrexate as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis in pediatric and young adult patients with hematologic malignancies (acute myeloid leukemia, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or myelodysplastic syndrome) undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) from a matched donor.

The primary objectives are to determine the safety of adding ruxolitinib to the standard GVHD prophylaxis regimen (safety lead-in segment), and to evaluate the efficacy of this regimen as assessed by 1-year GVHD-free and relapse-free survival rates (phase 2 segment).

Secondary objectives include estimating the incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, non-relapse mortality, overall and progression-free survival, relapse/progression, infection, and secondary malignancies. Exploratory objectives include characterizing hematologic recovery, donor cell engraftment, immune reconstitution, and

This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a temple stay experience in improving the symptoms and gut microbiome profile of patients with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The study will observe a group of IBS patients aged 20-69 years who voluntarily participate in a temple stay for up to 8 days. The primary outcome measure is the IBS symptom severity score (IBS-SSS), which will be assessed before, during, and 4 weeks after the temple stay. The secondary outcome measure is the change in fecal microbiome composition, diversity, and the proportion of key microbial species, which will also be evaluated at the same time points. The researchers hypothesize that the dietary and behavioral changes during the temple stay, such as vegetarian meals, mindful eating, and meditation, will lead to significant improvements in the gut microbiome and reduction in IBS symptoms, thereby enhancing the patients' quality of life.

The study aims to assess asthma patients' willingness to change from a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) containing greenhouse gases to a dry powder inhaler (DPI) with a lower carbon footprint, as well as prescribers' willingness to prescribe the alternative inhaler at the patient's request. The study will also evaluate patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers and the importance they attribute to this issue compared to other factors like cost and ease of use. Eligible participants are adults with a confirmed asthma diagnosis who are currently using a Ventolin MDI as a rescue inhaler. The intervention involves providing participants with an educational packet about the climate impact of inhalers and a pre-filled prescription for the lower-impact Bricanyl Turbuhaler DPI. The primary outcome is the proportion of participants who change from Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler within 30 days. Secondary outcomes include the rate of failure (switching back to Ventolin), the proportion who fill the Bricanyl prescription, patient awareness and willingness to change, and prescribers' willingness to prescribe the alternative inhaler.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a single-center, randomized, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of a hybrid procedure combining argon plasma coagulation (APC) and endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) compared to ESG alone for weight loss and improvement in obesity-related comorbidities.

The primary outcome is the durability of the gastroplasty construct, assessed by blinded experts at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include percent total body weight loss, percent excess weight loss, changes in blood pressure, HbA1c, quality of life, depression, and eating behaviors at 6 and 12 months.

The study population includes adults aged 21-65 with a BMI between 30-40 kg/m² who have failed non-surgical weight loss methods. Key exclusion criteria include prior gastrointestinal surgery, inflammatory bowel disease, and severe cardiopulmonary disease.

Participants will be randomized 1:1 to receive either the hybrid APC-ESG procedure or ESG alone. The study is designed as a triple-masked

The study aims to determine the effectiveness of cancer education based on the Health Belief Model in increasing the awareness and screening participation of women with physical disabilities for common female cancers. The study will randomly assign participants to two intervention groups: 1) cancer awareness training based on the Health Belief Model, and 2) standard cancer education. The primary outcome is the change in the Gynecological Cancers Awareness Scale score, and the secondary outcome is the change in the Champion's Health Belief Model Scale for Breast Cancer and Screening. The study will be conducted over 12 weeks, with the intervention groups receiving home visits and reinforcement activities during this period.

This systematic review aimed to assess the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and trastuzumab in achieving pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The review included 9 clinical trials that evaluated pCR as the primary or secondary endpoint. Among the 1,209 patients who received neoadjuvant chemotherapy and trastuzumab, the overall pCR rate was 42%. The review provided details on the trial designs, patient characteristics, treatment regimens, and slight variations in the definition of pCR across the trials.

This study aims to assess the feasibility of a coach-led digital health platform augmented by an Intelligent Coaching Assistant (ICA) for an urban community in Ireland over a 6-month period. The primary objectives are to:

1. Assess the feasibility of the coach-led digital health platform in terms of recruitment rates, user engagement, and adherence.
2. Evaluate the implementation of the ICA in supporting the human coaches.
3. Assess participants' experiences with the coach-led digital platform through qualitative interviews and focus groups.

The secondary objectives are to:

1. Identify the needs of vulnerable groups (perinatal women, lone parents, elderly citizens, those with chronic diseases, recent migrants, and the Irish Traveller community) to inform future adaptations of the digital coaching process.
2. Examine changes in participants' mental health, wellbeing, and lifestyle-related behaviors using validated questionnaires.

The study will be conducted in the community of Athy, Co. Kildare, and is a collaboration between the RCSI Centre for Positive Psychology and Health, Empeal (the technology provider), and local health and community organizations. The study

The study examined the effects of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and deep breathing exercises on dyspnea, fatigue, and sleep quality in patients with COPD. The PMR group received PMR exercises twice daily for 8 weeks, while the deep breathing group received deep breathing training. The control group received no intervention. The primary outcome measures were the Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and Asthma Fatigue Scale, Dyspnea-12 Scale, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, assessed at 2 weeks. The study had a randomized, controlled, parallel-group design with double-blinding.

This study aims to evaluate the functional diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in assessing de novo coronary artery lesions, using fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the reference standard. The primary outcome measures the sensitivity and specificity of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level, using FFR as the reference. Secondary outcomes include the sensitivity and specificity of UFR at the vessel level, the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in predicting functionally significant stenosis at the patient level, and the area under the receiver-operating characteristic curve (AUC) of UFR for coronary stenosis with FFR as the gold standard. The study includes patients with stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or after the acute phase of myocardial infarction, with intermediate coronary lesions. The interventions are diagnostic tests, including FFR, UFR, and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS).

This was a randomized controlled trial that examined the effect of Balint group activities on burnout and self-efficacy among nurse leaders in China. The study measured burnout using the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS) subscales for emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and personal accomplishment. Self-efficacy was measured using the General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES). Participants were randomized to either the Balint group intervention or a non-Balint group control. The Balint group completed a 3-month program of Balint group activities, including lectures and small group discussions. Outcomes were assessed at baseline and after the 3-month intervention period.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of non-pharmacological and traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)-based treatments for cognitive impairment in individuals with long COVID symptoms. The study has four arms: 1) Acupuncture, 2) TCM-based lifestyle management, 3) Acupuncture plus TCM-based lifestyle management, and 4) Wait-list control. The primary outcome measure is global cognitive function, assessed at baseline, mid-intervention (4 weeks), and post-intervention (8 weeks). Secondary outcome measures include cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality of life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes (IL-6, TNF-α, and cortisol). The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of these non-pharmacological and TCM-based interventions in improving cognitive function and other long-term symptoms associated with COVID-19.

The myCare-102 study is a survey that aims to assess the clinical utility and usability of Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports in facilitating treatment decisions for pan-cancer patients. The study includes two participant groups: 1) Singula, which includes patients with a diagnosis of cancer who have already received first-line therapy, and 2) Ventura, which includes patients with a diagnosis of relapsed or refractory cancer. The primary outcome measure is the surveyed view of the Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports by physicians and molecular tumor boards, with the goal of having a majority of them have a positive view. Secondary outcome measures include patient demographics (sex, ethnicity, age), institution demographics (type, orders placed, placement of orders), and patient disease status (indication, ECOG score).

The study aims to investigate the effect of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) on the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and activities of daily living in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. It is a single-center, experimental study with a pretest-posttest control group design. The intervention group will receive 14 sessions of CST, 2 days per week, each session lasting 45-50 minutes. The primary outcome measures are the effects of CST on the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and activities of daily living in Alzheimer's patients, which will be assessed through various validated scales. The study will be conducted from January 2023 to June 2024 at the Moral House affiliated with the Gaziantep Metropolitan Municipality Disabled and Health Services Department.

The study aimed to examine the effect of counselling and follow-up after breast cancer awareness education on early diagnosis behaviours and healthy lifestyle behaviours. It was a prospective, parallel, two-arm (1:1), randomised controlled experimental study involving 160 female administrative staff at Mersin University. All participants received one-hour training on breast cancer, risk factors, symptoms, screening, and breast self-examination. The experimental group received 6 months of counselling and weekly SMS reminders to check modifiable risk factors, while the control group received no additional intervention. The primary outcome measures were breast cancer early diagnosis behaviours, counselling, and healthy lifestyle behaviours, assessed at baseline and 6 months.

This study aimed to determine the effect of simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management training on the application skills, satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy of third-year midwifery students. The study used a randomized controlled single-blind experimental design, with participants randomly assigned to an intervention group (n=39) that received simulation-based training or a control group (n=39) that received standard training. 

The primary outcome measures were student satisfaction, self-confidence in learning, and self-efficacy, assessed using validated scales. Secondary outcome measures included an evaluation of simulation-based learning and an assessment of early postpartum hemorrhage management skills. 

The intervention group received practical training on postpartum hemorrhage assessment and management using a high-fidelity simulator, while the control group received standard training on a basic patient model. Assessments were conducted before the training, immediately after, and 4 weeks later.

The study aimed to evaluate the impact of the simulation-based training on the midwifery students' competencies in managing postpartum hemorrhage, as well as their satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy in this clinical skill.

The clinical study aimed to evaluate the effect of a mangrove sword bean food bar on the weight of older people affected by a landslide disaster in Cihanjuang Village, Indonesia. The study had a parallel assignment design, with a treatment group receiving 50g of the mangrove sword bean food bar daily for 15 days, and a control group receiving 50g of a regular sword bean food bar daily for the same duration. Both groups also received balanced nutrition education once during the first week of the study. The primary outcome measure was the change in weight of the participants, which was assessed by a trained enumerator using a digital weighing scale at the beginning and end of the two-week study period. The secondary outcome measure was the change in balanced nutrition knowledge of the participants, which was evaluated using baseline and end-line questionnaires. The study aimed to include healthy volunteers aged 60 to 80 years old, both male and female, who were affected by the landslide disaster and did not have any chronic or infectious diseases.

The study aims to develop a novel telemonitoring system that combines wearable sensors and artificial intelligence to understand the physical and emotional components of chronic pain in patients. The study will monitor pain levels, psychosocial factors, physiological biomarkers, and medication intake in patients with nociceptive or neuropathic pain, as well as healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include pain level, psychosocial components of pain, physiological components of pain, psychological and clinical factors affecting pain, and medication intake. Secondary outcome measures include the effects of rehabilitation and daily factors on pain, predictors of pain chronification, quality of life, and responsiveness to medication. The study is an observational study with no intervention, using a combination of wearable sensors, digital platforms, and AI-based analysis to provide a comprehensive understanding of the multidimensional nature of chronic pain.

This is a Phase 2a/2b single-arm, open-label study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intracystic administration of TARA-002 in participants aged 6 months to less than 18 years with macrocystic or mixed cystic lymphatic malformations. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants with clinical success after one treatment cycle of TARA-002 at 8 weeks after the last injection. Secondary outcome measures include safety, durable response, clinical success by lymphatic malformation type, investigator assessment of clinical improvement, and quality of life assessments. Participants will receive up to 4 intracystic injections of TARA-002 spaced approximately 6 weeks apart.

This is a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-parallel controlled clinical study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chiglitazar added to insulin glargine in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). The study enrolled 128 patients with T2DM who were on a stable regimen of metformin and insulin glargine but had poor glycemic control. Patients were randomly assigned 1:1 to receive either metformin and insulin glargine combined with Chiglitazar 48 mg/day or metformin and insulin glargine combined with placebo for 18 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the change in HbA1c from baseline at 18 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcome measures included changes in daily insulin dose, triglycerides, fasting blood glucose, and fasting C-peptide.

The study aims to evaluate the robustness of the EarSwitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements in people with assistive needs, as well as gather information on how well they can perform these voluntary movements. The study involves four main parts:

1. Co-design questionnaires to understand the participants' current assistive technologies and their opinions on them.

2. Insertion of the EarSwitch device and assessment of comfort and ease of installation.

3. Ear rumbling tests where participants perform voluntary tensor tympani muscle contractions in response to various stimuli, to evaluate the EarSwitch's ability to detect these movements.

4. Optional usability testing where participants interact with interfaces using the EarSwitch.

The primary outcome is to measure the robustness of the EarSwitch in detecting voluntary eardrum movements, using metrics like F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient, and area under the ROC curve. Secondary outcomes include assessing the accuracy of voluntary tensor tympani movements in assistive technology users versus healthy participants, and evaluating the comfort and ease of use of the EarSwitch device.

The study recruits both assistive technology users and healthy volunteers, using the

This is a prospective cohort study that aims to validate and assess the performance of an EHR-based pancreatic cancer risk prediction model (PRISM) in a real-time clinical setting. The study will be conducted across 44 healthcare organizations in the United States, involving individuals aged 40 years and above without a personal history of pancreatic cancer. The primary outcomes are to evaluate the discriminatory performance (AUROC) and calibration of PRISM in predicting incident pancreatic cancer, as well as its performance metrics (sensitivity, specificity, PPV, SIR) for identifying high-risk and medium-risk individuals for targeted screening and biomarker testing, respectively. Secondary outcomes include the timing of incident pancreatic cancer occurrence and tumor stage at diagnosis. The study will follow participants for up to 3 years to assess these outcomes at various time points.

This is a comparative study between autologous adipose tissue graft and microfracture for the treatment of articular cartilage defects in the knee. The study aims to evaluate the clinical outcomes of these two cartilage regeneration techniques. The study will enroll patients aged 18-60 years with cartilage defects of size 2-5 cm2 and Outer Bridge classification II & III. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: autologous adipose tissue graft, microfracture, or high tibial osteotomy. The primary outcome measure is the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score assessed at one year.

The study aims to investigate the effect of different recovery strategies during 8 weeks of high-volume exercise training on the immune system, cardiometabolic markers, and endocrine response. Participants will be randomized into three groups: a control group maintaining 35 hours/week of exercise, a lower exercise volume group (30 hours/week), and an extended recovery group (35 hours/week with longer rest intervals). The primary outcomes include changes in immune markers (TNF-α, IL-6, CRP), cardiometabolic markers (glucose, lipid profile), and endocrine markers (testosterone, GH, IGF-1). Secondary outcomes include changes in aerobic capacity (Wingate test, VO2 max) and body composition (BMI, waist circumference, fat-free mass). The study will enroll healthy, highly active participants aged 18-45 years.

This study aims to examine whether phosphodiesterase 4B (PDE4B) can be accurately quantified in the human brain and whether it is reduced in individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD) compared to healthy controls. The primary objective is to determine if PDE4B is reduced in the brains of individuals with MDD experiencing a major depressive episode. The secondary objectives are to determine the optimal length of scanning, the retest variability and reliability of [18F]PF-06445974, and whether PDE4B binding correlates with clinical rating scales.

The study will use the PET tracer [18F]PF-06445974 to image PDE4B in the brains of participants with MDD and healthy controls. The primary endpoint is the measurement of PDE4B density (distribution volume VT) in the brains of individuals with MDD compared to healthy volunteers. The secondary endpoints are to determine the optimal length for PDE4B scans, measure whole-brain VT of PDE4B in a retest setting, and assess the relationship between clinical rating scales and PDE4B binding.

Eligible participants include adults aged 18-70

This is a clinical trial that evaluates the 3D joint space in patients with knee osteoarthritis, focusing on the importance of weight-bearing and knee flexion. The study involves performing four MRI scans on participants - weight-bearing with flexed and extended knee, and non-weight-bearing with flexed and extended knee. The primary outcome measure is the medial joint space width, and the secondary outcome measure is the lateral joint space width, both measured in the four scan positions. The study includes patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis, aged 18 years and above, with Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2 or 3 severity.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback therapy tool called Biofeedback in Strength and Skill Training (BiSSKit) on swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). The study will compare the BiSSKit program, which incorporates both skill and strength training, to traditional behavioral swallowing therapy.

Participants will be randomized to either the BiSSKit group, which will complete daily swallowing exercises with at-home sEMG biofeedback, or the traditional treatment group, which will receive standard weekly swallowing therapy with daily at-home exercises.

The primary outcome measures are the Penetration Aspiration Scale (PAS) score to assess swallowing safety, and the amount of pharyngeal residue after swallowing. Secondary outcomes include the Eating Assessment Tool-10 (EAT-10), a quality of life measure of swallowing function.

Measurements will be taken at baseline and after 12 weeks of intervention

The Global Burden Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) study aims to:

1. Estimate the prevalence of HPV 16 and/or 18 infection among a representative sample of girls and women aged 9-50 years in low socio-economic populations in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia.

2. Estimate the incidence of ≥6-month persistent HPV 16 and/or 18 infection in selected sexually active populations aged 15-35 years over 2 years.

3. Estimate the prevalence of high-risk (HR) HPV infection and evaluate potential risk factors for HPV infection among the study population.

4. Estimate the incidence of ≥6-month persistent HR HPV infection in selected populations over 2 years.

5. Collect descriptive data on knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding HPV vaccination, cervical cancer screening, and treatment.

6. Collect descriptive data on perceptions of gender norms, stigma, and gender-related dynamics that may influence HPV burden and access to prevention, screening, and treatment services.

7

This is a double-blind, randomized controlled trial that aims to assess whether the application of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) during strategic memory training enhances the effect of the training in healthy older adults and individuals with subjective cognitive decline (SCD).

The study will recruit participants aged 65-85 years, both healthy and with SCD. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (strategic memory training + active tDCS) or the control group (strategic memory training + sham tDCS).

The primary outcome measure is the performance on an associative learning test, assessed immediately after the intervention (T1), 1 month (T2), and 3 months (T3) after the end of the intervention. Secondary outcome measures include performance on other memory tests (list learning, name-face learning, place learning, text learning, grocery learning) at the same time points.

The study aims to investigate whether the combined intervention of strategic memory training and tDCS can improve memory function and prevent cognitive decline in healthy aging and prodromal stages of dementia.

The study aims to develop and validate a predictive model for new-onset heart failure using anonymized primary care data linked to secondary administrative data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD-GOLD and CPRD-AURUM). The study population includes individuals aged 16 years and older with no history of heart failure and a minimum of one year of follow-up. The primary outcome measures are to develop and validate a predictive model for the risk of new-onset heart failure, and to identify and quantify the magnitude of predictors of new-onset heart failure. The study will use a retrospective observational cohort design without any interventions.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of the recommended time to resume sexual activity after hysterectomy on sexual function, as measured by the Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI®) score. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: one group will be advised to resume sexual activity 4 weeks after the hysterectomy, while the other group will be advised to resume at 8 weeks. The primary outcome is the FSFI® score at one year. Secondary outcomes include postoperative complications and adherence to the recommended time to resume sexual activity. The study includes women aged 18 and older who are sexually active and undergoing a hysterectomy for benign gynecological conditions.

The study aims to investigate whether human skeletal muscle possesses an epigenetic memory of testosterone exposure in older men. The study involves a randomized, triple-masked, parallel-group design with four arms: placebo, testosterone undecanoate, resistance exercise training plus placebo, and resistance exercise training plus testosterone undecanoate. The primary outcome measures are changes in fat-free mass, skeletal muscle size and cross-sectional area, and skeletal muscle fiber cross-sectional area. Secondary outcome measures include changes in DNA methylation, gene expression, myonuclei, satellite cells, isometric and dynamic muscle strength, and muscle force-velocity profiling. The study will be conducted in sedentary males aged 55-70 years with normal testosterone levels. The participants will undergo a 10-week treatment period, a 12-week detraining and abstinence period, and a 10-week retraining period, with assessments at various time points.

This is a two-stage stratified design study to assess the seroprevalence of dengue in the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires, Argentina. The study will use a sample of 1,487 participants aged 18 years and older, selected through a multi-stage sampling process from 100-300 primary sampling units. All participants will undergo a finger prick test to measure dengue-specific IgG antibodies using ELISA. In a subgroup of IgG-positive participants, additional blood samples will be collected to determine the specific dengue serotypes and the presence of other flavivirus infections. The primary outcome is the overall seroprevalence of dengue in the population. Secondary outcomes include the prevalence of other flavivirus infections and the distribution of specific dengue serotypes among the IgG-positive participants.

This study aims to evaluate the performance characteristics of COVID-19 antigen rapid diagnostic tests (Ag-RDTs), including the Abbott Panbio™ COVID-19 Ag Rapid Test, in a low-prevalence setting. The primary outcome is to assess the sensitivity and specificity of the Ag-RDTs compared to the reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) reference standard when used at ports of entry. The secondary outcome is to estimate the cost per test and cost per COVID-19 case detected for the Ag-RDTs compared to RT-PCR testing. The study will recruit participants aged 18 years and above crossing ports of entry in the Greater Gaborone Health District, excluding vulnerable populations. The study duration is 6 months.

The DESC-HBR trial is a randomized, open-label study that aims to compare the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy to clopidogrel 75mg, prasugrel 5mg or ticagrelor 60mg bid, with full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors, on the proportion of patients with optimal platelet reactivity (OPR) in high bleeding risk (HBR) patients with recent acute coronary syndrome (ACS). 

The primary outcome is the proportion of patients in the OPR range (platelet reactive units between 85 and 208) measured through the VerifyNow system at peak level after drug maintenance dose at 14±2 days. Key secondary outcomes include major, minor and nuisance bleeding, platelet reactivity at different timepoints, adverse clinical events, and cost-effectiveness. 

Eligible patients are those deemed at HBR (PRECISE-DAPT ≥25 or HBR-ARC criteria) who were treated with PCI for recent ACS 30±7 days earlier and are on full-dose potent P2

This is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the effects of different dietary and exercise interventions on blood glucose levels and metabolic responses in individuals with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Participants will wear a continuous glucose monitor (CGM) and a Fitbit fitness tracker for 10 days.
2. On days 1-6, participants will consume a standardized meal of 50g of white rice, with different "mitigator" foods (fat, protein, or fiber) on some days, and exercise on one day.
3. Participants will collect micro-blood samples at various time points before and after the standardized meals to measure changes in metabolites and proteins.
4. The primary outcome measures are the comparison of blood glucose levels and changes in postprandial metabolites after the different dietary and exercise interventions.
5. Secondary outcome measures include changes in postprandial proteomic responses and personal metabolic states throughout the day.
6. The study aims to stratify prediabetes based on the multi-omics profile of participants after food intake.

The study aims to adapt and test a behavioral intervention to prevent fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) and adverse infant outcomes. The intervention involves contingent incentives on abstinence from alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis, as well as text-based support based on educational components. The study will recruit pregnant or breastfeeding women who report alcohol, tobacco, or cannabis use. The primary outcome measures include urinalysis and self-reported use of alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis at 3 months postpartum. Secondary outcome measures include gestational incidents, infant weight, height, head circumference, and gestational weeks at birth. The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-assignment trial comparing the intervention group to a usual care group.

The study aims to investigate the use of operant conditioning of sensory brain responses to reduce phantom limb pain in people with limb amputation. The study will recruit participants who have had a limb amputation and are experiencing chronic phantom limb pain. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group that receives peripheral stimulation with real-time operant conditioning feedback, or a control group that receives peripheral stimulation only without feedback. The primary outcome measures are changes in pain intensity and quality, as well as changes in somatosensory evoked potential amplitude and latency, assessed at baseline, end of training (10 weeks), and 3- and 6-month follow-ups. Secondary outcomes include changes in the impact of pain on quality of life. The study aims to strengthen the weakened sensorimotor responses and reduce phantom limb pain through the operant conditioning training.

This is a single-center retrospective study that aims to evaluate the accuracy of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization and its associated complications in trauma patients admitted to the Trauma Intensive Care Unit (TICU). The primary outcome measure is the accurate placement of the central venous catheter (CVC) tip for measuring central venous pressure or invasive hemodynamic monitoring. The secondary outcome measures include puncture complications, thromboembolism events, TICU mortality, TICU length of stay, and duration of ventilator support. The study includes trauma patients who received axillary vein catheterization during their TICU stay, and excludes those without a record of the procedure or imaging confirmation of the catheter tip location.

This is a Phase 2 clinical trial evaluating the use of cevostamab consolidation therapy following BCMA CAR T cell therapy in patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The primary objective is to assess the proportion of patients who achieve MRD-negative complete remission at 12 months post-CAR T cell therapy. Secondary objectives include evaluating the safety and tolerability of cevostamab, the feasibility of administering cevostamab post-CAR T, and the impact of cevostamab consolidation on other clinical outcomes such as response rates. Eligible patients must have received prior BCMA CAR T cell therapy between 6-10 weeks before enrollment, and have not had disease progression. The study uses a single-arm, open-label design, with cevostamab administered intravenously every 3 weeks for up to 16 cycles.

This study aimed to evaluate the impact of rehabilitative ultrasonography imaging (RUSI) on core muscle function in patients with visceral adiposity. The study included 45 participants aged 25-45 years with a waist circumference over 102 cm for men and 88 cm for women, and a BMI between 25-29.9 kg/m2. Participants were randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis on the abdomen, 2) RUSI-guided core muscle exercises, or 3) a combination of cavitation and RUSI. The primary outcomes were diaphragm excursion and transverse abdominis contraction ratio, measured by ultrasound imaging over 5 weeks. Secondary outcomes were visceral fat thickness (by ultrasound) and waist circumference. The study used a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group design to evaluate the effects of the different interventions on core muscle function and body composition in individuals with visceral adiposity.

This is a prospective cardiac MRI pilot study that aims to investigate the impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients with ischemic stroke of undetermined origin. The study will enroll patients who have experienced a cryptogenic ischemic stroke within 7 days prior to inclusion and are scheduled for implantable loop recorder implantation within 3 months of the stroke. Participants will undergo cardiac MRI with contrast agent. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of an episode of atrial fibrillation lasting more than 30 seconds on the implantable loop recorder, assessed at a 3-year follow-up.

This is a randomized, open-label, phase II clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of different treatment regimens in premenopausal or perimenopausal patients with estrogen receptor-positive locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer. The study arms are:

1. Goserelin + Fulvestrant (control arm)
2. Goserelin + Fulvestrant + Capivasertib (AKT inhibitor)
3. Goserelin + Fulvestrant + Capivasertib + Durvalumab (AKT inhibitor + immunotherapy)
4. Goserelin + Fulvestrant + Durvalumab (immunotherapy)

The primary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS) comparison between the control arm and the other three experimental arms. Secondary endpoints include objective response rate (ORR) comparisons between the arms. Exploratory endpoints will evaluate biomarkers such as tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs) and PD-L1 expression in relation to treatment response.

The study population includes premenopausal or perimenopausal women with estrogen

This is a parallel-group, two-arm, prospective, randomized, non-blinded, fallback design, controlled superiority study to evaluate the impact of a new transitional care model for patients at high risk of 30-day unplanned hospital readmission at the University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center (UM CRMC).

The study aims to:
1. Determine if using the RecuR Score (an AI-powered risk score) to identify high-risk patients and providing enhanced pre-discharge and follow-up care interventions can reduce 30-day unplanned hospital readmissions in this high-risk group by 30%.
2. Determine if using the enhanced interventions can reduce the unplanned hospital readmission risk by 30% in patients determined to be at medium-high risk of readmission (RecuR Score level 2 or 3).

The enhanced interventions include additional educational materials, a focus on readmission risk during interdisciplinary team huddles, and home health care services. Patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either the standard of care or the enhanced interventions.

The study is a randomized, open-label, monocenter trial that aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in patients with allergic rhinitis (AR), compared to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). The primary outcome measure is the change in nasal congestion assessed by Visual Analog Scale (VAS) after 6 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include VAS, Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF), and Adapted Nasal Obstruction Symptom Evaluation (NOSE) scores at various time points during and after the treatment protocol. The study also assesses the effects of acupuncture on other nasal and ocular symptoms, general health, concentration, energy level, and equalization of middle ear pressure in AR patients.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the feasibility, safety, and potential cardioprotective effects of transcoronary cooling and dilution during primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). 

The study will enroll 60 STEMI patients undergoing primary PCI at Harefield Hospital. Patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either transcoronary cooling and dilution with saline infusion or standard of care. The primary outcomes are recruitment rate, feasibility (proportion of studies with complete data collection), and safety (adverse events). 

Secondary outcomes include various measures of coronary flow and microvascular function, biomarkers, myocardial salvage, infarct size, and clinical outcomes such as mortality and heart failure hospitalization at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.

The study aims to assess the feasibility of a pilot clinical trial that targets the maternal gut microbiome to improve mental health outcomes during the perinatal period. The study will recruit 100 pregnant women with a history of anxiety and/or depression who are currently stable. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four study groups: Gutopia (dietary modification, fish oil, and probiotics), Gutboost (fish oil and probiotics), Gutless (fish oil and placebo probiotics), or Gutnone (standard care with a one-time dietary consultation). The primary outcome measures are feasibility, including recruitment, adherence to supplements and dietary protocols, and completion of study visits. Secondary outcomes include documenting any obstacles encountered during the study. The study will collect data on dietary intake, mental health scores, and stool samples at six visits over 12 months postpartum. The goal is to determine the feasibility of this approach to improving perinatal mental health through targeting the maternal gut microbiome.

This study is a remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss intervention for Latina breast cancer survivors. It uses a sequential multiple assignment randomized trial (SMART) design with a baseline run-in period and two stages of randomization.

The key aspects of the study are:

1. Baseline: Participants receive instructions, equipment (scale, accelerometer), and undergo blood sample collection.

2. Stage I: Participants are randomized to one of two arms:
   - Arm I: Receives the online ¡Vida! program with digital health tools and materials.
   - Arm II: Receives the ¡Vida! program plus remote lifestyle health education sessions.

3. Stage II: Participants who achieve ≥2% weight loss at week 4 continue their assigned Stage I intervention. Non-responders (<2% weight loss) are re-randomized to one of four additional arms with varying levels of support (e.g., additional coaching, grocery delivery).

The primary outcome is percent change in body weight at 12 months, compared across the four embedded adaptive intervention (EAI) groups. Secondary outcomes include whether the EAI effectiveness is mod

This is a retrospective study evaluating the use of high-dose follitropin delta in a mixed protocol with either human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or highly-purified human menopausal gonadotropin (HP-hMG) in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment. The study included women aged 18-42 years with regular menstrual cycles and the presence of both ovaries. Exclusion criteria included endometriosis stage III/IV, recurrent miscarriages, and use of growth hormone during the stimulation cycle. The primary outcome measure was the number of good quality blastocysts obtained up to day 6 of the IVF cycle.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telemedicine in the management of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. The study will enroll 60 patients with IBD and randomize them into two groups: an outpatient observation group and a telemedical intervention group.

The telemedical intervention group will have access to the following:
1. Monthly completion of questionnaires on a web platform, including the Simple Clinical Colitis Activity Index (SCCAI) for ulcerative colitis, the Harvey-Bradshaw Index (HBI) for Crohn's disease, and the IBD disk questionnaire to evaluate disease dynamics.
2. The possibility of online consultation with a gastroenterologist upon request via chat or phone call.
3. Access to educational information about IBD, necessary lifestyle changes, and dietary recommendations.

The study will assess the following primary outcomes:
1. Change in quality of life in IBD measured by the Short Inflammatory Bowel Disease Questionnaire (SIBDQ) and the World Health Organization's Quality of Life (WHOQOL-26) questionnaire.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study is titled "Continuing Somatostatin Analogues Upon Progression in Neuroendocrine Tumour pAtients - The SAUNA Trial".

2. The study aims to evaluate the difference in progression-free survival (PFS) and time to deterioration (TTD) in patients with gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (GEP-NETs) who continue or stop second-line somatostatin analog (SSA) therapy.

3. Eligible patients are aged 18 years or older with histologically-proven, locally advanced or metastatic, non-functional, well-differentiated GEP-NETs who have documented radiological disease progression on first-line SSA treatment.

4. The study has two arms: 1) Active Comparator - Continuation of SSA treatment every 4 weeks for 18 months, and 2) No Intervention - Withdrawal of SSA treatment for 18 months.

This study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of a peer-mediated intervention on the social and language outcomes of preschool children with language impairment. The study involves 25 inclusive preschool classrooms, with 12 classrooms assigned to the treatment condition and 13 to the control condition. 

The key aspects of the study are:

1. Participants: Preschool children aged 36-66 months with language impairment and social isolation within their classroom social network.

2. Intervention: The treatment group receives a peer-mediated pivotal response training (PRT) intervention, where trained facilitators (classroom teachers or teaching assistants) work with two peers to engage the target child using specific strategies during center time activities.

3. Outcomes: The study measures the impact of the intervention on the target children's language skills (Preschool Language Screener 5), pragmatic language skills (Developmental Pragmatic Profile), social and behavioral competence (Teacher-Child Rating Scale), and peer interactions (peer incoming/outgoing talk, peer interactions, and play interactions).
