This study aims to investigate the combined effects of the drug dalfampridine and physical therapy on improving mobility impairment in people with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study will enroll 48 participants with MS-related mobility deficits and an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score of 6.5 or less. 

In the first phase, all participants will receive 6 weeks of dalfampridine treatment to assess its effects and determine individual responder status. After a 2-week washout period, participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups for the second phase:

1. Dalfampridine only (10 mg tablet twice per day)
2. Physical therapy only (one-on-one outpatient physical therapy twice per week) 
3. Dalfampridine plus physical therapy (10 mg tablet twice per day while receiving physical therapy)

The primary outcome measure is the change in Timed 25-Foot Walk (T25FW) from baseline to the end of each treatment phase. Secondary and tertiary

The study aims to evaluate the test-retest reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability of the CLEFT-Q, a questionnaire on health-related quality of life for patients with cleft lip and palate. The study includes patients aged 8-29 years with cleft lip and/or palate who are undergoing various types of secondary surgeries, including nose, lip, jaw, and speech-improving surgeries. The primary outcome measure is the CLEFT-Q change scores, assessed at enrollment and at various time points after surgery (1-2 weeks, 6 months, or 1 year). Secondary outcome measures include photographs and speech recordings before and after surgery. The study also involves interviews with 20 healthcare professionals to gather their experiences with the CLEFT-Q.

The study aimed to compare the effectiveness of core stabilization exercises and dynamic stretching exercises in reducing the symptoms and improving the quality of life in individuals with primary dysmenorrhea. The study was a randomized controlled trial with two experimental groups: one receiving stretching exercises and the other receiving dynamic core stabilizing exercises for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measures were the WaLIDD score (a scale measuring working ability, location, intensity, days of pain, and dysmenorrhea), side bridge test (to assess core strength), McGill Quality of Life questionnaire, and PFSD (pain, frequency, severity, duration) scale. The study included unmarried young females aged 18-25 years without any history of specific diseases or regular physical activity.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To measure non-invasively the variations of cerebral perfusion in patients with or without cardiovascular risk factors during controlled variations in blood pressure (BP) levels within the recommended safety standards during general anesthesia.

2. Intervention: Continuous monitoring of cerebral blood flow velocity by transcranial Doppler (TCD), cerebral oxygen saturation by near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), and brain function by frontal electroencephalogram (EEG) during controlled changes in mean arterial pressure (MAP) under general anesthesia.

3. Participants: Adult patients (≥18 years) undergoing scheduled surgery at Lariboisière Hospital under general anesthesia. Patients will be classified into cardiovascular risk groups based on their history and arterial stiffness measured by pulse wave velocity.

4. Outcomes: The primary outcome is to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in mean cerebral blood flow velocity (Vm) and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) of the frontal EEG during MAP changes. Secondary outcomes include the

The PediQUEST Response to Pain Of Children With Neurologic Disability (PQ-ResPOND) is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the feasibility of running a full-scale RCT comparing the PQ-ResPOND intervention to usual care in children and adolescents/young adults (AYA) with severe neurologic impairment (SNI) and moderate to severe recurrent pain.

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Objectives: 
   - Assess the study's feasibility and acceptability by evaluating recruitment, adherence, retention, and the potential for the intervention's efficacy.
   - Explore the effect sizes and variability of outcomes proposed for the full-scale RCT, including child recurrent pain and symptom burden, and parent outcomes.

2. Intervention:
   - PQ-ResPOND intervention group: Participants receive the PQ-ResPOND intervention, which combines parent-mediated activation through weekly surveys and feedback, and pediatric palliative care (PPC) team-mediated activation of primary clinicians and parents.

This is a prospective observational study investigating the use of minimal residual disease (MRD) dynamic monitoring in first-line treatment of extensive small cell lung cancer with serplulimab plus chemotherapy. The study aims to evaluate progression-free survival, overall survival, objective response rate, and disease control rate in this patient population. Eligible participants must have previously untreated extensive small cell lung cancer, an ECOG performance status of 0 or 2, and adequate organ function. Participants will receive 6 cycles of serplulimab plus chemotherapy (etoposide plus carboplatin/cisplatin), and MRD testing will be performed at multiple timepoints during and after treatment. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival at one year after the end of chemotherapy, and secondary outcomes include overall survival, objective response rate, and disease control rate at one year after the end of chemotherapy.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Aktivplan digital intervention for supporting regular heart-healthy physical activity levels following completion of a phase II cardiac rehabilitation program. It is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group pilot study. Participants will be randomized to either the Aktivplan digital intervention or usual care. The primary outcomes include recruitment rate, dropout rate, data completeness, adherence to the Aktivplan intervention, and user experience and acceptance of the intervention. Secondary outcomes include exercise capacity, physical activity behavior, cardiovascular risk factors, and health-related quality of life. The study will run for 10 weeks, and both quantitative and qualitative data will be collected.

The study is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, 2-period crossover trial evaluating the effects of 4 weeks of twice-daily intranasal oxytocin (24IU) versus placebo on social and repetitive behaviors in youth (ages 12-20) with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The primary outcome measures are social behavior (assessed by the Social Responsiveness Scale-Second Edition) and repetitive behavior (assessed by the Repetitive Behavior Scale-Revised), both completed by caregivers. Secondary outcome measures include behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, repetitive cognition, and vagally-mediated heart rate variability.

The study aims to create and validate a clinical evaluation scale called the ECAP (Evaluation Clinique de l'Abdomen du Prématuré) scale for assessing the abdominal condition of premature infants. It is an observational study with longitudinal follow-up, where premature infants (born before 37 weeks of gestation) will be evaluated daily for 21 days by nurses, physiotherapists, and residents. The evaluations will be performed before and after any abdominal massages. The primary outcome measure is the ECAP scale score (range 0-20), and the secondary outcome measures include the indication for abdominal massage based on the ECAP scale, the validity of the ECAP scale in the term birth population, and the impact of massage on the ECAP scale score.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of Empowered Relief (ER), a psycho-educational pain skills training program, delivered by ASPMN (American Society for Pain Management Nursing) nurses, compared to a wait-list control group, in adults with persistent pain. 

The primary outcome is the change in pain catastrophizing, and the secondary outcome is the change in pain intensity. The study will recruit 170 participants aged 18 and above with self-reported or clinically diagnosed persistent pain. Participants will be randomized 1:1 to either the ER group, who will receive the 2-hour online ER class, or the wait-list control group, who will receive the ER class after the initial 2-month period. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, 2 weeks, 4 weeks, and 8 weeks.

The study also aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the ER program delivered by the ASPMN nurses.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to improve pain communication between patients and healthcare nurses by examining the mental effort and confidence involved in choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings.

2. The study has 5 main objectives:
   a. Explore the mental effort involved in choosing and understanding different pain intensity rating scales (Aim 1).
   b. Compare patients' and nurses' perceptions of the mental effort in choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings (Aim 2).
   c. Determine the relationship between perceived mental effort and the importance of decreasing that effort for patients and nurses (Aim 3).
   d. Evaluate the equivalence of patients' and nurses' confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns (Aim 4).
   e. Test the relationship between confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns and the importance of increasing that confidence for patients and nurses (Aim 5).

3. The study includes patients aged 18 years and older who are being treated for a painful musculoskeletal condition, and nurses aged 18 years and older who routinely assess the musculoskeletal pain of adult outpatients.

This is a clinical study investigating the use of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) for the treatment of poor graft function (PGF) after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of MSC infusion in improving hematological recovery, reducing infection rates, and impacting graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and survival rates in patients with PGF following allo-HSCT. The study is an open-label, single-arm intervention, where eligible patients (aged 18-60 years, with Karnofsky Performance Status >60) will receive weekly infusions of 1x10^6/kg MSCs for 4 consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measure is the hematological recovery of patients, assessed by neutrophil engraftment, hemoglobin levels, and platelet count. Secondary outcomes include infection rate, incidence of GVHD, and 1-year overall and disease-free survival.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of two mind-body interventions - yoga and arts-based therapy - in improving the psycho-social-spiritual well-being among patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).

2. The study is a 2-arm randomized controlled trial, with the two experimental arms being:
   a. Mindful yoga intervention
   b. Arts-based therapy intervention

3. The primary outcome measures are:
   a. Change in perceived stress level
   b. Change in overall quality of life
   c. Change in PD-specific quality of life
   d. Change in PD-related symptoms
   e. Change in self-compassion

4. The secondary outcome measures include:
   a. Change in self-efficacy
   b. Change in perceived social support
   c. Change in constipation severity
   d. Change in bowel habits
   e. Change in gut microbiota composition
   f. User satisfaction with the interventions

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating the effectiveness of an integrated digital intervention called Quit Genius Alcohol (QG-A) compared to usual care (medical management, MM) for adults with alcohol use disorder (AUD). 

The QG-A intervention combines a mobile app with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy (naltrexone) delivered via telemedicine. The control group receives standard medical management with naltrexone. 

The primary outcome is change in past 30-day alcohol use from baseline to 6 months post-treatment entry. The study will also assess psychological and functional outcomes.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18+ with a DSM-V diagnosis of moderate to severe AUD, who have health insurance and are willing to take naltrexone. Exclusions include sensitivity to naltrexone, serious medical/psychiatric conditions, and recent use of certain medications.

This is a 2-arm, parallel-group, open-label RCT with 12, 24, 36 and 52-week follow-ups. The goal is to evaluate the efficacy of the integrated digital QG-A

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. This is an open-label, phase I trial with an expansion cohort, evaluating the combination of nab-paclitaxel, gemcitabine, cisplatin, botensilimab, balsilimab, chloroquine, and celecoxib in patients with previously untreated metastatic pancreatic cancer.

2. The primary objectives are to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of botensilimab in this combination regimen, and to evaluate the safety and tolerability.

3. The secondary objectives are to assess the preliminary efficacy, including complete response rate, overall response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival.

4. The trial consists of two parts - a dose escalation phase to determine the MTD, followed by an expansion cohort at the determined MTD.

The study aims to compare the clinical pregnancy rate between frozen embryo transfer (FET) in natural cycles versus substituted cycles in women under 40 years old who have undergone IVF and FET. Participants will be assigned to either the natural cycle FET group or the substituted cycle FET group. The primary outcome is the clinical pregnancy rate, defined as the presence of a fetal heartbeat at 6-8 weeks after the FET procedure.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of inhalational (sevoflurane) versus intravenous (propofol) anesthesia on postoperative delirium, postoperative cognitive dysfunction, functional decline, and patient-reported outcomes in older adults (≥75 years) undergoing elective, inpatient, non-cardiac surgery.

The primary outcome measures are:
1. Incidence of postoperative delirium, assessed using the 3D-Confusion Assessment Method (3D-CAM) and CAM-ICU-7, through postoperative day 3.
2. Incidence of postoperative neurocognitive disorder, assessed using a neuropsychiatric composite score, from preoperative baseline to 1 year.

The secondary outcome measures include:
1. Delirium severity and duration
2. Changes in blood phosphorylated tau 181 (p-tau181) levels from preoperative baseline to 12 months postoperatively
3. Incidence of postoperative functional decline, assessed using ADL, FAQ, and

The study aims to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease. It involves a comprehensive evaluation, including detailed history taking, general and systemic examination, and anthropometric measurements such as weight, height, length, head circumference, mid-arm circumference, and body mass index. The study will include children aged between 1 month and 18 years with cyanotic and acyanotic congenital heart disease, and will exclude those with other comorbidities. The primary outcome is to adopt a protocol to avoid nutritional deficiency and achieve normal growth in children with congenital heart disease.

This is a prospective, randomized controlled trial investigating the use of pH-sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer (CEST) MRI to guide surgical resection of glioblastoma. The study aims to determine if maximal safe resection of CEST-positive non-enhancing tumor regions, in addition to standard contrast-enhancing tumor resection, can improve progression-free survival compared to standard of care resection alone. 

Patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma will be randomized to either the experimental arm (standard of care resection plus CEST-guided resection of non-enhancing regions) or the control arm (standard of care resection only). The primary outcome is progression-free survival, with secondary outcomes including overall survival, surgical complication rate, and quality of life. The study plans to enroll 60 patients to provide 95% power to detect a 6-month difference in progression-free survival between the two arms.

The study aims to investigate the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan, from 2020 to 2022. It is a cross-sectional, hospital-based study conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital. The primary outcome measure is to understand the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of urinary bladder cancer in the region. The study includes all Sudanese patients living in Darfur who presented with a urinary bladder mass, with a minimum age of 18 years. Patients who do not live in Darfur or refused to participate in the study were excluded.

This is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the relationship between mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. The study will enroll 1,000 patients aged 18-75 years who are scheduled to undergo colonoscopy at the Endoscopy Centre of the Department of Gastroenterology, Renji Hospital, from May 2023 to August 2023. The primary outcome measure is the quality of bowel preparation, which will be assessed using the Boston bowel preparation scale (BPS) during the colonoscopy procedure. The study will collect participants' general information and administer physical and mental stress tests via questionnaires. The correlation between physical/mental stress and bowel preparation quality will be analyzed.

This study aims to examine the effects of playful interactions, compared to an active control condition, on the cognitive, social, and emotional functioning of older adults. The study will compare playful interactions in both online and face-to-face formats. 

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: 1) playful interactions first in a face-to-face format, 2) active control first in a face-to-face format, 3) playful interactions first in an online format, and 4) active control first in an online format. 

The primary outcome measures include cognitive tests (digit span, phonetic fluency, flanker task), as well as measures of perceived partner responsiveness, closeness, and mood. Secondary outcomes include measures of flow, mindfulness, and subjective arousal.

Participants will complete baseline assessments, followed by the first interaction (playful or control) and post-interaction assessments. After a one-week break, they will complete the second interaction (playful or control) and post-interaction assessments.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of the SkillFlix for Parents online video library in improving the sexual health communication skills of parents of teens with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). It is a randomized controlled trial with pre- and post-assessment, and a 3-month follow-up assessment. 

The study will recruit parent-youth dyads, where the parent is over 18 years old and the youth is aged 13-17 with ASD, reciprocal communication skills, and receptive language skills. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive access to the SkillFlix for Parents website and mobile app, or the control group, which will receive written materials with similar content.

The primary outcome measure is the demonstrated skill score in communicating with their teens about sexual health, based on a rubric. Secondary outcome measures include parent-reported and youth-reported frequency of discussions, parent and youth conversation quality scores, parent and youth confidence in communication skills, family sex communication, teen's sexual health knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors.

The study aimed to investigate the role of DDX17 in regulating septic vascular endothelial pyroptosis through the control of gasdermin D (GSDMD) pore formation in sepsis patients. The study collected data on population characteristics, disease-related information, treatment measures, and laboratory examination results, including leukocyte count, procalcitonin (PCT), and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) on days 1, 3, and 7. Patients were followed up for 28 days and categorized into survival and non-survival groups. Plasma samples were collected on days 1, 3, and 7, and ELISA was used to detect the levels of DDX17 and GSDMD.

The primary outcome measure was 28-day mortality, and the secondary outcome measures were the correlation between plasma levels of DDX17 and GSDMD with vascular endothelial injury, disease severity, and prognosis in sepsis patients.

This is a single-center prospective study that aims to evaluate non-invasive methods for diagnosing postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The study will focus on the early detection of allograft dysfunction, which is defined by the Olthoff criteria (bilirubin ≥ 10 mg/dL, INR ≥ 1.6, and ALT/AST > 2000 IU/L within the first 7 days after transplantation). The study will enroll liver transplant patients aged 18 to 75 years, excluding re-transplant patients and those with liver transplantation due to fulminant hepatitis. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of early allograft dysfunction within 2 weeks of liver transplantation.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a multi-center, phase II, randomized, controlled clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Elemene plus Stupp Protocol versus Stupp Protocol alone for patients with newly-diagnosed glioblastoma (IDH-wildtype). 

The primary outcome measure is the 12-month overall survival (OS) rate. The secondary outcome measures include OS, progression-free survival (PFS), 6-month PFS rate, and adverse events.

Eligible patients are adults (18-70 years old) with newly-diagnosed supratentorial glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype, and Karnofsky performance status ≥60. Patients will be randomized to receive either:
1) Stupp Protocol (standard of care) plus placebo, or 
2) Stupp Protocol plus Elemene.

The Stupp Protocol consists of maximal safe tumor resection, concurrent radiochemotherapy with temozolomide (TMZ), and adjuvant TMZ. Elemene or placebo will be given orally during the

The study aims to evaluate the physiological effects of prone vs. supine position on lung recruitability in infants/children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Eligible patients with PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 200 mmHg in the supine position will undergo a 4-step decremental PEEP trial in the supine position, followed by 1 hour in the prone position. The primary outcome is the effect of prone positioning on the PaO2/FiO2 ratio. Secondary outcomes include differences in gas exchange, ventilatory ratio, global and regional end-expiratory lung volume and dynamic strain measured by electrical impedance tomography, as well as safety endpoints like endotracheal tube displacements and oxygen desaturations during prone positioning.

The study aims to investigate and compare the effects of progressive relaxation training (PRT) on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perception, and social participation in women with tension-type headache (TTH) and migraine. The study included two experimental groups: women with TTH and women with migraine, aged 20-45 years. Both groups received PRT intervention, consisting of 30-minute sessions twice a week for 6 weeks. The primary outcome measures were Occupational Self-Assessment (OSA), World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule 2 (WHO-DAS II), Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS), Headache Impact Test-6 (HIT-6), and Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain intensity. The secondary outcome measure was the Migraine Disability Assessment Scale (MIDAS). The study aims to provide clinicians with a comprehensive evaluation and intervention approach to address the challenges encountered in daily life by women suffering from TTH and migraine.

This clinical trial aims to understand the microRNA response to opioid withdrawal and evaluate their potential as biomarkers for Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS). The study will enroll newborns ≥35 weeks gestation with chronic in-utero opioid exposure (>1 month of gestation exposure). The primary outcome measures include neurodevelopmental scores, maximum morphine concentration required for withdrawal symptom control, and salivary levels of specific microRNAs (let-7a, miR-146a, miR-192) at 24 hours of life and at discharge. The study will collect buccal swab saliva samples for genetic testing and microRNA quantification.

This study was a randomized controlled trial that examined the effect of patient education on pain level and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients. The study included 52 patients, with 26 in the intervention group and 26 in the control group. 

The intervention group received patient education on pain management, including preoperative preparation, operating room environment, breathing exercises, non-pharmacological pain management methods, and pharmacological pain management. The control group received standard patient education on the preoperative process.

The primary outcome measure was pain level, assessed using a Visual/Visual Analogue Scale. The secondary outcome measure was fear of pain, assessed using the Fear of Pain Scale-III. These measures were taken on the morning of the operation day, before the operation, every 4 hours for 24 hours after the operation, and on the day of discharge.

The study found that the postoperative pain level and fear of pain were lower in the intervention group compared to the control group.

The Patch BRIDGE trial is a randomized controlled study that evaluates the use of a transdermal buprenorphine patch for induction during pregnancy in women with opioid use disorder. The study aims to assess the severity of withdrawal symptoms, induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success between the experimental group receiving the buprenorphine patch and the control group receiving a sham patch. The primary outcome measure is the induction withdrawal severity as measured by the Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Scale (SOWS) scores. Secondary outcomes include induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success during pregnancy. The study is designed as a parallel assignment, double-masked trial.

This clinical trial aims to assess the use of transcutaneous oximetry (TcpO2) in characterizing vascular compression in patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The primary outcome measure is the variation in upper limb ischemia, estimated by TcpO2 measurement and calculating the DROPmin (TcpO2 variation from a reference) depending on the type of vascular damage (arterial, venous, or both). The secondary outcome measure is to assess the correlation between the severity of upper limb ischemia by TcpO2 measurement and the degree of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography. The study includes patients suspected of having TOS who have undergone additional diagnostic examinations, such as venous and arterial Doppler or dynamic arteriography and venography, as well as a dynamic TcpO2 recording. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This is a feasibility study of a mobile health app called "SmartCP" for symptom monitoring in people with chronic pancreatitis. The study aims to determine if the SmartCP app is feasible in the management of chronic pancreatitis, complementing current specialist clinical care. The study will have a single-arm, unblinded design with an uncontrolled, within-group baseline and post-intervention (16-week) assessment. The primary outcome measures are feasibility in terms of recruitment, acceptability, retention, incidents, and user statistics. Secondary outcome measures include the occurrence of crisis events, symptom monitoring, quality of life, hospitalizations, and use of communication and educational features within the app. The study will include participants residing in Ireland who have daily access to a compatible smartphone and home internet, and can read/write in English. Participants with acute illness, multi-morbidity, poor prognosis, or without access to the required technology will be excluded.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This was a retrospective cross-sectional study conducted over 3 months at Mansoura University Isolation Hospital in Egypt. The study aimed to investigate the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors and identify associated risk factors. 

The study included COVID-19 patients aged 20-70 years who were discharged home safely after treatment. Patients who did not experience anal pain or fissure, and those who died, were excluded. Data was collected through patient interviews and review of electronic medical records. 

The primary outcome was the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors. The secondary outcome was identifying risk factors associated with development of anal fissure in this population.

Overall, this study provides insights into the potential gastrointestinal complications, specifically anal fissures, that may occur in COVID-19 survivors.

This study was a randomized prospective controlled trial that evaluated the effects of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) on palatal wound healing following connective tissue harvesting. Patients with Miller class 1 or 2 gingival recession who required root coverage surgery were included. The study compared a test group that received PRF application to the donor site after connective tissue harvesting, and a control group that received standard suturing. 

The primary outcome measure was palatal tissue thickness, which was assessed using B-mode ultrasonography at baseline and on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 30, and 90. The secondary outcome measure was pulsatility index (PI), a measure of tissue vascularization, which was assessed using Doppler ultrasonography at baseline, days 3, 7, 14, 30, and 90.

The study aimed to determine if the application of PRF to the palatal donor site would improve wound healing and tissue vascularization compared to standard suturing alone.

The ARRC III Trial is a pilot registry study at the Royal Adelaide Hospital (RAH) that aims to evaluate the Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) model of care. ARRC has been shown to improve patient outcomes, hospital utilization, and cost-effectiveness compared to usual ward care. The primary outcome is the number of days spent at home within 90 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes include in-hospital complications, mortality up to 1 year, and cost-effectiveness. The study includes patients aged 18 and older scheduled for elective or unplanned surgery at RAH, with an expected hospital stay of at least one night and a 30-day mortality risk of 0.5% to 8%. Patients undergoing cardiac surgery or scheduled for postoperative intensive care are excluded. The study aims to collect high-quality data to ensure outcomes are maintained and potentially improved, allow for future benchmarking across institutions, identify surgical subgroups that benefit from ARRC, and generate hypotheses on how the benefits are achieved.

This is a Phase 3b, open-label, hybrid type 2 implementation and effectiveness trial to evaluate the use of oral (event-driven and daily) and long-acting injectable (cabotegravir) pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) among mobile men in South Africa and Uganda. 

The primary objectives are to:
1. Compare short-term (9 months) and longer-term (18 months) PrEP persistence patterns across oral and injectable PrEP modalities.
2. Compare the uptake and choice of oral and injectable PrEP modalities among the participants.

Secondary objectives include evaluating the effective coital coverage of oral daily/on-demand PrEP versus injectable PrEP, as well as assessing the safety, tolerability, and acceptance of the different PrEP methods.

The study will recruit 400 HIV-negative mobile men aged 18 years and above. Participants will be randomized to receive either oral TDF-FTC PrEP (event-driven or daily) or injectable cabotegravir PrEP for the first 9 months. After this,

The study aimed to conduct a preliminary assessment of the psycho-emotional state of patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) compared to a control group without TMD. The study enrolled 130 patients diagnosed with TMD (group I) and 130 patients without TMD (control group II). All participants completed a questionnaire survey that assessed their emotional state over the past 4 weeks, including factors such as mood, irritability, sadness, lack of desire for daily activities, concentration issues, self-isolation, and nervousness. The questionnaire responses were scored on a scale of 0 (most favorable) to 4 (most unfavorable), and the results were divided into four sections (A, B, C, D). The study was conducted between 2021 and 2023.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effects of different types of touch (therapeutic touch, affective touch, and static/nonspecific touch) on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers in preterm infants. The study will enroll preterm infants between 32.0 and 33.6 weeks gestational age, without comorbidities that could affect vital parameter stability. The primary outcome is pre-post changes in BOLD levels among different brain areas, measured 1 hour after the intervention. Secondary outcomes include changes in EEG power, urinary metabolites assessed by NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry at various time points up to 40 weeks. The study aims to evaluate the impact of different touch interventions on brain function and metabolism in preterm infants.

This is a non-myeloablative Phase I/II clinical trial evaluating a haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) regimen for patients with sickle cell disease (SCD), including those with compromised organ function. 

The primary objective is to evaluate the regimen success rate, defined as successful engraftment and absence of severe graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) at 1 year post-transplant. Secondary objectives include assessing event-free survival, overall survival, incidence of viral reactivation, autoimmune/hyperinflammatory complications, and the impact on organ function and quality of life.

The study will enroll adult and pediatric SCD patients at high risk of disease-related morbidity or mortality, including those with organ damage (e.g. stroke, renal insufficiency, pulmonary hypertension) or no other curative therapy options. Participants will receive a non-myeloablative conditioning regimen with alemtuzumab, total body irradiation, and sirolimus, along with the investigational agents briquilimab and abat

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of two sperm preparation methods, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, on the euploidy rate of pre-implantation genetic testing (PGT) in couples undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). Eligible women aged under 43 years will be randomly assigned to either the microfluidic chip group or the density gradient centrifugation group. The primary outcome measure is the euploid rate of blastocysts, and the secondary outcome measures include live birth rate, pregnancy rates, miscarriage rate, multiple pregnancy rate, DNA fragmentation, and ectopic pregnancy rate. The study will evaluate the impact of these two sperm preparation methods on IVF outcomes.

This study aims to investigate the association between Brain-derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) single nucleotide gene polymorphism and nerve growth factor as potential risk factors for the severity of allergic rhinitis. The study will involve diagnostic testing through genotyping, where 5 ml of blood will be drawn from participants and used for DNA extraction and quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction. The primary outcome measures include assessing the BDNF gene single nucleotide polymorphism, nerve growth factor serum level, IL-1 serum level, and C-reactive protein serum level, all in relation to the risk of allergic rhinitis. The study will be conducted on participants aged 20 to 70 years, with both males and females eligible.

The study aims to investigate the effect of a mindfulness-based intervention on cognitive and psychological well-being, as well as brain activity measured by EEG, in healthy older adults aged 60-75 years. The intervention consists of 8 weekly group sessions of mindfulness practices tailored for older adults, along with home practice. The primary outcome measures are changes in dispositional mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive mindfulness at week 8. The secondary outcome measure is change in EEG alpha power at week 8. The study uses a single-group assignment design with no masking.

The study aims to investigate the prevalence of Mycoplasma genitalium (MG) infection and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected males in Hong Kong. A total of 750 HIV-infected male participants attending an HIV specialist clinic will be recruited. The participants will self-collect urine, rectal, and pharyngeal samples for testing of MG, Chlamydia trachomatis (CT), and Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) using nucleic acid amplification tests. The study will also assess the prevalence of MG resistance mutations to macrolides and fluoroquinolones. Additionally, the study will evaluate the prevalence of other sexually transmitted infections, including syphilis and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, among the participants.

This is a randomized, open-label, phase 2 clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of the combination of dalpiciclib and physician-selected endocrine therapy compared to physician-selected chemotherapy in patients with hormone receptor-positive (HR+) and HER2-negative recurrent or metastatic breast cancer who have experienced treatment failure with prior CDK4/6 inhibitor therapy.

The primary outcome measure is investigator-assessed progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary outcome measures include objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS).

The study will utilize 18F-fluoroestradiol (FES) PET/CT imaging to non-invasively assess estrogen receptor (ER) expression in tumor lesions as a potential predictor of response to the dalpiciclib and endocrine therapy combination.

Eligible patients must have HR-positive and HER2-negative disease, with at least one ER-positive lesion on 18F-FES PET/CT, an ECOG performance status of 0-2, and have received prior treatment with a CDK4/6 inhibitor

This is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter study evaluating the efficacy and safety of the XELOX regimen combined with fruquintinib and sintilimab as conversion therapy for patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. 

The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), and secondary outcome measures include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), translation rate (proportion of patients undergoing radical surgery/ablation after treatment), and adverse events (AEs). 

The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years with histologically confirmed, HER2-negative or HER2 status unknown, late-stage gastric/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with only intrahepatic metastasis and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. Patients must have at least one measurable lesion and no prior treatment with VEGFR-targeted drugs or PD-1/PD-L1

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the impact of alternative incentives on physical activity levels of older adults. The study will recruit 200 older adults (aged 55 and above) who own a smartphone and are relatively inactive. Participants will be randomized to either a treatment group or a control group. 

The treatment group will receive incentives for reaching a daily step goal of 7,500 steps. The incentives include meal donations to Feeding America on behalf of the participants, as well as monetary incentives (up to 5 days per week). The control group will not receive these incentives.

The primary outcome is change in step count, measured using Fitbit devices, from baseline (week 1) to the end of the 8-week study period. The secondary outcome is change in depression scores (CES-D) from baseline to end of study.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of these alternative incentives on physical activity levels and mental health in older adults, compared to a control group that does not receive the incentives.

This is a post-market observation study evaluating the clinical impact and cost-effectiveness of a wireless vital sign monitor (neoGuard) for hospitalized newborns in Kenya. The study is being conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (MTRH) neonatal ward from April 2022 to June 2023. 

The study has an interrupted time series design, with newborns admitted from April-November 2022 receiving standard-of-care monitoring (comparison group), and newborns admitted from December 2022 onwards receiving monitoring with the neoGuard device (intervention group). The primary outcomes are the nurse's response time to patients in distress and the percentage of actionable alarms from the neoGuard device. Secondary outcomes include incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, and frequency of key interventions.

The study will also capture user experience and perceptions on the feasibility and sustainability of the neoGuard device through surveys with medical staff.

This is a Phase II clinical trial evaluating the use of hypofractionated radiation therapy (30 Gy in 5 fractions or 40 Gy in 15 fractions) in aged (≥ 70 years) or fragile (≥ 65 years) patients with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma. The study has two experimental arms: a neo-adjuvant cohort receiving radiation therapy prior to surgery, and an adjuvant cohort receiving radiation therapy after surgery. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients free of major surgical complications within 6 months of surgery. Secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, geriatric parameters, and radiation therapy toxicities over a 3-year follow-up period.

This is a retrospective study that aims to determine the prevalence of head and neck cancers at the Department of ENT-Head and Neck Surgery of Shree Birendra Hospital, a tertiary healthcare center in Nepal. The study collected data from the medical records of head and neck cancer patients who underwent treatment between May 2022 and April 2023. The data included demographic details, diagnosis, subsites of head and neck cancers, treatment modalities, and histopathology. The study used statistical analysis to evaluate the age-wise distribution of head and neck cancers, the distribution of cancers by subsite, histopathology, TNM staging, and the treatment modalities provided to the patients.

This study aims to evaluate the impact of a health communication message on improving the identification and management of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in children. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Intervention: Parents of children at risk for OSA will be randomized to either view a health communication message (infographic) about OSA symptoms or receive usual care without the additional information.

2. Primary Outcome: Rate of completed OSA referrals (e.g., polysomnogram, ENT, sleep medicine) among children who screened positive for OSA.

3. Secondary Outcomes: 
   - Rate of OSA referrals
   - Rate of evidence-based evaluation for pediatric OSA
   - Rate of OSA diagnosis
   - Rate of OSA treatment
   - Rate of parent activation (i.e., parents planning to discuss OSA with their child's provider)

4. Eligibility Criteria: Children aged 2-13.9 years who are primary care patients, have screened positive for OSA, and have no prior OSA diagnosis or referral in the past 2 years.

5. Study Design: Randomized

This is a multi-country, prospective, post-marketing study to evaluate the speed of onset and durability of effectiveness of upadacitinib in adult participants with moderate to severe Crohn's disease in real-world clinical practice. The primary outcome measures are the time to achieve first clinical response per patient-reported outcome 2 (PRO2) up to week 12, and the percentage of participants achieving clinical remission per Harvey Bradshaw Index (HBI) among those with clinical response at the end of induction therapy at week 52. Eligible participants must have a diagnosis of moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease and be initiating upadacitinib as part of their routine clinical care, in accordance with the approved local label.

The study aims to assess the prewriting skills of children aged 3 to 7 years old. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Intervention: Children will be asked to perform various tasks, including playing a drawing game on a tablet, copying shapes using a pencil, writing letters, and cutting paper with scissors. Parents/caregivers will also complete surveys about the child's development.

2. Outcome Measures:
   - Online QAPS: Children will be asked to draw shapes on a touch-screen tablet.
   - Beery VMI: Children will be asked to copy shapes of increasing difficulty using a pencil and paper.
   - Functional hand tasks: Children will demonstrate their handwriting and scissors skills.
   - Demographic survey, Emotionality Assessment, Strengths & Difficulties Questionnaire Inattention/Hyperactivity subscale, and Ego Resiliency Scale: Surveys completed by parents/caregivers.

3. Participation Criteria:
   - Inclusion: Children between 3 to 7 years old
   - Exclusion: Children unable to follow directions to attempt copying shapes

4.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) model for individuals with serious mental illness who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in Portugal. The intervention is delivered by Community Mental Health Workers and Peer Support Workers over a 9-month period and focuses on developing durable connections to support systems and providing practical and emotional support during the critical transition period. The study uses a randomized controlled trial design, with the intervention group receiving CTI-PS in addition to usual care, and the control group receiving only usual care. The primary outcome measures are health-related quality of life and unmet needs, while secondary outcomes include psychopathology, level of disability, orientation toward recovery, self-stigma, and substance use. The study includes individuals aged 18-65 years with a diagnosis of a psychotic disorder, including both non-affective and affective psychosis, who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in the month prior to recruitment.

This is a registry study that aims to conduct long-term follow-up examinations of patients with vascular injuries. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of vascular graft/vessel patency using non-invasive techniques such as ultrasound, ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurement, and imaging scans (CT or MRI) at various time points in the first year after the trauma. Secondary outcome measures include the reintervention rate for complications and the potential development of treatment patterns. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years and above with vascular involvement in trauma, and the study will enroll participants of all sexes.

This is a prospective randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of blood flow restriction (BFR) rehabilitation after open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of distal radius fractures. Participants will be divided into two groups: a control group receiving standard postoperative rehabilitation, and an intervention group receiving standard rehabilitation with the addition of BFR exercises. The primary outcome measures are body composition/bone density, forearm girth, grip strength, and pinch grip strength, assessed at various time points up to 12 weeks post-op. Secondary outcome measures include patient-reported outcomes such as the DASH survey, Michigan Hand Outcomes survey, and Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation, assessed up to 1 year post-op. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of incorporating BFR into the rehabilitation protocol for distal radius fractures treated with ORIF.

This is a 2-arm randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the effect of the "Stand up for your Health®" computer app on sitting time, musculoskeletal symptoms, cardiometabolic markers, and physical activity in office workers. The experimental group will receive the computer prompt app plus educational information, while the control group will only receive educational information. 

The primary outcome measures are sedentary behavior (occupational sitting time) assessed objectively using accelerometers and subjectively using questionnaires at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. 

The secondary outcome measures include cardiometabolic biomarkers (fasting blood glucose, insulin, cortisol, triglycerides, total cholesterol, LDL, HDL), anthropometric measurements (height, weight, waist circumference, BMI), and musculoskeletal symptoms (pain and symptoms) assessed using objective and subjective measures.

The study will be conducted over 6 months, with measurements taken at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. The study population includes office workers over 18 years of age who spend most of their workday sitting.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study investigating the chronic effects of low-load blood flow restriction (BFR) exercise and creatine supplementation in women. The study will involve 27 visits over 10 weeks and will assess changes in strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, endothelial function, and mood states. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four intervention groups: 1) creatine and BFR exercise, 2) creatine and no-BFR exercise, 3) placebo and BFR exercise, or 4) placebo and no-BFR exercise. The primary outcome measures are changes in strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, and endothelial function over the 9-month study period. The secondary outcome measure is changes in mood states.

The study aims to evaluate novel biomarkers, specifically Growth Differentiation Factor-15 (GDF-15), Neurofilament light chain (Nfl), and Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), in patients with anorexia nervosa (AN) and compare them to healthy controls. The primary outcome measures are the comparison of GDF-15 levels in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid between AN patients and controls. The study will enroll 8 adult patients with the restricting type of AN (non-exercising subtype), 8 patients with the restricting type of AN (exercising subtype), and 16 age- and sex-matched healthy controls. The study will assess body composition and energy expenditure in addition to the biomarker measurements. The findings from this study will help evaluate GDF-15 and cytokines as potential novel targets for the treatment of AN and provide a basis for a follow-up study using available neutralizing antibodies or inhibitors.

The key aspects of the provided clinical trial document are:

1. This is a prospective, observational study that aims to collect data on clinical, radiological, and patient-reported outcomes after pleural interventions.

2. The study will enroll patients aged 18 and above who are undergoing any type of pleural procedure, such as thoracocentesis, chest drain insertion, indwelling pleural catheter, pleural biopsies, or medical thoracoscopy.

3. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of complications within 30 days, including bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, organ injury, pain, and re-expansion pulmonary edema.

4. The secondary outcome measure is patient-reported outcomes of dyspnea and chest pain within 4 weeks of the procedure.

5. The study plans to involve at least 20 centers, including both district general and tertiary referral centers, to collect data and establish a best practice standard for pleural interventions.

The study aims to develop an AI-based model for risk stratification of patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) based on coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) data. The study has a retrospective cohort of 2,500 patients and a prospective cohort of 500 patients undergoing cCTA for CAD evaluation. The primary outcome measure is a composite of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction at 36 months from the cCTA examination. The secondary outcome measure is a composite of all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization at 36 months from the cCTA examination.

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase II clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol concentrated solution for injection combined with conventional medical therapy in patients with cerebral hemorrhage. The study is divided into two periods (Period A and Period B), with Period A being a dose escalation period. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of serious adverse events up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include incidence of deaths, proportion of subjects with various clinical outcomes (modified Rankin Score, Glasgow Outcome Score, National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale, Barthel Index), changes in imaging endpoints (perihematomal edema volume, hematoma volume, edema extension distance, relative perihematomal edema), plasma pharmacokinetic endpoints, and plasma biomarker endpoints.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting recovery in patients with COVID-19 during the convalescent phase.

2. Study Design: Multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study.

3. Participants: Middle-aged and elderly outpatients (50-80 years old) with COVID-19 in the convalescent phase, presenting with fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, and reduced exercise tolerance.

4. Intervention: Experimental group received Manzhi Guben granules (10g twice daily for 1-4 weeks), while the placebo group received a placebo.

5. Primary Outcome: Results of the 6-minute walk test on day 14.

6. Secondary Outcomes: Results of the 6-minute walk test on day 28, and pulmonary ventilation function on days 14 and 28.

The study aims to provide reliable evidence on the efficacy and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance

This is a non-interventional functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study that aims to investigate the neural bases of decision-making in 150 healthy individuals. The study will combine a behavioral assessment of decision-making and executive skills with multimodal fMRI data, including brain activity, structural morphometry, and structural connectivity. The primary outcome measure is the participants' decision-making performance, assessed in terms of loss aversion. The secondary outcome measures are the participants' executive functioning skills, the brain activity underlying decision-making and executive performance, and the brain structure related to these cognitive processes. The study aims to provide insights into the relationship between executive and decision-making skills, and their potential changes with aging, in healthy individuals. The results will serve as a baseline for investigating alterations of decision-making and executive functioning, and their neural bases, in pathological conditions.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study is a Neutrocheck Summative Usability Study investigating the usability of the Neutrocheck device among healthy volunteers and healthcare professionals.

2. The primary outcome measures are:
   a. Identification of use errors, close calls, and use difficulties associated with selected hazard-related use scenarios and participants' perceived root causes.
   b. Effectiveness of key safety information through a questionnaire.

3. The secondary outcome measures are:
   a. User satisfaction with the use of Neutrocheck through a questionnaire.
   b. Comparison of task completion rates between the paper instruction group and the app instruction group.
   c. Comparison of user satisfaction between the paper instruction group and the app instruction group.

4. The study includes healthy volunteers and excludes individuals with known HIV, active hepatitis B or C, phobia of needles or blood, and those currently undergoing or having received immunosuppressive treatment in the previous 3 months.

5. The study duration is 2 months.

This study aims to identify technical, attitudinal, and motivational obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's disease (PD) to adopt technology that can improve their gait. The study will use an individualized, blocked, stepped-wedge design to evaluate the use of the Heel2Toe sensor, a wearable device that provides real-time auditory feedback on heel strike during walking. The primary outcome measures include changes in ankle angular velocity during different phases of the gait cycle, as well as the coefficient of variation of these measures. Secondary outcome measures include motivation, apathy, walking behavior, health-related quality of life, cognitive ability, and cognitive performance. The study will enroll 100 participants with PD who meet the criteria for technology readiness and have sufficient walking capacity to use the Heel2Toe sensor at home. Participants will be randomized to receive the sensor and training either immediately or after a 3-4 week delay, and outcomes will be assessed at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year.

The study aims to examine the preliminary effects of a 4-week laughter yoga program on the mood, anxiety, and loneliness of adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school in Hong Kong. 

The study will randomly allocate 40 adolescents aged 10-19 years with mild to moderate intellectual and physical disabilities into either the laughter yoga intervention group or a control group receiving routine care. The intervention group will receive an 8-session (2 sessions per week) laughter yoga program, each session lasting 15 minutes. 

The primary outcome measures are:
1. Mood, assessed using a 5-point Mood Scale before and immediately after the intervention.
2. Anxiety, assessed using the 6-item STAI-6 scale before and immediately after the intervention. 
3. Loneliness, assessed using the 8-item UCLA Loneliness Scale before and immediately after the intervention.

The study will use appropriate statistical analyses to compare the changes in the outcome measures between the intervention and control groups.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of decision aids on the participation of South Asian women in cervical cancer screening. The study includes three intervention groups: 1) a printed screening decision aid, 2) a leaflet about healthy living, and 3) a mobile screening decision aid. The primary outcome measures are decisional conflict and cervical cancer screening uptake, which will be assessed at baseline, 2 weeks, and 3 months after the intervention. Secondary outcome measures include risk perception, screening decision choice predisposition, and screening decision choice. The study population includes Indian, Pakistani, or Nepalese women aged 25 to 64 years who have no history of cervical cancer or total hysterectomy, have a history of sexual activity, cannot understand Chinese but can read or communicate in English, Hindi, Urdu or Nepali, have not had a Pap/HPV test in the past 3 years, and have and are willing to use a smartphone.

The study aims to investigate the additional effect of correcting forward head posture (FHP) on temporomandibular dysfunction (TMD). It is a randomized controlled trial that compares three groups: 1) conservative treatment only, 2) conservative treatment with Denneroll cervical traction, and 3) a control group. The primary outcome measures are the Anamnestic questionnaire by Fonseca to evaluate TMD and the craniocervical angle (CVA) to assess FHP. Secondary outcome measures include mouth opening, orofacial pain, and mandibular opening. The study will be conducted on patients diagnosed with myogenic TMD and FHP, aged 18-40 years, recruited from the dental clinic of the University of Sharjah. The study aims to determine if the addition of Denneroll cervical traction to conservative treatment has a greater effect on improving TMD and FHP compared to conservative treatment alone.

The study is a comparison of the efficacy of Clindamycin Phosphate 1% gel versus once-daily Dapsone 5% gel in the treatment of moderate acne vulgaris. It is an open-label, randomized, parallel-assignment study. The primary outcome measure is the comparison of the efficacy of the two treatments, assessed using the Global Acne Grading Score (GAGS), over a 3-month period. The study includes participants aged 20 to 50 years with moderate acne vulgaris, and excludes those with systemic treatment, hematological abnormalities, or who are pregnant or lactating.

This is a cross-sectional study investigating the relationship between the severity of rotator cuff tears and the activation patterns of scapular and rotator cuff muscles. Participants will be divided into four groups based on the size of their rotator cuff tear (small, medium, large, or massive) as determined by MRI. The primary outcome measure is the muscle activation amplitude of the scapular and rotator cuff muscles (serratus anterior, upper and lower trapezius, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus) during functional tasks, such as shoulder flexion, abduction, and external rotation, assessed using surface electromyography (sEMG). The secondary outcome measure is the identification of differences in muscle activation patterns between the different tear size groups.

The SENIOR RCT is a 24-month multicenter randomized controlled trial conducted in two hospitals in Pavia, Italy, aimed at evaluating the efficacy of a 6-month sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults (≥65 years) compared to standard hospital care. The primary objectives are to assess changes in nutritional status, measured by weight gain and strength improvement, between the experimental and control groups. Secondary objectives include evaluating changes in blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life, and sarcopenia. The experimental group will receive a personalized, balanced nutritional protocol, while the control group will receive standard malnutrition treatment. Outcomes will be measured at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months. The study aims to develop a sustainable eating pattern to limit malnutrition in older adults.

This is a double-blind, multicenter, prospective observational cohort study that aims to investigate the dynamic changes of Torquetenovirus (TTV) load in Chinese renal transplant recipients during immunosuppressive therapy. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of biopsy-proven acute rejection and clinically diagnosed acute rejection from day 0 to day 365 after kidney transplantation. The secondary outcome measures include the incidence of infections (bacterial, fungal, mycobacterial, or viral), the development of de novo donor-specific antibodies (DSA) or a 30% increase in preformed DSA, and changes in donor-derived cell-free DNA from day 0 to day 365 after kidney transplantation. The study will enroll renal transplant recipients aged 18 to 65 years who receive ABO-compatible renal allotransplantation and maintenance immunosuppression with tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil (or mycophenolic acid), and prednisone, and universal prophylaxis for CMV and PJP infections.

The study aims to investigate the effects of vitamin B12 versus vitamin B3 on nerve regeneration and functional recovery in children with severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). The study recruited 600 children aged 6-15 years with severe TBI, divided into two groups. Group 1 received vitamin B3 (16 mg/day) and Group 2 received vitamin B12 (125-250 mcg/day). The primary outcome measure was the change in Stair Climb Test (SCT) score, which assesses functional strength, balance, and agility, at 18 months. The study used a non-randomized, parallel assignment design with an open-label approach.

This is a clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of pyrotinib in women with high-risk early stage or locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer after receiving standard anti-HER2 therapy (trastuzumab plus pertuzumab or T-DM1). The primary outcome measure is invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at 2 years. Secondary outcomes include disease-free survival at 2 years, overall survival, iDFS at 5 years, and safety assessments. The study has a single-arm, open-label design where all participants receive pyrotinib 400mg orally daily for one year.

This is a randomized controlled crossover trial that aims to assess the impact of the timing of pasta consumption (lunch vs. dinner) on various health outcomes in normal-weight individuals. The primary outcome is sleep quality, measured by actigraphy. Secondary outcomes include changes in anthropometric parameters (weight, BMI, fat mass), cardiovascular risk factors (glucose, lipids, inflammation markers), gut microbiota composition and function, and circadian rhythms. Participants will be randomized to either consume pasta at lunch or dinner for 3 months, followed by a crossover to the other intervention for another 3 months. The study will evaluate the differences between the two pasta consumption timings on the measured outcomes.

This is a phase 2, open-label, single-center study evaluating the use of 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT imaging in patients with multiple myeloma. The study aims to determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in detecting and measuring disease burden in patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) and relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM). 

The study will enroll up to 55 participants, with NDMM patients enrolled in Cohort 1 and RRMM patients enrolled in Cohort 2. All participants will undergo 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT at three timepoints: baseline (Timepoint #1), after induction treatment for NDMM or at 6 months for RRMM (Timepoint #2), and at progression or 5 years (Timepoint #3). 

The primary outcome is to determine the concordance between 18F-

This study aims to evaluate arm swing during walking in patients with early multiple sclerosis (MS) compared to healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include arm swing amplitude in the shoulder, elbow, and overall flexion-extension directions, as well as measures of step speed, two-minute walk test, timed up and go, and timed 25-foot walk test. The study will assess these outcomes 3 months after baseline in both the early MS group and the healthy control group. The study includes patients diagnosed with MS within the last 30 days who are clinically stable, and excludes those with acute medical illnesses, other neurological/psychiatric conditions, or orthopedic/rheumatologic/vestibular conditions affecting walking. Healthy volunteers are also accepted.

This is a randomized, open-label clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of adjuvant pyrotinib and capecitabine in patients with HER2-positive micro-invasive breast cancer. The primary outcome measure is invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at 5 years. Secondary outcome measures include distant disease-free survival (DDFS) and overall survival (OS) at 5 years. Eligible patients are women aged 18-70 with HER2-positive, hormone receptor-negative or -positive, T1mic, N0 breast cancer. Patients in the experimental arm will receive pyrotinib and capecitabine for 6 months, while the control arm will not receive any adjuvant chemotherapy or targeted therapy. Endocrine therapy will be given to hormone receptor-positive patients in both arms.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to compare the effectiveness of video biofeedback and laryngeal control therapy (LCT) in the treatment of paradoxical vocal fold motion (PVFM). The primary outcome measure is the change in Dyspnea Index (DI) score before and one month after treatment. Secondary outcomes include DI score at 3 months, responder rates, Clinical Global Impressions-Improvement (CGI-I) scale, and a qualitative survey. The study will enroll adults aged 18 and older with a referral for PVFM concerns and a pre-treatment DI score of 11 or higher. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either video biofeedback or LCT. The investigators hypothesize that there will be no clinically meaningful difference between the two interventions for the treatment of PVFM.

The study aims to evaluate the implementation of a multifaceted and multidisciplinary protocol to improve sleep quality in critically ill patients. The key aspects of the study are:

1. The study is a multicenter clinical trial with a quasi-experimental design.
2. The primary outcome is to demonstrate a better sleep quality in critical patients, as measured by the Richards-Campbell Sleep Quality Score, before and one month after implementation of the sleep protocol.
3. Secondary outcomes include changes in the Sleep in the ICU Questionnaire, Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU, patient and family perception of sleep, and the multidisciplinary team's knowledge and perception of the sleep protocol.
4. The study will also evaluate the long-term sleep quality of surviving patients at 3 and 6 months after hospital discharge using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and Epworth Sleepiness Scale.
5. The intervention involves a multifaceted protocol targeting environmental, physiological, and psychological factors, such as adjusting sound and light, providing earplugs and eye masks, optimizing analgesics and medications, and offering hypnotic medication if needed.

This is a pilot cluster randomized controlled trial using mixed methods (quantitative and qualitative) to evaluate the PACHA program, a community pharmacy-based intervention, to enhance adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy (AET) among breast cancer survivors.

The study will randomly assign participating pharmacies and their patients to either the PACHA program group or the usual care group. The PACHA program includes:
- An 85-minute web-based training for pharmacists on AET pharmacotherapy, motivational interviewing, and patient resources
- Standardized consultation guides and access to educational materials for pharmacists to use with patients
- Web-based educational videos, coping strategies, and resources for patients

The study will measure changes from baseline to 6 months in outcomes such as intention to adhere to AET, AET knowledge, attitudes, social support, behavioral control, anticipated regret, coping planning, fear of recurrence, and side effects. It will also assess the acceptability and feasibility of the PACHA program through interviews with pharmacists and patients.

The primary purpose is to evaluate the PACHA program as a supportive care intervention to enhance AET adherence among breast cancer

The study aims to investigate the effects of a Melissa officinalis L. extract in phytosome form (Melissa phytosome) on sleep characteristics, including sleep duration, sleep quality, anxiety levels, and quality of life. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of total sleep duration and time spent in different sleep phases, measured using a wearable sleep monitoring device. The secondary outcomes include subjective measures of perceived sleep quality, anxiety levels, and quality of life, as well as monitoring of any adverse effects. The study employs a randomized, double-blind, crossover design, where participants will receive either the Melissa phytosome or a placebo for 14 days, followed by a 7-day washout period and then the alternate treatment for another 14 days. The study population includes adults aged 18-65 years with a diagnosis of insomnia or sleep disturbances related to anxiety.

This is a multi-center, prospective, phase II clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of lenvatinib plus tislelizumab and CapeOX chemotherapy (experimental arm) versus tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy (control arm) as first-line treatment for advanced gastric cancer (GC) or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma (GEJC) with positive PD-L1 expression and low tumor microenvironment (TME) score. 

The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), defined as the time from start of treatment to disease progression or death. Secondary outcome measures include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and duration of response (DoR). 

Eligible patients must have histologically/cytologically confirmed advanced GC/GEJC, positive PD-L1 expression, low TME score, and no prior systemic anti-tumor therapy. Patients will be randomized to receive either the experimental regimen of lenvatinib, tislelizumab, and CapeOX chemotherapy or the control reg

This is a single-arm clinical trial of a Social Engage Coaching (S-ENG) intervention plus enhanced care as usual (eCAU) for 30 adults aged 60 and older who reside in senior living communities and report clinically significant loneliness and suicide ideation. The study aims to promote social connection and prevent late-life suicide. Participants will undergo 10 individual coaching sessions over 4 months focused on increasing social connection, with assessments at baseline, 8 weeks, and 16 weeks using smartphone-based ecological momentary assessment, passive sensing, and GPS tracking to measure loneliness, satisfaction with social activities, time in conversations, and time outside the home.

This study aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with premature ovarian insufficiency (POI). The study is a non-randomized, sequential assignment trial where participants will receive two different doses of transdermal estradiol gel (1.5 mg/day and 2.0 mg/day) combined with micronized progesterone for 14 days per cycle. The primary outcome measures include the evaluation of estrogen deficiency symptoms, quality of life assessments, and changes in sex hormone levels. Secondary outcomes include changes in bone mineral density over 12 months. The study population includes women aged 18-45 years with karyotypically normal spontaneous POI diagnosed before the age of 40.

The Symbiont-Restore Study is a single-blinded, 2 × 2 factorial design intervention study that aims to systematically compare the effects of a probiotic (Limosilactobacillus reuteri PB-W1™), a prebiotic blend (comprising 50% raffinose and 50% xylooligosaccharide), a synbiotic (combination of the probiotic and prebiotic), and placebo controls on markers of immune health, host metabolome, and gut microbiome in adults with a BMI between 30-40 kg/m².

The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in immune profile, including serum cytokine concentrations and immune cell response, at 8 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include changes in gut microbiota composition and diversity, metabolic profile, satiety rating, and gastrointestinal tolerance to the dietary fibre.

The study will enroll 120 participants between 21 and 45 years of age, who are overweight or obese (BMI 30-40 kg/m²) and meet other eligibility criteria. Participants

This was a single-center, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, dose-escalating study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 tablets in healthy adult subjects after a single administration. The study included 7 dosing cohorts that received either AD16 (5mg, 10mg, 20mg, 30mg, 40mg, 60mg, or 80mg) or matching placebo. The primary outcome measures were the incidence of adverse events, serious adverse events, abnormal laboratory results, vital signs, ECG, and physical examination findings, as well as pharmacokinetic parameters like Tmax, Cmax, t1/2, AUC, CL/F, Vd/F, and MRT. Secondary outcome measures included the amount of drug excreted in urine and feces, as well as renal clearance. Healthy adult subjects aged 18-45 years were eligible to participate in the study.

This is a double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study that aims to investigate the effects of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and biomarkers of nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. The study will recruit 54 participants aged 40-64 years with a body mass index (BMI) ≥30 kg/m2. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the urolithin A intervention group (1,000 mg daily) or the placebo control group. The primary outcome measure is the change in arterial function and local stiffness, as assessed by flow-mediated dilation. Secondary outcome measures include changes in blood flow on the hand surface, homeostatic cerebral blood flow, and plasma biomarkers of NO homeostasis and mitochondrial function. Data will be collected at baseline (day 0) and endpoint (day 28) for both groups, and the investigators will compare the outcomes between the control and intervention groups.

This study aims to examine the effects of vibration therapy using a percussion massage gun on pain, functionality, and proprioception in individuals with cervical disc herniation. The study will have two groups: a control group that receives a conventional treatment program, and an experimental group that receives the conventional treatment program plus vibration therapy applied to the trapezius, levator scapula, and cervical paravertebral muscles 3 days per week for 3 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the evaluation of joint position sense, and the secondary outcome measures are the Neck Disability Index, Visual Analogue Scale for pain, and the Tampa Kinesiophobia Scale. The study will include individuals aged 40-50 years old diagnosed with cervical disc herniation.

This is a descriptive, open-label, observational study aimed at creating a registry of patients with decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) to comprehensively assess the influence of various factors on short-term and long-term outcomes. The study plans to enroll 120 patients hospitalized with acute decompensation of HFpEF and 40 healthy controls. Key assessments include:

1. Evaluation of clinical, anamnestic, and comorbidity factors preceding hospitalization.
2. Assessment of drug therapy before and during hospitalization.
3. Evaluation of adverse in-hospital and 6-month post-discharge outcomes.
4. Assessment of body composition, congestion severity, and intracardiac hemodynamics.
