5. Measurement of serum biomarkers related to cellular stress (heat shock proteins) and their association with clinical characteristics.

The study aims to identify HFpEF phenotypes that impact hospitalization duration and adverse outcomes, and to explore the potential clinical utility of heat shock protein analysis in HFpEF management.

This study aims to adapt and pilot a novel group-level intervention called "Brothers Building Brothers by Breaking Barriers" (B6) for telehealth delivery (creating tele-B6) within the context of an established community-based organization. The goal is to enhance feasibility and scalability of the intervention prior to a larger efficacy trial.

The study will involve young Black gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (YB-GBMSM) living with HIV. Participants will be randomized to either the tele-B6 intervention or a waitlist control group. The tele-B6 intervention includes six group sessions delivered over six weeks, with survey assessments conducted at baseline, 2 months, 4 months, and 6 months.

The primary outcome measures are acceptability, changes in acceptability surveys, recruitment rates, retention, intervention fidelity, and safety. Secondary outcome measures include changes in perception of structural racism and discrimination, HIV stigma, internalized homonegativity, intersectional stigma, logistical barriers, individual and community resilience processes, and minority stress.

The study aims to improve engagement across the HIV continuum

This study aims to investigate the impact of direct vs. indirect caregiver training on the outcomes of Dynamic Temporal and Tactile Cueing (DTTC) treatment in children with Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS). 

Forty children with CAS, aged 2;5 to 7;11 years, will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:

1. Direct Training Group: Receives DTTC treatment, with half the session administered by the speech-language pathologist (SLP) and the other half by the caregiver under the SLP's direct coaching. Caregivers also complete an educational module and engage in home practice.

2. Indirect Training Group: Receives DTTC treatment administered solely by the SLP, while the caregiver observes. Caregivers complete the educational module and engage in home practice.

The study will measure changes in:
1. Whole-word accuracy (Multilevel word Accuracy Composite Scale)
2. Phoneme accuracy 
3. Speech intelligibility (Intelligibility in Context Scale)
4. Functional communication (FOCUS-34)

These outcomes

The study aims to evaluate the impact of workshops and exchange groups on the quality of life of laryngectomized patients. The study will include laryngectomized patients who have undergone the surgery within the last 4 years at Bichat Hospital or HEGP. Patients will participate in a 4-session cycle over 4 months, covering topics such as voice rehabilitation, body image, and daily life adjustments. 

The primary outcome is to assess differences in overall quality of life scores, measured by the WHOQOL-BREF questionnaire, between the intervention group and a control group of patients who do not participate in the exchange groups. 

Secondary outcomes include comparing the average quality of life scores (WHOQOL-BREF and EORTC QLQH&n43) before and after the intervention, as well as evaluating the participation rate in the exchange group sessions. Patients who cannot participate in the exchange groups will form the control group and complete the questionnaires 4 months apart.

The study aims to provide support and improve the quality of life for laryngectomized patients through the creation of these self-help and support groups.

This is a clinical trial study titled "MS-DETECT: Early Detection of Multiple Sclerosis Progression With MSCopilot® Detect". The study aims to evaluate the sensitivity of the MSCopilot® Detect mobile application in detecting disability worsening in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) or secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS). 

The primary objective is to assess the sensitivity of the MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores in detecting disability worsening based on the revised Multiple Sclerosis Functional Composite (MSFC) scores. 

The secondary objectives include evaluating the sensitivity of the MSCopilot® Detect scores in detecting disability worsening based on the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS), detecting disability worsening earlier than the EDSS, detecting disease progression in the absence of relapsing activity, and assessing the association between the MSCopilot® Detect scores and clinical scores, as well as the reproducibility and reliability of the MSCopilot® Detect scores. The study will also evaluate patient quality of life

The PCOS Challenge Study is a clinical trial aimed at collecting information to advance research and improve care for patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). The study includes two participant groups: the target population, which consists of individuals diagnosed with PCOS by a healthcare provider, self-diagnosed with PCOS, or exhibiting PCOS symptoms, and the control population, which includes people born biologically female who have not been diagnosed with PCOS and do not have PCOS symptoms. The primary outcome measure of the study is the collection of information, such as responses to survey questions, over a one-year period. The study is open to female participants aged 12 to 80 years and accepts healthy volunteers.

This is a cluster-randomized trial that aims to evaluate the risk of bleeding requiring blood transfusion and all-cause mortality within 30 days in patients with an indication for low molecular weight heparins (LMWH) treated with either dalteparin or tinzaparin. The study also measures several secondary outcomes, including 365-day all-cause mortality, blood transfusion during admission, risk of pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis within 90 days, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, liver failure, length of hospital admission, and days alive out of hospital. The study is an open-label, parallel-assignment trial, with patients allocated to either dalteparin or tinzaparin through a software module. The study does not accept healthy volunteers, and the eligible participants are adults aged 18 years and above with an indication for LMWH.

The study is a randomized, triple-masked, parallel-assignment clinical trial that compares two respiratory muscle training protocols in patients with acquired brain injury. The two experimental arms are:

1. Inspiratory Muscle Training (IMT) group: Participants receive inspiratory muscle training at 50% of maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP) using a pressure threshold device. The training load is adjusted every 2 weeks to maintain 50% of MIP.

2. Expiratory Muscle Training (EMT) group: Participants receive expiratory muscle training at 50% of maximum expiratory pressure (MEP) using a pressure threshold device, following the same protocol as the IMT group.

The primary outcome measures are inspiratory muscle strength (MIP) and expiratory muscle strength (MEP), assessed at 8 weeks. The secondary outcome measures are pulmonary volume (forced expiratory volume in 1 second, FEV1) and pulmonary flow (peak expiratory flow, PEF), also assessed at 8 weeks.

The study excludes participants with respiratory disease in the previous month, inability to understand the assessment tests or intervention, or

This is a randomized, controlled, crossover pilot study that aims to evaluate the effects of technological balance and gait rehabilitation using the Hunova robotic platform on functional, motor, and cognitive outcomes in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). 

The study will recruit 24 MS patients who will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the experimental group (HO) will receive 4 weeks of balance rehabilitation using the Hunova platform, followed by 4 weeks of observation; the control group (OH) will undergo 4 weeks of observation followed by 4 weeks of balance rehabilitation using the Hunova platform. 

The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) at 4 and 8 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include changes in fatigue, walking ability, activities of daily living, depression, and cognitive function, assessed through various validated scales and tests.

The study aims to determine the effects of this technological rehabilitation approach on functional, motor, and cognitive outcomes in MS patients.

The ASARD-TMA study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate an automated surveillance, alert, and rapid diagnosis system for thrombotic microangiopathies (TMA). The study includes patients admitted to the emergency ward or inpatients of the involved hospitals with a suspicion of TMA, based on clinical evaluation or alerts from the automated algorithm. The primary outcome measure is the time of diagnosis and treatment of TMA, evaluating the algorithm's ability to speed up diagnosis and treatment in smaller hospitals without 24-hour hematological guard service and awareness for TMA. The study includes patients aged 18 to 100 years of all sexes, and excludes those with a predictive probability of TMA less than 90% according to the diagnostic algorithm.

The key aspects of the clinical trial are:

1. The study aims to develop an innovative fountain faucet to enable individuals living with spinal cord injury (SCI) to access water more independently for basic activities of daily living.

2. The faucet incorporates electromechanical controls and software programs that adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. It also has a proximity sensor and voice recognition function to allow hands-free operation.

3. The study recruited subjects, including individuals living with SCI and healthy controls, to test the functionality of the faucet using eye gaze, voice, and motion sensors to control the water stream for drinking, rinsing, and grooming.

4. The primary outcome measure is the ability of the participants to complete tasks related to accessing water for drinking, rinsing, and grooming using the faucet, which will be assessed using a coding system and a System Usability Scale.

5. The study has a single-group assignment design and is an open-label trial to assess the feasibility of the prototype faucet.

The study is a cluster-randomized controlled trial that aims to examine the effect of an activity wristband-based intermittent teaching unit in physical education on students' physical activity and its psychological mediators. The study involves two groups: an experimental group that receives the intermittent teaching unit and a control group that does not receive any specific intervention. The primary outcome measures include changes in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation toward physical education and physical activity, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity. These measures are assessed at pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, and after a 6-week follow-up period. The study includes students enrolled in grades 7-10 who are eligible to participate in normal physical education lessons and do not have any health problems that would prevent them from engaging in physical activity.

This is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the agreement between an investigational device (Task Force® CORE/CARDIO) and a reference device in measuring blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output during Autonomic Function Testing (AFT) in patients with orthostatic intolerance. The primary outcome measures include the agreement of these parameters between the two devices during specific time periods of the AFT, which includes supine baseline, Valsalva maneuver, deep breathing, and head-up tilt table testing. The study will enroll adult patients (≥18 years) with orthostatic intolerance and exclude those with certain vascular conditions or implants that may affect the measurements. The study design involves a single group of participants undergoing the AFT with both the investigational and reference devices.

This study aims to develop and evaluate an online psychotherapy program and AI-assisted interventions for improving mental health among postsecondary students in the Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington (KFL&A) region in Ontario, Canada. The study has three main phases:

1. Pre-adoption phase: Assess students' current mental health needs through surveys and focus groups, and develop a 6-week online psychoeducation program and 12-week diagnosis-specific online cognitive behavioral therapy (e-CBT) programs.

2. Delivery phase: Determine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs by comparing them to treatment as usual.

3. Post-adoption phase: Monitor the success and fidelity of the programs using surveys and focus groups, and build capacity to scale the project to other Canadian municipalities.

The primary outcome measures include changes in anxiety, depression, stress, quality of life, resilience, social anxiety, and ADHD severity. The study will use a randomized, open-label design to compare the online interventions to treatment as usual.

This study aims to assess the efficacy of a combination therapy of Omnivirol (AV2) and salicylic acid (SA) compared to standard SA treatment for the treatment of cutaneous warts, with a focus on persistent warts. The primary outcome measures are the cure rate and recurrence rate of the index warts at 12 weeks and 6 months, respectively, between the two treatment groups. Secondary outcomes include the safety profile, time to clearance, change in size, and number of remaining warts, as well as the genotype-specific distribution and prevalence of HPV types in cutaneous warts. The study is a randomized, quadruple-masked, parallel-assignment trial in participants aged 12 years and older with cutaneous warts, excluding those with only seborrheic or facial warts, or with certain medical conditions. The experimental group receives the AV2-SA combination therapy, while the active comparator group receives standard SA treatment.

This study aims to assess the efficacy of letrozole compared to methotrexate in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy. Approximately 75 women diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) a single dose of methotrexate, 2) letrozole twice daily for 10 days, or 3) letrozole three times daily for 5 days. The primary outcome measures are beta-hCG levels on day 14 and anti-Müllerian hormone levels at 3 months. The study will also evaluate blood cell counts, liver enzymes, urea, and creatinine levels. This is an open-label, randomized, parallel-assignment study designed to compare the effectiveness of the different treatment regimens for ectopic pregnancy.

This study aimed to evaluate the effect of fenestrated ASD closure compared to non-fenestrated closure on left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole. Patients with ASD secundum and pulmonary hypertension who underwent surgical ASD closure with either fenestrated or non-fenestrated patch were included. The primary outcome measure was the improvement in left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole, assessed preoperatively and postoperatively. The study design was a cross-sectional comparison between the fenestrated and non-fenestrated closure groups.

The study aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The primary outcome measures include assessing H2O2 generation, TERT mitochondrial localization, the effect of oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation, mitochondrial oxidative stress generation, proliferation, apoptosis, and migration in thyroid cancer cell lines. The secondary outcome measures involve genetic characterization and expression profiling of tumor tissues. The study includes patients with papillary thyroid cancer whose tumor and contralateral healthy tissues can be collected for analysis.

Here is a summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

The COMET trial is a phase III, prospective, multi-center, open-label, randomized controlled trial comparing whole-body hypothermia (33.5±0.5°C for 72 hours) to targeted normothermia (36.5±0.5°C) in infants born at ≥36 weeks gestation with mild hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. 

The primary outcome is the mean Cognitive Composite Scale score from the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development IV at 22-26 months of age. Secondary outcomes include neonatal seizures, duration of intensive care and hospital stay, mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, infections, thrombocytopenia, opioid use, breastfeeding at discharge, brain injury on MRI, survival without neurological impairment, and preschool behavioral outcomes.

Eligible infants must have evidence of intrapartum hypoxia-ischemia, mild encephalopathy on neurological exam, and normal amplitude aEEG between

This is a first-in-human, open-label, non-randomized phase I/IIa clinical trial investigating the safety and tolerability of pTTL, an autologous T cell immunotherapy, in patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC). 

The trial is composed of 3 parts:
- Part I: Patient identification, recruitment, screening, and production of pTTL from tumor-draining lymph nodes.
- Part II: Pre-conditioning chemotherapy, administration of a single dose of pTTL, and 26-week safety follow-up.
- Part III: Long-term follow-up for up to 4.5 years after pTTL administration.

The primary objective is to assess the safety of pTTL administration, as determined by the incidence and severity of adverse events. Secondary objectives include evaluating objective response, time to treatment response, duration of response, time to tumor progression, kinetics of tumor progression, overall survival, progression-free survival, and disease-specific survival.

Eligible patients must have stage IV CRC, have received standard of care treatments or have limited treatment options, and meet various clinical and laboratory

The study aims to investigate the diagnostic and prognostic role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Comparison of mean serum SAA levels in patients with newly diagnosed intrathoracic sarcoidosis and healthy controls.
2. Correlation of serum SAA levels at diagnosis with other biomarkers of granulomatous inflammation, pulmonary interstitial disease, and lung function test results.
3. Correlation of serum SAA levels at diagnosis with radiologic extent of disease and changes in lung function and disease extent over a 3-year follow-up period.
4. Correlation of serum SAA levels at diagnosis with the need for ongoing therapy after 3 years of follow-up.

The study is designed as an observational study without any intervention, comparing the intrathoracic sarcoidosis cohort with healthy controls.

This is a randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial that aims to evaluate the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to the transfer of a thawed embryo from the first in vitro fertilization (IVF) attempt. The study includes women who have had a first fresh or frozen embryo transfer followed by pregnancy failure, and have at least two embryos eligible for transfer or freezing during their first IVF attempt.

The participants are randomly assigned to one of two groups: the experimental group receives a blank culture transfer (up to 0.1 ml of gassed embryo culture medium injected into the uterine cavity) two to three days before the transfer of the thawed embryo, while the sham comparator group receives a sham transfer (an empty catheter) during the same timeframe.

The primary outcome measure is the clinically progressive pregnancy rate between the two groups, assessed at 12 weeks of amenorrhea. Secondary outcome measures include the occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, and live birth, as well as the differential cost-result ratio and total estimated expenditure for the two care strategies.

This study aims to construct a database of prognostic risk factors and quality of life for patients with primary solid malignant cancers receiving immunotherapy for the first time, based on a questionnaire survey. It is a multicenter, observational, and controlled cohort study that will collect baseline information before treatment and follow-up information after treatment from solid tumor patients receiving immunotherapy for the first time. The study will analyze the risk factors affecting the efficacy and prognosis of immunotherapy, as well as the impact of immunotherapy on patients' health status. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), and the secondary outcomes include overall survival (OS) and the results of various questionnaires (PHQ-9, etc.). The study is expected to provide high-level evidence-based medical evidence to guide the selection of immunotherapy regimens, the prevention and management of adverse reactions, and the improvement of survival prognosis for these patients.

The study aims to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. It is a randomized controlled experimental study involving 70 participants (35 in the acupressure group and 35 in the control group) who have had a cesarean section, experience back pain, and are in the late postpartum period (1st and 4th weeks). The primary outcome measure is the visual analog scale (VAS) for assessing back pain before and after the acupressure application in the acupressure group. The secondary outcome measure is the VAS for assessing back pain before and after the late postpartum period (1st and 4th weeks) in both the acupressure and control groups. The study hypothesizes that acupressure application in the late postpartum period after cesarean section will reduce the level of back pain.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of confidential social network referrals for HIV testing in Moshi, Tanzania. The study has two arms: the experimental arm receives both CONSORT (SMS-based confidential social network) referrals and card referrals, while the control arm receives card referrals alone. The primary outcome measure is the uptake of HIV testing among referred clients within 30 days of the testing offer, per 100 index clients.

This was a randomized, placebo-controlled trial that investigated the effects of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in septic patients. The study enrolled patients over 18 years of age who were diagnosed with septic shock within the past 48 hours and were receiving a minimum dose of noradrenaline. Patients were randomized to receive either paroxetine (40 mg/day for 5 days or until shock resolution) or placebo. The primary outcome was time to vasopressor discontinuation, defined as discontinuation of all vasopressors for at least 48 consecutive hours. Secondary outcomes included cumulative vasopressor dose, changes in cardiovascular and total Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) scores, length of ICU stay, and mortality during ICU stay.

This is a single-center, randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a tele-education program on medication adherence in patients with moderate depressive episodes in primary care. 

The study will recruit patients with a moderate depressive episode who have started antidepressant treatment within the last 2 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the tele-education program group or the control group receiving usual care. 

The tele-education program consists of 5 individual remote sessions covering topics such as education about depression, personalized lifestyle recommendations, symptom identification, information on antidepressants, and a summary sent to the patient's general practitioner. 

The primary outcome is the rate of continuous antidepressant medication use at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in self-efficacy and barriers to treatment access at 3 months, measured using validated scales.

This is a pilot observational study to assess the ability of continuous 'home' EEG using the Dreem Headband to accurately diagnose narcolepsy type 1 and demonstrate response to treatment, compared to the standard ICSD-3 protocol. The primary outcome measures are the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of the Dreem Headband EEG in predicting a final diagnosis of narcolepsy, compared to the gold standard in-patient clinical testing with polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test. The study will enroll participants aged 12 to 25 years who are already under investigation for hypersomnolence, and will exclude those with any other diagnosed sleep, medical, or psychiatric disorders. The study duration is 2 years.

This is a prospective, phase I/II, randomized, triple-blind, two-parallel group, active controlled clinical trial to assess the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a lignocaine-impregnated microneedle patch compared to a standard 5% EMLA dermal patch for topical analgesia before venepuncture procedures in adults.

The study is divided into two phases:

Phase I (non-randomized): Evaluates the safety and tolerability of a 12.5 mg lignocaine-embedded microneedle in healthy adult patients undergoing routine vein-puncturing procedures.

Phase II (randomized): Compares the efficacy of the lignocaine-impregnated microneedle patch versus the 5% EMLA dermal patch for pain relief during venepuncture, as measured by visual analogue scale (VAS) score and skin conductance algesimeter index.

The primary outcomes are the VAS score and skin algesimeter index measured 1 minute after intravenous cannulation, following 30 minutes of application of either the lignocaine-impregnated micronee

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of psychopharmacological treatment, cognitive-behavioral couple therapy (CBCT), and their combination in reducing symptoms of distress and improving quality of life among couples during the perinatal period. The study will use a randomized clinical trial design with five participant groups:

1. Psychopharmacological intervention group: Receiving antidepressants (escitalopram, sertraline) and/or anxiolytics (alprazolam) prescribed by a gynecologist.

2. CBCT intervention group: Receiving CBCT with or without Zikr from a trained psychologist.

3. Combined intervention group: Receiving both psychopharmacological treatment and CBCT (with or without Zikr).

4. Placebo/no intervention control group: Receiving either a placebo or no intervention.

The primary outcome measures include changes in scores on the Parental Perinatal Distress Scale, Multidimensional Scale for Perceived Social Support, Dyadic Coping Inventory, Flourishing Scale, and WHOQOL-BREF. The study will also measure blood concentration

This is a Phase 1/Phase 2, open-label, dose-escalation, and dose expansion study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a single intravenous administration of SAR444836, an adeno-associated viral vector-mediated gene transfer of human phenylalanine hydroxylase, in adult participants with phenylketonuria (PKU).

The primary objective is to assess the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events. The secondary objectives include evaluating the proportion of participants with sustained plasma phenylalanine (Phe) levels below certain thresholds, changes in plasma Phe levels and dietary protein intake, and the duration of viral vector shedding.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18-65 years with a diagnosis of PKU due to phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) deficiency, with historical and screening plasma Phe values ≥ 600 μmol/L while on a Phe-restricted diet. Key exclusion criteria include the presence of neutralizing antibodies against the AAV vector, significant underlying liver disease, and certain laboratory abnormalities.

Participants will

The study aims to evaluate the clinical applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) as a substitute for FDG-PET in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The primary outcome measures are the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline, both overall and according to cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) biomarker profile. Secondary outcome measures include differences in brain hypoperfusion patterns based on amyloid and tau status, correlations between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological test scores, the predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and hypometabolism for conversion to dementia, and correlations between brain hypoperfusion and CSF/blood biomarkers. The study includes patients aged 18-80 years with MCI or SCD, and excludes those with contraindications, secondary causes of cognitive decline, major neurological/psychiatric comorbidities, or history of substance/alcohol abuse.

This is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter, observational safety surveillance study of tafamidis (VyndaMx® Capsules) in patients with transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. The primary objective is to assess the safety of tafamidis, as measured by the number of adverse events occurring within 6 months of first dosing. Adult patients (≥18 years) with a diagnosis of wild-type or hereditary ATTR-CM, who are prescribed tafamidis, will be enrolled. Patients with hypersensitivity to tafamidis or its excipients, rare hereditary problems of fructose intolerance, or contraindications to tafamidis according to the local product label will be excluded.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients undergoing median sternotomy surgery. The study aims to compare the STERN FIX device combined with wires versus the standard of care wires-only closure method.

The primary outcome is to assess sternal stability through clinical evaluation using the Sternal Instability Scale (SIS) at 1 month after surgery. Secondary outcomes include safety (adverse events, device deficiencies, reinterventions), prevalence of sternal wound infections and dehiscence, sternal closure time, surgeon-reported ease of use and satisfaction, patient-reported chest pain, blood loss, upper limb function, quality of life, and radiographic assessments of sternal union, alignment, integrity, and closure system integrity at 6 months.

The study will enroll patients undergoing median sternotomy surgery who have at least one risk factor such as obesity, diabetes, COPD, osteoporosis, or are scheduled for bilateral internal mammary artery grafting. Patients will be randomized to receive either the STERN FIX device combined with wires or the standard wires

The study aims to evaluate the effect of an active break intervention on reducing low back pain (LBP) and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting among young people. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two groups: an experimental group that receives an active break with lumbar and hip extension exercises every 30 minutes of sitting, and a control group that receives self-care recommendations. The primary outcomes are changes in pain intensity, disability, perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during sitting, and global perceived effect. The secondary outcome is a post-intervention questionnaire. The study includes participants aged 18-25 years with non-specific LBP of at least 3 months' duration. The study design is a parallel assignment with double masking.

This is a clinical trial study that aims to evaluate the performance and safety of vaginal administration of tocopherol acetate (vitamin E) in pre-peri and postmenopausal women. The study will assess the impact of the intervention on various parameters related to vaginal health, including:

1. Acidity measure of vaginal secretions (primary outcome)
2. Rate of vaginal mucosa dryness, mucosal integrity, and mucosa pallor
3. Quantity of vaginal discharge
4. Whiff test for presence of amines
5. Rate of Lactobacillus grade according to Ison Hay's classification
6. Microbiological evaluation by culture examination and next-generation sequencing (NGS) analysis of the vaginal microbiota

The study will enroll women aged 50 to 70 years, including those in the premenopausal, perimenopausal, and postmenopausal stages. The intervention involves the vaginal administration of Filme Gyno-V® Vaginal Ovules containing tocopherol (vitamin E) for 14 days. The study will also monitor the

The study aims to investigate the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in patients with polycythemia vera and secondary erythrocytosis. The study will collect data on clinical manifestations, history of thrombosis, and laboratory investigations including complete blood picture, serum uric acid, JAK2V617F mutation status, and bone marrow findings. Patients with secondary erythrocytosis will be included as controls, and they will be recruited from the internal medicine and chest departments at Sohag University Hospital. The study will be conducted from December 2022 to September 2023.

The study aimed to determine the effect of perfusion index (PI) measurement on the emergency triage classification in patients with dyspnea. Adult patients presenting with dyspnea had their PI and oxygen saturation measured using the Masimo Radical-7 device at admission, 1 hour, and 2 hours after admission. The study compared the superiority of PI and oxygen saturation in affecting the emergency triage classification. The primary outcome measures were the use of PI for determining the triage status of patients with dyspnea at the time of admission, 1 hour, and 2 hours after admission.

This is a randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled phase II clinical trial investigating the use of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) in palliative care. The study aims to evaluate the effects of LSD on state anxiety, pain, spiritual well-being, demoralization, quality of life, and other outcomes in patients with end-stage fatal diseases and a life expectancy of 12 weeks to 2 years. 

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the treatment arm, receiving 100-200 μg of LSD, or the active placebo arm, receiving 25 μg of LSD. The primary outcome measure is changes in state anxiety assessed by the State Anxiety Inventory (STAI-S) at baseline and 2 weeks after the second intervention. Secondary outcomes include changes in pain, opioid use, spiritual well-being, demoralization, quality of life, depression, anxiety, caregiver burden, and other measures at various timepoints up to 9 weeks after the second intervention. The study also aims to explore the relationship between acute LSD effects and long-term therapeutic outcomes.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a text messaging program called "SmartMom" in promoting healthy behaviors during pregnancy. The study is a randomized controlled trial where pregnant individuals are assigned to either the SmartMom messaging group or a control group receiving general pregnancy information. The primary outcomes are changes in pregnancy weight gain and attendance at prenatal care visits. Secondary outcomes include changes in health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, substance use, rates of planned vaginal birth after cesarean, exclusive breastfeeding, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. The study also evaluates the incremental cost-effectiveness of the SmartMom intervention compared to the control group. The study is being conducted in Canada, excluding British Columbia, and is recruiting pregnant individuals at 15 weeks gestation or earlier.
